vignette.presentation:
21. A 67-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after a 25-minute episode of right facial droop, weakness of the right arm
and hand, and an inability to talk. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, chronic atrial fibrillation, and gout. Her
medications include metoprolol, fosinopril, glyburide, and allopurinol. Her pulse is 80/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 18/min, and
blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Cardiac examinat ion shows no murmurs. Sensation is decreased to pinprick in the distal lower extremities.
Achilles tendon reflexes are decreased. The remainder of the neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the head shows no
areas of infarction or hemorrhage . Echocardiography shows dilation of the left atrium with thrombus in the left atrial appendage, left ventricular
hypertrophy, and mild mitral regurgitation. Carotid ultrasonography shows mild stenosis of both the right and left internal carotid arteries without
thrombus or ulceration. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prevent similar episodes in the future?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to prevent similar episodes in the future?

choices.text: Cataplexy G) Simple partial (motor) seizure with generalization
Complex partial seizure H) Simple partial (motor) seizure without generalization
Migraine I) Simple partial (sensory) seizure with generalization
Panic attack J) Simple partial (sensory) seizure without generalization
Primary generalized seizure L) Transient ischemic attack

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Transient ischemic attack is defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction caused by focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without evidence of infarction. This patient has multiple risk factors for ischemic stroke including hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, atherosclerotic disease, and atrial fibrillation. An embolic ischemic stroke involves an event in which a clot breaks off and travels to the brain, occluding blood flow at a cerebral artery. Emboli can come from proximal vessels, such as the internal carotid artery, or from an atrial thrombus. This patient has an atrial thrombus, which can embolize and cause an ischemic stroke. After a transient ischemic attack, measures for prevention of an ischemic stroke should be enacted. In this patient with atrial fibrillation and a known atrial thrombus, an anticoagulant would be the most appropriate pharmacotherapy to help prevent ischemic stroke. Warfarin is an anticoagulant that interferes with the carboxylation of coagulation factors. This occurs through the inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is necessary for recycling vitamin K, an essentia l cofactor in the synthesis of coagulation factors in the liver.

distractor_explanations.A: Aspirin and clopidogrel (Choice B) are antiplatelet agents commonly used in the prophylaxis of arterial thrombotic phenomena involving the coronary arteries (eg, myocardial infarction) and cerebral arteries (eg, cerebrovascular accidents).
distractor_explanations.C: Dipyridamole is a phosphodiesterase Ill (PDE3) inhibitor, which reduces the degradation of cAMP in platelets and vascular smooth muscle cells resulting in the inhibition of platelet aggregation and vasodilation. Ticlopidine (Choice D) is also an antiplatelet agent that inhibits platelet aggregation. It is not commonly used because of adverse effects of neutropenia and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. However, in a patient with a known atrial thrombus, anticoagulation with warfarin would be the most appropriate pharmacotherapy as opposed to an antiplatelet agent.

explanation.educational_objective: After a transient ischemic attack, management should be enacted to prevent a future thromboembolic event. Patients with atrial fibrillation and an atrial thrombus should be anticoagulated to decrease the risk for future ischemic stroke. ., Clinical For each patient who has transient episodes of acute neurologic dysfunction, select the most likely diagnosis. A) Cataplexy G) Simple partial (motor) seizure with generalization B) Complex partial seizure H) Simple partial (motor) seizure without generalization C) Migraine I) Simple partial (sensory) seizure with generalization D) Panic attack J) Simple partial (sensory) seizure without generalization E) Photomyoclonic seizure K) Syncope F) Primary generalized seizure L) Transient ischemic attack
explanation.concept: After a transient ischemic attack, management should be enacted to prevent a future thromboembolic event. Patients with atrial fibrillation and an atrial thrombus should be anticoagulated to decrease

vignette.presentation:
24. A 67-year-o ld man is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 6-week history of progressive cognitive changes and "twitching movements"
of his arms and legs. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild
ataxic dysarthria. Muscle strength is 5/5 throughout. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ throughout. He has an ataxic gait and frequent irregular jerks of
the upper and lower extremities. On mental status examination , he is alert but distractible. His Mini-Mental State Examination score is 19/30. A
lumbar puncture is performed. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows:
Glucose 80 mg/dl
Total protein 45 mg/dl
WBC none
RBC none
An MRI of the brain shows vague areas of abnormal T2 signal in the basal ganglia; these areas have no mass effect and do not enhance.
Additiona l CSF analysis is most likely to show which of the following abnormalities?

question_stem: most likely to show which of the following abnormalities?

choices.text: Positive herpes simplex polymerase chain reaction test
Positive herpes simplex polymerase chain reaction test

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's signs and symptoms of rapidly progressive deme ntia, myoclonus, and ataxia are consistent with a diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a neurodegenerative prion disorder characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins. CJD common ly develops sporadically but may be inherited or acquired through transmissible prion particles. In prion disorders, misfolded proteins induce the misfolding of normal, native proteins, leading to a rapid intracellular accumulation of the misfolded variant and to neuronal cell death. CJD produces spongiform encephalopathy identifiable as neuronal vacuolization on brain biopsy, along with MRI signal abnorma lities typically in the basal ganglia. CSF typically contains an increased concentration of 14-3-3 protein. CJD is uniformly fatal and most patients die within 1 year of symptom onset.

distractor_explanations.A: Abnormal cytologic study results may occur in the setting of leptomeningeal carcinomatosis, in which neoplastic cells metastasize to the meninges and CSF. Patients with leptomeningeal disease often manifest decreased concentrations of CSF glucose. This diagnosis- ·i s. l.e.s.s. l ikely in. a patient without a history of cancer, and this patient's symptoms of myoclonus are more suggestive of ·•-- -- • -• Clinical Please Walt i ·- •• Ill •• A • . A - • . C) Positive herpes simplex polymerase chain reaction test D) Positive serologic test for syphilis E) Presence of anti-Hu antibody Correct Answer: B. This patient's signs and symptoms of rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, and ataxia are consistent with a diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a neurodegenerative prion disorder characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins. CJD commonly develops sporadical ly but may be inherited or acquired through transmissible prion particles. In prion disorders, misfolded proteins induce the misfolding of normal, native proteins, leading to a rapid intracellular accumulation of the misfolded variant and to neuronal cell death. CJD produces spongiform encephalopathy identifiable as neuronal vacuolization on brain biopsy, along with MRI signal abnormalities typically in the basal ganglia. CSF typically contains an increased concentration of 14-3-3 protein. CJD is uniformly fatal and most patients die within 1 year of symptom onset. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. Abnormal cytologic study results (Choice A) may occur in the setting of leptomeningea l carcinomatosis, in which neoplastic cells metastasize to the meninges and CSF. Patients with leptomeningea l disease often manifest decreased concentrations of CSF glucose. This diagnosis is less likely in a patient without a history of cancer, and this patient's symptoms of myoclonus are more suggestive of CJD than of leptomeningeal disease Positive herpes simplex polymerase chain reaction test (Choice C) is useful for the diagnosis of herpes encephalitis, which typically presents with fever, altered mental status, and seizures. Positive serologic test for syphilis (Choice D) is useful for the diagnosis of neurosyphi lis, which presents with fever, meningismus, ataxia, Argyll Robertson pupil, and tabes dorsalis. Presence of anti-Hu antibody (Choice E) is characteristic of anti-Hu associated encephalitis, a rare form of paraneoplastic encephalitis most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer. Patients present with variable findings including confusion and altered mental status, hallucinations, memory loss, depression, and seizures. This diagnosis is less likely in a patient without a history of cancer.

explanation.educational_objective: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a neurodegenerative prion disease characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins and manifests with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, and ataxia. Brain biopsy confirms the diagnosis, which is also supported by the presence of an increased concentration of 14-3-3 protein in the cerebrospina l fluid. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
25. A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of gradual hearing loss in the left ear. She also has had difficulty
maintaining her balance over the past 3 months. Six months ago, she had an episode of nephrolithiasis complicated by a severe urinary tract
infection requiring intravenous antibiotic therapy. Examination shows a decrease of the left nasolabial fold and a slight perioral droop when she
smiles. The forehead movements are intact bilaterally. Her gait is normal, but she has difficulty with tandem walking. Audiomet ry shows moderate
high-frequency hearing loss on the left with impaired speech discrimination. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient most likely has an acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) compressing the vestibulocochlear nerve and the upper motor neurons that synapse on the facial nerve. Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors consisting of Schwann cells that arise from the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII). Lesions of the vestibulocochlear nerve typically disrupt ipsilateral hearing and the sensation of head and body position, which leads to difficulty with balance and tandem (heel-to-toe) gait as in this patient. Mass effect from progressive ly enlarging acoustic neuromas can compress the neighboring facial nerve or the upper motor neurons synapsing on the facial nerve, leading to a flattened nasolabial fold and perioral droop. If the upper motor neurons are affected, the forehead is spared, as the facial nerve nucleus that controls forehead musculature is dually innervated by upper motor neurons from bilateral precentral gyri. Because of this, the patient would be expected to symmetrically raise her eyebrows. Alternatively, lesions involving the lower motor neurons of facial expression (eg, facial nerve inflammation in Bell palsy) affect the forehead and lower face together. Depending on patient age, tumor size, and symptom burden, acoustic neuromas can be managed with observation, radiation, or surgery.

distractor_explanations.B: Aminoglycoside ototoxicity can damage the cochlea or the vestibular organs. However, facial nerve palsy and the onset of vestibular symptoms months after aminoglycoside exposure would be atypical. Brain stem infarction (Choice C) could lead to variable cranial nerve dysfunction. However, the onset would be acute and the cranial nerve deficits would occur simultaneously. This patient instead ,experienced slowly progressive cranial nerve dysfunction over months.
distractor_explanations.D: Mastoiditis refers to an infection of the mastoid air cells in the mastoid bone, typically resulting from middle ear infection in children and presenting with acute ear pain and postauricular tenderness. Transient hearing loss may occur and vestibular dysfunction can result from labyrinthitis (a complication of mastoiditis). Meniere disease (Choice E) is a condition of episodic vertigo and sensorineura l hearing loss that results from pressure accumulation in the endolymph of the inner ear. This patient's symptoms were constant and progressive rather than episodic, and facial nerve palsy would be atypical.

explanation.educational_objective: Acoustic neuromas, benign tumors of Schwann cells that arise from the vestibulocochlear nerve, may compress the vestibulocochlear and facial nerves. Acoustic neuromas can cause ipsilateral hearing loss and positional dizziness and, if compressing the facial nerve, can lead to facial nerve palsy. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Acoustic neuromas, benign tumors of Schwann cells that arise from the vestibulocochlear nerve, may compress the vestibulocochlear and facial nerves. Acoustic neuromas can cause ipsilateral hearing los

vignette.presentation:
26. A previous ly healthy 4 ?-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of progressively severe bifrontal headache. He has a
scant beard and a sallow, waxy complexion. Examination shows bilateral temporal hemianopia. Visual acuity is normal. Which of the following is
the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Occipital neuralgia K) Temporomandibular joint syndrome

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's findings of headache and bitemporal hemianopsia are consistent with a diagnosis of pituitary adenoma. Benign adenomas are the most common neoplasms identified in the pituitary gland, and may secrete hormones, such as prolactin or growth hormone, causing symptoms of hyperpituitarism. More common ly, pituitary mass lesions do not cause hyperpituitarism but instead cause compression of normal pituitary neurons, leading to hypopituitarism and dysfunction of multiple endocrine axes. The pituitary gland rests in the bony sella turcica, just inferior to the optic chiasm. Retinal ganglion cell fibers from the nasal retina, which supply the temporal visual fields, decussate at the chiasm, and are vulnerable to compression by pituitary mass lesions. Since the decussating nasal retinal fibers carry information from the temporal visual fields, the resultant visual field deficit is most commonly a bitemporal hemianopsia, a finding suggestive of a pituitary mass.
explanation.educational_objective: Pituitary adenomas are benign lesions of the pituitary gland and present with headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, and either hypopituitarism or hyperpituitarism. Retinal ganglion cell fibers from the nasal retina, which supply the temporal visual fields, decussate at the optic chiasm, and are vulnerable to compression by pituitary mass lesions Clinical
explanation.concept: Pituitary adenomas are benign lesions of the pituitary gland and present with headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, and either hypopituitarism or hyperpituitarism. Retinal ganglion cell fibers from the na

vignette.presentation:
27. A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening excessive daytime sleepiness, even during important
events such as meetings at work. She says she has trouble sustaining her attention and that her symptoms are beginning to impair her work
productivity. She also reports occasional episodes in which her muscles go limp and she falls suddenly. She has injured herself during two of these
episodes. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood
pressure is 120/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnorma lities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in
management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate initial step in
management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder characterized by daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis that responds to modafinil therapy. Narcolepsy arises from deficient production of orexins in the hypothalamus, which may result from genetic or autoimmune causes. Orexins typically induce the secretion of monoamines such as norepinephrine throughout the brain to promote wakefulness. As a result, patients suddenly and inappropriate ly transition into sleep during the day. Further, rapid-eye movement (REM) sleep features (eg, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) occur during wakefulness. Cataplexy refers to a sudden loss of muscle tone and usually occurs in response to positive emotion. The clinical diagnosis should be confirmed by a polysomnography (to confirm the rapid transition into REM sleep and rule out other causes of daytime sleepiness) and a multiple sleep latency test (to confirm decreased sleep latency). Treatment includes a regular sleep schedule, avoidance of daytime naps, and, in patients with severe daytime sleepiness, modafinil. Modafinil has an unclear mechanism of action that involves increasing orexin and monoamine availability.

distractor_explanations.F: and uvulopalatopharyngoplasty all target obstructive sleep apnea. Obstructive sleep apnea features repetitive obstruction of the pharyngeal airway during sleep and typically occurs in older, male patients with obesity as a result of a combination of structural, vascular, and neuromuscular factors. Patients become hypoxemic several times nightly and experience fragmented sleep, leading to daytime sleepiness. REM sleep phenomena during wakefulness is instead consistent with narcolepsy. In patients with suspected narcolepsy, comorbid obstructive slee a nea should be ruled out with ol somno ra h Clinical Please Walt , A , F) Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty Correct Answer: E. Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder characterized by daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis that responds to modafinil therapy. Narcolepsy arises from deficient production of orexins in the hypothalamus, which may result from genetic or autoimmune causes. Orexins typically induce the secretion of monoamines such as norepinephrine throughout the brain to promote wakefulness. As a result, patients suddenly and inappropriately transition into sleep during the day. Further, rapid-eye movement (REM) sleep features (eg, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) occur during wakefulness. Cataplexy refers to a sudden loss of muscle tone and usually occurs in response to positive emotion. The clinical diagnosis should be confirmed by a polysomnography (to confirm the rapid transition into REM sleep and rule out other causes of daytime sleepiness) and a multiple sleep latency test (to confirm decreased sleep latency). Treatment includes a regular sleep schedule, avoidance of daytime naps, and, in patients with severe daytime sleepiness, modafinil. Modafinil has an unclear mechanism of action that involves increasing orexin and monoamine availability. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and F. Weight loss program (Choice A), continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) (Choice B), and uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (Choice F) all target obstructive sleep apnea. Obstructive sleep apnea features repetitive obstruction of the pharyngeal airway during sleep and typically occurs in older, male patients with obesity as a result of a combination of structural, vascular, and neuromuscular factors. Patients become hypoxemic several times nightly and experience fragmented sleep, leading to daytime sleepiness. REM sleep phenomena during wakefulness is instead consistent with narcolepsy. In patients with suspected narcolepsy, comorbid obstructive sleep apnea should be ruled out with polysomnography.
distractor_explanations.C: Phototherapy can be utilized to promote wakefulness in patients with circadian rhythm sleep disorders such as advanced sleep phase disorder. These circadian rhythm disorders do not feature REM sleep phenomena during wakefulness. Phototherapy does not play a role in narcolepsy treatment. Clonazepam therapy (Choice D) may be utilized to treat REM sleep behavior disorder. REM sleep behavior disorder features absent muscle atonia during REM sleep, and patients typically act out their dreams in a coordinated, though sometimes violent, manner. The intrusion of REM sleep phenomena into wakefulness would be atypical.

explanation.educational_objective: Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder that involves deficient orexin secretion, leading to the intrusion of sleep phenomena (eg, sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) into times of wakefulness. Modafinil therapy, which likely increases orexin secretion, is the first-line medication for patients with severe daytime sleepiness. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder that involves deficient orexin secretion, leading to the intrusion of sleep phenomena (eg, sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, sleep paralysis) int

vignette.presentation:
28. A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a spinning sensation. She reports feeling as though the room is
spinning particularly when she tries to turn over in bed; the feeling usually resolves within 1 minute. She has no vomiting with an episode but does
feel a little queasy. Examination shows normal hearing. Ocular movements are full when the patient is sitting, but when her head is allowed to
hang off the examination table, she develops a coarse, rotatory nystagmus beating to one side. The remainder of the examination shows no
abnormalities. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is an abnormality at which of the following sites?

question_stem: The most likely cause of this patient's condition is an abnormality at which of the following sites?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a common cause of vertigo that occurs as a result of a calcium carbonate particle (otoconium) that gets displaced from the otolith organs into the adjacent semicircu lar canals. The otolith organs and semicircular canals are located in the inner ear and sense movement of the head. Normally, otoconia are contained within the matrix of the otolith organs, adding weight to the organs so that the organs shift in position when head position changes. When otoconia become dislodged, they cause abnormal movement of the endolymph within the semicircular canals and the subsequent sensation of head movement. Consequently, patients present with minutes-long, abrupt episodes of vertigo that may be accompanied by nausea, which resolve when holding still. The cochlear apparatus is intact, resulting in normal hearing. Symptom resolution with particle repositioning maneuvers such as the Epley maneuver serves to both diagnose and treat BPPV. Vertigo is the sensation that the surroundings are moving and is associated with lesions of the peripheral or central vestibular system. Peripheral vertigo is typically short-lived and sudden in onset, whereas central vertigo is insidious in onset and may cause constant and sustained vertigo. Peripheral causes of vertigo such as BPPV may also present with uni- or multidirectional nystagmus and may decrease as patients focus their gaze, while central causes of vertigo such as brainstem tumors or strokes typically lead to purely unidirectional nystagmus that does not improve with primary gaze.

distractor_explanations.B: A brain stem mass of the cerebellopontine angle (eg, acoustic neuroma, meningioma, glioma) typically affects the vestibulocochlear nerve and may also affect other cranial nerves (eg, trigeminal, abducens, facial nerves). The resulting vertigo would likely be insidious in onset and constant (rather than episodic); also likely to be accompanied by hearing loss. Additionally, sensory and r ~ -- - - , r, Exam Section : Item 28 of 50 Clinical Correct Answer: C. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a common cause of vertigo that occurs as a result of a calcium carbonate particle (otoconium) that gets displaced from the otolith organs into the adjacent semicircu lar canals. The otolith organs and semicircular canals are located in the inner ear and sense movement of the head. Normally, otoconia are contained within the matrix of the otolith organs, adding weight to the organs so that the organs shift in position when head position changes. When otoconia become dislodged, they cause abnormal movement of the endolymph within the semicircular canals and the subsequent sensation of head movement. Consequently, patients present with minutes-long, abrupt episodes of vertigo that may be accompanied by nausea, which resolve when holding still. The cochlear apparatus is intact, resulting in normal hearing. Symptom resolution with particle repositioning maneuvers such as the Epley maneuver serves to both diagnose and treat BPPV. Vertigo is the sensation that the surroundings are moving and is associated with lesions of the peripheral or central vestibular system. Peripheral vertigo is typically short-lived and sudden in onset, whereas central vertigo is insidious in onset and may cause constant and sustained vertigo. Peripheral causes of vertigo such as BPPV may also present with uni- or multidirectional nystagmus and may decrease as patients focus their gaze, while central causes of vertigo such as brainstem tumors or strokes typically lead to purely unidirectional nystagmus that does not improve with primary gaze. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Lesions of the auditory cortex (Choice A), located in the temporal lobe, result in impairment of the conscious perception of auditory sensations. The vestibular cortices are instead distributed across the parietal and temporal cortices. A brain stem (Choice B) mass of the cerebellopontine angle (eg, acoustic neuroma, meningioma, glioma) typically affects the vestibulocochlear nerve and may also affect other cranial nerves (eg, trigeminal, abducens, facial nerves). The resulting vertigo would likely be insidious in onset and constant (rather than episodic); also likely to be accompanied by hearing loss. Additionally, sensory and motor dysfunction of the face or extraocular muscles may occur. The ossicles (Choice D) are the small bones of the middle ear that transmit the mechanical vibrations of the tympanic membrane to the cochlea. The ossicles transmit sound but not vestibular information. The spiral ganglion (Choice E) of the cochlea is a group of cell bodies that receive innervation from the hair cells and unite to form the auditory nerve. The spiral ganglion does not carry vestibular information.

explanation.educational_objective: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is a common cause of vertigo that occurs as a result of a calcium carbonate particle (otoconium) that gets displaced from the otolith organs into the adjacent semicircular canals, leading to the erroneous sensation of position change. Patients typically present with episodic vertigo with nystagmus, nausea, and normal hearing. Particle repositioning maneuvers are key for diagnosis and treatment Clinical

vignette.presentation:
29. A 10-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents after the Thanksgiving holiday break because of a 4-day history of rapid, irregular
involuntary movements of her face, trunk, and extremities. Her parents say that during this period, she has been anxious and irritable and has had
headaches. She seems to be worrying obsessively about things that formerly would not have worried her. She has no history of serious illness
except for migratory joint pain that occurred in the early fall. Examination shows restless-appearing, generalized involuntary movements of the
face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Autoimmune disorder of the basal ganglia

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient likely has Sydenham chorea, which is a manifestation of an autoimmune disorder of the basal ganglia. The combination of choreiform movements and migratory joint pain suggest a diagnosis of rheumatic fever, a complication of Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) infection. Though arthritis is typically an early manifestation of acute rheumatic fever, Sydenham chorea is a latent manifestation and may occur months after the initial streptococcal infection. In acute rheumatic fever, streptococca l infection causes immune cross-reactivity with neuronal and cardiac cell membrane proteins and the deposition of immune complexes in the joints and soft tissues. The binding of antibodies to basal ganglia neurons results in choreiform movements (involuntary, random, irregular movements) of the face, trunk, and extremities that may be more prominent on one side of the body. Neuropsychiatric symptoms such as emotional !ability and obsessive-compulsive disorder (a disorder associated with basal ganglia pathology) may also occur. Sydenham chorea may occur as an isolated manifestation of acute rheumatic fever or in conjunction with arthritis, carditis, erythema marginatum, and/or subcutaneous nodules. As such, patients with Sydenham chorea should receive an echocardiography to evaluate for carditis. The treatment of acute rheumatic fever involves nonsteroida l anti-inflammatory drugs and penicillin to ensure the eradication of Streptococcus pyogenes (group A). Sydenham chorea is typically self-limited, but severe and impairing neuropsychiatric symptoms may be managed with antipsychotic or anticonvulsant medication.

distractor_explanations.C: Heavy metal toxicity (eg, copper, mercury) may cause neuropsychiatric symptoms, though chorea would be rare. Wilson disease is associated with copper accumulation in the basal ganglia, which may present as chorea, but this patient lacks other signs of Wilson disease such as liver disease or ocular findings.
distractor_explanations.D: Hypercalcemia may present with anxiety, depression, or cognitive dysfunction. Chorea would be atypical.
distractor_explanations.E: Hypothyroidism is associated with mood changes but not choreiform movements. Hyperthyroidism is associated with subacute chorea. Tandem repeat mutation on chromosome 4 (Choice F) leads to facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy. Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy is an inherited muscular dystrophy resulting in slowly progressive, asymmetric muscle weakness in the facial, scapular, upper arm, lower leg, and abdominal muscles. Chorea would be atypical.

explanation.educational_objective: Group A streptococcal pharyngitis can be complicated with acute rheumatic fever, which may present with arthritis, Sydenham chorea, carditis, erythema marginatum, or subcutaneous nodules as a result of immune cross-reactivity. The binding of antibodies to basal ganglia neurons results in choreiform movements (involuntary, random, irregular movements) of the face, trunk, and extremities, and may also lead to mood !ability and obsessive-compulsive disorder Clinical
explanation.concept: Group A streptococcal pharyngitis can be complicated with acute rheumatic fever, which may present with arthritis, Sydenham chorea, carditis, erythema marginatum, or subcutaneous nodules as a result o

vignette.presentation:
30. A 32-year-old woman with breast cancer metastatic to bone is brought to the emergency department because of a 12-hour history of severe pelvic
pain and numbness. She has not urinated for more than 24 hours. Her only medication is hydrocodone. On arrival, her temperature is
37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 152/70 mm Hg. Rectal examination shows decreased rectal
sphincter tone. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the lower extremities. Sensation to light touch is decreased in a saddle distribution. Abdominal
examination shows suprapubic fullness. Placement of a urinary catheter yields 800 ml of clear yellow urine and resolves the pelvic pain but not
the numbness. An MRI of the spine shows a tumor pushing into the L4-S 1 intrathecal space. Which of the following is the most appropriate
immediate next step in management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate
immediate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cauda equina syndrome occurs because of compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. Often, such compression occurs as a result of malignancy, trauma (eg, compression fractures with fragment retropulsion), disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural or subdural hematoma. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by inability to void and urinary retention. Emergent MRI of the lumbosacral spine is indicated to investigate the cause of cauda equina syndrome, and to determine the necessity of surgical decompression. Initial treatment for patients with epidural spinal cord compression and neurologic deficits include symptomatic treatment, pain control, and glucocorticoid therapy prior to operative therapy. High-dose glucocorticoid therapy (eg, dexamethasone) is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy, can help control pain, and may transiently improve neurologic function secondary to decreasing edema at the site of cord compression.

distractor_explanations.A: dose ibuprofen may be helpful for pain control, but many patients may require opioid analgesics to control severe pain. In a patient who takes hydrocodone and is opiate-tolerant, pain control will likely require opioid analgesics. Intravenous or intrathecal administration of chemotherapy (Choices C and D) or radiation therapy (Choice E) may all be helpful for definitive treatment of the tumor, but glucocorticoids are the next immediate step in management. Radiation therapy can help with expeditious local control of spinal metastases. Chemotherapy can be helpful for tumors causing cauda equina, however, systemic chemotherapy may take days to weeks to take effect. Patients with cauda equina syndrome require emergent management, typically r ~- , r, Clinical • .. immediate next step in management? A) Oral administration of high-dose ibuprofen B) Intravenous administration of high-dose dexamethasone C) Intravenous administration of chemotherapy D) lntrathecal administration of chemotherapy E) Radiation therapy to the spine Correct Answer: B. Cauda equina syndrome occurs because of compression of the spinal nerve roots comprising the cauda equina. Often, such compression occurs as a result of malignancy, trauma (eg, compression fractures with fragment retropulsion), disc herniation, spinal stenosis, spinal epidural abscess, or spinal epidural or subdural hematoma. Symptoms include lower extremity numbness, weakness, paralysis, hyporeflexia, perinea! anesthesia, fecal incontinence with poor rectal tone, and overflow incontinence marked by inability to void and urinary retention. Emergent MRI of the lumbosacral spine is indicated to investigate the cause of cauda equina syndrome, and to determine the necessity of surgical decompression. Initial treatment for patients with epidural spinal cord compression and neurologic deficits include symptomatic treatment, pain control, and glucocorticoid therapy prior to operative therapy. High-dose glucocorticoid therapy (eg, dexamethasone) is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy, can help control pain, and may transiently improve neurologic function secondary to decreasing edema at the site of cord compression. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. Oral administration of high-dose ibuprofen (Choice A) may be helpful for pain control, but many patients may require opioid analgesics to control severe pain. In a patient who takes hydrocodone and is opiate-tolerant, pain control will likely require opioid analgesics. Intravenous or intrathecal administration of chemotherapy (Choices C and D) or radiation therapy (Choice E) may all be helpful for definitive treatment of the tumor, but glucocorticoids are the next immediate step in management. Radiation therapy can help with expeditious local control of spinal metastases. Chemotherapy can be helpful for tumors causing cauda equina, however, systemic chemotherapy may take days to weeks to take effect. Patients with cauda equina syndrome require emergent management, typically with radiation and/or decompressive surgery.

explanation.educational_objective: In patients with cauda equina syndrome, high-dose glucocorticoid therapy is helpful as a bridge to definitive therapy, can help control pain, and may transiently improve neurologic function secondary to decreasing edema at the site of cord compression. ., Exam Section : Item 31 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
31. A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband after he found her in a confused state when he returned home from
a 3-day fishing trip. She has a long-standing relapsing psychiatric condition controlled with lithium carbonate, haloperidol, and clonazepam. She
does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She appears drowsy. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 16/min, and
blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. The pupils are 2 mm and reactive. There is a coarse tremor of the upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are
increased throughout. She responds only to vigorous stimulation. On mental status examination, her speech is slow and slurred. She appears
perplexed and sleepy and does not respond to questions. Laboratory studies show:
Leukocyte count 14,000/mm3
Serum
Urea nitrogen 60 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.5 mg/dL
Lithium 3.5 mEq/dL (therapeutic range=0.6-1.2)
In addition to discontinuing lithium carbonate, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient presents with signs and symptoms of lithium toxicity including confusion, neuromuscular excitability, coarse tremors, and myoclonic jerks. Severe lithium toxicity can cause seizures, status epilepticus, and encephalopathy. Lithium is also associated with kidney toxicity and end-stage kidney disease. Lithium is filtered in the glomerulus and is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules. Increased lithium reabsorption can occur in states of volume depletion and decreased lithium clearance can occur in kidney impairment. Management of lithium toxicity includes intravenous fluid resuscitation to maximize lithium clearance. Hemodialysis may be necessary in patients with severe lithium toxicity, seizures, altered mental status, or end-stage kidney disease resulting in impaired ability to excrete lithium.

distractor_explanations.A: Observation only would be inappropriate in this patient with severe lithium toxicity. Lithium is primarily excreted in the urine, which would be impaired in this patient with acute kidney injury. Therefore, in this case, lithium should be cleared by hemodialysis Exam Section : Item 31 of 50 Clinical i • • . . •· - ••• ii C) Add intravenous dantrolene D) Add intravenous flumazenil E) Begin hemodialysis Correct Answer: E. The patient presents with signs and symptoms of lithium toxicity including confusion, neuromuscular excitability, coarse tremors, and myoclonic jerks. Severe lithium toxicity can cause seizures, status epilepticus, and encephalopathy. Lithium is also associated with kidney toxicity and end-stage kidney disease. Lithium is filtered in the glomerulus and is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules. Increased lithium reabsorption can occur in states of volume depletion and decreased lithium clearance can occur in kidney impairment. Management of lithium toxicity includes intravenous fluid resuscitation to maximize lithium clearance. Hemodialysis may be necessary in patients with severe lithium toxicity, seizures, altered mental status, or end-stage kidney disease resulting in impaired ability to excrete lithium. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Observation only (Choice A) would be inappropriate in this patient with severe lithium toxicity. Lithium is primarily excreted in the urine, which would be impaired in this patient with acute kidney injury. Therefore, in this case, lithium should be cleared by hemodialysis. Discontinuing haloperidol (Choice B) would be unlikely to be helpful in this patient. The patient is showing signs of lithium toxicity, not adverse effects of haloperidol. Adverse effects of haloperidol can include akathisia, dystonia, muscle rigidity, and parkinsonism. Discontinuing haloperidol would be indicated in cases of neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which is characterized by severe hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, tachycardia, altered mental status, and autonomic dysfunction. Intravenous dantro lene (Choice C) would be indicated in the treatment of malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome. The patient's tremors and altered mental status are more likely because of lithium toxicity and not neuroleptic malignant syndrome.
distractor_explanations.D: Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine site on the y-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptor. Flumazenil is utilized to reverse accidental benzodiazepine overdose in patients who are not chronically dependent and benzodiazepine sedation after surgical procedures in select patients. Its use is limited as it can precipitate seizures.

explanation.educational_objective: Hemodialysis may be necessary in patients with severe lithium toxicity, seizures, altered mental status, or end stage kidney disease resulting in the impaired ability to excrete lithium. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Hemodialysis may be necessary in patients with severe lithium toxicity, seizures, altered mental status, or end stage kidney disease resulting in the impaired ability to excrete lithium. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
32. A previously healthy 62-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of intermittent drooping of his left eyelid and episodes of
double vision. Neurologic examinat ion shows bilateral ptosis, more prominent on the left. There is weakness of left eye abduction and adduction
and weakness of right eye abduction. Pupillary reflexes are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at
greatest risk for which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting findings of intermittent ptosis, diplopia, and reduction of extraocular movements are suggestive of myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis is a B lymphocyte-driven autoimmune disorder characterized by the formation of inhibitory anti-acetylcholine receptor autoantibodies. Patients typically experience muscular weakness and fatigue that worsens toward the end of the day, as well as ocular symptoms of drooping eyelids and diplopia. Many patients present with ocular findings and later develop generalized symptoms involving the proximal muscles. In severe exacerbations (myasthenic crises), patients may develop weakness of the muscles of the throat, diaphragm, and chest wall, leading to dysphagia and acute respiratory failure. Myasthenia gravis is diagnosed with the detection of serum autoantibodies. A chest x-ray is useful for detecting the presence of thymoma, which frequently produces myasthenia gravis as a paraneoplastic phenomenon. Some patients experience resolution of symptoms after surgical resection of a thymoma, although most patients require treatment with corticosteroids and acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (eg, pyridostigmine). Myasthenic crisis is treated with intravenous immune globulin, plasmapheresis, intubation, and mechanical ventilation.

distractor_explanations.A: Colon cancer is common in elderly patients, but rarely produces orbital metastases. Colon cancer more frequent ly metastasizes to the liver. While colon cancer may produce paraneoplastic findings, such as the Leser-Trelat sign, characterized by the sudden appearance of numerous seborrheic keratosis on the back and trunk, it does not typically cause myasthenia gravis.
distractor_explanations.B: Lymphoma may occur in the orbit, typically involving the conjunctiva or the orbital adnexal tissues such as the lacrimal gland, extraocular muscles, and eyelids. Patients typically present with unilateral proptosis and may present with ptosis or diplopia. However, these symptoms would be progressive and unremitting, rather than intermittent. Prostate cancer (Choice C) is common in elderly males and may rarely cause paraneoplastic syndromes. However, it does not typically cause myasthenia gravis, which is observed more frequently in association with thymoma. Small cell lung carcinoma (Choice D) may cause the paraneoplastic Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is characterized by the formation of autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channels and by impairment of acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction. While LEMS may present with similar symptoms to myasthenia gravis, it rarely affects the extraocular muscles.

explanation.educational_objective: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by the formation of inhibitory anti acetylcholine receptor autoantibodies. Common symptoms include muscular weakness, fatigue, diplopia, and ptosis that worsens toward the end of the day, along with dysphagia and potential respiratory distress. Patients may present with an associated thymoma Clinical Left eye Right eye
explanation.concept: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by the formation of inhibitory anti acetylcholine receptor autoantibodies. Common symptoms include muscular weakness, fatigue, d

vignette.presentation:
33. Over the past 3 months, a 60-year-o ld woman has had 2-minute episodes characterized by a rising sensation in the abdomen followed by loss of
awareness. During an episode, she stares, makes chewing movements, and makes fumbling moveme nts with her hands; afterwards, she is
confused for a few minutes. Visual fields are shown. Neurologic examination shows no other abnormalities. The most likely diagnosis is a lesion at
which of the following locations?

question_stem:
The most likely diagnosis is a lesion at
which of the following locations?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's visual fields demonstrate a left superior field quadrantanopia. In conjunction with her symptoms of seizures, characterized by staring, chewing movements, automatisms of the hands, and postictal confusion, a left superior field quadrantanopia raises concern for a lesion of the right tempora l lobe, such as an astrocytoma. After decussating at the optic chiasm, retinal ganglion cell axons carrying information from the left visual field traverse the optic radiations and synapse at the lateral geniculate nucleus. Neurons from the lateral geniculate nucleus travel to the primary visual cortex via the optic radiations, which divide into superior and inferior divisions Clinical Please Walt • • • C) Optic nerve D) Parietal lobe E) Temporal lobe Correct Answer: E. This patient's visual fields demonstrate a left superior field quadrantanopia. In conjunction with her symptoms of seizures, characterized by staring, chewing movements, automatisms of the hands, and postictal confusion, a left superior field quadrantanopia raises concern for a lesion of the right temporal lobe, such as an astrocytoma. After decussating at the optic chiasm, retinal ganglion cell axons carrying information from the left visual field traverse the optic radiations and synapse at the lateral geniculate nucleus. Neurons from the lateral geniculate nucleus travel to the primary visual cortex via the optic radiations, which divide into superior and inferior divisions. The right superior division travels through the right parietal lobe and carries information from the right inferior visual fields. In contrast, the right inferior division travels through the right temporal lobe by looping around the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle, forming the Meyer loop, and carries information from the right superior visual fields. Lesions of the temporal lobe that interrupt the Meyer loop produce a characteristic contralateral superior quadrantanopia, a visual defect described as a wedge-shaped loss of vision.

distractor_explanations.A: The frontal lobe contains the frontal eye fields, which are important in the generation of eye movements. Lesions affecting the frontal eye fields can produce an ipsilateral conjugate gaze preference but do not produce visual field deficits. The occipital lobe (Choice B) is the location of the primary visual cortex. Lesions of the occipital lobe produce homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The optic nerve (Choice C) carries all the visual information from the retina of its respective eye. A lesion of the optic nerve, such as in the setting of glioma, demyelinating optic neuritis, or trauma, produces a complete visual field defect of one eye. The parietal lobe (Choice D) contains the superior division of the optic radiation, which carries information from the inferior visual fields. A unilateral lesion of the parietal lobe may produce a contralateral inferior visual field quadrantanopia.

explanation.educational_objective: Temporal lobe lesions that interrupt the Meyer loop of the inferior division of the optic radiation produce a characteristic contralateral superior visual field quadrantanopia. Superior visual field quadrantanopia in conjunction with symptoms of seizures should raise suspicion for a mass of the temporal lobe, such as an astrocytoma. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Temporal lobe lesions that interrupt the Meyer loop of the inferior division of the optic radiation produce a characteristic contralateral superior visual field quadrantanopia. Superior visual field q

vignette.presentation:
34. A previously healthy 57-year-old man comes for a follow-up examination because of progressive weakness of his arms and legs. Six months ago,
examination showed no abnormalities except for 4/5 muscle strength in all extremities. Current examination shows fasciculations in the hands and
right lower extremity and pseudobulbar palsy. Sensation is normal and cranial nerves are intact. He is oriented, and affect is appropriate. An MRI of
the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's disease?

question_stem: the most likely mechanism of this patient's disease?

choices.text: Neoplastic infiltration of the central nervous system
Neuronal loss in the substantia nigra

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder arising in midlife that affects both lower motor neurons arising from the anterior horn and upper motor neurons of the lateral corticospinal tract within the brain and spinal cord. Neurons degenerate because of an unknown etiology that may involve RNA processing and/or excitotoxicity, and gliosis results. Patient presentations are variable, though typically feature a combination of upper motor neuron (eg, increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign) and lower motor neuron findings (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy) in an asymmetric distribution that may include the bulbar muscles. Some patients may experience cognitive or behavioral changes, though other patients are cognitively normal. The diagnosis is primarily clinical but may be supported by electromyographic findings of acute and chronic denervation and reinnervation. MRI of the brain and spine should be performed to rule out other diseases. Treatment should include riluzole, which may modestly improve survival but does not cure the disease.

distractor_explanations.A: Amyloid deposition occurs in Alzheimer disease. Alzheimer disease may feature apraxia (potentially related to parietal cortex damage) but does not typically lead to upper neuron or lower motor neuron dysfunction.
distractor_explanations.B: Demyelination occurs in acute conditions such as pontine myelinolysis and chronic autoimmune disorders such as multiple sclerosis. Demyelination can affect the white matter of the corticospinal tract but would not affect the anterior horns (gray matter). Neoplastic infiltration of the central nervous system (Choice D) may lead to localized upper motor neuron dysfunction because of mass effect. However, generalized dysfunction in both an upper and lower motor neuron pattern is more consistent with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Neuronal ganglioside GM deposition (Choice E) occurs in Tay-Sachs disease, a heritable lysosomal storage disease that presents with 2 motor neuron degeneration. A combination of upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron dysfunction is possible, but symptoms typically begin in infancy and are usually symmetric. Neuronal loss in the substantia nigra (Choice F) occurs in Parkinson disease and leads to resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability. Upper or lower motor neuron dysfunction would be atypical.

explanation.educational_objective: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder arising in midlife that affects both lower motor neurons arising from the anterior horn and upper motor neurons of the lateral corticospina l tract within the brain and spinal cord. Patients typically present with dysfunction of both upper motor neurons (eg, increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, Babinski sign) and lower motor neurons (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy) in an asymmetric distribution Clinical
explanation.concept: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder arising in midlife that affects both lower motor neurons arising from the anterior horn and upper motor neurons of the lateral

vignette.presentation:
35. A 62-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 3-year history of progressive forgetfulness. He has difficulty remembering
names, especially of people he has recently met. He retired from his profession as a retail clerk 12 weeks ago because he had been forgetting the
names of customers and new products and could no longer effectively perform his job. He also has had progressive difficulty with activities of daily
living; his wife now chooses his clothes for him. He has no history o1f head trauma. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications.
He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he has an indifferent
mood and affect. He is oriented to person, place, and time but takes a few minutes before he correctly names the date. His Mini-Mental State
Examination score is 22/30. There is no evidence of auditory or visual hallucinations. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges.
Administration of a drug from which of the following classes is most appropriate for this patient?

question_stem: most appropriate for this patient?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Alzheimer dementia (AD) results from decreased cholinergic signaling and is treated with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. Cholinergic neurons-which primarily originate from the locus coeruleus and basal forebrain and project widely to areas including the cortex mediate attention, learning, and memory. AD is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that begins with short-term memory impairment and decline in visuospatial abilities and progresses to apraxia, language abnormalities, and dysexecutive syndrome (resulting in the inability to pick out clothes in this patient). The disease culminates in behavioral and personality changes that prevent the patient from performing basic activities of daily living, such as bathing. Acetylcholinesterase normally hydrolyzes acetylcholine in synaptic clefts. Donepezil and other cholinesterase inhibitors non-competitively and reversibly inhibit acetylcholinesterase activity and thereby increase the amount of synaptic acetylcholine available for neurotransmission. Though donepezil may slow the rate of cognitive decline and modestly improve functiona lity, donepezil and the other cholinesterase inhibitors are not curative.

distractor_explanations.B: Dopamine agonists increase dopamine signaling and therefore relieve parkinsonism. This patient does not demonstrate motor findings typical of Parkinson disease such as tremor, bradykinesia, or postural instability. NMDA receptor agonists (Choice C), such as endogenous glutamate, mediate activity-dependent synaptic changes of learning and memory. However, NMDA agonism is not a known drug mechanism because of the risk for excitotoxicity Clinical E) Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor Correct Answer: A. Alzheimer dementia (AD) results from decreased cholinergic signaling and is treated with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. Cholinergic neurons-which primarily originate from the locus coeruleus and basal forebrain and project widely to areas including the cortex mediate attention, learning, and memory. AD is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that begins with short-term memory impairment and decline in visuospatial abilities and progresses to apraxia, language abnormalities, and dysexecutive syndrome (resulting in the inability to pick out clothes in this patient). The disease culminates in behavioral and personality changes that prevent the patient from performing basic activities of daily living, such as bathing. Acetylcholinesterase normally hydrolyzes acetylcholine in synaptic clefts. Donepezil and other cholinesterase inhibitors non-competitively and reversibly inhibit acetylcholinesterase activity and thereby increase the amount of synaptic acetylcholine available for neurotransmission. Though donepezil may slow the rate of cognitive decline and modestly improve functiona lity, donepezil and the other cholinesterase inhibitors are not curative. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. Dopamine agonists (Choice B) increase dopamine signaling and therefore relieve parkinsonism. This patient does not demonstrate motor findings typical of Parkinson disease such as tremor, bradykinesia, or postural instability. NMDA receptor agonists (Choice C), such as endogenous glutamate, mediate activity-dependent synaptic changes of learning and memory. However, NMDA agonism is not a known drug mechanism because of the risk for excitotoxicity. NMDA receptor antagonists (Choice D), such as memantine, protect the brain from glutamate excitotoxicity. Patients with moderate to severe AD ( eg, a mini-menta l state examination score less than 18) may modestly benefit from memantine monotherapy if they cannot tolerate cholinesterase inhibitors. However, cholinesterase inhibitors are the first-line medications for AD of all severities, and this patient does not have moderate to severe dementia. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (Choice E) increase synaptic serotonin activity and improve mood in patients with major depressive disorder. Major depressive disorder may cause cognitive impairment in older patients, which can improve with antidepressant treatment. However, this patient demonstrates an indifferent, not depressed, affect, and does not illustrate other signs of a depressive disorder.

explanation.educational_objective: Alzheimer dementia results from decreased cholinergic signaling in the cortex and basal forebrain. Alzheimer dementia is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that culminates in the inability to perform basic activities of daily living. Cholinesterase inhibitors, such as donepezil, are the first-line treatment. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
36. A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 20 minutes after he was found by a janitor on the floor of a restroom at
a bus station. At the scene, he was having continuous, generalized tonic-clonic seizures. An endotracheal tube was placed, and supplementa l
oxygen was administered. On arrival to the emergency department, he is flushed and diaphoretic. There are no external signs of trauma. His
temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. The pupils are 4 mm and reactive to
light. Examination shows tonic stiffening of the trunk and synchronous clonic jerking of the extremities. In addition to intravenous administration of
dextrose, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in treatment?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Status epilepticus is defined as continuous epileptic activity for at least five minutes, or at least two discrete seizures with incomplete interval recovery of consciousness. Status epilepticus is a neurologic emergency that portends increased morbidity and requires prompt evaluation and treatment. The first-line treatment for convulsive status epilepticus involves benzodiazepines (eg, lorazepam, midazolam, or diazepam), which have been shown to control seizures rapidly. Benzodiazepines bind the GABAA receptor, a chloride channel, and increase the frequency of its opening. y-Aminobutyric acid (GABA) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that counterbalances neuronal excitation, making benzodiazepines an effective treatment for seizure cessation.

distractor_explanations.A: Fosphenytoin blocks sodium channels and is typically a second-line choice in the treatment of status epilepticus. Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment of convulsive status epilepticus.
distractor_explanations.C: Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist used in the treatment of opiate or opioid overdoses, which classically present with bradypnea and pinpoint pupils. Naloxone has also been used to treat clonidine overdose.
distractor_explanations.D: Phenobarbital can be effective for controlling seizures, however it is not the first-line pharmacotherapy as a result of slow administration and adverse effects of prolonged sedation and hypotension. Valproic acid (Choice E) increases sodium channel inactivation and increases GABA concentration. It is typically second-line in the treatment of status epilepticus.

explanation.educational_objective: Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment of convulsive status epilepticus. ., Exam Section : Item 37 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment of convulsive status epilepticus. ., Exam Section : Item 37 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
37. A previously healthy 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 10-day history of increasingly severe headaches. The
pain has been unremitting for the past 18 hours; he describes it as severe and pounding. His pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood
pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. Examination of the face and neck shows mild swelling and a dusky reddish-purple skin color with venous distention
over the head and neck; the skin color below the neck is normal. Examinat ion of the optic fundi shows papilledema. Neurologic examination shows
no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's increased intracranial pressure?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's increased intracranial pressure?

choices.text: Obstruction of cerebrospina l fluid flow
Obstruction of venous return to the heart
Obstruction of venous return to the heart

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Obstruction of venous return to the heart through the superior vena cava (SVC) leads to superior vena cava syndrome, which presents with facial swelling, headaches, and occasionally altered mental status or respiratory distress. Superior vena cava syndrome is most commonly caused by extrinsic compression of the SVC by an intrathoracic malignancy, such as lung cancer or lymphoma. Physical examination typically shows facial plethora, venous distension over the head and neck, and papilledema, as in this patient. While a chest x-ray may be abnormal, CT venography is typically diagnostic. Stent placement and radiation therapy are used to treat symptoms, but superior vena cava syndrome is classically associated with a poor prognosis.

distractor_explanations.A: Dilation of cerebral arteries is associated with the development of migraine headaches, which present with unilateral, pounding-type headaches that are associated with photophobia and phonophobia. They typically last for less than 48 to 72 hours and may have a preceding aura. They do not cause facial plethora and venous distension. An intracranial mass lesion (Choice B) classically presents with focal neurologic deficits, such as hemiplegia, altered mental status, and signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as headache and nausea. Physical examination may demonstrate papilledema. However, it would not be expected to cause discoloration of the face or venous distension of the head and neck. Obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid flow (Choice C) and overproduction of cerebrospinal fluid (Choice E) can both lead to hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus commonly presents with headache, altered mental status or behavior, and nausea or vomiting because of increased intracranial pressure. While papilledema may be present, venous distension would not be. r ~- - - , r - - - -, Exam Section : Item 37 of 50 Clinical A) Dilation of cerebral arteries B) lntracranial mass lesion C) Obstruction of cerebrospinal fluid flow D) Obstruction of venous return to the heart E) Overproductio n of cerebrospinal fluid Correct Answer: D. vignette.presentation:
38. Five days after a left hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 62-year-old man is transferred to the intensive care unit because of temperatures to
40.6°C (105°F), lethargy, diaphoresis, and labile blood pressure for 3 hours. His postoperative course had been complicated by temperatures to
37.8°C (100°F) and nocturnal agitation since day 2; he has required haloperidol therapy (2 mg nightly). He has a history of bipolar disorder.
Medications include morphine by patient-controlled analgesia pump, lithium carbonate, and clonazepam. He is lying expressionless in a pool of
sweat and is drooling. His temperature is 40.6°C (105°F), pulse is 140/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. Examination shows wet skin
and dry mucosa. There is a herpetic lesion on his lower lip. The neck is supple and the intravenous catheter insertion site is nontender with no
erythema. Bowel sounds are hyperactive; there is no organomega ly. The wound is clean and dry with no erythema. Neurologic examination shows
a masked facies and a marked intention tremor. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperactive and symmetric. Babinski sign is absent. Laboratory studies
show:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 20,000/mm 3
Segmented neutrophils 80%
Bands 5%
Lymphocytes 10%
Monocytes 5%
Serum
Urea nitrogen 38 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL
Creatine kinase 1000 U/L
Urinalysis and an x-ray of the chest show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is most likely in this patient who has received high-potency antipsychotic medication. NMS is a life-threatening condition associated with the antagonism of dopamine that presents with altered mental status, muscle rigidity or tremor, hyperthermia, and autonomic dysfunction. Common causative agents are antipsychotics (especia lly high-potency antipsychotics Clinical Correct Answer: E. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is most likely in this patient who has received high-potency antipsychotic medication. NMS is a life-threatening condition associated with the antagonism of dopamine that presents with altered mental status, muscle rigidity or tremor, hyperthermia, and autonomic dysfunction. Common causative agents are antipsychotics (especia lly high-potency antipsychotics such as haloperidol) and antidopaminergic nausea medications. Rigidity and tremor result from dopamine antagonism in the nigrostriatal pathway, while autonomic dysfunction and hyperthermia may result from dopamine antagonism in the hypothalamus. Characteristic laboratory abnormalities include leukocytosis along with increased serum concentration of creatine kinase, lactate dehydrogenase, and alkaline phosphatase (as a result of prolonged muscle rigidity and consequent myolysis). Treatment is supportive and includes discontinuation of the offending medication, hydration, cooling blankets, and benzodiazepines if needed for agitation. Dantrolene is potentially beneficial.

distractor_explanations.A: related fever is unlikely in this patient. While some antibiotics can cause mild increases in body temperature, marked hyperthermia is not a common side effect of antibiotic therapy. Furthermore, this patient is not currently taking antibiotics. Herpes encephalitis (Choice B) presents with fever, altered mental status, and neurologic abnormalities, such as seizure, aphasia, hemiparesis, or cranial nerve deficits. Neuroimaging will typically demonstrate changes in the temporal lobe. Encephalitis is commonly associated with nuchal rigidity, which this patient does not demonstrate, making herpes encephalitis a less likely cause of his presentation. Additiona lly, an increased creatine kinase concentration is not consistent with herpes encephalitis. Lithium toxicity (Choice C) presents with nausea, vomiting, dysrhythmias, altered mental status, and neuromuscu lar excitability, such as tremors in acute toxicity. Chronic toxicity has more prominent neurologic symptoms and can also cause nephrogenic diabetes insipid us. Malignant hyperthermia (Choice D) is caused by a genetic defect in the ryanodine receptor and presents with muscle rigidity, tachycardia, fever, lactic acidosis, and hypercarbia when the patient is exposed to succinylcholine or volatile anesthetics. While the presentation is similar to NMS, this patient has not been exposed to agents that trigger malignant hyperthermia since his surgery, making this a less likely cause of his illness. Postoperative sepsis (Choice F) presents with fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and leukocytosis, as well as hypotension and lactic acidosis if the patient is in septic shock, in the setting of a known or suspected infection. It is rarely associated with hypertension. Furthermore, this patient has no signs of infection on physical examination.

explanation.educational_objective: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a life-threatening condition associated with the antagonism of dopamine that presents with altered mental status, muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and autonomic dysfunction. Characteristic laboratory abnormalities include leukocytosis along with increased concentrations of creatine kinase, alkaline phosphatase, and lactate dehydrogenase Clinical

vignette.presentation:
39. A 32-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department because of progressive visual dimming in her right eye since awakening 8 hours
ago. Her symptoms began with a mild headache over her right eye before going to bed last night. She says this headache is different than her
usual migraines that have improved since she started treatment with propranolol. Funduscopic examination shows no abnorma lities of the right
eye, but the patient cannot read and can barely count fingers with the right eye. Visual acuity in the left eye is normal. A CT scan of the head
shows normal findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Optic neuritis results from autoimmune demyelinating inflammation of the optic nerve and presents in young, often female, patients with unilatera l vision loss and pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements. Ocular examination demonstrates reduced visual acuity and color vision, a relative afferent pupillary defect, and may demonstrate optic disc edema. Diagnosis is confirmed with MRI demonstrating hyperintensity of the optic nerve. Patients with optic neuritis are at increased risk for multiple sclerosis (MS), and optic neuritis is a common initial finding in patients with MS. Recently, autoantibodies against myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) and aquaporin-4 (AQP4) have been identified as causative of some cases of optic neuritis. Patients who develop optic neuritis as a result of antibodies against MOG and AQP4 often have severe presentations but also have decreased risk for subsequent MS compared to patients with optic neuritis who lack these autoantibodies. The Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial demonstrated that a short course of treatment with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone speeds the rate of visual recovery and delays the onset of MS, although it does not impact final visual acuity, and demonstrated that the presence and quantity of periventricular white matter lesions on MRI is the most important prognostic risk factor for the subsequent development of MS.

distractor_explanations.A: Diabetic retinopathy results from microvascular damage to retinal capillaries and is characterized by the presence of microaneurysms, intraretinal hemorrhages, and retinal nerve fiber layer infarctions. Diabetic retinopathy is usually symmetric between both eyes and is not painful Clinical Correct Answer: E. Optic neuritis results from autoimmune demyelinating inflammation of the optic nerve and presents in young, often female, patients with unilateral vision loss and pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements. Ocular examination demonstrates reduced visual acuity and color vision, a relative afferent pupillary defect, and may demonstrate optic disc edema. Diagnosis is confirmed with MRI demonstrating hyperintensity of the optic nerve. Patients with optic neuritis are at increased risk for multiple sclerosis (MS), and optic neuritis is a common initial finding in patients with MS. Recently, autoantibodies against myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) and aquaporin-4 (AQP4) have been identified as causative of some cases of optic neuritis. Patients who develop optic neuritis as a result of antibodies against MOG and AQP4 often have severe presentations but also have decreased risk for subsequent MS compared to patients with optic neuritis who lack these autoantibodies. The Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial demonstrated that a short course of treatment with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone speeds the rate of visual recovery and delays the onset of MS, although it does not impact final visual acuity, and demonstrated that the presence and quantity of periventricular white matter lesions on MRI is the most important prognostic risk factor for the subsequent development of MS. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, F, G, and H. Diabetic retinopathy (Choice A) results from microvascular damage to retinal capillaries and is characterized by the presence of microaneurysms, intraretinal hemorrhages, and retinal nerve fiber layer infarctions. Diabetic retinopathy is usually symmetric between both eyes and is not painful. Fabry disease (Choice B) is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder that results from deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A. Ocular manifestations include corneal verticillata (vortex keratopathy), cataract, and retinal vascular tortuosity.
distractor_explanations.C: Migraine may present with visual aura symptoms of scintillating scotoma or fortification spectra but does not generally cause profound loss of visual acuity. Ophthalmic arteritis (Choice D) may occur secondary to giant cell arteritis. Giant cell arteritis presents with acute onset vision loss and temporal headache but is rare in patients under the age of 50. Retinal detachment (Choice F) may occur secondary to diabetic retinopathy, retinal tears, or retinal inflammatory disorders. Retinal detachment is discernible on fundoscopy and is typically painless. Retinal emboli (Choice G) cause branch or central retinal artery occlusion and commonly occur secondary to valvular or carotid artery disease. Retinal arterial occlusions are visible as localized or generalized swathes of retinal pallor and may manifest with a visible plaque occluding a retinal arteriole (Hollenhorst plaque). Retinitis pigmentosa (Choice H) refers to a family of inherited degenerative disorders of retinal photoreceptors. Fundus findings are typically symmetric between both eyes and include waxy optic disc pallor, retinal vascular attenuation, and retinal bone spicules.

explanation.educational_objective: Optic neuritis is an autoimmune, inflammatory disorder of the optic nerve that presents with acute onset vision loss and ocular pain that is exacerbated with extraocular movements. Patients typically present with profoundly decreased visual acuity and color vision, along with a relative afferent pupillary defect. Diagnosis is confirmed with MRI and with testing for serum autoantibodies. MRI provides important prognostic information regarding the subsequent risk for developing multiple sclerosis, which commonly occurs in association with optic neuritis. Treatment with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone speeds visual recovery and delays the onset of multiple sclerosis Clinical
