vignette.presentation:
40. A previously healthy 4 ?-year-o ld man is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressive weakness. He says that during this
period, his feet "flop" while walking, and he trips when walking up stairs. During the past week, he has had difficulty standing up from low chairs
and opening jars. He has not had pain or tingling. He has had constipation but no changes in bladder or sexual function. He has not had any
recent infections or vaccinations. He takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He drinks three to four beers
daily; for the past 6 weeks he has been drinking home-distilled whiskey. Examination shows atrophy of the intrinsic muscles of the hands and feet.
Muscle strength is 4/5 in the wrist and finger extensors, interosseous, iliopsoas, and hamstring muscles and 3/5 in the anterior tibialis, peronei, and
posterior tibial is muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ diffusely. Babinski sign is absent. Sensory examination shows no abnorma lities. Laboratory
studies show microcytic anemia and hyperuricemia . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's neurologic symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's neurologic symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Symptoms of acute lead poisoning occur within days or weeks of exposure and include abdominal pain, constipation, arthralgia, myalgias, muscle weakness, excessive fatigue, headache, and difficulty concent rating. With prolonged exposure, chronic neurologic symptoms such as decline in cognition, depression, distal motor neuropathy, decreased hearing, tremor, and decreased brain volume on imaging may be present. The distal motor neuropathy causes lower motor neuron signs such as atrophy of muscles and hyporeflexia, as shown in this patient. Microcytic anemia is also common, since lead inhibits the enzymes ferrochelatase and o-ALA dehydratase, resulting in decreased heme synthesis. In adults, exposure to lead primarily comes through occupation and/or hobbies. Individuals working with batteries, mining, construction , or ammunition are at higher risk. Illegally distilling alcohol has a risk for lead toxicity because of the leaching of lead from solder in the still, which is likely where this patient received exposure. Diagnosis is suspected based on exposure and symptoms and confirmed with increased serum lead concentration. Management of lead poisoning depends on the blood lead concentration and presence of symptoms, and includes chelation with dimercaprol, ethylene diamine tetraacetate, or succimer. Sources of lead should be investigated and eliminated.

distractor_explanations.A: Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosoma l dominant disorder caused by inactivating mutations of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase, resulting in deficient synthesis of heme and accumulation of porphobilinogen. Patients typically present during an acute attack with psychosis, abdominal pain, muscle weakness, neuropathy, and burgundy-colored urine. This patient's subacute presentation in the context of alcohol distillation is more consistent with lead poisoning ____ Clinical Correct Answer: E. Symptoms of acute lead poisoning occur within days or weeks of exposure and include abdominal pain, constipation, arthralgia, myalgias, muscle weakness, excessive fatigue, headache, and difficulty concentrating. With prolonged exposure, chronic neurologic symptoms such as decline in cognition, depression, distal motor neuropathy, decreased hearing, tremor, and decreased brain volume on imaging may be present. The distal motor neuropathy causes lower motor neuron signs such as atrophy of muscles and hyporeflexia, as shown in this patient. Microcytic anemia is also common, since lead inhibits the enzymes ferrochelatase and o-ALA dehydratase, resulting in decreased heme synthesis. In adults, exposure to lead primarily comes through occupation and/or hobbies. Individuals working with batteries, mining, construction, or ammunition are at higher risk. Illegally distilling alcohol has a risk for lead toxicity because of the leaching of lead from solder in the still, which is likely where this patient received exposure. Diagnosis is suspected based on exposure and symptoms and confirmed with increased serum lead concentration. Management of lead poisoning depends on the blood lead concentration and presence of symptoms, and includes chelation with dimercapro l, ethylene diamine tetraacetate, or succimer. Sources of lead should be investigated and eliminated. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Acute intermittent porphyria (Choice A) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by inactivating mutations of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase, resulting in deficient synthesis of heme and accumulation of porphobilinogen. Patients typically present during an acute attack with psychosis, abdomina l pain, muscle weakness, neuropathy, and burgundy-colored urine. This patient's subacute presentation in the context of alcohol distillation is more consistent with lead poisoning. Alcohol abuse (Choice B) may cause peripheral neuropathy as a result of vitamin deficiency, but this more often manifests with gait instability than muscle weakness. Guillain-Barre syndrome (Choice C) is a demyelinating polyneuropathy that starts with the distal extremities and progresses proximally. It may affect the lungs through diaphragmatic paralysis, which is the most serious complication of the disease. Hepatolenticular degeneration (Wilson disease) (Choice D) is caused by decreased ceruloplasmin concentrations which cause excess copper to accumulate both inside and outside the liver. While the presentation is varied, some degree of liver disease is almost always seen at the time of diagnosis, which this patient does not demonstrate. Copper may deposit in the basal ganglia or diffusely in the brain. Neurologic symptoms include dysarthria, gait abnormalities, dystonia, tremor, parkinsonism, chorea, or athetosis. Constipation, anemia, and hyperuricemia are not seen.

explanation.educational_objective: Neurologic manifestations of lead poisoning include cognitive dysfunction, encephalopathy, hearing loss, and peripheral neuropathy. Distal motor neuropathy causes lower motor neuron signs including weakness, atrophy, hypotonia, and hyporeflexia. Other manifestations of lead poisoning include renal tubular dysfunction, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, and anemia Exam Section : Item 41 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Neurologic manifestations of lead poisoning include cognitive dysfunction, encephalopathy, hearing loss, and peripheral neuropathy. Distal motor neuropathy causes lower motor neuron signs including we

vignette.presentation:
41. An 18-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after he fell 25 feet. On examination, he is paraplegic and has urinary
incontinence. Examination of the lower extremities shows absent reflexes and flaccid tone. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. X-rays of the spine
show a fracture dislocation of T10. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's urinary incontinence?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for this patient's urinary incontinence?

choices.text: Compression of the S3-4 nerve roots
Compression of the T10- 11 nerve roots
Compression of the thoracic spinal cord
Compressio n of the conus medullaris
Compressio n of the S3-4 nerve roots
Compressio n of the T10- 11 nerve roots
Compression of the thoracic spinal cord

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: An injury at the level of the thoracic spinal cord would affect the thoracic cord and may also affect segments distal to the level of the injury, including the lumbosacral segments that innervate lower extremity musculature and sensation. An injury at the level of T10 can affect sympathetic efferent fibers that provide inhibitory input to the bladder and urethra via the hypogastric nerve. Sympathetic stimulation through these fibers usually causes relaxation of bladder musculature and contraction of urethral sphincter, resulting in urinary retention. Injury to these fibers will cause urinary incontinence as a result of impaired inhibition of bladder contraction. Spinal cord pathologies that result in urinary incontinence result in complex interactions between signals from the parasympathetic, sympathetic, and somatic nervous systems and may present with urge or overflow incontinence, altogether termed neurogenic bladder.

distractor_explanations.A: Compression of the conus medullaris often occurs at the level of L2. It can also present with sphincter dysfunction, spastic or flaccid paralysis, as well as saddle anesthesia. An injury at T10 would be unlikely to affect the conus medullaris. Compression of the S3-4 nerve roots (Choice B) describes cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome presents with low back pain, weakness of lower extremities, bladder and rectal sphincter paralysis leading to urinary retention, and sensory deficits. Compression of the T10-11 nerve roots (Choice C) would result in a thoracic radiculopathy in a dermatomal distribution resulting in pain and numbness around the umbilicus. Rupture of the bladder neck (Choice E) would present with hematuria, pelvic pain, lower abdominal pain, and difficulty voiding. It would be unlikely to be the cause of the patient's urinary incontinence and would not present with lower extremity neurologic symptoms.

explanation.educational_objective: Compression of the thoracic spinal cord can affect sympathetic efferent fibers that provide inhibitory input to the r ~ - - - - , r - - - , Exam Section : Item 41 of 50 Clinical A) Compressio n of the conus medullaris B) Compressio n of the S3-4 nerve roots C) Compressio n of the T10- 11 nerve roots D) Compression of the thoracic spinal cord E) Rupture of the bladder neck Correct Answer: D. An injury at the level of the thoracic spinal cord would affect the thoracic cord and may also affect segments distal to the level of the injury, including the lumbosacral segments that innervate lower extremity musculature and sensation. An injury at the level of T10 can affect sympathetic efferent fibers that provide inhibitory input to the bladder and urethra via the hypogastric nerve. Sympathetic stimulation through these fibers usually causes relaxation of bladder musculature and contraction of urethra l sphincter, resulting in urinary retention. Injury to these fibers will cause urinary incontinence as a result of impaired inhibition of bladder contraction. Spinal cord pathologies that result in urinary incontinence result in complex interactions between signals from the parasympathetic, sympathetic, and somatic nervous systems and may present with urge or overflow incontinence, altogether termed neurogenic bladder. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Compression of the conus medullaris (Choice A) often occurs at the level of L2. It can also present with sphincter dysfunction, spastic or flaccid paralysis, as well as saddle anesthesia. An injury at T10 would be unlikely to affect the conus medullaris. Compression of the S3-4 nerve roots (Choice B) describes cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome presents with low back pain, weakness of lower extremities, bladder and rectal sphincter paralysis leading to urinary retention, and sensory deficits. Compression of the T10-11 nerve roots (Choice C) would result in a thoracic radiculopathy in a dermatomal distribution resulting in pain and numbness around the umbilicus. Rupture of the bladder neck (Choice E) would present with hematuria, pelvic pain, lower abdominal pain, and difficulty voiding. It would be unlikely to be the cause of the patient's urinary incontinence and would not present with lower extremity neurologic symptoms. Educational Objective: Compression of the thoracic spinal cord can affect sympathetic efferent fibers that provide inhibitory input to the bladder and urethra via the hypogastric nerve. Injury to these fibers will cause urinary incontinence because of impaired inhibition of bladder contraction. ., Clinical

42. Four days after admission to the hospital for intravenous antibiotic therapy for a leg rash, a 77-year-old man is unable to urinate. The rash
developed 10 days ago on his right foot and has now spread to his calf. On admission, the right lower extremity was warm and erythematous.
Yesterday, he had the onset of neck pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus currently treated with glyburide. He appears acutely ill. His temperature
is 39°C (102.2°F). Examination shows nuchal rigidity. The right lower extremity is warm and erythematous. Muscle strength is full in the proximal
upper extremities and is 4/5 in the hands. He is unable to lift the lower extremities against gravity. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk. Babinski sign is
present bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick is decreased below C?. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: An epidural abscess is a localized collection of pus in the epidural space between the dura mater and periosteum. It most commonly occurs in the spine but may occur in the brain. Most patients are elderly and have a history of concomitant infection and often have a history of immunocompromise (eg, diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, alcohol use disorder). Epidural abscess is more common in patients with a history of intravenous drug use. Infectious organisms usually spread to the epidural space hematogenously, from spinal surgery, or from adjacent osteomyelitis. Staphylococcus aureus is a frequent causative organism, but fungal infections also occur. Patients present with signs and symptoms of fever, altered mental status, meningismus, localized back pain and tenderness to palpation, and weakness, numbness, and paralysis below the affected spinal level. Treatment is with broad spectrum antibiotics and surgical drainage of the abscess.

distractor_explanations.B: Herniated cervical disc is caused by dislocation of the nucleus pulposus and annulus fibrosus of a cervical intervertebra l disc and may produce cervical radiculopathy or spinal cord compression. Patients present with neck pain and dermatomal arm pain and weakness. Infected hematoma of the spine (Choice C) may rarely occur following epidural hematoma formation in the spinal column. Patients often have a history of anticoagulation or coagulopathy plus immunocompromise or recent instrumentation.
distractor_explanations.D: Meningitis may result from meningeal bacterial, viral, or fungal infection, and presents with fever, meningismus and altered mental status. It is less likely to produce focal neurologic defects such as the lower extremity weakness and reduced pinprick noted in this patient. Subdural empyema (Choice E) occurs as an accumulation of pus and infectious material between the dura and arachnoid mater. It presents with fever and signs and symptoms of increased intracrania l pressure.

explanation.educational_objective: An epidural abscess of the spine may result from the hematogenous dissemination of bacterial or fungal infection to the epidural space between the dura mater and periosteum. It presents with fever, altered mental status, meningismus, localized back pain, and tenderness to palpation, along with weakness, numbness, and paralysis below the affected spinal level. Treatment is with broad spectrum antibiotics and surgical drainage of the abscess. ., Clinical

43. An otherwise healthy 52-year-old financia l advisor comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of progressive right hand weakness that is
interfering with his ability to write. There is no history of trauma to the hand. He takes no medications. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs
90 kg (199 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2 . Examination of the right hand shows decreased active abduction of the small and index fingers. He cannot cross
and uncross his right index and middle fingers, and he is unable to pinch the palmar aspect of the right thumb against the radial side of the index
finger without flexing the interphalangeal joint of the thumb to provide strength. Active flexion of the interphalangeal joints of the right hand is 5/5.
Sensation over the entire dorsal aspect of the hand is normal. The remainder of the neurologic examinat ion shows no focal findings. Which of the
following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Electrophysiological studies are utilized to diagnose ulnar neuropathy. Ulnar neuropathy typically arises from ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow or wrist, which may occur idiopathically or because of trauma, compression, or elbow joint pathology. While ulnar nerve entrapment at the elbow typically results in numbness and paresthesia of the medial hand and wrist, ulnar nerve entrapment at the wrist typically leads to weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles and the consequent loss of hand dexterity. The ulnar nerve innervates the palmaris brevis, hypothenar, lumbrical, interossei, and adductor pollicis muscles. As a result of adductor pollicis dysfunction, patients illustrate a decreased ability to pinch the first two digits together. As a result of interossei muscle dysfunction, this patient is unable to fully abduct or adduct the digits. Sensory dysfunction in the ulnar distribution may result from ulnar entrapment at the wrist as well. Electrophysiological studies (eg, nerve conduction studies or electromyography) confirm the clinical diagnosis. Management begins with conservative methods (eg, activity modification) but may include surgical decompression for severe or refractory symptoms.

distractor_explanations.A: plexus would diagnose brachia! plexopathies. Brachia! plexopathies typically present with numbness, paresthesia, or weakness of the shoulder and arm, and less common ly, the hand. If present, intrinsic hand weakness is typically accompanied by forearm or shoulder weakness. MRI of the neck (Choice B) could identify cervical radiculopathy. Cervical radiculopathy refers to cervical nerve root pathology that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesia, and pain in the dermatomal distribution that correlates to the affected nerve root. This patient's isolated intrinsic hand muscle weakness does not correlate with any dermatome Clinical • • II I I .. I• .. , .. E) Carpal tunnel release Correct Answer: C. As a result of interossei muscle dysfunction, this patient is unable to fully abduct or adduct the digits. MRI of the brachia! plexus (Choice A) would diagnose brachia! plexopathies. Brachia! plexopathies typically present with numbness, paresthesia, or weakness of the shoulder and arm, and less commonly, the hand. If present, intrinsic hand weakness is typically accompanied by forearm or shoulder weakness. MRI of the neck (Choice B) could identify cervical radiculopathy. Cervical radiculopathy refers to cervical nerve root pathology that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesia, and pain in the dermatomal distribution that correlates to the affected nerve root. This patient's isolated intrinsic hand muscle weakness does not correlate with any dermatome. Biopsy of the sural nerve (Choice D) assists in distinguishing between different causes of polyneuropathy (eg, diabetes, alcohol, vasculitis). The sural nerve is a purely sensory nerve. Lesions of the sural nerve would not result in weakness. Carpal tunnel release (Choice E) refers to the surgical decompression of the median nerve in patients with carpal tunnel syndrome. Carpal tunnel release does not assist in diagnosis. Carpal tunnel presents with predominantly sensory symptoms in the lateral hand and potential atrophy of the muscles of the thenar eminence late in the disease course.

44. A 23-year-old woman with sickle cell disease is brought to the emergency department after becoming obtunded; she has a 2-day history of cough
and fever. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg. She appears
stuporous. She is intubated and mechanically ventilated. There is m1oderate nuchal rigidity. Right basilar crackles are heard on auscultation.
Hematocrit is 21 % with many nucleated erythrocytes , and leukocyte count is 24,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step
in management?

question_stem:
the most appropriate next step
in management?

choices.text: Transfusion of 3 units of packed red blood cells

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Bacterial meningitis presents with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status, typically following a prodrome of upper respiratory tract infection symptoms, although it can also be concomitant with another infection. Physical examination may disclose a present Kernig or Brudzinski sign, indicative of meningeal irritation, and can also demonstrate focal neurologica l symptoms or signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as hemiparesis or abducens nerve palsy. Petechiae may be present. Laboratory evaluation will show leukocytosis, and coagulation studies can show signs of disseminated intravascular coagulopathy with thrombocytopenia, decreased fibrinogen, and increased d-dimer, depending on the specific pathogen. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) evaluation is the initial diagnostic step and will reveal an increased opening pressure, increased leukocyte count with prominent neutrophils, increased protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration. Culture of the CSF is utilized to diagnose the specific bacterial cause and to distinguish between viral and fungal meningitides, or alternative diagnoses. The most common causes of bacterial meningitis in patients with asplenia, whether functiona l or operative, are Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis. Treatment involves immediate antibiotic therapy, accompanied by glucocorticoids.

distractor_explanations.B: Administration of dopamine is utilized in the treatment of cardiogenic shock and advanced heart failure, as well as septic shock in rare circumstances. This patient is likely septic, given her tachycardia, tachypnea, fever, and leukocytosis. She is mildly hypotensive, and administration of intravenous fluids and antibiotics is the most important immediate therapy. Norepinephrine is a more appropriate initial vasopressor used to treat septic shock. CT scan of the head (Choice C) may be utilized in the evaluation of bacterial meningitis. It is commonly done prior to a lumbar puncture for CSF analysis in patients with signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as seizure, decreased level of consciousness, focal neurologic deficits, or papilledema. It is done to rule out a central nervous system mass or increased intracranial pressure that may lead t h . t' • I b • t I b t . I . •' t' h t I' t . d • d t th d . . t t' f I t' b. t' Clinical Correct Answer: A. Bacterial meningitis presents with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status, typically following a prodrome of upper respiratory tract infection symptoms, although it can also be concomitant with another infection. Physical examination may disclose a present Kernig or Brudzinski sign, indicative of meningeal irritation, and can also demonstrate focal neurologica l symptoms or signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as hemiparesis or abducens nerve palsy. Petechiae may be present. Laboratory evaluation will show leukocytosis, and coagulation studies can show signs of disseminated intravascular coagulopathy with thrombocytopenia, decreased fibrinogen, and increased d-dimer, depending on the specific pathogen. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) evaluation is the initial diagnostic step and will reveal an increased opening pressure, increased leukocyte count with prominent neutrophils, increased protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration. Culture of the CSF is utilized to diagnose the specific bacterial cause and to distinguish between viral and fungal meningitides, or alternative diagnoses. The most common causes of bacterial meningitis in patients with asplenia, whether functiona l or operative, are Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis. Treatment involves immediate antibiotic therapy, accompanied by glucocorticoids. Incorrect Answers: B, C, and D. Administration of dopamine (Choice B) is utilized in the treatment of cardiogenic shock and advanced heart failure, as well as septic shock in rare circumstances. This patient is likely septic, given her tachycardia, tachypnea, fever, and leukocytosis. She is mildly hypotensive, and administration of intravenous fluids and antibiotics is the most important immediate therapy. Norepinephrine is a more appropriate initial vasopressor used to treat septic shock. CT scan of the head (Choice C) may be utilized in the evaluation of bacterial meningitis. It is commonly done prior to a lumbar puncture for CSF analysis in patients with signs of increased intracranial pressure, such as seizure, decreased level of consciousness, focal neurologic deficits, or papilledema. It is done to rule out a central nervous system mass or increased intracranial pressure that may lead to herniation upon lumbar puncture. In bacterial meningitis, however, mortality is dependent on the administration of early antibiotics, and this should not be delayed to obtain neuroimaging. Transfusion of 3 units of packed red blood cells (Choice D) can be utilized in patients with symptomatic anemia, massive hemorrhage, or hemolysis. Unless there is active hemorrhage or hemodynamic instability, transfusion typically begins with one unit of packed red blood cells. This patient's hematocrit does not meet the transfusion threshold and is likely chronically low in the setting of her sickle cell disease.

explanation.educational_objective: Bacterial meningitis presents acutely with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status. Treatment with intravenous antibiotics should begin immediately. CSF evaluation is the initial diagnostic step and will reveal an increased opening pressure, increased leukocyte count with prominent neutrophils, increased protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration. Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis are the most common causes in asplenic patients Clinical

vignette.presentation:
45. A 57-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of progressive weakness in both legs over the past 5 months. He has trouble arising from a
chair and climbing stairs; he finds it easier to arise from a chair if he rocks back and forth first. During this time, he has also had a persistent cough,
a 14-kg (30-lb) weight loss, and a dry mouth. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Examination shows weakness of hip
flexion and knee extens ion. There is no muscle tenderness . All reflexes are absent. Babinski sign is absent. Sensory examination shows no
abnorma lities. His erythrocyte sedimentat ion rate is 95 mm/h, and serum creatine kinase activity is 25 U/L. An x-ray of the chest shows a right
upper lobe mass. Which of the following is the most likely location of the abnorma lity?

question_stem: the most likely location of the abnorma lity?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome is an uncommon neurologic condition that affects neuromuscu lar junction transmission. Normally, action potentials lead to depolarization in the termina l bouton of the axon. Voltage-gated calcium channels consequently open and allow calcium influx, which triggers the exocytosis of neurotransmitter-fil led vesicles into the synaptic cleft. Patients with myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome possess antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic lower motor neurons, which decreases calcium influx and acetylcholine release to postsynaptic skeletal muscle cells. This patient with a smoking history, persistent cough, weight loss, and increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate likely has small cell lung cancer and paraneoplastic autoantibody production against voltage-gated calcium channels, causing myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome. Patients consequent ly demonstrate progressive proxima l muscle weakness with depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes. The muscle weakness typically improves with exercise as small amounts of acetylcholine accumulate in the synaptic cleft over time, increasing the frequency of postsynaptic action potentials in skeletal muscle cells. Autonomic symptoms such as decreased salivation (and consequent dry mouth) may also occur. The diagnosis may be confirmed with nerve conduction studies and electromyography with exercise testing.

distractor_explanations.A: Anterior horn cell degeneration can be caused by poliovirus infection, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or spinal muscular atrophy (a congenital disease presenting with progressive anterior horn disease). Patients would present with a lower-motor neuron pattern of weakness with decreased reflexes. However, anterior horn cell disease is not associated with lung cancer Clinical Myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome is an uncommon neurologic condition that affects neuromuscular junction transmission. Normally, action potentials lead to depolarization in the terminal bouton of the axon. Voltage-gated calcium channels consequently open and allow calcium influx, which triggers the exocytosis of neurotransmitter-filled vesicles into the synaptic cleft. Patients with myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome possess antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic lower motor neurons, which decreases calcium influx and acetylcholine release to postsynaptic skeletal muscle cells. This patient with a smoking history, persistent cough, weight loss, and increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate likely has small cell lung cancer and paraneoplastic autoantibody production against voltage-gated calcium channels, causing myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome. Patients consequently demonstrate progressive proximal muscle weakness with depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes. The muscle weakness typically improves with exercise as small amounts of acetylcholine accumulate in the synaptic cleft over time, increasing the frequency of postsynaptic action potentials in skeletal muscle cells. Autonomic symptoms such as decreased salivation (and consequent dry mouth) may also occur. The diagnosis may be confirmed with nerve conduction studies and electromyography with exercise testing. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, E, and F. Anterior horn cell (Choice A) degeneration can be caused by poliovirus infection, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or spinal muscular atrophy (a congenital disease presenting with progressive anterior horn disease). Patients would present with a lower-motor neuron pattern of weakness with decreased reflexes. However, anterior horn cell disease is not associated with lung cancer. Disease of the muscle (Choice B) such as polymyositis or muscular dystrophy may present with proximal muscle weakness. However, because of muscle degeneration, creatine kinase concentrations would be increased, and polymyositis would additionally present with muscle pain and stiffness. Further, these diseases are not associated with the paraneoplastic production of antibodies. Disease of the peripheral nerve axon (Choice D) occurs in axonal polyneuropathy, a rare form of Guillain-Barre syndrome that involves the autoimmune attack of the spinal nerve root axons. Peripheral nerve demyelination (Choice E) occurs in Guillain-Barre syndrome, which results in destruction of the myelin on the spinal nerve roots. Both syndromes typically present with acute-onset, symmetric, ascending muscle weakness with hyporeflexia and may include sensory and autonomic dysfunction. This patient instead presents with the insidious onset of muscle weakness that begins in the proximal, rather than distal, lower extremities. Spinal cord disease (Choice F), such as transverse myelitis, could cause acute bilateral motor dysfunction of the lower extremities. However, the distal lower extremity musculature would also be affected, and this patient instead experienced slowly progressive motor dysfunction.

explanation.educational_objective: Patients with myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome possess antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic lower motor neurons, which decrease calcium influx and acetylcholine release to postsynaptic skeletal muscle cells. In some patients, tumors are associated with these antibodies, resulting in paraneoplastic myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome. Patients present with progressive proximal muscle weakness that improves with exercise and demonstrate a creatine kinase concentration within normal reference ranges Clinical
explanation.concept: Patients with myasthenic (Lambert-Eaton) syndrome possess antibodies to voltage-gated calcium channels on presynaptic lower motor neurons, which decrease calcium influx and acetylcholine release to po

46. A 52-year-old man who is HIV positive is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-month history of forgetfulness and inappropriate
behavior. He also has been buying numerous items from the Internet. He also has had diarrhea. During the past year, he has been noncompliant
with his antiretroviral medication regimen and has had a 16-kg (35-lb) weight loss. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 46 kg (101 lb); BMI is
15 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows
thrush. On mental status examination, he has a labile affect. He recalls zero of three objects after 5 minutes. A CT scan of the head shows
prominent atrophy of the cortex and demyelination in the subcortical white matter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a life-threatening demyelinating disease that occurs as a result of the reactivation of human polyomavirus 2 (formerly JC virus) in patients who are immunocompromised. Most people experience an asymptomatic infection with human polyomavirus 2 during childhood, at which point the virus becomes latent. In severely immunocompromised patients, human polyomavirus 2 can reactivate and infect oligodendrocytes, leading to demyelination. Patients typically present with the subacute onset of focal neurologic deficits related to the affected brain area and cognitive impairment. Patients who are immunocompromised enough to have PML may also present with symptoms of other opportunistic infections. This patient's thrush and potential Mycobacterium avium complex infection (which likely explains his fever, diarrhea, and weight loss) indicate severe immune compromise in the setting of decreased adherence to antiretroviral therapy. MRI may demonstrate unilateral or bilateral white matter lesions without mass effect indicative of demyelination, which may progress to cortical atrophy. Lumbar puncture and cerebrospina l fluid analysis confirm the diagnosis. Treatment requires restarting antiretroviral therapy.

distractor_explanations.B: Alzheimer type results from decreased cholinergic signaling in the cortex and basal forebrain. Alzheimer r ~- - -- - , r - , Clinical Correct Answer: E. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a life-threatening demyelinating disease that occurs as a result of the reactivation of human polyomavirus 2 (formerly JC virus) in patients who are immunocompromised. Most people experience an asymptomatic infection with human polyomavirus 2 during childhood, at which point the virus becomes latent. In severely immunocompromised patients, human polyomavirus 2 can reactivate and infect oligodendrocytes, leading to demyelination. Patients typically present with the subacute onset of focal neurologic deficits related to the affected brain area and cognitive impairment. Patients who are immunocompromised enough to have PML may also present with symptoms of other opportunistic infections. This patient's thrush and potential Mycobacterium avium complex infection (which likely explains his fever, diarrhea, and weight loss) indicate severe immune compromise in the setting of decreased adherence to antiretroviral therapy. MRI may demonstrate unilateral or bilateral white matter lesions without mass effect indicative of demyelination, which may progress to cortical atrophy. Lumbar puncture and cerebrospina l fluid analysis confirm the diagnosis. Treatment requires restarting antiretroviral therapy. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Central nervous system lymphoma (Choice A), or primary CNS lymphoma, is a rare variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs most commonly in immunocompromised patients. Typical presentation includes focal neurological deficits, neuropsychiatric symptoms, or signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, positional headache, nausea, vomiting). MRI typically demonstrates a solitary mass lesion but can reveal multiple periventricular white matter mass lesions. Primary CNS lymphoma lesions do not involve demyelination and are more likely to produce a mass effect than PML lesions. Dementia, Alzheimer type (Choice B) results from decreased cholinergic signaling in the cortex and basal forebrain. Alzheimer dementia is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that culminates in the inability to perform basic activities of daily living. Alzheimer dementia is not associated with personality changes early in the disease course, demyelination, or . . 1mmunosuppress1on. Multiple sclerosis (Choice C) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease that presents with focal neurologic deficits separated in space and time. Cortical atrophy would be atypical, and multiple sclerosis is not associated with immunosuppression. Pick disease (Choice D), or frontotemporal dementia, is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by atrophy of the frontal and temporal lobes, causing deficits in social behavior or personality along with dementia. Frontotemporal dementia is not associated with demyelination or immunosuppression.

explanation.educational_objective: In severely immunocompromised patients, human polyomavirus 2 can reactivate and infect oligodendrocytes, leading to demyelination and resulting in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. Patients typically present with the subacute onset of focal neurologic deficits and cognitive impairment. MRI of the brain may demonstrate unilateral or bilateral white matter lesions indicative of demyelination and cortical atrophy Exam Section : Item 47 of 50 Clinical 4 7. A previously healthy 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive weakness, numbness, and tingling of both arms. Her pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the upper extremities and 4/5 in the lower extremities. There is muscle wasting and atrophy of the forearms and hands bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the upper extremities and 4+ in the lower extremities. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. There is decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch in the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis B) Guillain-Barre syndrome C) Postherpetic neuralgia D) Syringomyelia E) Tabes dorsalis Correct Answer: D. This patient presenting with an upper motor neuron pattern of dysfunction in the lower extremities and a lower motor neuron-pattern of dysfunction in the upper extremities likely has syringomyelia. Syringomyelia features a progressively expanding cystic lesion involving midline spinal cord structures. Syringomyelia may be associated with congenital malformations such as Chiari type I malformation, spinal cord infections, autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis, neoplasms, or spinal cord trauma. Syringomyelia typically damages spinothalamic fibers decussating in the anterior white commissure. Consequent ly, patients present with deficits in pain and temperature sensation in the bilateral upper extremities (since the ascending spinothalamic tracts in the lateral spinal cord are unaffected, sensation in the lower body is intact). The spinothalamic tract also carries sensory fibers that mediate poorly localized light touch (versus localized light touch fibers of the posterior columns). The cystic lesion can expand to the bilateral anterior horns (the location of the cell bodies of lower motor neurons). Therefore, patients may also present with a lower motor neuron pattern of dysfunction in the bilateral upper extremities (eg, decreased muscle tone, hyporeflexia, early muscle atrophy). The cyst may also progressive ly expand to the lateral corticospinal tract in severe cases, leading to an upper motor neuron pattern of dysfunction (eg, spastic weakness, hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign) in the lower body. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Choice A) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that affects the anterior horns along with the lateral corticospinal tract as it descends in the brain and spinal cord. Subsequently, patients demonstrate a combination of upper and lower motor neuron findings in an asymmetric distribution that may include the bulbar muscles. Sensory impairment would be atypical, and a pattern of dysfunction that can be localized to a single lesion within the cervical spine is more consistent with syringomyelia. Guillain-Barre syndrome (Choice B) is an inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy that presents with acute-onset, ascending, j •
explanation.concept: In severely immunocompromised patients, human polyomavirus 2 can reactivate and infect oligodendrocytes, leading to demyelination and resulting in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. Patients

vignette.presentation:
48. A 77-year-o ld woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of a 3-day history of visual difficulties. He says she seems a little
"off balance." She agreed to come in after denting the car on the left side while parking it in the garage. She has not had any headaches or noticed
any difficulty using either side of her body. She has not fallen recently. She has a 2-year history of atrial fibrillation treated with aspirin. She is
sitting comfortab ly in a chair. Her temperatu re is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg.
Examination shows a left homonymous hemianopia. Muscle strength, muscle tone, and sensation are intact bilaterally. Speech is normal. She is
alert and oriented to person, place, and time. When asked to read, she only reads the words on the right side of the page. A CT scan of the head is
most likely to show an infarct in the territory of which of the following cerebral arteries?

question_stem: most likely to show an infarct in the territory of which of the following cerebral arteries?

choices.text: Aspirin therapy now and temporal artery biopsy within 24 hours
Corticosteroid therapy now and temporal artery biopsy within 3 days
Temporal artery biopsy now with therapy determined by pathology

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Occlusion of the right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) explains this patient's deficits. The PCA supplies much of the occipital lobes as well as the inferomedial temporal lobe, posteromedial parietal lobe, thalamus, and parts of the brainstem. Visual symptoms are a prominent feature of a PCA territory infarction and include cortical blindness, contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, visual agnosia, and prosopagnosia. Occlusion of the right PCA typically leads to left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (caused by damage of the right primary visual cortex) and may lead to left hemineglect (caused by damage of the right parietal cortex). Left homonymous hemianopia likely explains this patient's car accident and may lead to mild balance difficulties. Occlusion of the right PCA may also result in left hemisensory deficit (caused by thalamus damage) and left hemiparesis (caused by damage to the cerebral peduncles in the midbrain). Cerebral infarctions, also known as strokes, occur as a result of ischemic or hemorrhagic loss of blood supply to the brain. Approximately 80% to 85% of strokes are ischemic, commonly arising from thromboembolic disease (eg, middle cerebral artery occlusion from a thrombus), whereas 15% to 20% of strokes are hemorrhagic because of blood vessel rupture (eg, hypertension-related intraparenchymal hemorrhage from a perforating artery). Risk factors for stroke include smoking, hypertension, diabetes, carotid or intracranial atherosclerotic disease, history of hypercoagulabi lity, atrial fibrillation, and advanced age. Classically, strokes manifest as a neurologic deficit related to the affected part of the brain.

distractor_explanations.C: The left PCA supplies the posterior parietal and occipital lobes (including the visual cortex) along with the thalamus and midbrain. Occlusion of the left PCA typically leads to right homonymous hemianopsia and alexia without agraphia, finger agnosia, and right-left disorientation (and may also lead to right hemisensory deficit and right hemiparesis).

explanation.educational_objective: The posterior cerebral arteries (PCAs) supply the posterior parietal and occipital lobes (including the primary visual cortex) along with the thalamus and midbrain. Occlusion of the right PCA typically leads to left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (caused by damage of the right primary visual cortex) and left contralateral hemineglect (caused by damage of the right parietal cortex) Clinical 'f 49. A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician 2 hours after the sudden onset of dim vision in her right eye. Her symptoms began 3 weeks ago with generalized stiffness, aches in the morning, and a bitemporal headache. Examination shows firm, tender temporal arteries bilaterally. Corrected visual acuity is 20/200 in the right eye and 20/40 in the left. Laboratory studies show: Hematocrit 32% Leukocyte count 6000/mm3 Platelet count 300,000/mm3 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 110 mm/h Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management? A) Carotid angiography now B) Aspirin therapy now and temporal artery biopsy within 24 hours C) Corticosteroid therapy now and temporal artery biopsy within 3 days D) Plasmapheresis now E) Temporal artery biopsy now with therapy determined by pathology Correct Answer: C. This patient's presenting findings of abrupt onset monocular vision loss, headache, stiffness, and temporal tenderness are consistent with a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis (GCA). GCA is an autoimmune inflammatory vasculitis of medium and large vessels. Classic findings include systemic symptoms of fever, chills, and weight loss, headache, history of preceding transient vision loss (amaurosis fugax), jaw claudication, tenderness of the scalp, and pale optic disc edema. New headaches in an elderly patient should raise suspicion for GCA. GCA frequently occurs in association with polymyalgia rheumatica, which is characterized by stiffness of proximal muscles. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates increased inflammatory markers, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein concentration, and thrombocytosis. GCA is characterized by a predilection for the vessels of the head and neck, and often affects the ophthalmic artery, inflammatory occlusion of which can result in sudden, ischemic damage to the retina. Once vision loss occurs it is not reversible and is commonly followed by vision loss in the contralateral eye within days or weeks. The diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy of the temporal artery demonstrating granulomatous vasculitis. Treatment with high dose corticosteroids should occur immediately once GCA is suspected in order to preserve vision. Corticosteroid treatment does not generally compromise biopsy results as long as the biopsy is performed within 1 to 2 weeks. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Carotid angiography (Choice A) is not a preferred diagnostic method for the detection of GCA. Temporal artery biopsy remains the standard diagnostic test. Steroid treatment should not be deferred while pursuing other tests Clinical Correct Answer: C. This patient's presenting findings of abrupt onset monocular vision loss, headache, stiffness, and temporal tenderness are consistent with a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis (GCA). GCA is an autoimmune inflammatory vasculitis of medium and large vessels. Classic findings include systemic symptoms of fever, chills, and weight loss, headache, history of preceding transient vision loss (amaurosis fugax), jaw claudication, tenderness of the scalp, and pale optic disc edema. New headaches in an elderly patient should raise suspicion for GCA. GCA frequently occurs in association with polymyalgia rheumatica, which is characterized by stiffness of proximal muscles. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates increased inflammatory markers, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein concentration, and thrombocytosis. GCA is characterized by a predilection for the vessels of the head and neck, and often affects the ophthalmic artery, inflammatory occlusion of which can result in sudden, ischemic damage to the retina. Once vision loss occurs it is not reversible and is commonly followed by vision loss in the contralatera l eye within days or weeks. The diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy of the temporal artery demonstrating granulomatous vasculitis. Treatment with high dose corticosteroids should occur immediately once GCA is suspected in order to preserve vision. Corticosteroid treatment does not generally compromise biopsy results as long as the biopsy is performed within 1 to 2 weeks. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Carotid angiography (Choice A) is not a preferred diagnostic method for the detection of GCA. Temporal artery biopsy remains the standard diagnostic test. Steroid treatment should not be deferred while pursuing other tests. Immediate aspirin therapy and temporal artery biopsy within 24 hours (Choice B) is incorrect. Aspirin does not provide a sufficiently robust anti-inflammatory effect to protect the ophthalmic artery from inflammation caused by GCA, which requires high-dose corticosteroids. Plasmapheresis (Choice D) is not commonly used for the treatment of GCA. GCA is characterized by granulomatous vasculitis and is therefore driven, at least in part, by a T lymphocyte and macrophage autoimmune response. Plasmapheresis is especially useful for the treatment of B lymphocyte driven autoimmune disorders, such as myasthenia gravis. Immediate temporal artery biopsy with treatment to be determined by pathology (Choice E) is not appropriate. Once the diagnosis of GCA is suspected, high-dose corticosteroid treatment should start immediately. Delaying initiation of corticosteroid therapy even by hours while awaiting biopsy results puts the patient at risk for preventable and irreversible blindness. Educational Objective: Giant cell arteritis is a common vasculitis of medium and large vessels in elderly patients and commonly presents with systemic symptoms, headache, jaw claudication, and proximal muscle stiffness. Vasculitis of the ophthalmic artery may occur and cause blindness. Immediate high-dose corticosteroid treatment should occur once the diagnosis is suspected and does not generally compromise biopsy resu lts as long as the biopsy is performed within 1 to 2 weeks Clinical

vignette.presentation:
50. A previously healthy 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by
her brother 1 hour after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that lasted 5 minutes. The
patient and her brother emigrated from Central America 6 months ago. She takes no
medications. She is drowsy but cooperative. Her temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8°F),
pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg.
Examination and laboratory studies show no other abnormalities. Toxicology
screening is negative. A CT scan of the head with contrast is shown. Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neurocysticercosis is a central nervous system (CNS) infection caused by the pork tapeworm Taenia so/ium that occurs most commonly in endemic rural regions of Latin America, Asia, and Africa. Symptoms include headache, seizures, signs of increased intracranial pressure, and, rarely, altered vision. Certain patients are asymptomatic, and other patients present with muscle or subcutaneous nodules. Typical manifestations on CT or MRI include cystic, ring-enhancing, calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma, meninges, ventricles, spinal cord, or orbit. A scolex (larval head) may also be demonstrated on imaging. Treatment may include symptomatic management of increased intracranial pressure and seizures, antiparasitic therapy, or steroids.

distractor_explanations.A: Behget syndrome is a vasculitis that commonly presents in Exam Section : Item 50 of 50 Clinical Neurocysticercosis is a central nervous system (CNS) infection caused by the pork tapeworm Taenia so/ium that occurs most commonly in endemic rural regions of Latin America, Asia, and Africa. Symptoms include headache, seizures, signs of increased intracranial pressure, and, rarely, altered vision. Certain patients are asymptomatic, and other patients present with muscle or subcutaneous nodules. Typical manifestations on CT or MRI include cystic, ring-enhancing, calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma, meninges, ventricles, spinal cord, or orbit. A scolex (larval head) may also be demonstrated on imaging. Treatment may include symptomatic management of increased intracranial pressure and seizures, antiparasitic therapy, or steroids. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, E, F, and G. Behget syndrome (Choice A) is a vasculitis that commonly presents in patients 20 to 40 years of age with mucocutaneous ulcers, including oral and urogenital lesions. Other symptoms include erythema nodosum, uveitis, and neurologic abnormalities. It can present with brain lesions on MRI, but they are more commonly subcortical and would be unlikely to be calcified. Central nervous system lymphoma (Choice B) is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs most commonly in immunocompromised patients and presents with focal neurologic deficits, increased intracrania l pressure (eg, headache), vision changes, and personality changes depending on the location of the lesion. Neuroimaging will most commonly reveal a well circumscribed solitary lesion near the ventricles, rather than the multiple lesions seen in this patient. Metastatic carcinoma (Choice C) can present with multifocal cerebral lesions. Lung cancer, melanoma, and renal cell carcinoma commonly metastasize to the brain. Brain metastases typically present with focal neurologic deficits, headache, and seizures. However, the lesions are more commonly localized at the gray-white matter junction and associated with significant vasogenic edema Clinical circumscribed solitary lesion near the ventricles, rather than the multiple lesions seen in this patient. Metastatic carcinoma (Choice C) can present with multifocal cerebral lesions. Lung cancer, melanoma, and renal cell carcinoma common ly metastasize to the brain. Brain metastases typically present with focal neurologic deficits, headache, and seizures. However, the lesions are more commonly localized at the gray-white matter junction and associated with significant vasogenic edema. Progressive multifocal leukoencepha lopathy (Choice E) is a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system caused by the human polyomavirus 2 (formerly JC virus), most commonly in immunocompromised patients. It presents subacutely with altered mental status, ataxia, vision changes, and hemiparesis. Lesions occur primarily in the white matter and are not enhanced with contrast; rather, they appear as hypodense lesions.
distractor_explanations.F: Toxoplasmosis typically presents with a mild flu-like illness and cervical lymphadenopathy. lmmunocompetent patients can be asymptomatic, but immunocompromised patients can develop signs of intracerebral disease, that appears on CT scan as multiple ring-enhancing lesions scattered throughout the brain. Symptoms of cerebral disease include focal neurologic deficits and seizures, as well as altered mental status. Tuberculous meningitis (Choice G) typically presents in a sub.acute fashion with nuchal rigidity, fever, altered mental status, and cranial nerve palsies caused by rupture of a tubercle into the subarachnoid space. Radiologic evaluation will show basilar exudates, periventricular infarcts, and hydrocephalus, rather than the small diffuse calcified lesions seen in this patient.

vignette.presentation:
1. A 72-year-old man with a 10-day history of fever, nausea and vomiting, and progressive confusion remains hospitalized because his symptoms
have not resolved despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. He has a 6-year history of severe emphysema treated with courses of
corticosteroids during the past year. Medications include intravenous ceftriaxone and ampicillin, albuterol inhalers, theophylline, and prednisone. He
is confused and stuporous. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 142/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows
meningismus. An MRI of the brain shows diffuse meningeal enhancement with a basilar predominance. A lumbar puncture is done; cerebrospinal
fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 322/mm3 (86% lymphocytes), a glucose concentration of 17 mg/dL, and a protein concentration of
212 mg/dl. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Chronic use of immunosuppressants including glucocorticoids increase the likelihood of tuberculosis reactivation. Tuberculous meningitis typically presents with nuchal rigidity, fever, and altered mental status, similar to the symptoms seen in bacterial meningitis. However, unlike bacterial meningitis which presents acutely, tuberculous meningitis typically shows a subacute presentation. Presence of cranial nerve palsies is also more likely in tuberculous meningitis than bacterial meningitis. Physical examination may show a positive Kernig or Brudzinski sign, indicative of meningeal irritation. Results of laboratory studies will show nonspecific changes including leukocytosis and mild anemia. A tuberculin skin test or interferon-gamma release assay are usually positive, but a negative result is also possible. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) evaluation is the initial diagnostic step and will reveal an increased opening pressure, increased white blood cell count with prominent lymphocytes, increased protein concentration, and decreased glucose concentration. Culture of the CSF for acid-fast bacilli may be positive, though the sensitivity of this test for tuberculous meningitis is less than 50%. Radiologic evaluation may show basilar exudates, as in this case, as well as periventricu lar infarcts and hydrocephalus.

distractor_explanations.A: Herpes simplex encephalitis presents with fever, altered mental status, and neurologic abnormalities, such as seizure, aphasia, hemiparesis, or cranial nerve deficits. Neuroimaging will typically show changes in the temporal lobe. The basilar predominance in this case is more suggestive of a tuberculous meningitis than herpes encephalitis. Lyme disease (Choice B) caused by disseminated Borrelia burgdorferi infection may cause neuropathy and meningitis. However, this would be expected to be accompanied by a rash in the pattern of erythema migrans and history of tick exposure Clinical Correct Answer: E. Radiologic evaluation may show basilar exudates, as in this case, as well as periventricu lar infarcts and hydrocephalus. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Neuroimaging will typically show changes in the temporal lobe. The basilar predominance in this case is more suggestive of a tuberculous meningitis than herpes encephalitis. Lyme disease (Choice B) caused by disseminated Borrelia burgdorferi infection may cause neuropathy and meningitis. However, this would be expected to be accompanied by a rash in the pattern of erythema migrans and history of tick exposure.
distractor_explanations.C: Neurosarcoidosis is defined as the presence of neurologic symptoms in a patient with known sarcoidosis. As any portion of the central or peripheral nervous system may be affected, symptoms may stem from cranial nerve palsies, hypothalamic dysfunction, spinal cord involvement, or peripheral neuropathy. This patient does not show other features of sarcoidosis, including pulmonary, eye, or skin involvement.
distractor_explanations.D: Neurosyphilis presents with fever, meningismus, ataxia, Argyll Robertson pupil, and tabes dorsalis. Tabes dorsalis refers to infection of the posterior columns and dorsal roots of the spinal cord causing impaired sensation of light touch, vibration, and proprioception along with ataxia. Serologic testing of the CSF for syphilis using a venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) or rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test is positive.

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) evaluation is the initial diagnostic step and will disclose an increased opening pressure, increased white blood cell count with prominent lymphocytes, increased protein concentration, decreased glucose concentration, and positive culture for acid-fast bacilli Clinical

vignette.presentation:
2. An 8-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of increased irritability over the past month. During this period, she has had
intermittent low-grade fever and episodes of stiffening of her body. Her father reports that she previously interacted with them and smiled when
prompted but has not made eye contact for the past 3 days. She has a history of hypotonia. She cannot yet roll over or sit up. Her parents are third
cousins. She is awake and irritable and has poor visual regard. Examination of the skin shows no neurocutaneous lesions. The optic nerves are
pale. Neurologic examination shows hyperextension of the head and back, ankle spasticity, and fisting. Deep tendon reflexes are brisk, and
Babinski sign is present. An MRI of the brain is most likely to show which of the following?

question_stem: most likely to show which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This infant's presentation of fever, spasticity, hypotonia, vision loss, optic nerve pallor, and Babinski sign, as well as a family history of consanguinity are consistent with a diagnosis of Krabbe disease, also known as galactosylceramide lipidosis. Krabbe disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by mutations in the GALC gene that encodes galactocerebrosidase, the deficiency of which results in accumulation of galactocerebroside and demyelinating neuronal degeneration. Patients typically present within the first year of life with progressive neurologic degeneration, spasticity, stiffness, seizures, feeding difficulty, and peripheral neuropathy, including optic neuropathy. The diagnosis is confirmed with serum enzyme assays, although MRI of the brain will show white matter degeneration caused by demyelination. There is no effective treatment for Krabbe disease and most affected children die during the first several years of life.

distractor_explanations.A: Cerebellar hypoplasia and hydrocephalus (Choice D) are both observed in Dandy-Walker malformation. Patients present during the first year of life with hydrocephalus and associated nausea, vomiting, seizures, and downward displacement of the eyes. Dandy-Walker malformation does not typically present with spasticity and stiffness and presents with papilledema rather than optic nerve pallor.
distractor_explanations.C: Holoprosencephaly is a congenital malformation in which the prosencephalon does not divide into two hemispheres. Most cases result in death in utero and are also accompanied by craniofacial malformations including cyclopia and the presence of a proboscis. Lysosomal storage disorders, including Krabbe disease, are not frequent causes of holoprosencephaly. Periventricular calcifications (Choice E) is a frequent finding in several congenital infections, such as in congenital toxoplasmosis or cytomegalovirus infection. While such infections can have profound developmental consequences, they do not typically cause progressive neurodegeneration.
distractor_explanations.F: Schizencephaly is a rare congenital malformation characterized by clefts through the cerebral parenchyma between the ventricles and pia mater. Lysosomal storage disorders, including Krabbe disease, are not a frequent cause of schizencephaly. No abnormalities (Choice G) would not be an expected finding in this infant with profound neurologic degeneration during the first year of life.

explanation.educational_objective: Krabbe disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by mutations in the GALC gene that encodes galactocerebrosidase, the deficiency of which results in the accumulation of galactocerebroside and secondary demyelinating neuronal degeneration. Patients typically present within the first year of life with progressive neurologic degeneration, spasticity, stiffness, seizures, feeding difficulty, and peripheral neuropathy, including optic neuropathy Clinical

vignette.presentation:
3. A 57-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after a simple partial seizure. Examination shows mild weakness of the
right lower extremity. A CT scan of the head shows a 1.5-cm, uniformly and intensely enhancing parasagitta l mass in the left frontal region. Which of
the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Meningioma is a common, benign central nervous system (CNS) tumor derived from the meninges that occurs along the surfaces of the brain and spinal cord, often in the parasagittal region. They occur in women more often than men and are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 and multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. Patients may be asymptomatic or experience seizures or focal neurologic deficits related to the tumor location. Meningiomas are typically benign but can be malignant. Malignant meningiomas may grow rapidly, leading to symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (eg, postural headache, nausea, papilledema), or may metastasize. Meningiomas appear as well-circumscribed, extra-axia l (ie, outside of the brain parenchyma) masses that compress the parenchyma. They show uniform enhancement on imaging. Definitive diagnosis requires histologic examination of tissue, which will show spindle cells arranged in a whorled pattern with psammoma bodies. Treatment may include antiepileptics or surgical resection to alleviate the tumoral mass effect if significant, though often, periodic surveillance is all that is necessary.

distractor_explanations.A: Astrocytoma is a primary CNS neoplasm that can occur as benign pilocytic astrocytoma in children or malignant glioblastoma multiforme (Choice C) in adults. Glioblastoma are highly malignant tumors appearing as intra-axial masses in the cerebral hemispheres, which typically show areas of necrosis and can spread to the opposite hemisphere across the corpus callosum.
distractor_explanations.B: Ependymoma is a CNS neoplasm formed from ependymal cells. Location typical ly involves the fourth ventricle. Histologic characteristics include perivascular pseudorosettes formed by malignant cells arranged around a blood vessel.
distractor_explanations.E: Schwannoma are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells in peripheral nerve sheaths. They commonly affect the facial and vestibulococh lear nerves, and mass effect may result in sensorineural hearing loss or ataxia. They are associated with neurofibromatosis type 2.

explanation.educational_objective: Meningiomas are benign CNS tumors arising from the meninges that may compress the brain or spinal cord and cause focal neurologic deficits as well as seizures. Neuroimaging shows a spherica l and well-circumscribed mass that indents the parenchyma. Lesions show uniform enhancement on imaging. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Meningiomas are benign CNS tumors arising from the meninges that may compress the brain or spinal cord and cause focal neurologic deficits as well as seizures. Neuroimaging shows a spherica l and well

vignette.presentation:
4. A 67-year-o ld semiretired corporate executive comes to the physician with his wife because she is concerned about his increasing disorgan ization
at home over the past year. She also notes that he is unable to remember the names of recent acquaintances. He has insisted on working part-time
since stepping down from a CEO position. His secretary has told his wife that he has been forgetting scheduled appointments and becomes angry
and tearful when he is reminded. He drinks one to two cocktails each evening. Physical examination shows no abnorma lities. On mental status
examination, he is mildly agitated and has word-finding difficulty and short-term memory deficits. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Which of
the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Acute stress disorder J) Hypercalcem ia
Alcohol-induced amnest ic disorder K) Major depressive disorder
Dementia , Alzheimer type L) Multi-infarct (vascular) dementia
General paresis N) Normal-pressure hydrocep halus
Hepatolenticular degenerat ion (Wilson disease) P) Pick disease
HIV encepha litis Q) Normal aging

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Alzheimer dementia (AD) is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that begins with short-term memory impairment and decline in visuospatial abilities and progresses to apraxia, language abnormalities, and dysexecutive syndrome (resulting in the inability to recall scheduled appointments in this patient). The disease culminates in behavioral and persona lity changes that prevent the patient from performing basic activities of daily living such as bathing. AD may be treated with drugs that both directly and indirectly increase acetylcholine in synaptic clefts. These include donepezi l and cholinesterase inhibitors which non-competitively and reversibly inhibit acetylcholinesterase and thereby increase the amount of synaptic acetylcho line available for neurotransmission. Though these drugs may slow the rate of cognitive decline and modestly improve functiona lity, they are not curative for AD.

vignette.presentation:
5. A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 2 hours after he dove
into a shallow lake and struck the back of his head on the bottom. Hie immediately had the
onset of pain in his neck and a sensation of an electric shock radiating from his neck to his left
shoulder. He did not have loss of consciousness. He was able to stand, and two friends helped
him out of the water into a supine position on the dock. At the scene, his spine was immobilized
with a cervical collar, and his head was taped to a backboard. On arrival, he is alert. Vital signs
are within normal limits. Muscle strength is 3/5 on extension of the left wrist. Deep tendon
reflexes are normal. Babinski sign is absent. Sensorimotor examination of the right upper
extremity and lower extremities shows no abnormalities. Sensation to light touch is decreased
over the radial aspect of the left forearm and hand and over the palmar and dorsal aspects of
the left thumb. Rectal examination shows normal sphincter tone and sensation. A lateral x-ray
of the cervical spine is shown. This patient most likely has which of the following cervical spine
injuries?

question_stem:
most likely has which of the following cervical spine
injuries?

choices.text: Bilateral dislocation of facets with impingement of the left CS nerve root
Bilateral dislocation of facets with impingement of the left C6 nerve root
Unilateral dislocation of a facet with impingement of the left CS nerve
would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the lateral aspect of the
