explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient likely has bilateral dislocation of facets with impingement of the left C6 nerve root caused by cervical spinal injury. The C6 dermatom,e is located on the lateral (radial) aspect of the forearm and extends to the lateral two digits of the hand. Injury to the C6 nerve root will cause decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in these distributions (or part of this distribution) along with motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension. The C6 nerve root carries efferent information for the biceps reflex, so patients with C6 nerve injury may present with a diminished or absent biceps reflex. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Disc herniation and spondylosis are common causes of spinal nerve root compression in older patients, and trauma Exam Section : Item 5 of 50 Clinical This patient likely has bilateral dislocation of facets with impingement of the left C6 nerve root caused by cervical spinal injury. The C6 dermatom,e is located on the lateral (radial) aspect of the forearm and extends to the lateral two digits of the hand. Injury to the C6 nerve root will cause decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in these distributions (or part of this distribution) along with motor • dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension. The C6 nerve root carries efferent information for the biceps reflex, so patients with C6 nerve injury may present with a diminished or absent biceps reflex. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Disc herniation and spondylosis are common causes of spinal nerve root compression in older patients, and trauma and consequent vertebral dislocation or fracture is a common cause of root compression in younger patients such as in this case. Sensory deficits, motor dysfunction, and pain typically occur in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected nerve root.

distractor_explanations.A: Anterior spinal artery thrombosis typically manifests with bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function below the level of the lesion, along with autonomic dysfunction. The anterior spinal artery supplies the corticospinal, spinothalamic, and autonomic tracts. Bilateral dislocation of facets with impingement of the left CS nerve root (Choice B) and unilateral dislocation of a facet with impingement of the left CS nerve (Choice E) would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the lateral aspect of the shoulder and upper arm. CS nerve compression typically results in an absent biceps reflex, as the CS nerve root carries afferent information for this reflex. However, CS nerve compression would not cause decreased sensation in the digits. Brown-Sequard syndrome (Choice D) refers to hemisection of the spinal cord, which damages the anterior horn along with three major spinal cord tracts: the corticospinal tract, dorsal column-medial lemniscus tract, and spinothalamic tract. r ~- , r, Clinical When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Disc herniation and spondylosis are common causes of spinal nerve root compression in older patients, and trauma and consequent vertebral dislocation or fracture is a common cause of root compression in younger patients such as in this case. Sensory deficits, motor dysfunction, and pain typically occur in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected nerve root. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Anterior spinal artery thrombosis (Choice A) typically manifests with bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation and motor function below the level of the lesion, along with autonomic dysfunction. The anterior spinal artery supplies the corticospinal, spinothalamic, and autonomic tracts. Bilateral dislocation of facets with impingement of the left CS nerve root (Choice B) and unilateral dislocation of a facet with impingement of the left CS nerve (Choice E) would lead to sensory and motor dysfunction in the lateral aspect of the shoulder and upper arm. CS nerve compression typically results in an absent biceps reflex, as the CS nerve root carries afferent information for this reflex. However, CS nerve compression would not cause decreased sensation in the digits. Brown-Sequard syndrome (Choice D) refers to hemisection of the spinal cord, which damages the anterior horn along with three major spinal cord tracts: the corticospinal tract, dorsal column-media l lemniscus tract, and spinothalamic tract. Because of the decussation of the spinothalamic tract inferior to the lesion, patients typically present with contralateral impairment in pain and temperature sensation and ipsilateral deficits in other sensory domains and motor function.

explanation.educational_objective: Cervical spinal injury can lead to vertebra l dislocation and impingement of the spinal nerve root, which leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesia, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 nerve root compression will cause decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and lateral two digits. Additionally, C6 root compression causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension Clinical
explanation.concept: Cervical spinal injury can lead to vertebra l dislocation and impingement of the spinal nerve root, which leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesia, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution

vignette.presentation:
6. A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the sudden
onset of headache and left-sided weakness that have become increasingly severe.
He has hypertension treated with lisinopril and chronic neck pain treated with
325-mg aspirin. On arrival, he appears mildly lethargic. His pulse is 60/min,
respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 180/100 mm Hg. Examination shows
moderate weakness of the lower left side of the face. Muscle tone is decreased in
the left upper and lower extremities. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the left and 5/5 on the
right. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the left. Babinski sign is present on the left. A
CT scan of the head without contrast is shown. Which of the following is the most
likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypertensive intracerebral hematomas (ICHs) can occur in patients with chronic hypertension, typically because of hemorrhage from small penetrating arteries in the pons, midbrain, thalamus, putamen, caudate, or cerebellum. Risk factors for hypertensive ICH include uncontrolled hypertension and antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy, such as with aspirin or warfarin. Patients can present with headache, vomiting, confusion, altered mental status, stupor, or coma. Focal neurologic deficits depend on the site of the ICH and can include hemiparesis, hemisensory symptoms, gaze palsy, dysarthria, aphasia, or if in the cerebellum, ataxia, vomiting, and disequilibrium. Patients may manifest upper motoneuron examination findings such as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar reflex (Babinski sign). Diagnosis is made with noncontrast CT scan of the head which will show hyperdense intraparenchyma l products, which is the appearance of acute bleeding in the brain as seen in this patient's right hemisphere Clinical

distractor_explanations.A: Cerebral amyloid angiopathy occurs secondary to amyloid deposition in cerebral blood vessels and leptomeninges. It can cause spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage in older adults, typically in a lobar location, because of the location of amyloid deposits in cortical vessels. In contrast, hypertensive hemorrhages typically occur in a deep location such as the putamen, thalamus, midbrain, or pons. lschemic cerebral infarction (Choice C) can occur as a result of thromboembol ic occlusion of cerebral arteries. Patients typically present with acute focal neurologic deficits, especially on one side of the body, and may have speech difficulty, dysarthria, or aphasia. A CT scan would not show hyperdense blood products unless the infarction is complicated by hemorrhagic conversion. Ruptured arteriovenous malformation (Choice D) can lead to intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage. Arteriovenous malformations are uncommon and usually present in individuals younger than 50 years old with intracranial hemorrhage, seizure, neurologic deficit, or headache, or may be an incidental finding. In an older patient with uncontrolled hypertension, a hypertensive intracerebral hematoma is more likely. Ruptured berry aneurysm (Choice E) typically leads to a subarachnoid hemorrhage. Patients typically present with an acute, severe headache (o ften described as the worst headache of the patient's life), along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. CT scan of the head typically shows hyperdense blood products in the cerebral sulci and basal cisterns.

explanation.educational_objective: Hypertensive intracerebral hematomas can occur in patients with chronic hypertension, typically as a result of hemorrhage from small penetrating arteries in the pons, midbrain, thalamus, putamen, caudate, or cerebellum. Patients can present with headache, vomiting, confusion, altered mental status, stupor, upper motoneuron signs, and focal neurologic deficits such as hemiparesis and hemisensory symptoms Clinical
explanation.concept: Hypertensive intracerebral hematomas can occur in patients with chronic hypertension, typically as a result of hemorrhage from small penetrating arteries in the pons, midbrain, thalamus, putamen, caud

vignette.presentation:
7. Over the past 6 months, an otherw ise healthy 19-year-old cheerleader has had increasingly severe neurologic symptoms. Initially, she had difficulty
jumping; 2 weeks later she had a tingling feeling in the toes of her right foot that quickly spread to the left foot. Over the past 2 weeks, she has
stumbled and fallen severa l times. Examination of the upper extremities shows normal findings. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower
extremities. She is unable to heel walk and has mild difficulty walking on her toes and rising from a low squatting position. Position sensation is
normal, but pinprick feels less sharp distally and occasiona l light touch stimuli are missed over the toes. Peronea l motor conduction velocity is
moderately slowed (22 m/sec; N=42-57). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Chronic inflammator y demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathYi G) Spinal cord tumor
Diabetic neuropathy H) Spinal epidural abscess
Epidural spinal cord metastasis I) Spondylotic myelopathy
Spinal cord infarction L) Vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradicu lopathy (CIDP) is an immune-mediated demye linating condition affecting the spinal nerve roots. The pathogenesis of CIDP involves inflammation of myelin by an unknown mechanism. The ventra l nerve roots containing motor efferents are common ly involved, though the dorsal nerve root (controlling sensation) may also be affected. As such, patients typical ly present with relapsing-remitting or gradually progressive symmetric muscle weakness with depressed or absent deep tendon reflexes (reflecting a lower motoneuron pattern of dysfunction) that affects the proxima l and distal lower extremities simultaneous ly and may also affect the upper extremities. Autonomic dysfunction may occur but is typically mild. Sensory deficits may occur (though these symptoms are typically mild compared to motor dysfunction). A slowing of conduction velocity on nerve conduction studies indicates demyelination and supports the diagnosis. The diagnosis is further supported by increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell counts on lumbar puncture, termed albuminocyto logic dissociation and thought to reflect generalized inflammation. Management includes glucocorticoids, immunomodulators, plasma exchange, or intravenous immunog lobulin therapy.
explanation.concept: TBD

vignette.presentation:
8. A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressive weakness of his legs during the past week. He has chronic
kidney disease and receives dialysis three times weekly via a percutaneous tunneled catheter. Last week, he had an episode of sweating and chills.
His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 100/min and regular, and blood pressure is 150/92 mm Hg. Examination shows severe tenderness to
percussion over the lumbar spine. The catheter site appears normal. There is trace edema of the lower extremities. Muscle strength is 3/5 on flexion
and extension of the knees and ankles. Deep tendon reflexes are increased at the patellae. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 19,200/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 90%
Bands 5%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 4%
Platelet count 290,000/mm3
An MRI of the spine shows an epidural abscess at L4. Blood cultures grow Staphylococcus aureus. In addition to antibiotic therapy and drainage of
the abscess, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Epidural abscess is a localized collection of pus in the epidural space between the dura mater and periosteum. It most commonly occurs in the spine but may occur in the brain. Most patients have a history of another preceding or associated (even occult) infection and often have a history of immunocompromise (eg, diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, alcohol use disorder). Epidural abscess is more common in patients with a history of intravenous drug use or indwelling intravenous lines. Infectious organisms usually spread to the epidural space hematogenously, from spinal surgery, or from adjacent osteomyelitis. Staphylococcus aureus is a frequent causative organism. Patients present with signs and symptoms of fever, altered mental status, meningismus, localized back pain, and tenderness to palpation, along with weakness, numbness, and paralysis below the affected spinal level as a result of cord compression. Treatment is with broad spectrum antibiotics and surgical drainage of the abscess. It is also crucial to identify and remove potential sources of bacterial colonization, such as indwelling venous catheters. r ~• • ,• ! a , • : • - •• r, Clinical -• · JI• • _. . J.- I • 1 · • · 1n • · •til • .1 • • ii Iii I I• i 1H I .1 ·-1 . • Ii 1 · 1. · 11 · • .tJ.. · i i . · .i• I the abscess, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A) Removal of the cathete B) Electromyography C) Technetium 99m bone scan D) Bone biopsy of L4 E) Lumbar puncture Correct Answer: A. Epidural abscess is a localized collection of pus in the epidural space between the dura mater and periosteum. It most commonly occurs in the spine but may occur in the brain. Most patients have a history of another preceding or associated (even occult) infection and often have a history of immunocompromise (eg, diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, alcohol use disorder). Epidural abscess is more common in patients with a history of intravenous drug use or indwelling intravenous lines. Infectious organisms usually spread to the epidural space hematogenously, from spinal surgery, or from adjacent osteomyelitis. Staphylococcus aureus is a frequent causative organism. Patients present with signs and symptoms of fever, altered mental status, meningismus, localized back pain, and tenderness to palpation, along with weakness, numbness, and paralysis below the affected spinal level as a result of cord compression. Treatment is with broad spectrum antibiotics and surgical drainage of the abscess. It is also crucial to identify and remove potential sources of bacterial colonization, such as indwelling venous catheters.

distractor_explanations.B: Electromyography is useful for the diagnosis of various neuromuscular and inflammatory disorders, such as polymyositis, myasthenia gravis, or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. This patient's MRI has shown a clear cause of his lower extremity weakness, and further testing for other etiologies is less appropriate than removal of potential sources of bacterial colonization. Technetium 99m bone scan (Choice C) or bone biopsy (Choice D) may be useful for the diagnosis of osteomyelitis or malignancy of bone. Pursuing further diagnostic testing is less appropriate than removal of potential sources of bacterial colonization. Lumbar puncture (Choice E) is useful for the diagnosis of meningitis but is not usually necessary for patients with epidural abscess.

explanation.educational_objective: Epidural abscess may result from hematogenous dissemination of bacterial or fungal infection to the epidural space between the dura mater and periosteum. It presents with fever, altered mental status, meningismus, localized back pain, and tenderness to palpation, along with weakness, numbness, and paralysis below the affected spinal level. Treatment is with broad spectrum antibiotics, surgical drainage of the abscess, and the identification and removal of any potential sources of bacterial colonization, such as indwelling venous catheters Clinical
explanation.concept: Epidural abscess may result from hematogenous dissemination of bacterial or fungal infection to the epidural space between the dura mater and periosteum. It presents with fever, altered mental status,

vignette.presentation:
9. A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 30 minutes after a 15-minute episode of inability to speak. He has a 15-year
history of poorly controlled hypertension . Three weeks ago, he had a transmural myocardial infarction and underwent placement of a stent in the left
anterior descending coronary artery. Current medications include clopidogrel, benazepril, and 81-mg aspirin. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes
daily for 30 years. On arrival, he is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. His pulse is 60/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is
160/100 mm Hg. A grade 1/ 6 systolic murmur is heard best at the second left intercostal space. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings.
Carotid duplex ultrasonography shows 40% stenosis of the left carotid artery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: An embolic ischemic stroke involves an event in which a clot breaks off and travels to the brain, occluding blood flow within a cerebral artery. Emboli can originate from proximal vessels, such as the internal carotid artery, or from an atrial or ventricular thrombus. This patient had a recent myocardial infarction, which predisposes him to a ventricular aneurysm. Ventricular aneurysms are more likely to form in the case of large, anterior myocardial infarctions as a result of obstruction of the left anterior descending coronary artery, as was the case in this patient. A small systolic murmur of mitral regurgitation may be heard. Within the aneurysm, as a result of areas of stagnant blood flow and despite being on clopidogrel, a thrombus can form that can embolize and cause an ischemic stroke. If a patent foramen ovale is present, an embolism may arise from either the right or left side of the heart. This patient also has other risk factors for ischemic stroke including hypertension and atherosclerotic disease. Because his symptoms resolved within less than 24 hours, his embolic event is classified as a transient ischemic attack.

distractor_explanations.B: Infarct of the lacunar artery causes ischemia to the deep cerebral white matter, pons, or basal ganglia. A lacunar stroke may present with purely motor symptoms, purely sensory symptoms, ataxic hemiparesis, or dysarthria. Infarcts in these deep penetrating vessels are secondary to hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. While these risk factors would also predispose to myocardial infarction, this patient's transient ischemic event is most likely caused by an embolism from the left ventricle as opposed to a primary central nervous system infarction. lntraparenchyma l cerebral hemorrhage (Choice C) and subarachnoid hemorrhage (Choice E) are both causes of hemorrhagic stroke and are caused by ruptured intracranial or subarachnoid blood vessels in the setting of hypertension. A CT scan of the head without r ~ - - - - , r - - - -, Clinical D) Spasm of a cerebral artery E) Subarachnoid hemorrhage Correct Answer: A. An embolic ischemic stroke involves an event in which a clot breaks off and travels to the brain, occluding blood flow within a cerebral artery. Emboli can originate from proximal vessels, such as the internal carotid artery, or from an atrial or ventricular thrombus. This patient had a recent myocardial infarction, which predisposes him to a ventricular aneurysm. Ventricular aneurysms are more likely to form in the case of large, anterior myocardial infarctions as a result of obstruction of the left anterior descending coronary artery, as was the case in this patient. A small systolic murmur of mitral regurgitation may be heard. Within the aneurysm, as a result of areas of stagnant blood flow and despite being on clopidogrel, a thrombus can form that can embolize and cause an ischemic stroke. If a patent foramen ovale is present, an embolism may arise from either the right or left side of the heart. This patient also has other risk factors for ischemic stroke including hypertension and atherosclerotic disease. Because his symptoms resolved within less than 24 hours, his embolic event is classified as a transient ischemic attack. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. Infarct of the lacunar artery (Choice B) causes ischemia to the deep cerebral white matter, pons, or basal ganglia. A lacunar stroke may present with purely motor symptoms, purely sensory symptoms, ataxic hemiparesis, or dysarthria. Infarcts in these deep penetrating vessels are secondary to hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. While these risk factors would also predispose to myocardial infarction, this patient's transient ischemic event is most likely caused by an embolism from the left ventricle as opposed to a primary central nervous system infarction. lntraparenchyma l cerebral hemorrhage (Choice C) and subarachnoid hemorrhage (Choice E) are both causes of hemorrhagic stroke and are caused by ruptured intracranial or subarachnoid blood vessels in the setting of hypertension. A CT scan of the head without contrast is typically obtained in the acute setting to confirm the presence of blood, which is shown on imaging as hyperdense material. A transient ischemic attack is not caused by hemorrhage. Spasm of a cerebral artery (Choice D) is a potential complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage which tends to occur within 4 to 10 days after the initial bleed. It leads to subsequent ischemia in the area supplied by the spasmed artery. It is not the cause of this patient's transient ischemic attack.

explanation.educational_objective: An embolic ischemic stroke is caused by a clot that has broken off from either a proximal vessel or thrombus and has occluded blood flow within a cerebral artery. A ventricular aneurysm after a myocardial infarction can cause a thrombus to form in the left ventricle, increasing the risk for an embolic event. ., Exam Section : Item 10 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: An embolic ischemic stroke is caused by a clot that has broken off from either a proximal vessel or thrombus and has occluded blood flow within a cerebral artery. A ventricular aneurysm after a myocar

vignette.presentation:
10. One month after starting isoniazid and rifampin therapy for pulmonary tuberculosis, a 62-year-old woman develops weakness, fatigue, and
paresthesias. Examination shows pallor and diminished light touch sensation in the extremities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 9 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 78 µm3
Leukocyte count 8000/mm3
Platelet count 210,000/mm3
These symptoms are most likely to respond to treatment with which of the following?

question_stem: most likely to respond to treatment with which of the following?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: lsoniazid and rifampin are used in the treatment of primary tuberculosis, which results from an initial exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. lsoniazid binds vitamin B (pyridoxine) which may result in early excretion and inactivation of pyridoxine, and also inhibits 6 pyridoxine phosphokinase, which is necessary to activate it. Pyridoxine deficiency results, of which primary symptoms are peripheral neuropathy and paresthesia. Pyridoxine deficiency limits synthesis of histamine, hemoglobin, and neurotransm itters including epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine, serotonin, and y-aminobutyric acid (GABA). In addition to peripheral neuropathy, deficiency commonly presents with dermatitis, sideroblastic anemia, glossitis, and seizures. These adverse effects may all be avoided by pyridoxine supplementation in all patients taking isoniazid.

distractor_explanations.A: Folic acid is converted to tetrahydrofo lic acid and is used as a coenzyme in the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleosides. Folate is contained in leafy vegetables and absorbed in the jejunum. Folate deficiency is often seen in patients with malnutrition, alcoholism, and patients taking anti-folate medications (eg, phenytoin, methotrexate). It is not caused by isoniazid or rifampin and is not responsible for this patient's symptoms.
distractor_explanations.B: Iron deficiency also presents with microcytic anemia. However, it is not induced by isoniazid or rifampin and its supplementation in this case would not address the symptoms of pyridoxine deficiency. Vitamin B (thiamine) (Choice C) supplementation is not necessary in patients taking isoniazid or rifampin. Thiamine deficiency causes 1 variable manifestations including dry beriberi (peripheral neuropathy with mental status change), wet beriberi (dilated cardiomyopathy leading to heart failure), and Wernicke encephalopathy (confusjon, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia), but not microcytic anemia. Vitamin B (cyanocobalamin) (Choice E) supplementation is necessary in vegans and patients with malabsorption (eg, sprue), 12 pernicious anemia, and Crohn disease. It is not needed when taking isoniazid or rifampin. Vitamin B deficiency presents with 12 megaloblastic anemia, not microcytic anemia, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

explanation.educational_objective: lsoniazid therapy for latent tuberculosis without sufficient pyridoxine supplementation can lead to pyridoxine deficiency. This is characterized by peripheral neuropathy, dermatitis, sideroblastic anemia, glossitis, and seizures. ., Exam Section : Item 11 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: lsoniazid therapy for latent tuberculosis without sufficient pyridoxine supplementation can lead to pyridoxine deficiency. This is characterized by peripheral neuropathy, dermatitis, sideroblastic ane

vignette.presentation:
11. A 22-year-old man who is a collegiate volleyball player comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive pain and weakness in
his right shoulder. There is no history of trauma. He is 196 cm (6 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2 . There is significant loss of
muscle mass in the dorsal scapula region, especially in the area of the scapular spine. Passive abduction and external rotation of the right
shoulder and protraction of the scapula reproduce the pain. There is weakness with resisted external rotation and initiation of abduction. Active
range of motion shows full flexion and abduction. Sensory examinat ion shows no cutaneous deficits along the right side of the neck or in the right
upper extremity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are most consistent with entrapment of the suprascapu lar nerve. The suprascapular nerve originates from the superior trunk of the brachia! plexus and innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles. Nerve compression secondary to traction injury is common among volleyball players. Irritation of the suprascapular nerve results in pain along the course of the nerve and may result in chronic neuropathy with subsequent muscle wasting, atrophy, and degeneration of the infraspinatus and supraspinatus muscles. The supraspinatus is responsib le for adduction of the shoulder, and the infraspinatus is responsible for external rotation of the shoulder, which reproduce the pain and disclose weakness in this patient. Initial treatment is conservative with activity modification and physical therapy. Operative intervention may be required.

distractor_explanations.A: Adhesive capsulitis is a common cause of shoulder pain in adults, characterized by severely limited range of motion. Patients typically note a gradual onset of progressive shoulder stiffness and pain. Physical examination would disclose limited range of motion while this patient discloses full range of motion. Axillary nerve damage (Choice B) results in weakness of the deltoid and teres minor, which abduct and stabilize the shoulder. The axillary nerve gives rise to the superficial lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, and sensory deficits would be expected if injured. Brachia! plexus palsy (Choice C) describes a range of injury to the nervous system complex that gives rise to the nerves of the upper extremity. The mechanism is usually high-impact trauma or forced abduction of the shoulder. Physical examination typically discloses motor and sensory deficits involving several peripheral nerves Exam Section : Item 11 of 50 Clinical i .. J. · •J.•• .. ·· - C) Brachia! plexus palsy D) Herniated cervical disc E) Irritation of the suprascapular nerve Correct Answer: E. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are most consistent with entrapment of the suprascapu lar nerve. The suprascapular nerve originates from the superior trunk of the brachia! plexus and innervates the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles. Nerve compression secondary to traction injury is common among volleyball players. Irritation of the suprascapular nerve results in pain along the course of the nerve and may result in chronic neuropathy with subsequent muscle wasting, atrophy, and degeneration of the infraspinatus and supraspinatus muscles. The supraspinatus is responsib le for adduction of the shoulder, and the infraspinatus is responsible for external rotation of the shoulder, which reproduce the pain and disclose weakness in this patient. Initial treatment is conservative with activity modification and physical therapy. Operative intervention may be required. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Adhesive capsulitis (Choice A) is a common cause of shoulder pain in adults, characterized by severely limited range of motion. Patients typically note a gradual onset of progressive shoulder stiffness and pain. Physical examination would disclose limited range of motion while this patient discloses full range of motion. Axillary nerve damage (Choice B) results in weakness of the deltoid and teres minor, which abduct and stabilize the shoulder. The axillary nerve gives rise to the superficial lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, and sensory deficits would be expected if injured. Brachia! plexus palsy (Choice C) describes a range of injury to the nervous system complex that gives rise to the nerves of the upper extremity. The mechanism is usually high-impact trauma or forced abduction of the shoulder. Physical examination typically discloses motor and sensory deficits involving several peripheral nerves. Herniated cervical disc (Choice D) typically presents with neck pain, occipital headache, and unilateral upper extremity weakness, numbness, and/or pain caused by compression of a cervical nerve root. Like brachia! plexus palsy, physical examination typically discloses deficits involving multiple peripheral nerves.

explanation.educational_objective: Shoulder pain associated with impaired innervation to the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles is suggestive of suprascapu lar neuropathy. Causes include mass effect as a result of lesions compressing the nerve sheath, trauma, and traction injury (most commonly seen in volleyball players). ., Exam Section : Item 12 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Shoulder pain associated with impaired innervation to the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles is suggestive of suprascapu lar neuropathy. Causes include mass effect as a result of lesions compress

vignette.presentation:
12. A 32-year-o ld woman comes to the physician with her husband because of a 6-month history of fluctuating symptoms including fatigue, loss of
balance, blurred vision, and the sensation of pins and needles over he r arms and legs. Her husband says that she has also had mood swings with
episodes of uncontro llable crying over the past 2 months. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood
pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows reduced medial gaze of the left eye and numbness to pinprick over the left distal lower
extremities. Romberg sign is present. Babinski sign is present on the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Measurement of serum vitamin B (cobalam in) concentration

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Multiple sclerosis (MS), the most prevalent immune-mediated demyelinating disease, may present with episodic or progressive neurologic dysfunction. According to the McDonald criteria for MS diagnosis, patients must have evidence of demyelinating lesions that are separated in time and location. This evidence is typically based on subjective symptoms and radiologic studies. Lesions affecting the left medial longitudina l fasciculus (leading to decreased medial gaze of the left eye), the prefronta l cortex or corticobulbar tracts (leading to pseudobu lbar affect, or uncontrollable crying), and the major central nervous system (CNS) tracts innervating the extremities (lesions of the corticospina l tract causing Babinski sign, spinothalamic tract causing decreased pinprick, dorsal column-media l lemniscus causing Romberg sign and paresthesia) are likely separated in space. This patient experienced two discrete periods of symptom onset at 6 months and 2 months, illustrating separation in time. MRI typically shows white matter hyperintensities in the periventricular region, cortex, subcortical region, cerebellum, or spine. Oligoclonal bands of immunog lobulins, indicating immune overactivation, can be found in the cerebrospinal fluid but are not necessary for diagnosis. Treatment includes corticosteroids for symptomatic management of acute flares and long-term disease-modifying treatments such as interferon or monoclonal antibodies.

distractor_explanations.A: EEG assists in diagnosing seizures. Hypothalamic seizures can lead to uncontrollable crying. However, seizures typically last seconds to minutes; months of persistent sensory and motor dysfunction would be atypical. Measurement of serum ammonia concentration (Choice B) supports a diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy. Hepatic encephalopathy presents acutely with confusion or stupor along with neurologic symptoms such as asterixis, tremor, myoclonus, and frontal release signs. Measurement of serum calcium concentration (Choice C) would confirm hyper- or hypocalcemia. Hypercalcemia typically presents with confusion, fatigue, polyuria, constipation, and bone pain. Hypocalcemia features muscle spasms, paresthesias, circumoral numbness, and seizures. Measurement of serum copper concentration (Choice D) diagnoses Wilson disease, in which copper accumulates in the liver, brain, and eyes. Though mood swings and extrapyramidal symptoms (from copper deposits in the basal ganglia) may occur, months of medial gaze palsy along with sensorimotor dysfunction would be atypical. Measurement of serum vitamin B (cobalamin) concentration (Choice E) helps in diagnosing subacute combined degeneration, 12 affecting the spinocerebel lar tracts, lateral corticospina l tracts, and dorsal columns. Measurement of urine porphobilinogen concentration (Choice F) assists in diagnosing acute intermittent porphyria, which is characterized by episodic abdominal pain, polyneuropathy, psychologica l symptoms, and port wine-colored urine. Serum antinuclear antibody assay (Choice H) can assist in diagnosing autoimmune diseases affecting the CNS and are expressed at decreased concentrations in multiple sclerosis. However, characteristic MRI findings are more specific for MS. Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test in cerebrospinal fluid (Choice I) assists in diagnosing neurosyphilis, which typically presents with progressive dementia or tabes dorsalis.

explanation.educational_objective: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease that presents with focal neurologic deficits separated in space and time. Though most patients present with episodic deficits, some present with progressive disease. MRI, which confirms the diagnosis, typically shows white matter hyperintensities in the periventricu lar region, cortex, subcortical region, cerebellum, or spine Clinical

13. A physician makes a house call for an 87-year-old woman who is unable to come to the office because of difficulty with transportation. Her family
reports that she has fallen frequently during the past 6 weeks. The patient says that she has had some difficulty feeling where her feet are but that
she is otherwise well. She has not had loss of consciousness. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within
normal limits. Muscle strength is 4/5 on flexion of the hips and extension of the knees and ankles bilaterally. Proprioception and sensation to
vibration are decreased in the lower extremities. Sensation to light touch is intact. She has a slapping gait. Mental status examination shows no
abnormalities. The physician counsels the patient about making enhancements to her home to prevent falls. Which of the following is the most
appropriate next step in diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Subacute combined degeneration, caused by demyelination of the dorsal columns, lateral corticospinal tracts, and spinocerebellar tracts, is a feature of vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency. Subacute combined degeneration causes a combination of motor and sensory 12 symptoms including ataxic gait, muscle weakness, paresthesia , and loss of proprioception and vibration sense. The effects of these features may include frequent falls, as in this case. Vitamin B deficiency is often a result of inadequate dietary intake, seen in 12 veganism, malabsorption, or pernicious anemia. Occasionally, elderly patients with poor nutrition may develop B deficiency. Other 12 manifestations include dementia and megaloblastic anemia. In an elderly patient with an acute or subacute change in behavior or activities of daily living, organic causes such as vitamin deficiency should be ruled out.

distractor_explanations.A: Determination of erythrocyte sedimentation rate may be useful in supporting the diagnosis of an inflammatory process, such as polymyositis, as the cause of this patient's lower extremity weakness. However, erythrocyte sedimentation rate is nonspecific and would not suggest a definitive diagnosis. Furthermore, the patient's symptoms are more consistent with vitamin B deficiency than an 12 inflammatory process. X-rays of the lumbosacral spine (Choice C) may be warranted in a patient with recent falls who is suspected to have fractures or other musculoskeletal pathology. However, it is not useful in diagnosing subacute combined degeneration. EEG (Choice D) is the test of choice in diagnosing a s.e izure disorder. While seizur.e s could be a cause of recurrent falls, in this case r ~ - - - - , r - - - - , Clinical A) Determination of erythrocyte sedimentation rate B) Measurement of serum vitamin B (cobalamin) concentration 12 C) X-rays of the lumbosacra l spine D) EEG E) Electromyography Correct Answer: B. Subacute combined degeneration causes a combination of motor and sensory 12 symptoms including ataxic gait, muscle weakness, paresthesia , and loss of proprioception and vibration sense. The effects of these features may include frequent falls, as in this case. Occasionally, elderly patients with poor nutrition may develop B deficiency. Other 12 manifestations include dementia and megaloblastic anemia. In an elderly patient with an acute or subacute change in behavior or activities of daily living, organic causes such as vitamin deficiency should be ruled out. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. Determination of erythrocyte sedimentation rate (Choice A) may be useful in supporting the diagnosis of an inflammatory process, such as polymyositis, as the cause of this patient's lower extremity weakness. However, erythrocyte sedimentation rate is nonspecific and would not suggest a definitive diagnosis. Furthermore, the patient's symptoms are more consistent with vitamin B deficiency than an 12 inflammatory process. X-rays of the lumbosacral spine (Choice C) may be warranted in a patient with recent falls who is suspected to have fractures or other musculoskeletal pathology. However, it is not useful in diagnosing subacute combined degeneration. EEG (Choice D) is the test of choice in diagnosing a seizure disorder. While seizures could be a cause of recurrent falls, in this case subacute combined degeneration caused by vitamin B deficiency is more likely. An EEG is not helpful in making the diagnosis of 12 vitamin B deficiency. 12
distractor_explanations.E: Electromyography and nerve conduction studies are used to support a diagnosis of inflammatory myopathy, such as polymyositis. The motor weakness seen in this patient is caused by the demyelination of the lateral corticospinal tracts rather than damage to the peripheral muscles, so electromyography will not be useful.

A 27-year-o ld nulligravid woman has had cafe au lait spots and multiple neurofibromas since birth. A diagnosis of neurofibromatos is is made. She is concerned that she might pass this condition on to her children. Her parents and three siblings do not have this disorder. The risk for neurofibromatosis in her children is closest to which of the following? A) 50% for each child, since neurofibromatosis is autosomal dominan t B) 25% for each child, since neurofibroma tosis is autosoma l recessive C) 10% for each child, since neurofibroma tosis is controlled by severa l genes D) No risk, since neurofibromatos is is not a genetic disorder E) No risk, since the patient represe nts a new mutation Correct Answer: A. Neurofibromatosis type I is a genetically inherited disorder caused by a defect in NF1, the gene which encodes neurofibromin on chromosome 17. It follows an autosoma l dominant pattern of inheritance. It is characterized by a constellation of cutaneous manifestations (eg, neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas, cafe au lait spots, and axillary freckling), a variety of central nervous system tumors including optic nerve glioma and iris hamartoma (ie, Lisch nodule), and bony abnorma lities such as long bone dysplasia and sphenoid wing dysplasia. Patients are also at higher risk for developing astrocytomas, brainstem gliomas, and soft tissue sarcomas. Because it follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, only one alle le is needed to develop the condition. Thus, the chance of this patient passing on the dominant allele containing the mutation on chromosome 17 is 50% for each child. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. 25% for each child (Choice B) would be the chance of a child developing an autosoma l recessive disease if both his or her parents were carriers. The defect in NF1 that causes neurofibromatosis type I is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. 10% for each child (Choice C) could be the chance of a developing a disease which is controlled by several genes, or for which there is variable penetrance or expressivity, but neurofibromatosis type I is caused by a defect in a single gene, NF1, located on chromosome

vignette.presentation:
15. A 57-year-old man comes to the physician 2 hours after the sudden onset of visual
loss in his right eye. He has no history of similar episodes . He has a 12-year history
of type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin and hypertension treated with
lisinopril. He sustained a myocardial infarction 2 years ago. His pulse is 90/min, and
blood pressure is 170/96 mm Hg. Findings on right funduscopic examination are
shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's presenting signs and symptoms of abrupt, painless vision loss and a pale fundus with normal foveal color are consistent with a diagnosis of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). CRAO commonly occurs as a result of embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery but may occur secondary to vasculitis, such as in giant cell arteritis (GCA). Patients may have a history of preceding amaurosis fugax. Examination shows profound diminishment of visual acuity, a relative afferent pupillary defect, and a pale fundus with preserved foveal color. CRAO is a medical emergency, as it an ischemic stroke of the ophthalmic vasculature and indicates a high risk for associated ischemic stroke to the brain. Patients who present with CRAO should be admitted to a stroke center for emergent evaluation, including a search for a possible embolic source with echocardiography and duplex ultrasonography of the carotid arteries. A careful history and laboratory evaluation of erythrocyte sedimentation rate, serum concentration of C-reactive protein, and platelet count should be performed to evaluate for possible GCA. There is no proven medical or surgical therapy for CRAO, and the visual prognosis Is poor.
explanation.educational_objective: Central retinal artery occlusion frequently occurs secondary to embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery in carotid or cardiac valvular disease. Patients present with acute, painless vision loss and examination findings including diminished visual acuity, relative afferent pupillary defect, and a pale fundus with preserved foveal color. Patients who present with central retinal artery occlusion should be admitted to a stroke center for emergent evaluation Exam Section : Item 16 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
16. A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of facial numbness for 2 weeks. Her symptoms began as a "funny feeling" over a patch of
skin on the left side of her chin and have gradually progressed to a 1'novocaine" sensation. She has had no facial pain or numbness of the gums or
oral mucosa. She has a 3-year history of breast cancer metastatic to the lungs treated with tamoxifen. Examination shows supraclavicular
adenopathy. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and temperature is absent over the left side of the chin. Neurologic examination shows no other
abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely location of the abnormality?

question_stem: the most likely location of the abnormality?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Numb chin syndrome, or mental neuropathy, is an indication of bony metastasis to the mandible in this patient with a history of breast cancer. The mandibular (V branch of the trigeminal nerve passes through the bony canal of the mandible, branches to form the ) 3 inferior alveolar nerve, and branches again proximal to the mental foramen to form the mental nerve. The mental nerve branch affected by mandibular bony metastases provides sensory innervation to the ipsilateral skin of the anterior chin (another unaffected mental nerve branch provides sensory innervation to the ipsilateral lower lip and buccal gingiva). Compression of the mental nerve branch by bony metastasis of the mandible leads to anesthesia of the chin. Numb chin syndrome may indicate systemic malignancy, autoimmune disease (eg, multiple sclerosis), or may be related to local infection, trauma, or dental disease. This patient should receive full-body imaging to evaluate for metastatic spread.

distractor_explanations.A: plexopathy typically presents with weakness, numbness, and/or paresthesia of the shoulder, arm, and/or hand. The chin would be unaffected. Cavernous sinus thrombosis (Choice B) classically follows an infection or injury involving a structure drained by the cavernous sinus ( eg, sinusitis), and results in cranial nerve deficits involving those that traverse the cavernous sinus (generally 111, IV, V or V , or VI). 1 2 Classic symptoms include ipsilateral orbit pain, proptosis, periorbital edema, and impairment in extraocular movement, pupil reactivity, or symmetry. A mass of the cerebellopontine angle (Choice C) (eg, acoustic neuroma, meningioma, glioma) typically affects the vestibulocochlear nerve and may affect other cranial nerves (eg, trigeminal, abducens, facial nerves). The entirety of the trigeminal nerve would be r ~ - - - - , r, Exam Section : Item 16 of 50 Clinical Please Walt • J .. • • A E) Parietal lobe Correct Answer: D. Numb chin syndrome, or mental neuropathy, is an indication of bony metastasis to the mandible in this patient with a history of breast cancer. The mandibular (V branch of the trigeminal nerve passes through the bony canal of the mandible, branches to form the ) 3 inferior alveolar nerve, and branches again proximal to the mental foramen to form the mental nerve. The mental nerve branch affected by mandibular bony metastases provides sensory innervation to the ipsilateral skin of the anterior chin (another unaffected mental nerve branch provides sensory innervation to the ipsilateral lower lip and buccal gingiva). Compression of the mental nerve branch by bony metastasis of the mandible leads to anesthesia of the chin. Numb chin syndrome may indicate systemic malignancy, autoimmune disease (eg, multiple sclerosis), or may be related to local infection, trauma, or dental disease. This patient should receive full-body imaging to evaluate for metastatic spread. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Brachia! plexopathy (Choice A) typically presents with weakness, numbness, and/or paresthesia of the shoulder, arm, and/or hand. The chin would be unaffected. Cavernous sinus thrombosis (Choice B) classically follows an infection or injury involving a structure drained by the cavernous sinus ( eg, sinusitis), and results in cranial nerve deficits involving those that traverse the cavernous sinus (generally 111, IV, V or V or VI). 1 2 Classic symptoms include ipsilateral orbit pain, proptosis, periorbital edema, and impairment in extraocular movement, pupil reactivity, or symmetry. A mass of the cerebellopontine angle (Choice C) (eg, acoustic neuroma, meningioma, glioma) typically affects the vestibulocochlear nerve and may affect other cranial nerves (eg, trigeminal , abducens, facial nerves). The entirety of the trigeminal nerve would be affected rather than the mental branch specifically. The parietal lobe (Choice E) is a large brain region that processes sensory information and promotes spatial awareness of the body. Damage to the parietal lobe can result in symptoms such as agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation (dominant hemisphere, known as Gerstmann syndrome) or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere).

explanation.educational_objective: Numb chin syndrome, or mental neuropathy, may be caused by systemic malignancy, autoimmune disease, or local dental processes. In numb chin syndrome secondary to malignancy, bony metastasis to the mandible leads to compression of a branch of the mental nerve, resulting in anesthesia of the ipsilateral chin. ., Exam Section : Item 17 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
17. A 32-year-old woman with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of painful burning sensations in her hands and feet.
Examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial
pharmacotherapy?

question_stem:
the most appropriate initial
pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Topical lidocaine to the affected areas
Topical lidocaine to the affected areas

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Peripheral neuropathy is a frequent finding in patients with HIV and may occur either secondary to direct viral infection of peripheral nerves or secondary to neurotoxicity associated with antiretrovira l medications, frequently medications in the nucleoside analog reverse-transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) class. HIV-associated neuropathy most frequently presents with symmetric, distal polyneuropathy characterized by sensations of burning, tingling, or numbness in a stocking-g love distribution, as well as reduced vibratory or pinprick sensation. As with other forms of distal polyneuropathy, tricyclic antidepressants such as nortriptyline are effective as first-line treatment. Other effective treatments include gabapentin, pregabalin, lamotrigine, and topical capsaicin or lidocaine.

distractor_explanations.A: Oral fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and is not typically used as a first-line agent for peripheral neuropathic pain. While some SSRls, such as duloxetine, may be effective for the treatment of neuropathic pain, fluoxetine is not effective in treating nerve pain. Oral lorazepam (Choice B) is a short-acting benzodiazepine and is not recommended for the treatment of neuropathic pain because of its significant adverse effects and risk for dependency. Oral prednisone (Choice D) is a corticosteroid. While corticoste roids, including prednisone, may be effective for some forms of neuropathic pain, this is not an appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient given the significant adverse effects of corticosteroids, which includes immunosuppression. Topical lidocaine to the affected areas (Choice E) is not the best initial pharmacotherapy for peripheral neuropathy because they are less effective in comparison with systemic oral therapy such as tricyclic antidepressants. . r ~- - - , r - , Exam Section : Item 17 of 50 Clinical B) Oral lorazepam C) Oral nortriptyline D) Oral prednisone E) Topical lidocaine to the affected areas Correct Answer: C. Other effective treatments include gabapentin, pregabalin, lamotrigine, and topical capsaicin or lidocaine. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Oral prednisone (Choice D) is a corticosteroid. While corticosteroids, including prednisone, may be effective for some forms of neuropathic pain, this is not an appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient given the significant adverse effects of corticosteroids, which includes immunosuppression. Topical lidocaine to the affected areas (Choice E) is not the best initial pharmacotherapy for peripheral neuropathy because they are less effective in comparison with systemic oral therapy such as tricyclic antidepressants.

vignette.presentation:
18. A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of moderate low back pain. He thinks he may have hurt his back while
doing yard work. His pain moderately improves with rest; he has been spending a great amount of time in bed. He has not had other symptoms,
weight loss, or a recent infection. He has no history of serious illness. His only medication is ibuprofen for the pain. He does not use intravenous
drugs or anabolic steroids. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Examination shows mild paraspinal muscle
tenderness. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Oxycodone therapy as needed for pain
Oxycodone therapy as needed for pain

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Low back pain is a common presenting complaint and it can be difficult to identify an exact underlying cause. Most nonspecific low back pain is attributed to musculoskeletal injury from exertion, overuse, or trauma. The majority of these cases will resolve with conservative management, which includes activity modification, stretching, over-the-counter analgesics such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), massage, acupuncture, and heat therapy. Certain red flag signs and symptoms should prompt more urgent evaluation for a cause, especially if there is concern for infection, malignancy, or fracture. These include new fevers, intravenous drug use, focal neurologic deficits (such as urinary retention, saddle anesthesia, bowel incontinence which may suggest cauda equina syndrome), progressive lower extremity neurologic symptoms, current or recent cancer history, advanced age, systemic corticosteroid use, and a significant traumatic mechanism. In this young, otherwise healthy patient with a mild inciting event, the next best step in management is continuation of ibuprofen therapy.

distractor_explanations.A: days is not recommended for acute low back pain, as patients tend to have increased pain and a slower return to normal function. Activity modification for symptom relief should be advised, with encouragement to continue normal activities of daily living and non-exacerbating exertion. X-ray of the lumbar spine (Choice B) and MRI of the lumbar spine (Choice C) should be reserved for patients who present with red flag signs and symptoms to evaluate for evidence of fracture, infection, or malignancy. For otherwise healthy patients with back pain that has persisted for less than 4 weeks, imaging studies do not genera lly change management. Oxycodone therapy as needed for pain (Choice E) should be reserved for severe or refractory cases of acute low back pain Exam Section : Item 18 of 50 Clinical B) X-ray of the lumbar spine C) MRI of the lumbar spine D) Continuation of ibuprofen therapy; E) Oxycodone therapy as needed for pain Correct Answer: D. Low back pain is a common presenting complaint and it can be difficult to identify an exact underlying cause. Most nonspecific low back pain is attributed to musculoskeletal injury from exertion, overuse, or trauma. The majority of these cases will resolve with conservative management, which includes activity modification, stretching, over-the-counter analgesics such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), massage, acupuncture, and heat therapy. Certain red flag signs and symptoms should prompt more urgent evaluation for a cause, especially if there is concern for infection, malignancy, or fracture. These include new fevers, intravenous drug use, focal neurologic deficits (such as urinary retention, saddle anesthesia, bowel incontinence which may suggest cauda equina syndrome), progressive lower extremity neurologic symptoms, current or recent cancer history, advanced age, systemic corticosteroid use, and a significant traumatic mechanism. In this young, otherwise healthy patient with a mild inciting event, the next best step in management is continuation of ibuprofen therapy. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Bed rest for 10 days (Choice A) is not recommended for acute low back pain, as patients tend to have increased pain and a slower return to normal function. Activity modification for symptom relief should be advised, with encouragement to continue normal activities of daily living and non-exacerbating exertion. X-ray of the lumbar spine (Choice B) and MRI of the lumbar spine (Choice C) should be reserved for patients who present with red flag signs and symptoms to evaluate for evidence of fracture, infection, or malignancy. For otherwise healthy patients with back pain that has persisted for less than 4 weeks, imaging studies do not genera lly change management. Oxycodone therapy as needed for pain (Choice E) should be reserved for severe or refractory cases of acute low back pain.

explanation.educational_objective: Acute low back pain is a common presenting complaint in multiple medical settings. General management for pain persisting less than 4 weeks is conservative with over-the-counter analgesics, activity modification, and nonpharmacologic pain relief options. Initial imaging is not typically recommended in the absence of signs or symptoms suggestive of infection, malignancy, spinal cord compromise, or vertebral fracture. ., Exam Section : Item 19 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Acute low back pain is a common presenting complaint in multiple medical settings. General management for pain persisting less than 4 weeks is conservative with over-the-counter analgesics, activity m

vignette.presentation:
19. A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 3 weeks after operative repair of a circle of Willis berry aneurysm. Her
husband says that her behavior has changed since the operation. She is unmotivated and just sits around all day like a "bump on a log." She has
not had depressed mood. Examination shows psychomotor retardation. She is oriented to person, place, and time. She is cooperative and her
speech is fluent and grammatica l, but there is little spontaneous speech during conversation. Which of the following cerebral cortical regions is
most likely affected?

question_stem: most likely affected?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient is exhibiting symptoms of frontal lobe dysfunction. The frontal lobe is the largest lobe of the cerebral cortex, separated from the parietal lobe by the central sulcus. The major areas of the frontal lobe are the primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, prefrontal cortex, Broca area, and the frontal eye fields. Symptoms depend on the location of the lesion. Involvement of the primary motor cortex and premotor cortex result in impaired motor function of the contralateral side of the body and psychomotor retardation. Disruption of Broca area may cause expressive aphasia with retention of language comprehension. Lesions of the frontal eye fields result in ipsilateral deviation of the eyes. Dysfunction of the prefrontal cortex can result in disinhibition, apathy, personality changes, aggressive behavior, and impairments in judgement, concentration, and orientation, as exhibited by this patient. Patients should be evaluated for other medical causes of cognitive impairment, such as vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency, hypothyroidism, syphilis infection, and 12 intoxication. In this patient with a recent invasive procedure, CT scan or MRI of the brain is likely to show the diagnosis.

distractor_explanations.B: Insular cortex lesions may result in impairments in emotional and/or sensory processing, motor control, and speech. Patients may display a progressive expressive dysphasia characterized by non-fluent and grammatically incoherent speech.
distractor_explanations.C: Occipital lobe lesions typically present with difficulties in processing visual sensory inputs. Patients may complain of visual field cuts depending on the precise location of the lesion.
distractor_explanations.D: Parietal lobe lesions manifest differently depending on the side affected. Dominant parietal lobe lesions, most commonly on the left side, may result in Gerstmann syndrome, characterized by agraphia, aphasia, agnosia, acalculia, and right-left confusion. Nondominant parietal lobe lesions typically manifest with hemineglect of the contralateral side.
distractor_explanations.E: Temporal lobe lesions may involve Wernicke area, the limbic system, and/or the amygdala. Wernicke area lesions result in receptive aphasia with loss of language comprehension. Disruption of the limbic system results in dysfunctional emotional processing, and may present with excessive fear, anxiety, and behavioral changes.

explanation.educational_objective: The frontal lobe contains the primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, Broca area, frontal eye fields, and prefrontal cortex, which is involved in the regulation of behavior, inhibition, and other executive functions. Injury to the frontal lobe may result in personality or behavior changes, disinhibited behavior, expressive aphasia, and motor dysfunction. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: The frontal lobe contains the primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, Broca area, frontal eye fields, and prefrontal cortex, which is involved in the regulation of behavior, inhibition, and other execu

vignette.presentation:
20. A 10-day-old newborn is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after a seizure that involved clonic jerking of the left arm. He had been well
until 2 days ago when he began sleeping somewhat more but continued to feed well. Pregnancy, labor, and delivery were uncomplicated. Vital
signs are within normal limits. He is difficult to awaken but moves all extremities when stimulated. He is hypotonic but hyperreflexic. Babinski sign
is present. During examination, he has a clonic seizure of the right lower extremity. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Cerebrospina l
fluid analysis shows:
Glucose 55 mg/dl
Protein 110 mg/dl
Leukocyte count 85/mm3
Erythrocyte count 860/mm3
A Gram stain is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is the most likely diagnosis in this 10-day old infant with new onset seizures, a normal head CT scan, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing increased protein and leukocyte count with a low-normal glucose concentration, which is consistent with aseptic (nonbacterial) meningitis. Further suggestive is the presence of erythrocytes in the CSF which is often seen in herpetic encephalitis. Most cases of HSV encephalitis are caused by HSV-2, although infection with HSV-1 occurs and is treated in the same way. Most patients acquire the virus via transmission from the mother, often during the third trimester, with encephalitis developing usually within a week. Symptoms are nonspecific and include fever, lethargy, poor feeding, and occasionally seizures or focal neurologic deficits. Concomitant oral lesions may occur, but their absence does not rule out the diagnosis. The CSF findings include increased protein, lymphocytic pleocytosis, and a normal or low-normal glucose concentration. In many instances the causative virus can be identified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of the CSF, although empiric therapy with intravenous acyclovir is warranted prior to diagnosis. Failure to recognize and treat infection can result in organ dysfunction and death, or long-term neurologic sequelae.

distractor_explanations.A: Congenital infection with cytomegalovirus is associated with petechiae, bilateral sensorineura l hearing loss, jaundice, microcepha ly, hepatosplenomegaly, and hypotonia. The patient lacks these other features. lntracranial calcifications may be present on CT scan. Congenital infection with syphilis (Choice B) presents typically within five weeks with hepatomegaly, maculopapular rash, rhinitis, and skeletal abnormalities including periostitis or bone demineralization. CSF findings may show pleocytosis and increased protein but would be positive for Treponema pal/idum. Congenital infection with toxoplasmosis (Choice C) may present with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and seizures. Toxoplasma gondii can be detected in the CSF. lntracranial calcifications may be present on CT scan. Neonatal Escherichia coli meningitis (Choice D) may present with fever, lethargy, and hypotonia, and CSF findings would include a neutrophilic pleocytosis with a decreased glucose concentration. Treatment is with ampicillin if the organism is sensitive, or with a cephalosporin combined with gentamicin. Neonatal group B streptococcus (GBS) meningitis (Choice E) presents similarly to E. coli meningitis but is more common in patients born to mothers who are colonized with GBS who have not received prophylactic treatment. Colonization is usually detected and treated prior to delivery, and if the status is unknown, prophylactic antibiotics are given.

explanation.educational_objective: HSV encephalitis should be suspected in neonates who develop fever, lethargy, and/or neurologic symptoms, including focal deficits or seizures shortly after birth. A history of HSV infection in the mother may or may not be present. Evaluation of the CSF typically shows an increased protein concentration with a lymphocytic pleocytosis but normal glucose concentrations. Therapy is with intravenous acyclovir Exam Section : Item 21 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
21. A 47-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because of increasingly frequent headaches during the past 3 months. The headaches are
throbbing, occur only on the right side, and are associated with nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. She has had one or two
headaches yearly since the age of 17 years but now has two or three weekly. She is a schoolteacher and has had no changes in work, lifestyle, or
environment. Four months ago, conjugated estrogen therapy was begun for treatment of menopausal symptoms. Her temperature is
37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Butalbital therapy combined with acetaminophen and caffeine

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Migraine is a common condition that presents with recurrent primary headaches. Migraine headaches are typically severe, unilateral, throbbing, and associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. The pain is usually located behind or adjacent to the eye. Some patients additiona lly experience an aura before or during the headache, which may present with vision loss followed by the perception of scintillating shapes or lines and/or paresthesia. Migraine triggers include stress, menstruation and changes in hormonal concentrations , weather changes, fasting, and alcohol. Sleep may improve migraines. Patients who experience migraines associated with conjugated estrogen therapy may require discontinuation of therapy or a reduction in dose. Migraines are postulated to arise from deficient serotonin inhibition of descending pain pathways. Acute migraine treatment may include triptans and/or nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). For patients with disabling or frequent migraines, prophylactic treatment is also recommended and includes ~-adrenergic blockers, antidepressants such as tricyclic antidepressants and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, and anticonvulsants.

distractor_explanations.A: CT scan of the head is unnecessary given a likely cause for the patient's migraines and absence of any neurologic abnormalities. Butalbital therapy combined with acetaminophen and caffeine (Choice B) may be appropriate in the treatment of a primary migraine, however, it carries risk given the adverse effects and dependency associated with barbiturates. Removal of likely offending agents is a more appropriate first step for the treatment of this patient's likely-triggered migraine. r ~, r -- - , Exam Section : Item 21 of 50 Clinical E) Lumbar puncture Correct Answer: C. Migraine is a common condition that presents with recurrent primary headaches. Migraine headaches are typically severe, unilateral, throbbing, and associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia. The pain is usually located behind or adjacent to the eye. Some patients additionally experience an aura before or during the headache, which may present with vision loss followed by the perception of scintillating shapes or lines and/or paresthesia. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. CT scan of the head (Choice A) is unnecessary given a likely cause for the patient's migraines and absence of any neurologic abnormalities. Butalbital therapy combined with acetaminophen and caffeine (Choice B) may be appropriate in the treatment of a primary migraine, however, it carries risk given the adverse effects and dependency associated with barbiturates. Removal of likely offending agents is a more appropriate first step for the treatment of this patient's likely-triggered migraine. EEG (Choice D) is useful for the diagnosis of seizure disorders but is rarely useful for the evaluation or treatment of migraine. Lumbar puncture (Choice E) is useful for the diagnosis of meningitis or idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). While IIH may be associated with hormonal therapy, this patient's symptoms of unilateral, throbbing headache, photophobia and phonophobia are more suggestive of migraine. The headaches associated with IIH are more commonly holocephalic and associated with transient visual obscurations and pulsatile tinnitus.

explanation.educational_objective: Migraines are typically unilateral, pulsating headaches that are associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia, and may present with visual or sensory aura. Changes in hormone concentrations are a common migraine trigger. Patients who experience migraines associated with conjugated estrogen therapy may require discontinuation of therapy or a reduction in dose. ., Clinical 'f 22. A 67-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 1-month history of deafness, ringing in both ears, dizziness, and difficulty with balance. He also has had an occasiona l sensation that the room is spinning. He was discharged from the hospital 21 days ago after prolonged treatment for pneumonia and sepsis with intravenous ceftriaxone and gentamicin. He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and congestive heart failure. He has a history of tuberculosis 10 years ago. Medications include digoxin, metformin, and losartan. His pulse is 84/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Examination shows nystagmus on lateral gaze bilaterally. There is severe loss of hearing bilaterally. Air conduction is greater than bone conduction. Results of Weber test are normal. Muscle strength, deep tendon reflexes, and sensory findings are normal. His gait is broad-based, and he is unable to walk in tandem. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Aminoglycoside-induced ototoxicit~ B) Cerebellopontine angle tumor C) Meniere disease D) Pontine infarction E) Vestibular neuronitis Correct Answer: A. Ototoxicity is a frequent adverse effect of aminoglycosides, such as gentamicin, which exert bactericidal effects by binding the bacterial 30S ribosomal subunit. Aminoglycosides accumulate in the inner ear endolymph and perilymph, and can cause cochlear ototoxicity and vestibulotoxicity, which is typically irreversible. The risk for ototoxicity associated with aminoglycosides may be as high as 10% in some patient populations. While there is an increased risk for ototoxicity with repeat dosing or with high doses, ototoxicity may occur with even the first dose of aminoglycoside. While aminoglycosides are high ly effective against a broad range of Gram-negative bacterial infections, such as with Escherichia coli, Klebsiel/a, Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Serratia species, their use is limited by their significant adverse effects. In addition to ototoxicity and vestibulotoxicity, aminoglycosides are also associated with nephrotoxicity. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. Cerebellopontine angle tumor (Choice B), such as an acoustic neuroma, meningioma, or glioma, typically affects the vestibulococh lear nerve and other cranial nerves (eg, trigeminal, abducens, facial nerves). Patients may present with hearing loss and vertigo; sensory and motor dysfunction of the face and/or extraocular muscles are also possible. Meniere disease (Choice C) is a condition of episodic vertigo and sensorineural hearing loss that results from pressure accumulation in the endolymph of the inner ear. This patient's lack of episodic symptoms suggests against this diagnosis. Pontine infarction (Choice D) may occur as a sequela of basilar artery occlusion and present with truncal ataxia, diplopia, nystagmus, locked-in state, or coma Clinical ·· A) Aminoglycoside-induced ototoxicit~ B) Cerebellopontine angle tumor C) Meniere disease D) Pontine infarction E) Vestibular neuronitis Correct Answer: A. While aminoglycosides are high ly effective against a broad range of Gram-negative bacterial infections, such as with Escherichia coli, Klebsiel/a, Proteus, Pseudomonas, and Serratia species, their use is limited by their significant adverse effects. In addition to ototoxicity and vestibulotoxicity, aminoglycosides are also associated with nephrotoxicity. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. Cerebellopontine angle tumor (Choice B), such as an acoustic neuroma, meningioma, or glioma, typically affects the vestibulocochlear nerve and other cranial nerves (eg, trigeminal, abducens, facial nerves). Patients may present with hearing loss and vertigo; sensory and motor dysfunction of the face and/or extraocular muscles are also possible. Meniere disease (Choice C) is a condition of episodic vertigo and sensorineural hearing loss that results from pressure accumulation in the endolymph of the inner ear. This patient's lack of episodic symptoms suggests against this diagnosis. Pontine infarction (Choice D) may occur as a sequela of basilar artery occlusion and present with truncal ataxia, diplopia, nystagmus, locked-in state, or coma. Vestibular neuronitis (Choice E), also known as labyrinthitis, is caused by inflammation of the vestibular labyrinths and presents with vertigo and nystagmus over a period of several weeks. Patients typically do not present with hearing loss. Educational Objective: Aminoglycosides, such as gentamicin, carry a significant risk for ototoxicity and vestibulotoxicity through accumulation in cochlear endolymph and perilymph, and may cause toxicity with even the first dose. Ototoxicity and vestibulotoxicity associated with aminoglycosides are typically irreversible. ., Clinical
