vignette.presentation:
23. A 72-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of pain in the left thigh and flank and weakness of the left leg. She has a
30-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus currently controlled with glyburide. Examination shows weakness of the left iliopsoas and quadriceps
muscles. Deep tendon reflex of the left quadriceps muscle is decreased. Sensation to pinprick is decreased over the left lateral thigh and medial
calf. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?

question_stem: the most likely location of the lesion?

choices.text: Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve J) S1 Radiculopathy

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Lower extremity neuropathies can be caused by nerve compression, ischemia, inflammation, degeneration, infection, or transection. Diabetic patients may develop spontaneous femora l neuropathies secondary to inflammation and ischemia. The femoral nerve arises from L2 to L4 and exits the lumbosacral plexus by passing under the inguinal ligament. Neuropathy of the femoral nerve or its roots presents with unilatera l quadriceps and iliopsoas weakness, decreased sensation over the anteromedial thigh and medial calf (the latter via its saphenous branch), and absent patellar tendon reflex.
explanation.concept: TBD

vignette.presentation:
24. A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a progressive tremo r of his hands. He and his family have noticed that
his movements have become more shaky during this period and that he has been walking more slowly during the past year. He has hypertension.
Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and aspirin. There is no family history of serious illness. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His
pulse is 56/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a fine tremor of the hands at rest; the tremor is exacerbated with
movement. There is cogwheel rigidity of the upper extremities. His gait is slow and shuffling. Mental status examination shows no abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Carbidopa-levodopa is a dopamine agonist used to treat Parkinson disease by increasing the amount of dopamine available in the nigrostriatal pathway. Carbidopa and levodopa are given together in order to increase availability of levodopa to the brain. Levodopa is converted to dopamine by the enzyme dopa decarboxylase in the peripheral circulation and the brain. Dopamine is not able to cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB), so any levodopa which is converted to dopamine peripherally is unable to effect change in the basal ganglia. Carbidopa indirectly increases dopamine availability in the basal ganglia by inhibiting dopa decarboxylase peripherally. In this way, more levodopa is able to cross the BBB and be converted to dopamine in the brain, where it is then able to act on the nigrostriatal pathway. Increased dopamine leads to improvement of Parkinson disease symptoms including the tremor, rigidity, akinesia, and postural instability shown by this patient.

distractor_explanations.C: Donepezil is an anticholinesterase inhibitor which indirectly increases the concentration of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine. It is used to treat Alzheimer disease. Acetylcholine and dopamine have opposing effects in the basal ganglia related to movement such that decreasing acetylcholine has the same effect as increasing dopamine. Thus, medications which decrease, not increase, acetylcholine are used in Parkinson disease.
distractor_explanations.D: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker and does not play a role in the treatment of Parkinson disease.

explanation.educational_objective: Carbidopa-levodopa is the first-line treatment used in Parkinson disease. Carbidopa cannot cross the blood brain barrier. It therefore increases the bioavailability of levodopa to the brain without inhibiting the conversion of levodopa to dopamine in the brain Clinical
explanation.concept: Carbidopa-levodopa is the first-line treatment used in Parkinson disease. Carbidopa cannot cross the blood brain barrier. It therefore increases the bioavailability of levodopa to the brain without in

vignette.presentation:
25. A 52-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of a 2-hour history of a diffuse, bilateral, dull headache. He has hypertens ion and has been
poorly compliant with his medication. He is alert but confused. His blood pressure is 240/150 mm Hg. Funduscopic examination shows
hemorrhages and exudates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hypertensive encephalopathy may result from acute and severe increases in blood pressure. It potentially manifests with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure, and may progress to obtundation and coma. Visual symptoms may result from cortical dysfunction or from hypertensive retinopathy , including retinal hemorrhages and exudates. Treatment includes carefully lowering the blood pressure while avoiding excessively rapid drops in blood pressure, which can cause end-organ ischemia. In general, a decrease in the mean arterial pressure of 25% within the first hour is appropriate, with gradual correction over the next day or more following. Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator and is a preferred agent because of its short half-life, allowing it to be titrated via intravenous infusion.

distractor_explanations.A: Cerebral hemorrhage can be idiopathic or secondary to trauma, aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations, tumors, or hypertension. Patients can present with a severe headache that can be associated with vomiting. In a patient with noncomp liance with antihypertensive medications, hypertensive encephalopathy is more likely. Cerebral infarction (Choice B), or stroke, can occur as a sudden change in mental status as well as focal neurologic deficits and upper motoneuron signs. Patients typically present with acute focal neurologic deficits, especially on one side of the body, and may have speech difficulty, dysarthria, or aphasia. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (Choice D) or pseudotumor cerebri is an idiopathic increase in intracranial pressure (ICP) that typically occurs in obese women of childbearing age and presents with headaches that may be postural, visual deficits caused by pressure on the optic nerve, and nausea/vomiting (symptoms of increased ICP) Clinical Correct Answer: C. Hypertensive encephalopathy may result from acute and severe increases in blood pressure. It potentially manifests with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure, and may progress to obtundation and coma. Visual symptoms may result from cortical dysfunction or from hypertensive retinopathy, including retinal hemorrhages and exudates. Treatment includes carefully lowering the blood pressure while avoiding excessively rapid drops in blood pressure, which can cause end-organ ischemia. In general, a decrease in the mean arterial pressure of 25% within the first hour is appropriate, with gradual correction over the next day or more following. Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator and is a preferred agent because of its short half-life, allowing it to be titrated via intravenous infusion. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, E, F, and G. Cerebral hemorrhage (Choice A) can be idiopathic or secondary to trauma, aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations, tumors, or hypertension. Patients can present with a severe headache that can be associated with vomiting. In a patient with noncompliance with antihypertensive medications, hypertensive encephalopathy is more likely. Cerebral infarction (Choice B), or stroke, can occur as a sudden change in mental status as well as focal neurologic deficits and upper motoneuron signs. Patients typically present with acute focal neurologic deficits, especially on one side of the body, and may have speech difficulty, dysarthria, or aphasia. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (Choice D) or pseudotumor cerebri is an idiopathic increase in intracranial pressure (ICP) that typically occurs in obese women of childbearing age and presents with headaches that may be postural, visual deficits caused by pressure on the optic nerve, and nausea/vomiting (symptoms of increased ICP).
distractor_explanations.E: Migraine is a type of primary headache that usually does not cause neurologic deficits and would be unlikely to cause confusion or altered mental status. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Choice F) typically presents with an acute, severe headache (often described as the worst headache of the patient's life), along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. Retinal hemorrhage, exudates, and headaches with severely increased blood pressure are more indicative of hypertensive encephalopathy. A subdural hematoma (Choice G) can occur after blunt head trauma as a result of shearing injury of bridging veins, especially in patients with cerebral atrophy such as elderly patients, or those with severe alcohol use disorder. On imaging, subdural hematoma appears as a crescent-shaped fluid collection abutting the internal surface of the skull, not bound by suture lines.

vignette.presentation:
26. A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of excessive sleepiness and fatigue. She has required more sleep for several years, but the
problem has become increasingly worse during the past 7 months. She sometimes falls asleep in the middle of conversations and at dinner. She
recently collapsed onto the floor of her apartment; she was aware o1f her surroundings but unable to move for 5 minutes. She has no history of
seizures or other neurologic disorders. Her only medication is celecoxib for treatment of osteoarthritis. She appears well nourished. Physical
examination shows limited range of motion in the lower extremities. There is swelling and crepitus of the knees. She has moderate pain on
standing. An ECG, EEG, and 72-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring show no abnormalities. Polysomnography is pending. Which of the following is
the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

question_stem: the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Methylphenidate is a non-amphetamine central nervous system stimulant medication that is used in the treatment of narcolepsy, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with fatigue and episodes of cataplexy. Methylphenidate works by blocking the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine into presynaptic neurons. The pathogenesis of narcolepsy involves the loss of orexin-A and orexin-B, which are neurotransmitters found primarily in the hypothalamus that promote wakefulness and inhibit rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. Loss of these neurotransmitters permits abnormal transition from wakefulness to REM sleep with subsequent development of hallucinations and other features of narcolepsy including cataplexy and sleep paralysis. Diagnosis can be made in patients with daytime somnolence and cataplexy or, in cases where cataplexy is not present, with sleep latency testing. Polysomnography is appropriate to support the diagnosis and to rule out similar sleep-related conditions such as sleep apnea. Occasionally patients undergo lumbar puncture to directly measure concentrations of orexin-A in the cerebrospinal fluid, but this is generally not required for the diagnosis. Pharmacotherapy is directed at promoting wakefulness, and methylphenidate is one relatively safe and effective stimulant used to do this.

distractor_explanations.B: Mirtazapine is an antidepressant that increases presynaptic release of serotonin and norepinephrine. It tends to cause drowsiness and weight gain and is occasiona lly used to treat patients with depression and sleep disturbances.
distractor_explanations.C: Nortriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant that is used to treat major depressive disorder and is used off label for a number of conditions including chronic pain, postherpetic neuralgia, and diabetic neuropathy. It can cause drowsiness.
distractor_explanations.D: Trazodone inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and is also a potent histamine blocker. It is used to treat depression but also causes drowsiness and is used off label to treat insomnia.
distractor_explanations.E: Zaleplon binds to y-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptors and is used to treat insomnia. It is not useful in the treatment of patients with narcolepsy.

explanation.educational_objective: Narcolepsy should be suspected in patients with daytime somnolence, hypnagogic hallucinations, or cataplexy. Diagnosis can be made clinically if cataplexy is present but otherwise requires sleep latency testing, which shows a shorter time from wakefulness to the initiation of REM sleep. Treatment is initially with stimulants such as methylphenidate, which promote wakefulness Clinical
explanation.concept: Narcolepsy should be suspected in patients with daytime somnolence, hypnagogic hallucinations, or cataplexy. Diagnosis can be made clinically if cataplexy is present but otherwise requires sleep laten

vignette.presentation:
27. A 72-year-o ld right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of double vision and right-sided weakness
that began while she was eating breakfast. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Medications include glyburide and atenolol. Her
temperatu re is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, and blood pressure is 170/105 mm Hg. She is alert and oriented. Her speech is fluent
but mildly slurred. She can follow complex commands. Cranial nerve examination shows left ptosis. Adduction and elevation of the left eye are
impaired. Ocular movements are full on the right. The right pupil is 3 mm, and the left pupil is 5 mm. The right pupil reacts normally, but the left
pupil does not constrict either to direct or consensual light stimulation. There is drooping of the right side of the mouth. Muscle strength is normal in
the left upper and lower extremities and is 4/5 in the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the right and 2+ on the left.
Babinski sign is present on the right and absent on the left. There is no ataxia. Sensation is intact. Which of the following is the most likely location
of this patient's lesion?

question_stem:
the most likely location
of this patient's lesion?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient likely has a lesion of the left midbrain that affects the cerebral peduncle and the oculomotor nerve, which causes contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral oculomotor palsy, known as Weber syndrome. The cerebral peduncle refers to the anterior portion of the midbrain and includes the crus cerebri, which contains the corticospinal tract and is supplied by paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery. A brainstem lesion of the corticospinal tract leads to contralateral weakness in an upper motoneuron pattern of dysfunction (eg, spastic paralysis, Babinski sign, and hyperreflexia). The corticobulbar tract (located within the cerebral peduncle) may also be affected in Weber syndrome, leading to facial droop and weakness. The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve Ill) is located anteriorly between the two cerebral peduncles and may be affected by strokes of the paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery, leading to ipsilateral dysfunction of the extraocu lar muscles and consequent diplopia, ptosis, and primary gaze palsy along with a deficit in pupillary constriction. Cerebral infarctions, or strokes, occur as a result of ischemic or hemorrhagic loss of blood supply to the brain. Risk factors for stroke include smoking, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, carotid or intracranial atherosclerotic disease, history of hypercoagulability, atrial fibrillation, and advanced age. Classically, strokes manifest as a neurologic deficit related to the affected part of the brain.

distractor_explanations.A: Lesions of the left cerebral cortex may cause contralateral hemiparesis of the upper or lower extremities and facial weakness. However, oculomotor palsy would be atypical Clinical Correct Answer: D. This patient likely has a lesion of the left midbrain that affects the cerebral peduncle and the oculomotor nerve, which causes contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral oculomotor palsy, known as Weber syndrome. The cerebral peduncle refers to the anterior portion of the midbrain and includes the crus cerebri, which contains the corticospinal tract and is supplied by paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery. A brainstem lesion of the corticospinal tract leads to contralateral weakness in an upper motoneuron pattern of dysfunction (eg, spastic paralysis, Babinski sign, and hyperreflexia). The corticobulbar tract (located within the cerebral peduncle) may also be affected in Weber syndrome, leading to facial droop and weakness. The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve Ill) is located anteriorly between the two cerebral peduncles and may be affected by strokes of the paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery, leading to ipsilateral dysfunction of the extraocular muscles and consequent diplopia, ptosis, and primary gaze palsy along with a deficit in pupillary constriction. Cerebral infarctions, or strokes, occur as a result of ischemic or hemorrhagic loss of blood supply to the brain. Risk factors for stroke include smoking, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, carotid or intracranial atherosclerotic disease, history of hypercoagu lability, atrial fibrillation, and advanced age. Classically, strokes manifest as a neurologic deficit related to the affected part of the brain. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Lesions of the left cerebral cortex (Choice A) may cause contralateral hemiparesis of the upper or lower extremities and facial weakness. However, oculomotor palsy would be atypical. Lesions of the left internal capsule (Choice B) occur in lacunar infarcts. The internal capsule primarily contains the descending corticospinal tract, though it also contains axons of additional pathways, including third-order sensory neurons. Internal capsule lacunar infarcts can present with purely motor deficits that cause contralateral hemiparesis, ataxic hemiparesis, or clumsy hand-dysarthria. The left medulla (Choice C) contains the nuclei of multiple cranial nerves, the spinal trigeminal nucleus, solitary nucleus, vestibular nuclei, and nucleus ambiguus, as well as tracts including the sympathetic, spinothalamic, and spinocerebellar tracts. Consequently, lesions of the lower medulla may lead to ipsilateral facial numbness, taste loss in the anterior tongue, vertigo with nystagmus, dysphonia, dysarthria, dysphagia, Horner syndrome, pain and temperature sensation deficits in the contralateral body, and/or ipsilateral ataxia. This constellation of symptoms is known as Wallenberg syndrome. The left pons (Choice E) contains several cranial nerve nuclei (ie, the vestibular nuclei, facial nucleus, spinal trigeminal nucleus, cochlear nuclei) along with the spinothalamic tract, corticospinal tract, sympathetic fibers, and the middle and inferior cerebellar peduncles. Consequently, lesions of the left pons lead to vertigo, nystagmus, facial paralysis, decreased lacrimation, decreased salivation, taste loss in the anterior tongue, hearing loss, decrease in pain and temperature sensation of the contralateral body, contralateral hemiparesis, ipsilateral limb ataxia, and/or dysmetria. This constellation of symptoms is known as lateral pontine syndrome.

explanation.educational_objective: In Weber syndrome, a stroke of the paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery affects the cerebral Clinical contralateral hemiparesis and ipsilateral oculomotor palsy, known as Weber syndrome. The cerebral peduncle refers to the anterior portion of the midbrain and includes the crus cerebri, which contains the corticospinal tract and is supplied by paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery. A brainstem lesion of the corticospina l tract leads to contralateral weakness in an upper motoneuron pattern of dysfunction (eg, spastic paralysis, Babinski sign, and hyperreflexia). The corticobulbar tract (located within the cerebral peduncle) may also be affected in Weber syndrome, leading to facial droop and weakness. The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve Ill) is located anteriorly between the two cerebral peduncles and may be affected by strokes of the paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery, leading to ipsilateral dysfunction of the extraocular muscles and consequent diplopia, ptosis, and primary gaze palsy along with a deficit in pupillary constriction. Lesions of the left cerebral cortex (Choice A) may cause contralateral hemiparesis of the upper or lower extremities and facial weakness. However, oculomotor palsy would be atypical. Lesions of the left internal capsule (Choice B) occur in lacunar infarcts. The internal capsule primarily contains the descending corticospinal tract, though it also contains axons of additional pathways, including third-order sensory neurons. Internal capsule lacunar infarcts can present with purely motor deficits that cause contralateral hemiparesis, ataxic hemiparesis, or clumsy hand-dysarthria. The left medulla (Choice C) contains the nuclei of multiple cranial nerves, the spinal trigeminal nucleus, solitary nucleus, vestibular nuclei, and nucleus ambiguus, as well as tracts including the sympathetic, spinothalamic, and spinocerebella r tracts. Consequently, lesions of the lower medulla may lead to ipsilateral facial numbness, taste loss in the anterior tongue, vertigo with nystagmus, dysphonia, dysarthria, dysphagia, Horner syndrome, pain and temperature sensation deficits in the contralateral body, and/or ipsilateral ataxia. This constellation of symptoms is known as Wallenberg syndrome. The left pons (Choice E) contains several cranial nerve nuclei (ie, the vestibular nuclei, facial nucleus, spinal trigeminal nucleus, cochlear nuclei) along with the spinothalamic tract, corticospinal tract, sympathetic fibers, and the middle and inferior cerebellar peduncles. Consequently, lesions of the left pons lead to vertigo, nystagmus, facial paralysis, decreased lacrimation, decreased salivation, taste loss in the anterior tongue, hearing loss, decrease in pain and temperature sensation of the contralateral body, contralateral hemiparesis, ipsilateral limb ataxia, and/or dysmetria. This constellation of symptoms is known as lateral pontine syndrome. Educational Objective: In Weber syndrome, a stroke of the paramedian branches of the posterior cerebral artery affects the cerebral peduncle, which contains the corticospinal tract and neighboring oculomotor nerve. Patients typically present with ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy (eg, diplopia, ptosis, primary gaze palsy, pupillary constriction deficits) and contralateral hemiparesis with an upper motoneuron-pattern of dysfunction Clinical

vignette.presentation:
28. Over the past 3 months, a 40-year-o ld woman has had multiple 1- to 2-minute episodes of numbness and tingling that begin in the right hand and
then spread to the right arm and the face. Neurologic examination shows normal findings. The most likely cause is a lesion at which of the
following sites?

question_stem:
The most likely cause is a lesion at which of the
following sites?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Focal neurologic deficits that start in one area of the body and spread are suggestive of partial seizure activity. Without an alteration in level of consciousness, this would be defined as a simple partial seizure manifesting with sensory symptoms, also called a simple partial somatosensory seizure. This type of seizure is most commonly associated with lesions of the parietal lobe as a result of the involvement of the primary somatosensory cortex, which processes sensory input from the contralatera l side of the body. Patients typically present with numbness, tingling, warmth, and/or pain. Other manifestations of parietal lobe epileptic activity may include receptive aphasia, dyslexia, and other language/comp rehensio n disturbances because of involvement of Wernicke area at the junction of the parietal and temporal lobes.

distractor_explanations.A: Frontal lobe lesions more commonly present with complex partial seizures, with impaired awareness as a result of the disruption of normal frontal lobe cognitive functions. Simple partial seizure activity with motor symptoms may also occur because of involvement of the primary motor cortex. Brainstem lesions involving the medulla (Choice B), midbrain (Choice C), or pons (Choice F) may result in focal seizure activity characterized by convulsive movements; however, brainstem involvement more typically occurs with generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Occipital lobe (Choice D) lesions are uncommon causes of focal seizure activity, but typically present with visual manifestations such as visual hallucinations, cortical blindness, and deviated gaze Clinical F) Pons G) Retina H) Temporal lobe Correct Answer: E. Focal neurologic deficits that start in one area of the body and spread are suggestive of partial seizure activity. Without an alteration in level of consciousness, this would be defined as a simple partial seizure manifesting with sensory symptoms, also called a simple partial somatosensory seizure. This type of seizure is most commonly associated with lesions of the parietal lobe as a result of the involvement of the primary somatosensory cortex, which processes sensory input from the contralatera l side of the body. Patients typically present with numbness, tingling, warmth, and/or pain. Other manifestations of parietal lobe epileptic activity may include receptive aphasia, dyslexia, and other language/comprehension disturbances because of involvement of Wernicke area at the junction of the parietal and temporal lobes. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, F, G, and H. Frontal lobe (Choice A) lesions more commonly present with complex partial seizures, with impaired awareness as a result of the disruption of normal frontal lobe cognitive functions. Simple partial seizure activity with motor symptoms may also occur because of involvement of the primary motor cortex. Brainstem lesions involving the medulla (Choice B), midbrain (Choice C), or pons (Choice F) may result in focal seizure activity characterized by convulsive movements; however, brainstem involvement more typically occurs with generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Occipital lobe (Choice D) lesions are uncommon causes of focal seizure activity, but typically present with visual manifestations such as visual hallucinations, cortical blindness, and deviated gaze.
distractor_explanations.G: Retina lesions are not likely to result in epileptiform activity affecting the upper extremity. The retina is an extension of the central nervous system, and lesions may result in visual disturbances. Temporal lobe (Choice H) lesions may involve Wernicke area, the limbic system, and/or the amygdala. The temporal lobe is the most common location of focal seizure activity, typically presenting with complex partial seizures that may involve an aura, motor symptoms (especially motor automatisms such as lip-smacking or fidgeting), autonomic dysfunction, and/or confusion.

explanation.educational_objective: Focal neurologic deficits without loss of awareness are characterized as simple partial seizures. Pure sensory symptoms likely originate from an epileptiform focus or lesion in the primary somatosensory cortex located in the parietal lobe. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Focal neurologic deficits without loss of awareness are characterized as simple partial seizures. Pure sensory symptoms likely originate from an epileptiform focus or lesion in the primary somatosenso

vignette.presentation:
29. A 72-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of increasingly depressed mood, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, and a
decreased appetite resulting in a 2.3-kg (5-lb) weight loss. He was diagnosed with Parkinson disease 2 years ago. He also has hypertension and
benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medications are amlodipine, carbidopa-levodopa, and tamsulosin. He has smoked one and one-half packs of
cigarettes daily for 4 7 years. He states that he would like to stop smoking. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild
cogwhee l rigidity, resting tremor of the hands, and gait instability. On mental status examination, he has a depressed mood and forlorn affect.
Results of laboratory studies, including thyroid function tests, are within the reference ranges. Addition of which of the following is the most
appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Bupropion can be utilized in patients with Parkinson disease, major depressive disorder, and nicotine use disorder to treat depression and promote abstinence from nicotine. Depression is a common complication of Parkinson disease. Since this patient's depression began after his Parkinson disease diagnosis, his depression is likely a result of Parkinson disease and should be diagnosed as depressive disorder caused by another medical condition. Many patients with this diagnosis improve once the medical condition resolves. Since Parkinson disease does not remit, the depression should be treated pharmacologically. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are first-line medications for patients with major depressive disorder and are frequent ly utilized for patients with comorbid Parkinson disease and major depressive disorder because of their effectiveness and low risk for adverse effects. However, serotonergic medications are not effective for smoking cessation. Bupropion is an antidepressant medication that increases the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine (which targets depressive symptoms) and antagonizes the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (which targets tobacco use). Bupropion can increase blood pressure, so this patient with a history of hypertension should have his blood pressure monitored closely.

distractor_explanations.B: Citalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, duloxetine (Choice C) is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, and mirtazapine (Choice E) is a selective a -receptor antagonist and serotonin modulator. All these medications can 2 be utilized in major depressive disorder or depressive disorder caused by another medical condition (including Parkinson disease). However, none of these medications are effective for smoking cessation.
distractor_explanations.D: Lorazepam is a positive allosteric modulator of the GABAA receptor and is utilized for acute anxiety, alcohol withdrawal, and convulsions. Lorazepam alone is ineffective for depressive disorders.

explanation.educational_objective: Bupropion is an antidepressant medication that decreases dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake, and antagonizes the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. Bupropion is the medication of choice in patients with nicotine use disorder and a comorbid depressive disorder who wish to quit smoking. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Bupropion is an antidepressant medication that decreases dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake, and antagonizes the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. Bupropion is the medication of choice in patients w

vignette.presentation:
30. A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of visual hallucinations during the past 2 weeks. She has a 10-year
history of hypertension and a 5-year history of Parkinson disease. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, metoprolol, and
carbidopa-levodopa. Three weeks ago, her carbidopa-levodopa dose was increased because of decreased mobility, and metoprolol was added to
her medication regimen because of inadequate blood pressure control. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 10 years
ago. She drinks one glass of wine with dinner every night. Her temperatu re is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 58/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood
pressure is 148/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Neurologic examination shows a resting tremor of the
hands and cogwheel rigidity. Deep tendon reflexes are absent at the ankles. Her gait is shuffling. Mental status examination shows a constricted
affect. She is oriented to person but not to place or time. She can recall one of three objects after 5 minutes. She says she sees ghost-like figures
entering the room. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference range. A CT scan of the head shows mild atrophy. Which of the following
is the most likely cause of this patient's visual hallucinations?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's visual hallucinations?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Adverse effect of carbidopa-levodopa is the most likely cause of this patient's visual hallucinations. Parkinson disease is a progressive neurologic disease that manifests with bradykinesia, rigidity, masked facies, and a resting tremor. It is secondary to the destruction of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra, so pharmacotherapy focuses on replacing dopamine with carbidopa-levodopa. Frequently, early in the disease course, treatment is effective, but over time, many patients experience an "on-off'' phenomenon whereby pharmacotherapy only works for a short time after each dose before the effects dissipate. This often prompts an increase in the dose of carbidopa-levodopa, or a change in the dosing interval, but in elderly patients this can result in multiple off-target adverse effects including hallucinations. This patient has no evidence of another underlying medical illness that may cause hallucinations, so the next step should be to lower the dose of carbidopa-levodopa to resolve her hallucinations. Patients who are intolerant or refractory to pharmacotherapy should be considered for deep brain stimulation.

distractor_explanations.B: Major depressive disorder is diagnosed when patients meet criteria established in the DSM-5 including impaired sleep (either insomnia or hypersomnolence), loss of interest, guilt, loss of energy, poor concentration, poor appetite, psychomotor retardation , or suicidal ideation. This patient does not meet the criteria. \ j Clinical C) Multi-infarct (vascular) dementia D) Normal-pressure hydrocepha lus E) Progression of Parkinson disease Correct Answer: A. Adverse effect of carbidopa-levodopa is the most likely cause of this patient's visual hallucinations. Parkinson disease is a progressive neurologic disease that manifests with bradykinesia, rigidity, masked facies, and a resting tremor. It is secondary to the destruction of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra, so pharmacotherapy focuses on replacing dopamine with carbidopa-levodopa. Frequently, early in the disease course, treatment is effective, but over time, many patients experience an "on-off'' phenomenon whereby pharmacotherapy only works for a short time after each dose before the effects dissipate. This often prompts an increase in the dose of carbidopa-levodopa, or a change in the dosing interval, but in elderly patients this can result in multiple off-target adverse effects including hallucinations. This patient has no evidence of another underlying medical illness that may cause hallucinations, so the next step should be to lower the dose of carbidopa-levodopa to resolve her hallucinations. Patients who are intolerant or refractory to pharmacotherapy should be considered for deep brain stimulation. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, and E. Major depressive disorder (Choice B) is diagnosed when patients meet criteria established in the DSM-5 including impaired sleep (either insomnia or hypersomnolence), loss of interest, guilt, loss of energy, poor concentration, poor appetite, psychomotor retardation, or suicidal ideation. This patient does not meet the criteria. Multi-infarct (vascular) dementia (Choice C) presents frequently with a stepwise decline in cognitive performance over several years and occurs as a result of cumulative damage from many small ischemic strokes. It does not present with hallucinations. Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (Choice D) classically presents with enlarged ventricles on imaging with normal opening pressure on lumbar puncture, dementia, gait disturbance, and urinary incontinence. Progression of Parkinson disease (Choice E) is a possibility in this patient as evidenced by her worsening bradykinesia, but this is less likely to be the cause of her hallucinations than the time-correla ted effect of increasing the doses of medications with known hallucinogenic adverse effects.

explanation.educational_objective: Carbidopa- levodopa is the primary treatment for Parkinson disease. As the disease progresses, patients often require increasingly higher doses, which can cause hallucinations. If this occurs, the dose should be lowered. An alternative therapy for Parkinson disease includes deep brain stimulation. ., Exam Section : Item 31 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Carbidopa- levodopa is the primary treatment for Parkinson disease. As the disease progresses, patients often require increasingly higher doses, which can cause hallucinations. If this occurs, the dos

vignette.presentation:
31. A 77-year-o ld man comes to the physician because of increasingly severe low back pain for 3 months. He has had poor control of bowel and
bladder function for 2 weeks. He fell yesterday on his way to the bathroom. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 60 years. Examination
shows marked weakness of the lower extremities, normal upper extremity strength, bilateral brisk deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities, a
sensory level at T9, and a flaccid anal sphincter. There is tenderness over the lower thoracic spine. Babinski sign is present. Which of the following
is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Epidural metastatic carcinoma resulting in spinal cord impingement is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with bowel and bladder incontinence, bilateral lower extremity weakness with hyperreflexia, and a sensory level at T9 that has developed over the preceding 3 weeks. Vertebral masses may be the first presenting sign of a systemic malignancy, or they may be a late complication of metastatic disease. In either scenario, large masses can result in compression of the spinal cord at any segment, with subsequent sensory and motor deficits below the affected segment. In this instance, the sensory level at T9 likely indicates the presence of a mass at or just above the T9 vertebra l body in the epidura l space, with compression of the spinal cord at that level. Masses related to cancer must be distinguished from abscesses or hematomas, as the treatment between the entities differs significantly. Depending upon the type of cancer, steroids or radiation may be an initial option to reduce the inflammation associated with malignant compression of the spinal cord. In many cases, surgical decompression is required.

distractor_explanations.A: Carcinomatous meningitis can occur as a result of metastatic spread of a primary malignancy to the meninges around the brain, but it would present with headache and often with cranial nerve deficits. It does not present with neurologic evidence of spinal cord dysfunction. Cervical spondylosis (Choice B) refers to gradual, age-related degenerative changes of the cervical spine with osteophyte development Exam Section : Item 31 of 50 Clinical motor deficits below the affected segment. In this instance, the sensory level at T9 likely indicates the presence of a mass at or just above the T9 vertebral body in the epidural space, with compression of the spinal cord at that level. Masses related to cancer must be distinguished from abscesses or hematomas, as the treatment between the entities differs significantly. Depending upon the type of cancer, steroids or radiation may be an initial option to reduce the inflammation associated with malignant compression of the spinal cord. In many cases, surgical decompression is required. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, E, F, G, and H. Carcinomatous meningitis (Choice A) can occur as a result of metastatic spread of a primary malignancy to the meninges around the brain, but it would present with headache and often with cranial nerve deficits. It does not present with neurologic evidence of spinal cord dysfunction. Cervical spondylosis (Choice B) refers to gradual, age-related degenerative changes of the cervical spine with osteophyte development and vertebral body displacement that can impinge on the spinal cord. Symptoms may include neck pain, radiculopathy, or when severe, myelopathy. Lumbar spinal stenosis (Choice D) classically causes low back pain and neurogenic claudication whereby patients experience lower extremity pain with prolonged standing or walking. The pain classically improves with bending forward. Myasthenia gravis (Choice E) is an autoimmune disease caused most often by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor at the neuromuscu lar junction. Symptoms include generalized weakness that worsens throughout the day and ptosis.
distractor_explanations.F: Syringomyelia refers to a fluid collection that develops in the central spinal cord, most often between C2 and T9 and can cause sensory loss to pain and temperature or weakness in the limbs of the upper and lower extremities, depending upon its location. Vibration and position sense are generally preserved. Tabes dorsalis (Choice G) is a late finding of neurosyphilis and affects the dorsal columns of the spinal cord. Symptoms include sensory disturbances and lancinating pain that may last for minutes to days. Argyll Robertson pupils are often seen in conjunction with this disorder. Transverse myelitis (Choice H) refers to an inflammatory syndrome involving a particular spinal cord segment leading to weakness and sensory disturbances below the level of the lesion. It often follows an infection and symptoms reach maximum intensity within days, not weeks, and gradually improve.

explanation.educational_objective: Lung, breast, and prostate are the most common malignancies that have a predilection for the spine. Metastatic disease within the epidural space can cause compression of the spinal cord, with consequent development of a distinct sensory level, bowel and bladder incontinence, and weakness below the level of the lesion. Depending upon the type of malignancy, steroids, radiation, and/or surgical intervention may be required to relieve the compression Clinical
explanation.concept: Lung, breast, and prostate are the most common malignancies that have a predilection for the spine. Metastatic disease within the epidural space can cause compression of the spinal cord, with conseque

vignette.presentation:
32. A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friend 30 minutes after being found unconscious in his bed. The patient lives
alone in a trailer park, and his friend says he was well the night before. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He
does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. He appears well nourished. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are
20/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. The nail beds and oral mucosa are pink. Neurologic examination shows no meningismus. The pupils
are 4 mm and sluggishly reactive. The doll's eye (oculocephalic) reflex is intact. There is no verbalization or eye opening in response to painful
stimuli. He withdraws all extremities symmetrically to painful stimuli. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ throughout. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally.
Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a Pco of 30 mm Hg and Po of
2 2
80 mm Hg. In addition to supportive care, which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's condition?

question_stem: the most appropriate therapy for this patient's condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning occurs as a consequence of inhaling the gas, often because of its generation in an area of poor ventilation (eg, a garage with door shut and car running, a space heater in a poorly-ventilated room, a malfunctioning basement furnace). CO is a byproduct of combustion. When inhaled, it avidly crosses the pulmonary capillary membrane and tightly binds hemoglobin, inducing a conformationa l change in the molecule and preventing the binding of oxygen. CO has an affinity for hemoglobin that is hundreds of times greater than that of oxygen, readily displacing oxygen from heme. CO also has affinity with the mitochondrial electron transport chain, thus, in addition to hypoxemia resulting from interference with oxygen carrying capacity, cells may not be able to make use of the oxygen that they do receive via aerobic metabolism. As a result, anaerobic metabolism dominates, and lactic acidosis caused by hypoxia ensues. Symptoms of CO poisoning include headache, loss of consciousness, dizziness, vomiting, and fatigue; in severe cases, seizures, dysrhythmias, coma, and death may occur. Examination may show red skin. Treatment for CO poisoning begins with the administration of 100% oxygen regardless of pulse oximetry readings, and if any neurologic symptoms or signs of end-organ dysfunction are present, as in this case, hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be indicated.

distractor_explanations.B: Methylene blue is an antidote for methemoglobinemia; it serves to reduce iron in methemoglobin to Fe2 restoring its ability +, to bind and transport oxygen. Methemoglobinemia may occur secondary to the use of nitrites and anesthetics.
distractor_explanations.C: Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist used in the treatment of opiate overdose, which presents with bradypnea and miosis. Naloxone has also been used to treat clonidine overdose.
distractor_explanations.D: Physostigmine is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that is most commonly used in myasthenia gravis but may have a role in the treatment of anticholinergic toxicity as it can cross the blood-brain barrier. Anticholinergic toxicity is characterized by pupillary dilation, dry mouth, tachycardia, and urinary retention. Vitamin B (thiamine) (Choice E) is used to treat thiamine deficiency such as beriberi or Wernicke encephalopathy. Dry beriberi 1 presents as peripheral neuropathy with mental status change. Wet beriberi exhibits a dilated cardiomyopathy leading to heart failure. Wernicke encephalopathy classically presents as confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia.

explanation.educational_objective: Carbon monoxide (CO) has an affinity for hemoglobin that is hundreds of times greater than that of oxygen, readily displacing oxygen from heme. Treatment for CO poisoning begins with the administration of 100% oxygen and may require hyperbaric oxygen if symptoms are severe. ., Clinical
explanation.concept: Carbon monoxide (CO) has an affinity for hemoglobin that is hundreds of times greater than that of oxygen, readily displacing oxygen from heme. Treatment for CO poisoning begins with the administratio

vignette.presentation:
33. A 5-year-old girl has the insidious onset of a clumsy gait over the past 3 months. Examination shows pes cavus of the left foot. There is
generalized diminished girth of the left leg, and a decreased tendon reflex of the left ankle. The tendon reflexes at the knees are brisk. There is a
sacral tuft of hair. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tethered spinal cord, a defect in neural development whereby a caudal portion of the spinal cord becomes tethered to fixed fibrous structures that cause traction on the cord as the patient grows, is the most likely diagnosis. The filum terminale is a band of tissue that stretches between the caudal portion of the spinal cord and the sacrum, and persistent tethering of the spinal cord results in stretching as the child develops and axial growth occurs. Depending upon the severity, symptoms may present at infancy or can develop many years later, but progressive lower extremity neurologic dysfunction is typical as the spinal cord stretches and bends during normal activity. Sensory and gait abnormalities are typical, and bladder or bowel incontinence may also occur. Low back pain that worsens with activity and pain in the perineum can also occur. Clues to diagnosis include a tuft of hair over the sacrum or the presence of hemangiomas or dimples in the same region. Early detection and surgical intervention can improve symptoms and halt the progression of neurologic dysfunction.

distractor_explanations.A: telangiectasia is a genetic disorder that leads to early ataxia with progressively worsening gross and fine motor capabilities as children reach school age. Other findings include oculocutaneous telangiectasias and immunodeficiency. Friedreich ataxia (Choice B) is caused by a loss of function mutation in the frataxin gene resulting from a trinucleotide repeat. Patients usually present in adolescence with progressive ataxia of all limbs and dysarthria. Distal sensory loss and dysphagia may also be seen. Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Choice C) has a diverse presentation but patients usually develop systemic symptoms including fevers and rash in addition to arthritis, which may affect nearly any joint. It does not present with asymmetric gait abnormalities or hyperreflexia. Spastic diplegia (Choice D) is a subtype of cerebral palsy and presents with symmetric spasticity of the lower extremities with associated sensory loss. In rare cases, the upper extremities may be involved, and intellectual disability can occur Clinical C) Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis D) Spastic diplegia E) Tethered spinal cord Correct Answer: E. Tethered spinal cord, a defect in neural development whereby a caudal portion of the spinal cord becomes tethered to fixed fibrous structures that cause traction on the cord as the patient grows, is the most likely diagnosis. The filum terminale is a band of tissue that stretches between the caudal portion of the spinal cord and the sacrum, and persistent tethering of the spinal cord results in stretching as the child develops and axial growth occurs. Depending upon the severity, symptoms may present at infancy or can develop many years later, but progressive lower extremity neurologic dysfunction is typical as the spinal cord stretches and bends during normal activity. Sensory and gait abnormalities are typical, and bladder or bowel incontinence may also occur. Low back pain that worsens with activity and pain in the perineum can also occur. Clues to diagnosis include a tuft of hair over the sacrum or the presence of hemangiomas or dimples in the same region. Early detection and surgical intervention can improve symptoms and halt the progression of neurologic dysfunction. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and D. Ataxia-telangiectasia (Choice A) is a genetic disorder that leads to early ataxia with progressively worsening gross and fine motor capabilities as children reach school age. Other findings include oculocutaneous telangiectasias and immunodeficiency. Friedreich ataxia (Choice B) is caused by a loss of function mutation in the frataxin gene resulting from a trinucleotide repeat. Patients usually present in adolescence with progressive ataxia of all limbs and dysarthria. Distal sensory loss and dysphagia may also be seen. Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Choice C) has a diverse presentation but patients usually develop systemic symptoms including fevers and rash in addition to arthritis, which may affect nearly any joint. It does not present with asymmetric gait abnormalities or hyperreflexia. Spastic diplegia (Choice D) is a subtype of cerebral palsy and presents with symmetric spasticity of the lower extremities with associated sensory loss. In rare cases, the upper extremities may be involved, and intellectual disability can occur.

explanation.educational_objective: Tethered cord syndrome occurs when a caudal portion of the spinal cord remains attached to fibrous tissue near the sacrum leading to progressive stretching of the spinal cord as the child grows. It presents with either symmetric or asymmetric weakness and sensory changes in the lower extremities, and clues to the diagnosis include the presence of a sacral dimple or tuft of hair. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
34. A 42-year-old woman with AIDS comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressive right-sided weakness, slurred speech, and
headache. She is right-handed. Funduscopic examination shows papilledema. Neurologic examination shows aphasia, right homonymous
hemianopia, and right-sided spastic weakness. A CT scan of the head with contrast shows multiple small ring-enhancing lesions with surrounding
edema and mass effect in the left frontal, right occipital, and left parietal lobes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Toxop/asma gondii is an intracellular protozoan parasite. Transmission can occur through the ingestion of oocysts from cat feces or infected meat, direct transmission between a mother and fetus, or from organ transplantation, which leads to invasion followed by dissemination of the parasite where it typically lies dormant. It is a ubiquitous organism and nearly 10% of individuals will be seropositive for T gondii, but the parasite does not usually cause severe disease in immunocompetent individuals. In patients with HIV infection and CD4+ T-lymphocyte counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, however, reactivation can occur with several distinct clinical syndromes of which cerebral toxoplasmosis results in the most morbidity. Cerebral toxoplasmosis typically presents with multiple ring enhancing lesions scattered throughout the brain. Seizures, focal neurologic deficits, and systemic symptoms are common, as are signs of increased intracranial pressure. Patients with HIV infection and positive Toxop/asma lgG antibodies are typically treated empirically with a sulfonamide and pyrimethamine if cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected, but confirmatory diagnosis occurs through a brain biopsy, which will show a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells, along with the presence of the T gondii organism. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an AIDS-defining disease.

distractor_explanations.A: Cryptococcosis is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, an encapsulated fungus and opportunistic pathogen in immunocompromised patients. It can cause cryptococca l meningitis, encephalitis, and pulmonary cryptococcosis. Meningoencephalitis presents subacutely with fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity, often accompanied by cough and shortness of breath caused by concurrent pulmonary infection. Focal neurologic deficits and mass lesions on neuroimaging are rare.
distractor_explanations.B: Cysticercosis is caused by Taenia so/ium and presents with headache, seizures, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show cystic, ring-enhancing, calcified lesions in the brain parenchyma, meninges, ventricles, spinal cord, and/or orbit. It less commonly presents with focal neurologic deficits such as those seen in this patient. Primary central nervous system lymphoma (Choice C) is a rare form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs in immunocomp romised patients and presents with focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. It appears similar to toxoplasmosis on neuroimaging but is much less common than toxoplasmos is. If this patient failed to improve with pyrimethamine and sulfonamide therapy, central nervous system lymphoma would be the likely diagnosis. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (Choice D) is a demyelinating disease of the central nervous system caused by human polyomavirus 2 (formerly JC virus), most commonly in immunocompromised patients. It presents subacutely with altered mental status, ataxia, vision changes, and hemiparesis. Lesions occur primarily in the white matter and are not enhanced with contrast; rather, they appear as hypodense lesions.

explanation.educational_objective: Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxop/asma gondii, an intracellular protozoan parasite that is most commonly transmitted via the ingestion of cat feces or infected meat. In immunocompromised patients, particularly AIDS patients with CD4+ T lymphocyte counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, it can cause cerebral toxoplasmos is, which presents with seizures, focal neurologic deficits, systemic symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show multiple ring-enhancing lesions, and treatment is with pyrimethamine and sulfonamide therapy Clinical

vignette.presentation:
35. A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of progressive numbness and weakness of his legs. Six
years ago, he had non-Hodgkin lymphoma treated successful ly with chemotherapy and radiation therapy. He is currently taking no medications.
Cranial nerve examination shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength is intact in the upper extremities but 3/5 in the proximal lower extremities and
4/5 in the distal lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ in the upper extremities and 3+ in the lower extremities. Babinski sign is present
bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick is decreased below the level of the nipples, and sensation to vibration is decreased over the feet and ankles.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Metastatic spinal cord compression occurs most commonly in prostate, lung, or breast cancer, although it can occur with any malignancy. It is generally caused by vertebral bony metastases that tend to occur in the vertebral body, particularly of the thoracic spine. Its presentation depends on the level of the lesion and the degree of spinal cord compression. Symptoms include back pain, which is often worse at night or with lying down, muscle weakness, sensory abnormalities, bladder or bowel dysfunction, and gait instability. It will generally present with an upper motoneuron pattern of injury in the lower extremities with hyperreflexia and positive Babinski signs, as in this patient, assuming the compression is in the thoracic or upper lumbar region. Ascending numbness or paresthesias are also common. Diagnosis is classically made utilizing MRI of the spine. Patients may be treated with glucocorticoids, radiation therapy, and/or surgical decompression and spine stabilization.

distractor_explanations.A: induced polyneuropathy classically presents with sensory loss and paresthesias in the distal extremities that ascend in a "stocking and glove" pattern. Most chemotherapy-induced polyneuropathy will improve over time after chemotherapy is stopped, making this a less likely explanation for this patient's acute onset of symptoms. Guillain-Barre syndrome (Choice B) is caused by autoimmune-mediated nerve destruction following a systemic infection, such as Campy/obacter jejuni. It classically presents with ascending paralysis with absent deep tendon reflexes that begins in the lower extremities. It can also ascend to involve the upper extremities, diaphragm, and cranial nerves in some patients.
distractor_explanations.D: Myopathy is caused by a disorder affecting the muscle itself, rather than the nerves that innervate it. Generally, it presents with symmetric proximal muscle weakness in response to genetic metabolic abnormalities, toxins (eg, alcohol or medications), endocrine dysfunction (eg, hypothyroidism), or inflammation. It does not present with sensory changes. Paraneoplastic neuropathy (Choice E) is an immune-mediated destruction of neuronal tissue in the presence of an underlying malignancy. It can present in a variety of ways, such as an acute sensorimotor radiculopathy, chronic sensorimotor neuropathy, or autonomic neuropathy. This patient's symptoms would be most similar to an acute sensorimotor radiculopathy, but this syndrome presents with a predominant ascending motor paralysis.

explanation.educational_objective: Metastatic spinal cord compression presents in malignancy with back pain worse at night, muscle weakness, sensory abnormalities, bladder or bowel dysfunction, and gait instability. Physical examination may disclose hyperreflexia, Babinski sign, and changes in perception of pinprick or vibratory sensation. Treatment includes glucocorticoids, radiation therapy, and/or surgical decompression and spine stabilization. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
36. A previously healthy 62-year-o ld man has had progressive difficulty with speech and swallowing over the past year. Symptoms were subtle at first,
and only he and his family noticed a problem. Recently, two ham radio colleagues have commented that he sounds different on the air. He has
also noticed that he has difficulty manipulating objects in the left hand, walking smoothly, and going up and down stairs. He has not had any
difficulty with his thought processes. Examination shows slow deliberate speech with mild dysarthria. Cranial nerves are otherwise normal. There
is wasting of intrinsic hand muscles and distal weakness in the left hand. Gait is slightly broad-based, but Romberg sign is absent. Deep tendon
reflexes are 3+ in the left upper extremity, 2+ in the right upper extremity, and 3+ in the lower extremities. Jaw jerk is hyperactive . His serum
potassium concentrat ion is 3.2 mEq/L. An x-ray of the chest shows normal findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Alcoholic rhabdomyolysis J) Hypokalemic periodic paralysis
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis K) Hypothyroid myopathy
Becker muscular dystrophy L) Lumbar spinal stenos is
Epidural metastatic carcinoma P) Sensorimotor periphera l neuropathy
Epstein-Barr virus infection Q) Spinal cord compression

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is likely given insidious onset of upper and lower motoneuron deficits. ALS is caused by the progressive destruction of motoneurons. Patients may develop asymmetric weakness of the extremities. Unilateral hand weakness, foot drop, and bulbar symptoms (eg, dysphagia, voice changes) may occur simultaneous ly. On physical examination, the presence of both upper motoneuron signs such as hyperreflexia and spasticity, combined with lower motoneuron signs such as hyporeflexia suggests the diagnosis. Parkinsonian features such as masked facies, tremor, and shuffling gait may occur, as can autonomic dysfunction. Eventually, patients develop respiratory insufficiency. The clinical progression is relentless and results in death.

vignette.presentation:
37. A 27-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 4-week history of difficulty with speech and weakness of his right leg. He has a 5-year
history of HIV infection treated with antiretroviral therapy. On admission, his temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). Examination shows thrush. There is mild
nonfluent aphasia. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the right lower extremity. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the right lower extremity and 2+ elsewhere.
Babinski sign is present on the right. An MRI of the brain shows six ring-enhancing lesions in the cerebral hemispheres bilaterally; the largest
lesion is in the left frontal lobe. Some of the lesions have surrounding edema. Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine therapy is started. Two weeks later,
there is no improvement in his symptoms. A second MRI of the brain shows no decrease in the size of the lesions, and some have increased in
size. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma is a rare variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs most commonly in immunocompromised patients. It can occur in the brain, spinal cord, leptomeninges, or eyes. Presenting symptoms include focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, headache, nausea, emesis). In immunocompetent patients, neuroimaging will most commonly show a solitary, hypodense periventricular mass with well defined borders and mild surrounding edema. In immunocompromised patients, however, the development of primary CNS lymphoma is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, with additional risk factors in HIV including a decreased CD4+ T lymphocyte count, increased viral load, and chronic co-infection with hepatitis B or C virus. Imaging in immunocompromised patients more commonly shows multifocal disease, numerous, ring- or heterogeneously enhancing lesions throughout the corpus callosum, periventricular areas, and periependyma l regions. The diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow cytometry or cytology, with evidence of EBV DNA in the CSF supporting the diagnosis. Treatment typically consists of high-dose and generally intrathecal chemotherapeutics and antiretroviral therapy.

distractor_explanations.A: abscesses of the brain can occur in immunocompromised patients. These are typically microabscesses that can lead to the development of encephalopathy with altered mental status and are seen on MRI as small, ring-enhancing lesions often with a hemorrhagic component. However, these patients commonly present with fever, nuchal rigidity, and headache, which this patient does not demonstrate Exam Section : Item 37 of 50 Clinical Central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma is a rare variant of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs most commonly in immunocompromised patients. It can occur in the brain, spinal cord, leptomeninges, or eyes. Presenting symptoms include focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, headache, nausea, emesis). In immunocompetent patients, neuroimaging will most commonly show a solitary, hypodense periventricular mass with well defined borders and mild surrounding edema. In immunocompromised patients, however, the development of primary CNS lymphoma is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection, with additional risk factors in HIV including a decreased CD4+ T lymphocyte count, increased viral load, and chronic co-infection with hepatitis B or C virus. Imaging in immunocompromised patients more commonly shows multifocal disease, numerous, ring- or heterogeneously enhancing lesions throughout the corpus callosum, periventricular areas, and periependyma l regions. The diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow cytometry or cytology, with evidence of EBV DNA in the CSF supporting the diagnosis. Treatment typically consists of high-dose and generally intrathecal chemotherapeutics and antiretroviral therapy. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, E, and F. Candida! abscesses (Choice A) of the brain can occur in immunocompromised patients. These are typically microabscesses that can lead to the development of encephalopathy with altered mental status and are seen on MRI as small, ring-enhancing lesions often with a hemorrhagic component. However, these patients commonly present with fever, nuchal rigidity, and headache, which this patient does not demonstrate. Cryptococcal meningitis (Choice C) presents subacutely with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, and photophobia, as well as encephalopathy in severe cases. It is most common in immunocompromised patients. Neuroimaging typically shows no abnormalities, and the diagnosis is made with serum cryptococcal antigen and CSF evaluation. Listeria! meningoencephalitis (Choice D) occurs in patients at the extremes of age (neonates, elderly) and in those that are immunocompromised. It classically presents with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, altered mental status, cranial nerve palsies, and focal neurologic deficits. While Listeria monocytogenes can cause brain abscesses, this is exceedingly rare. Nocardial abscesses (Choice E) can occur in immunocompromised patients. They classically present with fever, headache, signs of meningeal irritation, and focal neurologic deficits. It more commonly occurs in a concurrent pulmonary infection, which is associated with fever, weight loss, cough, hemoptysis, shortness of breath, and chest pain. Toxoplasma encephalitis (Choice F) commonly presents with headache, fever, and neurologic deficits, as well as altered mental status. Toxoplasma lesions appear as ring-enhancing lesions on brain MRI, similar to CNS lymphoma. However, toxoplasma encephalitis would be expected to improve with sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine.

explanation.educational_objective: CNS lymphoma is a rare form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma that occurs in immunocompromised patients with focal neurologic deficits, vision changes, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show ring enhancing lesions that do not improve with sulfadiazine or pyrimethamine therapy Clinical

vignette.presentation:
38. A 67-year-old woman comes for a routine health maintenance examination. She is concerned about developing dementia because she lives alone;
she does not want to be a burden to her children. Her father was just diagnosed with dementia, Alzheimer type. She takes no medications other
than hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. Her blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following
measures is most likely to decrease her risk for multi-infarct (vascular) dementia?

question_stem: most likely to decrease her risk for multi-infarct (vascular) dementia?

choices.text: Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementation
Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementatio n

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Vascular dementia is the second most common form of dementia after Alzheimer type, characterized by stepwise cognitive decline following recurrent cerebral infarctions (strokes). The rate of decline and specific symptoms depend on the regions of the brain affected, and patients typically develop cognitive impairment, motor dysfunction, and behavioral changes as the disease progresses. Risk factors include age, hypertension, obesity, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and prior cerebrovascular accidents. Diagnosis is made clinically with support of neuroimaging demonstrating cerebral ischemic changes. Risk factor reduction is the primary approach to prevention. Continued control of blood pressure is most likely to decrease the risk for this patient developing vascular dementia.

distractor_explanations.D: Daily fish oil supplementation and daily vitamin E supplementation (Choice F) have also been shown to have a mild protective effect. However, control of blood pressure has a stronger association with cardiovascular risk reduction. Daily aspirin prophylaxis (Choice C) is recommended for patients who have existing clinically significant cardiovascular disease (such as history of a myocardial infarction or cerebrovascular event). It is not likely to significantly lower the risk for vascular dementia in this patient. Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementation (Choice E) is recommended for women who are postmenopausal, patients taking chronic systemic corticosteroids, and patients with advanced renal disease to reduce the risk for osteoporosis and fragility fractures. Educational Ob'ective: The risk for develo in vascular dementia can be reduced b the mana ement of modifiable risk factors for Clinical measures is most likely to decrease her risk for multi-infarct (vascular) dementia? A) Continued control of blood pressure B) Regular aerobic exercise C) Daily aspirin prophylaxis D) Daily fish oil supplementation E) Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementatio n F) Daily vitamin E supplementatio n Correct Answer: A. Vascular dementia is the second most common form of dementia after Alzheimer type, characterized by stepwise cognitive decline following recurrent cerebral infarctions (strokes). The rate of decline and specific symptoms depend on the regions of the brain affected, and patients typically develop cognitive impairment, motor dysfunction, and behavioral changes as the disease progresses. Risk factors include age, hypertension, obesity, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and prior cerebrovascular accidents. Diagnosis is made clinically with support of neuroimaging demonstrating cerebral ischemic changes. Risk factor reduction is the primary approach to prevention. Continued control of blood pressure is most likely to decrease the risk for this patient developing vascular dementia. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, E, and F. Efforts to reduce overall cardiovascular risk factors should be encouraged, which includes regular aerobic exercise (Choice B). Daily fish oil supplementation (Choice D) and daily vitamin E supplementation (Choice F) have also been shown to have a mild protective effect. However, control of blood pressure has a stronger association with cardiovascular risk reduction. Daily aspirin prophylaxis (Choice C) is recommended for patients who have existing clinically significant cardiovascula r disease (such as history of a myocardial infarction or cerebrovascular event). It is not likely to significantly lower the risk for vascular dementia in this patient. Daily vitamin D and calcium supplementation (Choice E) is recommended for women who are postmenopausal, patients taking chronic systemic corticosteroids, and patients with advanced renal disease to reduce the risk for osteoporosis and fragility fractures.

explanation.educational_objective: The risk for developing vascular dementia can be reduced by the management of modifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease. This includes the control of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, obesity, and antiplatelet agents in the setting of prior cardiovascular disease. ., Clinical

vignette.presentation:
39. A previously healthy 45-year-o ld woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after she lost consciousness while shopping in a
department store; on regaining consciousness, she had a severe headache and photophobia. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min,
respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examinat ion shows slight neck stiffness with flexion. There is pain with lateral
deviation of the eyes. Neurologic examination shows no other abnormalities. A CT scan of the head shows no lesions or evidence of bleeding.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharging the patient with analgesic therapy

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) refers to bleeding into the subarachnoid space and can be caused by aneurysmal or non-aneurysma l rupture of an artery in the subarachnoid space. Patients typically present with an acute, severe headache (often described as the worst headache of their life), along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases. Fever can be associated with SAH and is associated with worse outcomes. CT scan of the head typically shows hyperdense blood products in the cerebral sulci and basal cisterns. However, the sensitivity of CT scan for SAH is lower with small volume bleeding or a delayed presentation. If there is strong suspicion for SAH with a negative CT scan, a lumbar puncture can be performed, which may show red blood cells or xanthochromia, which represents hemoglobin degradation products. As the blood products circulate within the subarachnoid space, complications include the development of communicating and/or obstructive hydrocephalus in the acute stage, along with the potential for re-bleeding and vasospasm in the days following the initial bleed. It is a neurosurgical emergency that may be fatal if progressive or untreated.

distractor_explanations.A: Admission for observation would not be indicated until further workup is performed to evaluate for subarachnoid hemorrhage. First, a subarachnoid hemorrhage should be investigated by lumbar puncture, and if findings are consistent with subarachnoid hemorrhage, vessel imaging should occur to evaluate for aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Discharging the patient with analgesic therapy (Choice B) would be dangerous in the care of this patient, as further evaluation for subarachnoid hemorrhage is indicated. The patient is at risk for hydrocephalus, vasospasm, rebleeding, or severe hemorrhage after a sentinel bleed. r ~ - - , r - - - , Clinical ' E) Lumbar puncture Correct Answer: E. Admission for observation (Choice A) would not be indicated until further workup is performed to evaluate for subarachnoid hemorrhage. First, a subarachnoid hemorrhage should be investigated by lumbar puncture, and if findings are consistent with subarachnoid hemorrhage, vessel imaging should occur to evaluate for aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation. Discharging the patient with analgesic therapy (Choice B) would be dangerous in the care of this patient, as further evaluation for subarachnoid hemorrhage is indicated. The patient is at risk for hydrocephalus, vasospasm, rebleeding, or severe hemorrhage after a sentinel bleed. Carotid ultrasonography (Choice C) is frequently used for the evaluation of atherosclerosis at the carotid arteries. Carotid artery atherosclerosis increases risk for ischemic stroke as plaque breakage can travel to and cause blockage within cerebral arteries. This patient does not have focal neurologic deficits or imaging indicating an ischemic stroke, so carotid ultrasonography would not be the next step in management. MRI of the brain (Choice D) would be indicated for evaluation of ischemic stroke or tumor. The patient does not display any focal neurologic symptoms or aphasia to suggest an ischemic stroke. Tumors can also cause headaches, but typically chronic or subacute headaches, associated with vomiting and papilledema.

explanation.educational_objective: Patients with SAH typically present with an acute, severe headache (often described as the worst headache of their life), along with neck stiffness, photophobia, and possible stupor or coma in severe cases.
