vignette.presentation:
9. A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of stiffness and pain of her neck, shoulders, and hips. She has difficulty
dressing herself and combing her hair in the morning. She also has had generalized weakness, malaise, and a low-grade fever. She has had a
2.3-kg (5-lb) weight loss during the past month despite no changes in diet. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is occasiona l
acetaminophen for pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows pitting edema of the hands and the dorsal aspects of the feet.
Range of motion of the neck, shoulders, and hips is limited. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 110 mm/h. Additiona l laboratory findings, including
her serum thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration, are within the reference ranges. X-rays of the shoulders and feet show no abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory condition in which aching and stiffness develop in the shoulders, hip, and neck. The most common risk factors are age (older than 50 years) and being female. It is also frequently associated with giant cell, or temporal arteritis, which presents with unilateral headache and vision loss, if untreated. Other inflammatory signs, such as malaise and fever, are often present, though localized muscle weakness is not typically seen. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates increased inflammatory markers, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein, and thrombocytosis. Polymyalgia rheumatica is responsive to glucocorticoids, which are the first-line therapy for the disease. Low-dose prednisone is the treatment of choice.

distractor_explanations.A: Bursitis is inflammation of one or more bursae and is manifested by pain and swelling over a single joint. Some examples include the subacromial bursa which can cause pain in the shoulder, the trochanteric bursa which can cause pain over the lateral aspect of the hip, and the olecranon bursa which can cause pain and swelling posterior to the elbow. When inflamed or injured, fluid can collect inside the potential space of the bursa causing swelling, which can be appreciated on examination as a fluctuant, tender, circumscribed mass. Muscle stiffness is not a typical feature.
distractor_explanations.B: Dermatomyositis and polymyositis (Choice E) are autoimmune inflammatory myopathies characterized by muscle weakness, rather than stiffness, of the proximal muscles. Dermatomyositis additionally demonstrates cutaneous findings including a light pink- or heliotrope-colored rash on the eyelids and Gottron papules on the dorsal fingers. Unlike PMR, fibromyalgia (Choice C) affects middle-aged women at various anatomica l sites in conjunction with anxiety, stress, and point tenderness. ESR is normal. This patient's limited involvement to the pelvic and hip girdles along with other inflammatory symptoms including generalized weakness, malaise, and fever suggest a diagnosis of PMR over fibromya lgia. Rheumatoid arthritis (Choice F) is a common autoimmune disease characterized by joint destruction, pain, and upregulation of immunomodulatory cytokines. Muscle pain and stiffness are not typical features.

explanation.educational_objective: Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory condition in which aching and stiffness develop in the muscles of the hip and shoulder girdles. Low-dose prednisone is the treatment of choice Exam Section : Item 10 of 50 Clinical 'f 10. A 57-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because of daily headaches for 8 months. The headaches are localized to the right temple and usually worsen throughout the day. At times, the headaches are exacerbated by chewing. She has a history of migraines but has not had one since menopause 6 years ago. She recently divorced and is under a great deal of stress at work. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her temperatu re is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 144/86 mm Hg. Examination shows pain with movement of the jaw and tenderness under the right zygoma tic arch. The nasal mucosa is normal. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 20 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Bacterial meningitis B) Cluster headache C) Migraine D) Sinusitis E) Temporal arteritis F) Temporomandibu lar joint syndrome G) Tension-type headache H) Trigeminal neuralgia Correct Answer: F. The temporomandibu lar joint (TMJ) forms the articulation between the mandibular condyle and the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone. TMJ syndrome occurs because of a combination of structural damage to the TMJ and a variety of neurologic and psychological factors related to pain and stress. Patients usually present with unilatera l, dull, occasionally sharp or stabbing pain near the TMJ or anterior to the auricle that is exacerbated by chewing or jaw clenching. Patients may also experience popping or clicking sensations associated with movement of the jaw and a decreased range of jaw motion. Treatment includes physical therapy, cognitive behavior therapy or biofeedback therapy to treat underlying stress, and pharmacologic therapy including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or tricyclic antidepressants. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, G, and H. Bacterial meningitis (Choice A) presents with fever and signs of meningeal irritation (nausea, irritability, confusion, anorexia, headache, and nuchal rigidity). This patient's absence of fever and meningismus renders this diagnosis unlikely. Cluster headache (Choice B) are primary headaches that typical ly present with short-lived, unilateral, severe, often lancinating pain in the orbital, supraorbital, or tempora l region of the head and are accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (eg, lacrimation, mydriasis, perspiration, nasal congestion) Exam Section : Item 10 of 50 Clinical Correct Answer: F. The temporomandibu lar joint (TMJ) forms the articulation between the mandibular condyle and the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone. TMJ syndrome occurs because of a combination of structural damage to the TMJ and a variety of neurologic and psychological factors related to pain and stress. Patients usually present with unilateral, dull, occasionally sharp or stabbing pain near the TMJ or anterior to the auricle that is exacerbated by chewing or jaw clenching. Patients may also experience popping or clicking sensations associated with movement of the jaw and a decreased range of jaw motion. Treatment includes physical therapy, cognitive behavior therapy or biofeedback therapy to treat underlying stress, and pharmacologic therapy including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or tricyclic antidepressants. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, G, and H. Bacterial meningitis (Choice A) presents with fever and signs of meningeal irritation (nausea, irritability, confusion, anorexia, headache, and nuchal rigidity). This patient's absence of fever and meningismus renders this diagnosis unlikely. Cluster headache (Choice B) are primary headaches that typically present with short-lived, unilateral, severe, often lancinating pain in the orbital, supraorbital, or temporal region of the head and are accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (eg, lacrimation, mydriasis, perspiration, nasal congestion). Migraines (Choice C) are a common cause of headache in adult patients. They may present with visual aura of scintillating scotoma or fortification spectra but are not associated with focal tenderness of the jaw or pain with chewing. Sinusitis (Choice D) may be associated with bilateral, pressure-like, periorbital headaches and nasal congestion. Patients may experience focal tenderness and tenderness to percussion overlying the affected sinus (typically overlying the brow or maxilla) but rarely experience focal jaw tenderness overlying the TMJ. Temporal arteritis (Choice E), also known as giant cell arteritis, is a vasculitis of medium and large vessels in elderly patients and commonly presents with systemic symptoms, headache, jaw claudication, proximal muscle stiffness, and sudden, irreversible vision loss. This patient's chronic course, lack of associated systemic symptoms, and normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate render this diagnosis less likely. Tension-type headache (Choice G) typically presents with bilateral dull, pressure-like or band-like pain across the bilateral frontal and temporal areas. It does not tend to present with focal tenderness of the jaw or pain with chewing. Trigeminal neuralgia (Choice H), also known as tic douloureux, presents with brief, recurrent, sudden episodes of pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve. This is typically triggered by minor stimulation to the affected area, such as light touch, cold air, talking, or brushing one's teeth. Treatment includes physical therapy, cognitive behavior therapy or biofeedback therapy to treat underlying stress, and pharmacologic therapy including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or tricyclic antidepressants. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, G, and H. Bacterial meningitis (Choice A) presents with fever and signs of meningeal irritation (nausea, irritability, confusion, anorexia, headache, and nuchal rigidity). This patient's absence of fever and meningismus renders this diagnosis unlikely. Cluster headache (Choice B) are primary headaches that typically present with short-lived, unilateral, severe, often lancinating pain in the orbital, supraorbital, or temporal region of the head and are accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (eg, lacrimation, mydriasis, perspiration, nasal congestion). Migraines (Choice C) are a common cause of headache in adult patients. They may present with visual aura of scintillating scotoma or fortification spectra but are not associated with focal tenderness of the jaw or pain with chewing. Sinusitis (Choice D) may be associated with bilateral, pressure-like, periorbital headaches and nasal congestion. Patients may experience focal tenderness and tenderness to percussion overlying the affected sinus (typically overlying the brow or maxilla) but rarely experience focal jaw tenderness overlying the TMJ. Temporal arteritis (Choice E), also known as giant cell arteritis, is a vasculitis of medium and large vessels in elderly patients and commonly presents with systemic symptoms, headache, jaw claudication, proximal muscle stiffness, and sudden, irreversible vision loss. This patient's chronic course, lack of associated systemic symptoms, and normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate render this diagnosis less likely. Tension-type headache (Choice G) typically presents with bilateral dull, pressure-like or band-like pain across the bilateral frontal and temporal areas. It does not tend to present with focal tenderness of the jaw or pain with chewing. Trigeminal neuralgia (Choice H), also known as tic douloureux, presents with brief, recurrent, sudden episodes of pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve. This is typically triggered by minor stimulation to the affected area, such as light touch, cold air, talking, or brushing one's teeth. Patients often describe the pain as sharp, stabbing, or electric. Patients present with unilateral preauricular pain exacerbated by chewing or jaw clenching, decreased jaw range of motion, and popping or clicking sensations associated with jaw movement. Treatment includes physical therapy, cognitive behavior therapy or biofeedback therapy to treat underlying stress, and pharmacologic therapy including nonsteroida l anti-inflammatory drugs or tricyclic antidepressants Exam Section : Item 11 of 50 Clinical

vignette.presentation:
10. A 57-year-o ld woman comes to the physician because of daily headaches for 8 months. The headaches are localized to the right temple and
usually worsen throughout the day. At times, the headaches are exacerbated by chewing. She has a history of migraines but has not had one
since menopause 6 years ago. She recently divorced and is under a great deal of stress at work. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily
for 25 years. Her temperatu re is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 144/86 mm Hg. Examination shows pain with movement of
the jaw and tenderness under the right zygoma tic arch. The nasal mucosa is normal. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 20 mm/h. Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The temporomandibu lar joint (TMJ) forms the articulation between the mandibular condyle and the glenoid fossa of the temporal bone. TMJ syndrome occurs because of a combination of structural damage to the TMJ and a variety of neurologic and psychological factors related to pain and stress. Patients usually present with unilatera l, dull, occasionally sharp or stabbing pain near the TMJ or anterior to the auricle that is exacerbated by chewing or jaw clenching. Patients may also experience popping or clicking sensations associated with movement of the jaw and a decreased range of jaw motion. Treatment includes physical therapy, cognitive behavior therapy or biofeedback therapy to treat underlying stress, and pharmacologic therapy including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or tricyclic antidepressants.

vignette.presentation:
11. A 42-year-old man comes to the physician with his wife because of a 6-month history of increasing clumsiness and a 1-month history of irritability.
His wife has noticed jerkiness of his limbs when he walks down stairs or walks quickly. During the past month, he has had the same involuntary
movements at rest after stressful days at work. He has not had fever, chills, or night sweats. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use
illicit drugs. He goes camping several times yearly. He does not appear to be in distress. Examination shows involuntary movements of the right
upper extremity, which the patient is able to suppress when made aware of them. His gait is ataxic. Additional testing is most likely to show which
of the following abnormalities?

question_stem:
most likely to show which
of the following abnormalities?

choices.text: Atrophy of the caudate nucleus on brain imaging
Increased oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid
Increased serum acetylcholine esterase inhibitor concentration
Increased oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid
Increased serum acetylcholine esterase inhibitor concentration

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Atrophy of the caudate nucleus on brain imaging would be expected in this patient who most likely has Huntington disease, a progressive neurodegenerat ive condition that arises from misfolded proteins as the result of a trinucleotide expansion in the Huntington gene. Patients develop choreiform movements, which are characterized by involuntary flailing motions of the upper extremities. Eventually, these motor disturbances and others, including ataxic gait, greatly interfere with daily life. Concomitant psychiatric disturbances such as emotional !ability, anxiety, depression, and psychosis may also occur in the later stages of the disease. Many patients exhibit a family history of similar symptoms, but the disease can also arise de novo. Since this is an autosomal dominant disease, there is a 50% chance that an affected individual will pass it on to offspring. Anticipation, whereby symptoms manifest at progressive ly earlier ages and/or more severely in subsequent generations, is also typical of this disease.

distractor_explanations.B: concentration is not correct. High concentrations of MMA are seen in vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency, which can lead to subacute combined degeneration of the spine. 12 Dilated ventricles on brain imaging (Choice C) are seen in patients with hydrocephalus, which can either be communicating or noncommunicating. Patients can present with headaches, nausea, vomiting, or gait instability but would not typically exhibit choreiform movemen.ts Exam Section : Item 11 of 50 Clinical J. • • • .. .. • • D) Increased oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid E) Increased serum acetylcholine esterase inhibitor concentration F) Positive serum lgM Lyme titer Correct Answer: A. Atrophy of the caudate nucleus on brain imaging would be expected in this patient who most likely has Huntington disease, a progressive neurodegenerative condition that arises from misfolded proteins as the result of a trinucleotide expansion in the Huntington gene. Patients develop choreiform movements, which are characterized by involuntary flailing motions of the upper extremities. Eventually, these motor disturbances and others, including ataxic gait, greatly interfere with daily life. Concomitant psychiatric disturbances such as emotional !ability, anxiety, depression, and psychosis may also occur in the later stages of the disease. Many patients exhibit a family history of similar symptoms, but the disease can also arise de novo. Since this is an autosomal dominant disease, there is a 50% chance that an affected individual will pass it on to offspring. Anticipation, whereby symptoms manifest at progressive ly earlier ages and/or more severely in subsequent generations, is also typical of this disease. Incorrect Answers: B, C, D, E, and F. Decreased serum methylma lonic acid (MMA) concentration (Choice B) is not correct. High concentrations of MMA are seen in vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency, which can lead to subacute combined degeneration of the spine. 12 Dilated ventricles on brain imaging (Choice C) are seen in patients with hydrocepha lus, which can either be communicating or noncommunicating. Patients can present with headaches, nausea, vomiting, or gait instability but would not typically exhibit choreiform movements. Increased oligoclona l bands in cerebrospinal fluid (Choice D) is characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS). Patients can develop a variety of sensory and motor symptoms but characteristical ly present with internuclear ophthalmoplegia. They do not exhibit choreiform movements. Increased serum acetylcholine esterase inhibitor concentration (Choice E) is seen in patients with organophosphate poisoning. Cholinergic toxicity presents with excess salivation, bradycardia, emesis, and central nervous system depression. Positive serum lgM Lyme titer (Choice F) can be seen in acute Lyme disease, which presents with erythema migrans following a tick bite. Late neurologic manifestations of Lyme disease include cranial nerve palsies, but choreiform movements would not be expected.

explanation.educational_objective: Huntington disease presents with progressive neurodegeneration leading to choreiform movement, ataxia, and neuropsychiatric decline. On MRI, the caudate nucleus often appears atrophic Exam Section : Item 12 of 50 Clinical
explanation.concept: Huntington disease presents with progressive neurodegeneration leading to choreiform movement, ataxia, and neuropsychiatric decline. On MRI, the caudate nucleus often appears atrophic Exam Section : I

vignette.presentation:
12. A previously healthy 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of difficulty communicat ing. His wife
reports that when he awoke this morning, he seemed slightly confused and "did not make sense." He has hyperlipidemia treated with simvastatin.
He does not appear to be in distress. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m2 . His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F),
pulse is 85/min and irregular, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Examination shows mild right pronator drift. During the
examination, he is attentive but has some difficulty naming objects correctly and following two-step commands. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation.
Which of the following is this patient's greatest risk factor for his neurologic condition?

choices.text: Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community
Brachia! plexus compression G) Median nerve compress ion at the wrist
Central nervous system compression H) Radial nerve compression at the elbow
Central nervous system demyelination I) Radial nerve compression at the spiral groove
Central nervous system ischemia J) Ulnar nerve compression at the elbow
Cervical nerve root compression K) Ulnar nerve compression at the wrist
Median nerve compress ion at the elbow

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The acute onset of focal neurologic deficits, motor weakness, confusion, and dysphasia is concerning for a thromboembo lic cerebral infarction, or stroke. Atrial fibrillation is a major independent risk factor for strokes, and stroke prevention is an essential aspect of management. The loss of coordinated atrial contraction in this dysrhythmia results in blood stasis within the atrial compartment and promotion of thrombus formation. Embolism to the cerebral arteries results in ischemic stroke. The presence of right-sided hemiplegia and expressive dysphasia are suggestive of a lesion involving the left middle cerebral artery distribution. The middle cerebral arteries are the most common cerebral arteries involved in acute thromboembolic stroke.

distractor_explanations.E: and weight are all additional risk factors for cardiovascular disease and stroke. Other risk factors include tobacco use, diabetes mellitus, presence of mechanical heart valves, hypercoagu lable conditions, patent foramen ovale (allowing for passage of paradoxical venous thromboembo lism to the systemic circulation), heart failure with severely decreased ejection fraction, and a personal or family history of prior stroke. The presence of atrial fibrillation in this patient is the greatest risk factor for a stroke.

explanation.educational_objective: Atrial fibrillation is a major independent risk factor for ischemic stroke. Preventative anticoagulation should be considered for patients with additional risk factors, such as congestive heart failure, hypertension, advanced age, diabetes mellitus, prior stroke or transient ischemic attack, and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease Clinical "t 13. A 77-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because he has become increasingly forgetful during the past 6 months. His daughter states that his short-term memory is quite impaired, and he says that he is frustrated with his memory. He lives alone and is able to perform activities of daily living independently. On questioning, he reports a 1-month history of a mild nonproductive cough, constipation, mild pain in his hips with movement, mild numbness of the toes of both feet, and a few episodes of urinary incontinence. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. His wife died 6 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mm Hg. Muscle strength is normal. Cranial nerves are intact. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. Sensation to vibration is mildly decreased over the distal lower extremities. Proprioception is intact. His gait is wide based, and he has impaired tandem walking. His Mini-Mental State Examination score is 24/30; he recalls one of three objects after 5 minutes. An MRI of the brain shows slightly enlarged ventricles with minimal cortical atrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A) Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community B) Discontinuation of atorvastatin therapy C) Discontinuation of metformin therapy D) Addition of donepezil therapy E) Addition of paroxetine therapy F) Lumbar puncture ~- Correct Answer: F. The patient is presenting with findings concerning for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), with the characteristic combination of dementia (eg, frontal executive dysfunction), gait instability, and urinary incontinence. NPH refers to a type of communicating (nonobstructive) hydrocephalus in which the ventricles are enlarged, leading to damage of the white matter tracts connecting the frontal lobes and basal ganglia. Signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, papilledema, postural headaches) are typically absent. Many cases of NPH are idiopathic, though some are secondary to a defect in cerebrospinal fluid drainage from the ventricles as a result of scarring or obstruction of the ventricular lining from prior hemorrhage or meningitis. The diagnosis is primarily clinical, although ventriculomegaly on brain imaging is suggestive. The most appropriate next step in management is a lumbar puncture to assess the opening pressure and clinical response to removing cerebrospinal fluid. Placement of a ventricular shunt may be needed for long-term management. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and E. Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community (Choice A) is inappropriate prior to a thorough evaluation for intervenable causes. Recovery of executive function in patients with NPH that has progressed to dementia is uncertain. It may be appropriate to refer to assisted living if the patient continues to decline and is unable to manage activities of daily living. . r ~- - - , r - - - , Clinical Please Walt F) Lumbar puncture Correct Answer: F. The patient is presenting with findings concerning for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), with the characteristic combination of dementia (eg, frontal executive dysfunction), gait instability, and urinary incontinence. NPH refers to a type of communicating (nonobstructive) hydrocepha lus in which the ventricles are enlarged, leading to damage of the white matter tracts connecting the frontal lobes and basal ganglia. Signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, papilledema, postural headaches) are typically absent. Many cases of NPH are idiopathic, though some are secondary to a defect in cerebrospinal fluid drainage from the ventricles as a result of scarring or obstruction of the ventricular lining from prior hemorrhage or meningitis. The diagnosis is primarily clinical, although ventriculomegaly on brain imaging is suggestive. The most appropriate next step in management is a lumbar puncture to assess the opening pressure and clinical response to removing cerebrospinal fluid. Placement of a ventricular shunt may be needed for long-term management. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and E. Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community (Choice A) is inappropriate prior to a thorough evaluation for intervenable causes. Recovery of executive function in patients with NPH that has progressed to dementia is uncertain. It may be appropriate to refer to assisted living if the patient continues to decline and is unable to manage activities of daily living. Discontinuation of atorvastatin therapy (Choice B) and discontinuation of metformin therapy (Choice C) may be considered later in the patient's course depending on the degree of recovery. Medications that confer long-term benefits are often discontinued in patients with progressive dementia or life-limiting conditions to avoid unnecessary side effects and pill burden. Addition of donepezil therapy (Choice D) may be considered in the future if the patient's cognitive symptoms do not improve. The next best initial step in management for this patient is to perform a lumbar puncture and assess his clinical response to the removal of cerebrospinal fluid. Addition of paroxetine therapy (Choice E) would not be indicated currently. Cognitive impairment and memory disturbances may be manifestations of depression, especially in older adults, and patients should be screened for depression as part of the initial evaluation. Initiating an antidepressant would not be appropriate at this time. Educational Objective: The triad of cognitive impairment, urinary incontinence, and gait instability should raise concern for normal pressure hydrocephalus. Initial evaluation should include neuroimaging and a lumbar puncture to assess the patient's opening pressure and clinical response to the removal of cerebrospinal fluid Exam Section : Item 14 of 50 Clinical "t 14. A previously healthy 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of intermittent pain and tingling that radiates from his right shoulder blade to his right thumb and index finger. These symptoms worsen with coughing and sneezing. There is no history of neck, shoulder, or arm injury. His pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnorma lities. The cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep te ndon reflexes are 1 + in the right biceps muscle and 2+ elsewhere. Babinski sign is absent. Sensation to pinprick is decreased over the dorsal aspect of the right thumb and index finger. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms? A) Brachia! plexus compression G) Median nerve compress ion at the wrist B) Central nervous system compression H) Radial nerve compression at the elbow C) Central nervous system demyelination I) Radial nerve compression at the spiral groove D) Central nervous system ischemia J) Ulnar nerve compression at the elbow E) Cervical nerve root compression K) Ulnar nerve compression at the wrist F) Median nerve compress ion at the elbow Correct Answer: E. Cervical nerve root compression explains this patient's symptoms of cervical radiculopathy. Radiculopathy refers to pathology affecting a specific spinal nerve root that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesias, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 radiculopathy will result in pain that radiates from the neck into the arm along with decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and the lateral two digits. Additional ly, C6 radiculopathy causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension, and a diminished or absent biceps reflex. Radiculopathy symptoms may worsen with activities that increase pressure such as coughing and sneezing. Radiculopathy may be caused by spondylosis (degenerative changes of the spine), disc herniation, infection, tumor, demyelination, or infarction. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by the efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, F, G, H, I, J, and K. Brachia! plexus compression (Choice A) typically presents with weakness, numbness, and/or paresthesias of the majority of the upper extremity. Brachia! plexus compression typical ly affects multiple nerve roots and motor dysfunction typically predominates over sensory dysfunction and pain early in the disease process. Central nervous system (CNS) compression (Choice B), demyelination (Choice C), or ischemia (Choice D) typically affects major central nervous system tracts, leading to sensory, motor, and/or autonomic dysfunction contralateral to the lesion. This patient instead demonstrates deficits that are localized to a single spinal nerve root Exam Section : Item 14 of 50 Clinical Cervical nerve root compression explains this patient's symptoms of cervical radiculopathy. Radiculopathy refers to pathology affecting a specific spinal nerve root that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesias, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 radiculopathy will result in pain that radiates from the neck into the arm along with decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and the lateral two digits. Additional ly, C6 radiculopathy causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension, and a diminished or absent biceps reflex. Radiculopathy symptoms may worsen with activities that increase pressure such as coughing and sneezing. Radiculopathy may be caused by spondylosis (degenerative changes of the spine), disc herniation, infection, tumor, demyelination, or infarction. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by the efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, F, G, H, I, J, and K. Brachia! plexus compression (Choice A) typically presents with weakness, numbness, and/or paresthesias of the majority of the upper extremity. Brachia! plexus compression typically affects multiple nerve roots and motor dysfunction typically predominates over sensory dysfunction and pain early in the disease process. Central nervous system (CNS) compression (Choice B), demyelination (Choice C), or ischemia (Choice D) typically affects major central nervous system tracts, leading to sensory, motor, and/or autonomic dysfunction contralateral to the lesion. This patient instead demonstrates deficits that are localized to a single spina l nerve root. Median nerve compression at the elbow (Choice F) typically causes anterior interosseous syndrome, a pure motor neuropathy leading to a decreased ability to pinch the first two digits and form a fist. Median nerve compression at the wrist (Choice G) initially leads to pain and paresthesias in the first three digits and may progress to hand weakness, known as carpal tunnel syndrome. Radial nerve compression at the elbow (Choice H) presents primarily with pain of the elbow and dorsal forearm that may radiate to the dorsum of the fingers. Motor and sensory symptoms are less prominent. Radial nerve compression at the spiral groove (Choice I) results in extensor muscle dysfunction of the elbow, wrist, and fingers. Numbness, pain, and/or paresthesias from the triceps to the fingers may occur. The triceps reflex, not the biceps reflex, would be affected. While ulnar nerve compression at the elbow (Choice J) typically results in numbness and paresthesias of the medial hand and wrist, ulnar nerve compression at the wrist (Choice K) typically leads to weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles and the consequent loss of hand dexterity. Patients may demonstrate a decreased ability to abduct and adduct the digits. Educationa l Objective: Radiculopathy refers to pathology affecting a specific spinal nerve root that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesias, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 radiculopathy will cause decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and the lateral two digits. Additionally, C6 radiculopathy causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension, along with an absent biceps reflex Clinical "t 15. A 67-year-old man with hypertension is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a stroke. Examination shows Horner syndrome and paralysis of the palate on the right. Sensation is decreased to pain over the right side of the face and left side of the body, and sensation is absent to hot and cold over the right face and left side of the body. There is no paralysis of the extremities. Which of the following is the most likely site of infarction? A) Right brachium pontis B) Right lateral medulla C) Right midbrain D) Right temporal lobe E) Right thalamus Correct Answer: B. Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome is caused by occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery, leading to an ischemic stroke of the lateral medulla. Five main structures are affected, which include the nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nuclei, lateral spinothalamic tract, spinal trigeminal nucleus, sympathetic fibers, and inferior cerebellar peduncle. Loss of the nucleus ambiguus leads to dysphagia, a decreased gag reflex, and hoarseness. The vestibular nucleus loss causes vomiting, vertigo, and nystagmus. The contralateral body and ipsilateral face will develop decreased pain and temperature sensation from involvement of the lateral spinothalamic tract. Horner syndrome may result if the sympathetic fibers are damaged. Additiona lly, ataxia and dysmetria from the involvement of the cerebellar peduncles will also be present. However, a patient with lateral medullary syndrome may not necessarily demonstrate all of these findings in equal proportion, as in this case. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. The brachium pontis (Choice A), or middle cerebellar peduncles projecting from the pons, may be affected by ischemic events involving the anterior inferior cerebellar artery. Similar to lateral medullary syndrome, symptoms of an infarct involving the brachium pontis include ataxia and dysmetria, which are absent in this case. Infarction of the midbrain (Choice C) occurs when the basilar artery becomes occluded. This would impact the oculomotor and trochlear nerves. This patient does not demonstrate any eye movement impairment. Infarction of the right temporal lobe (Choice D), depending on the side of the patient's dominant hemisphere, may impact regions such as the Wernicke area of speech and Meyer loop of the visual pathway. As well, it may impact the primary auditory cortex, resulting in varying degrees of hearing impairment depending on the extent of infarction. Clinical Please Walt .. E) Right thalamus Correct Answer: B. Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome is caused by occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery, leading to an ischemic stroke of the lateral medulla. Five main structures are affected, which include the nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nuclei, lateral spinothalamic tract, spinal trigeminal nucleus, sympathetic fibers, and inferior cerebellar peduncle. Loss of the nucleus ambiguus leads to dysphagia, a decreased gag reflex, and hoarseness. The vestibular nucleus loss causes vomiting, vertigo, and nystagmus. The contralateral body and ipsilateral face will develop decreased pain and temperature sensation from involvement of the lateral spinothalamic tract. Horner syndrome may result if the sympathetic fibers are damaged. Additiona lly, ataxia and dysmetria from the involvement of the cerebellar peduncles will also be present. However, a patient with lateral medullary syndrome may not necessarily demonstrate all of these findings in equal proportion, as in this case. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. The brachium pontis (Choice A), or middle cerebellar peduncles projecting from the pons, may be affected by ischemic events involving the anterior inferior cerebellar artery. Similar to lateral medullary syndrome, symptoms of an infarct involving the brachium pontis include ataxia and dysmetria, which are absent in this case. Infarction of the midbrain (Choice C) occurs when the basilar artery becomes occluded. This would impact the oculomotor and trochlear nerves. This patient does not demonstrate any eye movement impairment. Infarction of the right temporal lobe (Choice D), depending on the side of the patient's dominant hemisphere, may impact regions such as the Wernicke area of speech and Meyer loop of the visual pathway. As well, it may impact the primary auditory cortex, resulting in varying degrees of hearing impairment depending on the extent of infarction. Infarction of the right thalamus (Choice E) may develop from occlusion of one of four different arteries, the tuberothalamic artery, paramedian artery, inferolateral artery, or posterior choroidal artery. Depending on the artery involved, symptoms may range from cognitive behavioral disturbances and memory deficits, to sensorimotor impairment and visual field defects. When the right thalamus is involved, hemineglect is typically also present. Educational Objective: Lateral medullary syndrome is caused by occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. Symptoms include a combination of dysphagia, decreased gag reflex, hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus, decreased pain and temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralatera l body, Horner syndrome, ataxia, and dysmetria. ., Exam Section : Item 16 of 50 Clinical A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 4-hour history of unsteady gait and two episodes of vomiting. Three weeks ago, she had an upper respiratory tract infection that did not require treatment. There is no history of trauma or evidence of toxic ingestion. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36. 7°C (98°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Examination shows slight horizontal nystagmus. Funduscopic examination shows no abnorma lities. The patient is able to sit without support but is unable to walk without support. Deep tendon reflexes are normal, and sensation is intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A) Re-examination in 24 hours B) Complete blood count C) CT scan of the head D) EEG E) Lumbar puncture Correct Answer: C. The patient is showing signs and symptoms concerning for cerebellar ataxia, including gait disturbance and nystagmus. Other associated findings may include dysarthria, speech abnormalities, impaired coordination, vomiting, and headache. Patients typically do not present with a fever, meningismus, or seizures. Acute cerebellar ataxia usually occurs following an acute febrile illness in children under 6 years of age. In the setting of an acute presentation with neurologic deficits, CT scan of the head is effective to evaluate for acute intracranial hemorrhage, tumor, or hydrocephalus that may require emergent management. Incorrect Answers: A, B, D, and E. Re-examination in 24 hours (Choice A) would not be appropriate, as the patient is showing concerning neurologic findings that should be evaluated urgently. Complete blood count (Choice B) could be helpful in evaluating for infection or anemia, neither of which would be the likely cause of the patient's cerebellar neurologic symptoms. An EEG (Choice D) would be helpful in evaluating seizures, which are typically characterized by involuntary rhythmic movements, lapse of consciousness, a posticta l state, and may be accompanied by tongue biting and/or incontinence. This patient's symptoms are taking place while she is awake, alert, and following commands, making seizures unlikely. A lumbar puncture (Choice E) would be the test of choice to evaluate for meningitis. Meningitis is characterized by fever, neck rigidity, and headache. While meningitis can cause focal neurologic deficits, they are typically cranial nerve abnormalities. In addition, this patient is not showing associated signs of meningitis. r ~, - . r,

vignette.presentation:
13. A 77-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because he has become increasingly forgetful during the past 6 months. His
daughter states that his short-term memory is quite impaired, and he says that he is frustrated with his memory. He lives alone and is able to
perform activities of daily living independently. On questioning, he reports a 1-month history of a mild nonproductive cough, constipation, mild pain
in his hips with movement, mild numbness of the toes of both feet, and a few episodes of urinary incontinence. He has hypertension,
hyperlipidemia, and well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. His wife
died 6 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood
pressure is 128/72 mm Hg. Muscle strength is normal. Cranial nerves are intact. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. Sensation to vibration is mildly
decreased over the distal lower extremities. Proprioception is intact. His gait is wide based, and he has impaired tandem walking. His Mini-Mental
State Examination score is 24/30; he recalls one of three objects after 5 minutes. An MRI of the brain shows slightly enlarged ventricles with
minimal cortical atrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The patient is presenting with findings concerning for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), with the characteristic combination of dementia (eg, frontal executive dysfunction), gait instability, and urinary incontinence. NPH refers to a type of communicating (nonobstructive) hydrocephalus in which the ventricles are enlarged, leading to damage of the white matter tracts connecting the frontal lobes and basal ganglia. Signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, papilledema, postural headaches) are typically absent. Many cases of NPH are idiopathic, though some are secondary to a defect in cerebrospinal fluid drainage from the ventricles as a result of scarring or obstruction of the ventricular lining from prior hemorrhage or meningitis. The diagnosis is primarily clinical, although ventriculomegaly on brain imaging is suggestive. The most appropriate next step in management is a lumbar puncture to assess the opening pressure and clinical response to removing cerebrospinal fluid. Placement of a ventricular shunt may be needed for long-term management.

distractor_explanations.A: Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community is inappropriate prior to a thorough evaluation for intervenable causes. Recovery of executive function in patients with NPH that has progressed to dementia is uncertain. It may be appropriate to refer to assisted living if the patient continues to decline and is unable to manage activities of daily living. . r ~- - - , r - - - , Clinical Please Walt F) Lumbar puncture Correct Answer: F. The patient is presenting with findings concerning for normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), with the characteristic combination of dementia (eg, frontal executive dysfunction), gait instability, and urinary incontinence. NPH refers to a type of communicating (nonobstructive) hydrocepha lus in which the ventricles are enlarged, leading to damage of the white matter tracts connecting the frontal lobes and basal ganglia. Signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, papilledema, postural headaches) are typically absent. Many cases of NPH are idiopathic, though some are secondary to a defect in cerebrospinal fluid drainage from the ventricles as a result of scarring or obstruction of the ventricular lining from prior hemorrhage or meningitis. The diagnosis is primarily clinical, although ventriculomegaly on brain imaging is suggestive. The most appropriate next step in management is a lumbar puncture to assess the opening pressure and clinical response to removing cerebrospinal fluid. Placement of a ventricular shunt may be needed for long-term management. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and E. Recommendation that the patient move to an assisted living community (Choice A) is inappropriate prior to a thorough evaluation for intervenable causes. Recovery of executive function in patients with NPH that has progressed to dementia is uncertain. It may be appropriate to refer to assisted living if the patient continues to decline and is unable to manage activities of daily living. Discontinuation of atorvastatin therapy (Choice B) and discontinuation of metformin therapy (Choice C) may be considered later in the patient's course depending on the degree of recovery. Medications that confer long-term benefits are often discontinued in patients with progressive dementia or life-limiting conditions to avoid unnecessary side effects and pill burden. Addition of donepezil therapy (Choice D) may be considered in the future if the patient's cognitive symptoms do not improve. The next best initial step in management for this patient is to perform a lumbar puncture and assess his clinical response to the removal of cerebrospinal fluid. Addition of paroxetine therapy (Choice E) would not be indicated currently. Cognitive impairment and memory disturbances may be manifestations of depression, especially in older adults, and patients should be screened for depression as part of the initial evaluation. Initiating an antidepressant would not be appropriate at this time.

explanation.educational_objective: The triad of cognitive impairment, urinary incontinence, and gait instability should raise concern for normal pressure hydrocephalus. Initial evaluation should include neuroimaging and a lumbar puncture to assess the patient's opening pressure and clinical response to the removal of cerebrospinal fluid Exam Section : Item 14 of 50 Clinical "t

vignette.presentation:
14. A previously healthy 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of intermittent pain and tingling that radiates from his
right shoulder blade to his right thumb and index finger. These symptoms worsen with coughing and sneezing. There is no history of neck,
shoulder, or arm injury. His pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnorma lities. The cranial
nerves are intact. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep te ndon reflexes are 1 + in the right biceps muscle and 2+ elsewhere. Babinski
sign is absent. Sensation to pinprick is decreased over the dorsal aspect of the right thumb and index finger. Which of the following is the most
likely mechanism of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Brachia! plexus compression G) Median nerve compress ion at the wrist
Central nervous system compression H) Radial nerve compression at the elbow
Central nervous system demyelination I) Radial nerve compression at the spiral groove
Central nervous system ischemia J) Ulnar nerve compression at the elbow
Cervical nerve root compression K) Ulnar nerve compression at the wrist
Median nerve compress ion at the elbow

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cervical nerve root compression explains this patient's symptoms of cervical radiculopathy. Radiculopathy refers to pathology affecting a specific spinal nerve root that leads to weakness, numbness, paresthesias, and pain in the dermatomal and myotomal distribution that correlates to the affected root. C6 radiculopathy will result in pain that radiates from the neck into the arm along with decreased sensation, pain, and/or paresthesia in the lateral forearm and the lateral two digits. Additional ly, C6 radiculopathy causes motor dysfunction of elbow flexion and wrist extension, and a diminished or absent biceps reflex. Radiculopathy symptoms may worsen with activities that increase pressure such as coughing and sneezing. Radiculopathy may be caused by spondylosis (degenerative changes of the spine), disc herniation, infection, tumor, demyelination, or infarction. Dermatomes and myotomes are components of the embryonic somite, a paired segment of paraxial mesoderm. When fully developed, the dermatome is an area of skin whose afferent fibers travel within a single spinal nerve, and myotome is a group of muscles innervated by the efferent fibers from a single spinal nerve.

vignette.presentation:
15. A 67-year-old man with hypertension is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a stroke. Examination shows Horner syndrome and
paralysis of the palate on the right. Sensation is decreased to pain over the right side of the face and left side of the body, and sensation is absent
to hot and cold over the right face and left side of the body. There is no paralysis of the extremities. Which of the following is the most likely site of
infarction?

question_stem:
the most likely site of
infarction?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome is caused by occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery, leading to an ischemic stroke of the lateral medulla. Five main structures are affected, which include the nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nuclei, lateral spinothalamic tract, spinal trigeminal nucleus, sympathetic fibers, and inferior cerebellar peduncle. Loss of the nucleus ambiguus leads to dysphagia, a decreased gag reflex, and hoarseness. The vestibular nucleus loss causes vomiting, vertigo, and nystagmus. The contralateral body and ipsilateral face will develop decreased pain and temperature sensation from involvement of the lateral spinothalamic tract. Horner syndrome may result if the sympathetic fibers are damaged. Additiona lly, ataxia and dysmetria from the involvement of the cerebellar peduncles will also be present. However, a patient with lateral medullary syndrome may not necessarily demonstrate all of these findings in equal proportion, as in this case.

distractor_explanations.C: Infarction of the midbrain occurs when the basilar artery becomes occluded. This would impact the oculomotor and trochlear nerves. This patient does not demonstrate any eye movement impairment. Infarction of the right temporal lobe (Choice D), depending on the side of the patient's dominant hemisphere, may impact regions such as the Wernicke area of speech and Meyer loop of the visual pathway. As well, it may impact the primary auditory cortex, resulting in varying degrees of hearing impairment depending on the extent of infarction. However, a patient with lateral medullary syndrome may not necessarily demonstrate all of these findings in equal proportion, as in this case. Incorrect Answers: A, C, D, and E. The brachium pontis (Choice A), or middle cerebellar peduncles projecting from the pons, may be affected by ischemic events involving the anterior inferior cerebellar artery. Similar to lateral medullary syndrome, symptoms of an infarct involving the brachium pontis include ataxia and dysmetria, which are absent in this case. Infarction of the midbrain (Choice C) occurs when the basilar artery becomes occluded. This would impact the oculomotor and trochlear nerves. This patient does not demonstrate any eye movement impairment. Infarction of the right temporal lobe (Choice D), depending on the side of the patient's dominant hemisphere, may impact regions such as the Wernicke area of speech and Meyer loop of the visual pathway. As well, it may impact the primary auditory cortex, resulting in varying degrees of hearing impairment depending on the extent of infarction. Infarction of the right thalamus (Choice E) may develop from occlusion of one of four different arteries, the tuberothalamic artery, paramedian artery, inferolateral artery, or posterior choroidal artery. Depending on the artery involved, symptoms may range from cognitive behavioral disturbances and memory deficits, to sensorimotor impairment and visual field defects. When the right thalamus is involved, hemineglect is typically also present.

vignette.presentation:
17. A 37-year-old woman with a 10-year history of HIV infection comes to the physician because of headache and fever for 2 days. Her temperature is
38.9°C (102°F). Examination shows confusion and mild weakness of the left upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are increased, and
Babinski sign is present on the left. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 4/mm3 (Normal~500), and plasma HIV viral load is 60,000 copies/ml. Which
of the following is the most likely finding on MRI of the brain?

question_stem: the most likely finding on MRI of the brain?

choices.text: Diffuse leukoaraiosis with periventricular white matter changes
Markedly enlarged sulci with generalized loss of brain matter
Markedly enlarged ventricles with minimal changes in sulci
Mass lesion within the substance of the right frontal cortex with shift to the left of midline structures
Opaque mass over convexity of left frontal cortex with compress ion of brain substance

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Toxop/asma gondii is an intracellular protozoan parasite. Transmission can occur through the ingestion of oocysts from cat feces or infected meat, direct transmission between a mother and fetus, or from organ transplantation, which leads to invasion followed by dissemination of the parasite where it typically lies dormant. It is a ubiquitous organism and nearly 10% of individuals will be seropositive for T gondii, but the parasite does not usually cause severe disease in immunocompetent individuals. In patients with HIV infection and CD4+ cell counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, however, reactivation can occur with several distinct clinical syndromes of which cerebral toxoplasmosis results in the most morbidity. Cerebral toxoplasmosis typically presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions within the substance of the cerebral cortex, most commonly the frontal and parietal lobes, although single lesions can occur. It is commonly associated with cerebral edema, which may result in mass effect and shifting of adjacent structures. Seizures, focal neurologic deficits, and systemic symptoms are common, as are signs of increased intracranial pressure. Patients with HIV and positive toxoplasma lgG antibodies are typically treated empirically with a sulfonamide and pyrimethamine if cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected. If necessary, the confirmatory diagnosis occurs through a brain biopsy, which will demonstrate a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells, along with the presence of the T gondii organisms. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an AIDS defining disease.

distractor_explanations.A: Diffuse leukoaraiosis with periventricular white matter changes describes hyperintense signal alterations on MRI in the white matter surrounding the lateral ventricles. It is associated with chronic vascular pathology, such as hypertension, diabetes, and vascular dementia. Markedly enlarged sulci with generalized loss of brain matter (Choice B) occurs in cerebral atrophy associated with age, dementia, and alcohol use disorder. This patient with HIV and focal neurologic deficit more likely has an opportunistic infection of the central nervous Exam Section : Item 17 of 50 Clinical Please Walt Toxop/asma gondii is an intracellular protozoan parasite. Transmission can occur through the ingestion of oocysts from cat feces or infected meat, direct transmission between a mother and fetus, or from organ transplantation, which leads to invasion followed by dissemination of the parasite where it typically lies dormant. It is a ubiquitous organism and nearly 10% of individuals will be seropositive for T. gondii, but the parasite does not usually cause severe disease in immunocompetent individuals. In patients with HIV infection and CD4+ cell counts less than 100 cells/mm however, reactivation can occur with several distinct clinical syndromes of 3, which cerebral toxoplasmosis results in the most morbidity. Cerebral toxoplasmosis typically presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions within the substance of the cerebral cortex, most commonly the frontal and parietal lobes, although single lesions can occur. It is commonly associated with cerebral edema, which may result in mass effect and shifting of adjacent structures. Seizures, focal neurologic deficits, and systemic symptoms are common, as are signs of increased intracranial pressure. Patients with HIV and positive toxoplasma lgG antibodies are typically treated empirically with a sulfonamide and pyrimethamine if cerebral toxoplasmosis is suspected. If necessary, the confirmatory diagnosis occurs through a brain biopsy, which will demonstrate a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells, along with the presence of the T. gondii organisms. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an AIDS defining disease. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Diffuse leukoaraiosis with periventricu lar white matter changes (Choice A) describes hyperintense signal alterations on MRI in the white matter surrounding the lateral ventricles. It is associated with chronic vascular pathology, such as hypertension, diabetes, and vascular dementia. Markedly enlarged sulci with generalized loss of brain matter (Choice B) occurs in cerebral atrophy associated with age, dementia, and alcohol use disorder. This patient with HIV and focal neurologic deficit more likely has an opportunistic infection of the central nervous system. Markedly enlarged ventricles with minimal changes in sulci (Choice C) is seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus, which classically presents with dementia, urinary incontinence, and ataxia. These symptoms do not describe this patient's clinical presentation. An opaque mass over convexity of left frontal cortex with compression of brain substance (Choice E) describes a meningioma, which is a benign brain tumor that develops from the meninges. Symptoms are dependent on the location of the tumor, and patients are often asymptomatic. Common presenting symptoms include seizures, vision changes, altered mental status, and focal neurologic deficits. However, it does not cause a fever, as seen in this patient.

explanation.educational_objective: Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxop/asma gondii, an intracellular protozoan parasite that is most commonly transmitted via ingestion of cat feces or infected meat. In immunocompromised patients, particularly AIDS patients with CD4+ T lymphocyte counts less than 100 cells/mm 3, it can cause cerebral toxoplasmosis, which presents with seizures, focal neurologic deficits, systemic symptoms, and increased intracranial pressure. Neuroimaging will show one or more ring-enhancing lesions within the cerebral cortex, and empiric treatment is with pyrimethamine and sulfonamide therapy Exam Section : Item 18 of 50 Clinical "t 18. An 87-year-old man comes to the physician because of headaches over the past 6 weeks; they fluctuate in severity during the day and occasionally awaken him from sleep. He describes the pain as an aching pressure that is worse in the front. His vision is unchanged. He takes aspirin for cervical osteoarthr itis. His son died 3 months ago. He is lethargic and yawns during the interview. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 88/min and regular, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Funduscopic examination shows cataracts. There is moderate stiffness of the neck with flexion and when the head is turned to the left and right. There is a pronator drift of the right upper extremity. Reflexes are 3+ at the biceps and triceps muscles and knees and 1+ at the ankles. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. He has a slow unsteady gait with short steps. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Craniopharyngioma B) Hypertensive encephalopathy C) Major depressive disorder D) Migraine E) Subdural hematoma F) Temporal arteritis Correct Answer: E. Head trauma, the use of anticoagulants, physical abuse, alcohol use disorder, cerebral atrophy, and malignancy are associated with an increased risk for developing a subdural hematoma (SDH). Elderly patients are at risk for cerebral atrophy, which places traction on dural bridging cortical veins. In this setting, minor trauma such as falls can result in shearing of the veins leading to hemorrhage. In some cases, patients may not report a history of trauma. Patients may present with headaches, vomiting, meningismus, or hemiparesis, or they may manifest upper motoneuron examination findings such as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar reflex (Babinski sign). In some cases, the SDH may be large enough to compress adjacent brain parenchyma; the displacement of the cerebral hemisphere can result in neurologic deficits, altered mental status, seizures, herniation syndromes, and signs of increased intracranial pressure. On imaging, SDH appears as a crescent-shaped fluid collection abutting the internal surface of the skull, not bound by suture lines. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and F. Craniopharyngioma (Choice A) is a rare pituitary mass derived from remnants of the Rathke pouch that may present with bitemporal hemianopsia. It is usually detected in youth. Hypertensive encephalopathy (Choice B) may result from acute and severe increases in blood pressure and may manifest with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure. It may progress to obtundation and coma. This patient's blood pressure is mildly increased but not severe enough to cause hypertensive encephalopathy Exam Section : Item 18 of 50 Clinical Please Walt 1graine E) Subdural hematoma F) Temporal arteritis Correct Answer: E. Head trauma, the use of anticoagulants, physical abuse, alcohol use disorder, cerebral atrophy, and malignancy are associated with an increased risk for developing a subdural hematoma (SDH). Elderly patients are at risk for cerebral atrophy, which places traction on dural bridging cortical veins. In this setting, minor trauma such as falls can result in shearing of the veins leading to hemorrhage. In some cases, patients may not report a history of trauma. Patients may present with headaches, vomiting, meningismus, or hemiparesis, or they may manifest upper motoneuron examination findings such as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar reflex (Babinski sign). In some cases, the SDH may be large enough to compress adjacent brain parenchyma; the displacement of the cerebral hemisphere can result in neurologic deficits, altered mental status, seizures, herniation syndromes, and signs of increased intracranial pressure. On imaging, SDH appears as a crescent-shaped fluid collection abutting the internal surface of the skull, not bound by suture lines. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, and F. Craniopharyngioma (Choice A) is a rare pituitary mass derived from remnants of the Rathke pouch that may present with bitemporal hemianopsia. It is usually detected in youth. Hypertensive encephalopathy (Choice B) may result from acute and severe increases in blood pressure and may manifest with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure. It may progress to obtundation and coma. This patient's blood pressure is mildly increased but not severe enough to cause hypertensive encephalopathy. Major depressive disorder (Choice C) may cause cognitive impairment in older patients, which can improve with antidepressant treatment. It would not cause foca l neurologic deficits or upper motoneuron signs. Migraine (Choice D) is a type of primary headache that usually does not typically cause neurologic deficits and would be unlikely to cause altered mental status or upper motoneuron signs. Temporal arteritis (Choice F) is a common vasculitis of medium and large vessels in elderly patients and commonly presents with systemic symptoms, headache, jaw claudication, proximal muscle stiffness, and sudden, irreversible vision loss. Treatment is with immediate, high-dose corticosteroids. Educational Objective: Elderly patients are at risk for cerebral atrophy, which causes traction on dural bridging cortical veins such that minor trauma can result in venous injury leading to a subdural hematoma Exam Section : Item 19 of 50 Clinical "t 19. A 67-year-o ld woman is brought to the physician because of progressive imbalance and memory difficulties over the past year. Two years ago, she began to have episodes of sudden imbalance with a tendency to fall backwards. She has developed progressive slowness of thought and movement and has had brief episodes of double vision. Examination shows mildly decreased short-term memory and slowness of verbal responses. Downward gaze and upward gaze are markedly impaired. There is marked rigidity of the neck and mild rigidity of the limbs. The gait is broad based with short shuffling steps, and she easily loses her balance, falling backwards. All movements are performed slowly. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows moderate, diffuse atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Creutzfe ldt-Jakob disease B) Dementia, Alzheimer type C) Hydrocep halus D) Hypothyroidism E) Multi-infarct (vascular) dementia F) Parkinson disease with dementia G) Progressive supranuclear palsy; H) Syphilis I) Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome Correct Answer: G. Progressive supranuclear palsy, an atypical parkinsonian disorder, is a neurodegenerative disease associated with tau-positive neurofibri llary tangles in the basal ganglia, cortex, and brainstem. Patients typically present at an average age of 65 years with gait instability, oculomotor deficits (classically vertical gaze palsy), frontal lobe deficits, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity. The gait pattern varies in step length and base width, though patients typically walk and pivot too quickly (as a result of impulsivity from frontal lobe damage), leading to backward falls. Definitive diagnosis occurs by neuropathologic examination illustrating a pattern of neurofibrillary tangles in the characteristic distribution. Neuroimaging illustrating midbrain and/or cerebral cortex atrophy supports the diagnosis. Death typically occurs 6 to 9 years after disease onset. Management is supportive and includes physical and occupational therapy along with advanced care planning. Incorrect Answer: A, B, C, D, E, F, H, and I. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (Choice A) is a human prion disease that presents with rapidly progressing dementia, neuropsychiatric symptoms, cerebellar dysfunction, corticospinal tract dysfunction, basal ganglia dysfunction, and stimulus-induced myoclonus. Vertical gaze palsy would be atypical. r ~•-··-·, - ! ·- ··- ·- •• - : ·- •••• - - -· •••••• - • - -· ••••••• - - ••• - ·- ·-r•- ,•• •- - •

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Head trauma, the use of anticoagulants, physical abuse, alcohol use disorder, cerebral atrophy, and malignancy are associated with an increased risk for developing a subdural hematoma (SDH). Elderly patients are at risk for cerebral atrophy, which places traction on dural bridging cortical veins. In this setting, minor trauma such as falls can result in shearing of the veins leading to hemorrhage. In some cases, patients may not report a history of trauma. Patients may present with headaches, vomiting, meningismus, or hemiparesis, or they may manifest upper motoneuron examination findings such as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and extensor plantar reflex (Babinski sign). In some cases, the SDH may be large enough to compress adjacent brain parenchyma; the displacement of the cerebral hemisphere can result in neurologic deficits, altered mental status, seizures, herniation syndromes, and signs of increased intracranial pressure. On imaging, SDH appears as a crescent-shaped fluid collection abutting the internal surface of the skull, not bound by suture lines.

distractor_explanations.A: Craniopharyngioma is a rare pituitary mass derived from remnants of the Rathke pouch that may present with bitemporal hemianopsia. It is usually detected in youth. Hypertensive encephalopathy (Choice B) may result from acute and severe increases in blood pressure and may manifest with headache, vomiting, agitation, altered mental status, and seizure. It may progress to obtundation and coma. This patient's blood pressure is mildly increased but not severe enough to cause hypertensive encephalopathy. Major depressive disorder (Choice C) may cause cognitive impairment in older patients, which can improve with antidepressant treatment. It would not cause foca l neurologic deficits or upper motoneuron signs.
distractor_explanations.D: Migraine is a type of primary headache that usually does not typically cause neurologic deficits and would be unlikely to cause altered mental status or upper motoneuron signs. Temporal arteritis (Choice F) is a common vasculitis of medium and large vessels in elderly patients and commonly presents with systemic symptoms, headache, jaw claudication, proximal muscle stiffness, and sudden, irreversible vision loss. Treatment is with immediate, high-dose corticosteroids.

explanation.educational_objective: Elderly patients are at risk for cerebral atrophy, which causes traction on dural bridging cortical veins such that minor trauma can result in venous injury leading to a subdural hematoma Exam Section : Item 19 of 50 Clinical "t
explanation.concept: Elderly patients are at risk for cerebral atrophy, which causes traction on dural bridging cortical veins such that minor trauma can result in venous injury leading to a subdural hematoma Exam Section

vignette.presentation:
19. A 67-year-o ld woman is brought to the physician because of progressive imbalance and memory difficulties over the past year. Two years ago, she
began to have episodes of sudden imbalance with a tendency to fall backwards. She has developed progressive slowness of thought and
movement and has had brief episodes of double vision. Examination shows mildly decreased short-term memory and slowness of verbal
responses. Downward gaze and upward gaze are markedly impaired. There is marked rigidity of the neck and mild rigidity of the limbs. The gait is
broad based with short shuffling steps, and she easily loses her balance, falling backwards. All movements are performed slowly. A CT scan of the
head without contrast shows moderate, diffuse atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Progressive supranuclear palsy, an atypical parkinsonian disorder, is a neurodegenerative disease associated with tau-positive neurofibri llary tangles in the basal ganglia, cortex, and brainstem. Patients typically present at an average age of 65 years with gait instability, oculomotor deficits (classically vertical gaze palsy), frontal lobe deficits, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity. The gait pattern varies in step length and base width, though patients typically walk and pivot too quickly (as a result of impulsivity from frontal lobe damage), leading to backward falls. Definitive diagnosis occurs by neuropathologic examination illustrating a pattern of neurofibrillary tangles in the characteristic distribution. Neuroimaging illustrating midbrain and/or cerebral cortex atrophy supports the diagnosis. Death typically occurs 6 to 9 years after disease onset. Management is supportive and includes physical and occupational therapy along with advanced care planning.

distractor_explanations.A: Jakob disease is a human prion disease that presents with rapidly progressing dementia, neuropsychiatric symptoms, cerebellar dysfunction, corticospinal tract dysfunction, basal ganglia dysfunction, and stimulus-induced myoclonus. Vertical gaze palsy would be atypical. r ~•-··-·, - ! ·- ··- ·- •• - : ·- •••• - - -· •••••• - • - -· ••••••• - - ••• - ·- ·-r•- ,•• •- - • Exam Section : Item 19 of 50 Clinical Correct Answer: G. Progressive supranuclear palsy, an atypical parkinsonian disorder, is a neurodegenerative disease associated with tau-positive neurofibrillary tangles in the basal ganglia, cortex, and brainstem. Patients typically present at an average age of 65 years with gait instability, oculomotor deficits (classically vertical gaze palsy), frontal lobe deficits, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity. The gait pattern varies in step length and base width, though patients typically walk and pivot too quickly (as a result of impulsivity from frontal lobe damage), leading to backward falls. Definitive diagnosis occurs by neuropathologic examination illustrating a pattern of neurofibrillary tangles in the characteristic distribution. Neuroimaging illustrating midbrain and/or cerebral cortex atrophy supports the diagnosis. Death typically occurs 6 to 9 years after disease onset. Management is supportive and includes physical and occupational therapy along with advanced care planning. Incorrect Answer: A, B, C, D, E, F, H, and I. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (Choice A) is a human prion disease that presents with rapidly progressing dementia, neuropsychiatric symptoms, cerebellar dysfunction, corticospinal tract dysfunction, basal ganglia dysfunction, and stimulus-induced myoclonus. Vertical gaze palsy would be atypical. Dementia, Alzheimer type (Choice B) is the most prevalent dementia, presenting with progressive cognitive decline that culminates in the inability to perform basic activities of daily living. Vertical gaze palsy, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity would be atypical.
distractor_explanations.C: Hydrocephalus may present acutely with signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, positional headache, papilledema, nausea, vomiting). This patient's chronic progressive course and lack of ventriculomegaly on MRI are inconsistent with hydrocephalus.
distractor_explanations.D: Hypothyroidism is associated with mood changes but does not lead to focal neurologic deficits. Multi-infarct (vascular) dementia (Choice E) refers to cognitive impairment caused by cerebrovascular disease. Patients typically demonstrate stepwise, not progressive, focal neurologic deficits and functional decline. MRI of the brain usually demonstrates multiple infarcts. Parkinson disease with dementia (Choice F) presents with dysfunction of voluntary movements in the form of bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. Dementia may occur late in the disease course. Vertical gaze palsy would be atypical, and the gait pattern is typically narrow based.
distractor_explanations.H: Neurosyphilis typically presents with a progressive dementia or tabes dorsalis (disease of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord). Vertical gaze palsy, muscle rigidity, and bradykinesia would be atypical. Patients may demonstrate a tabetic gait (a wide-based, purposeful gait). Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome (Choice I), caused by thiamine deficiency, most often in association with chronic alcohol abuse, is characterized by altered mental status, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and retrograde and anterograde amnesia. A narrow-based gait and a purely vertical gaze palsy would be atypical, since ophthalmoplegia typically manifests as nystagmus or horizontal gaze palsy. Further, bradykinesia and muscle rigidity would be atypical. MRI of the brain would likely show focal atrophy (eg, mammillary bodies).

Patients typically present at an average age of 65 years with gait instability, oculomotor deficits (classically vertical gaze, palsy), frontal lobe deficits, bradykinesia, and muscle rigidity Clinical
