This can occur at bilirubin concentrations of 25 to 30 mg/dl. Treatment of the underlying cause of the jaundice and phototherapy for unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia or exchange transfusion prevents this potentially fatal consequence. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, C, D, and F. ABO isoimmunization (Choice A) occurs when maternal lgG antibodies to fetal red blood cell antigens cause either fetal or neonatal destruction of these red blood cells. Bilirubin production is increased, and an indirect hyperbilirubinemia ensues. This cause of neonatal jaundice will present with pathologic findings such as an early presentation and rapid rate of rise, neither of which are present in this case. Biliary obstruction (Choice B) caused by biliary atresia is a common cause of direct hyperbilirubinemia. In congenital biliary atresia, the common bile duct is occluded or atretic and bile is unable to pass into the duodenum. Dehydration (Choice C) is the mechanism behind breastfeeding jaundice. In the first week of life, as a breastfeeding mother's milk begins to establish, the infant may become dehydrated. Dehydration leads to increased enterohepatic circulation and reabsorption of bilirubin, resulting in indirect hyperbilirubinemia. In this case, the infant's consistent wet diapers and stools argue against a dehydrated state. Erythrocyte enzyme defect (Choice D) such as glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency causes increased hemolysis of red blood cells and a subsequent increase in unconjugated bilirubin. This cause of neonatal jaundice would present with an early presentation and rapid rate of rise, along with a substantial decrease in the newborn's hematocrit. Polycythemia (Choice F) in a neonate is defined as a hematocrit concentration greater than 65%. This infant's hematocrit is well below this cutoff. Neonates with polycythemia can develop hyperbilirubinemia as a result of increased turnover of excess red blood cells. Educational Objective: Benign neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, or physiologic jaundice, is caused by the increased breakdown of red blood cells and thus generation of bilirubin, the immature liver metabolism of bilirubin, and the increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin. Jaundice within the first 24 hours of life that rises faster than 0.5 mg/dl per hour and a predominance of direct bilirubin are features suggestive of a pathologic cause of hyperbilirubinemia. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 44 of 50 'I 44 . A 4-year-old girl is admitted to the hospital because of a 6-hour history of fever , decreased alertness , and a rash over her chest , arms , and legs. On admission , the patient is obtunded . Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 120/min , respirations are 30/min and shallow , and blood pressure is 70/30 mm Hg. Examination shows a purple macular rash over the trunk and extremities . The face and extremities are edematous . Fluid is administered by intravenous bolus , and intravenous administration of ceftriaxone and vancomycin is started . Fifteen minutes after admission , the patient becomes apneic . She is intubated , and mechanical ventilation is started . Serum studies show : Na • 135 mEq/L K+ 4 mEq/L HC0 15 mEq/L 3 Urea nitrogen 35 mg/dl Creatinine 0.8 mg/dl Her urine output is 1.5 mUkg/h . Arterial blood gas analysis on 40% oxygen shows : 7.2 35 mm Hg 100 mm Hg One hour later, her urine output decreases to less than 0.5 mUkg/h . A chest x-ray shows hazy lung fields bilaterally and cardiomegaly . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A) Intravenous administration of an isotonic fluid bolus B) Intravenous administration of dopamine C) Intravenous administration of furosemide D) Intravenous administration of nitroprusside E) Increased inhaled oxygen concentration Correct Answer: B. A patient with fever, hypotension, edematous extremities, cardiomegaly, decreased urine output, and respiratory distress raises suspicion for myocarditis and cardiogenic shock. Cardiogenic shock can occur when decreased cardiac output leads to organ hypoperfusion. In cardiogenic shock, dysfunction of cardiac myocytes results in decreased chronotropy, lusitropy, or inotropy. Decreased cardiac output and increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure result from such dysfunction. Systemic vascular resistance is increased as a physiologic attempt to maintain mean arterial pressure in the setting of decreased cardiac output and peripheral perfusion. Physical examination findings can include tachycardia, tachypnea, crackles on auscultation of the lungs, and an S or S gallop on cardiac auscultation. Dopamine is a vasopressor and 3 4 inotrope at increased doses. Intravenous administration of dopamine may be appropriate in cases of cardiogenic shock or refractory hypotension. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Intravenous administration of an isotonic fluid bolus (Choice A) is typically done initially in cases of distributive or hypovolemic shock. It would be harmful in a patient with cardiogenic shock because of impaired cardiac output and exacerbation of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and it was already empirically attempted in this case. Intravenous administration of furosemide (Choice C) would not be an initial step in the management of cardiogenic shock. Although total body fluid volume is increased (eg, pulmonary edema and extremity edema), cardiac output to the kidneys is decreased. Restoration of cardiac output and mean arterial pressure to prevent further damage to organs is the first priority. Intravenous administration of nitroprusside (Choice D) would be detrimental to this patient who is hypotensive. Nitroprusside is an intravenous, titratable vasodilator that can be used for the treatment of hypertensive emergencies. It breaks down in circulation to release nitric oxide, which in turn activates guanylate cyclase in vascular smooth muscle to result in vascular smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Increased inhaled oxygen concentration (Choice E) would not be beneficial to this patient. Arterial blood gas analysis of this patient shows adequate partial pressure of oxygen. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 44 of 50 " q K+ 4 mEq/L HCO 15 mEq/L 3 Urea nitrogen 35 mg/dl Creatinine 0.8 mg/dl Her urine output is 1.5 mUkg/h . A) Intravenous administration of an isotonic fluid bolus B) Intravenous administration of dopamine C) Intravenous administration of furosemide D) Intravenous administration of nitroprusside E) Increased inhaled oxygen concentration Correct Answer: B. A patient with fever, hypotension, edematous extremities, cardiomegaly, decreased urine output, and respiratory distress raises suspicion for myocarditis and cardiogenic shock. Cardiogenic shock can occur when decreased cardiac output leads to organ hypoperfusion. In cardiogenic shock, dysfunction of cardiac myocytes results in decreased chronotropy, lusitropy, or inotropy. Decreased cardiac output and increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure result from such dysfunction. Systemic vascular resistance is increased as a physiologic attempt to maintain mean arterial pressure in the setting of decreased cardiac output and peripheral perfusion. Physical examination findings can include tachycardia, tachypnea, crackles on auscultation of the lungs, and an S or S gallop on cardiac auscultation. Dopamine is a vasopressor and 3 4 inotrope at increased doses. Intravenous administration of dopamine may be appropriate in cases of cardiogenic shock or refractory hypotension. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Intravenous administration of an isotonic fluid bolus (Choice A) is typically done initially in cases of distributive or hypovolemic shock. It would be harmful in a patient with cardiogenic shock because of impaired cardiac output and exacerbation of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and it was already empirically attempted in this case. Intravenous administration of furosemide (Choice C) would not be an initial step in the management of cardiogenic shock. Although total body fluid volume is increased (eg, pulmonary edema and extremity edema), cardiac output to the kidneys is decreased. Restoration of cardiac output and mean arterial pressure to prevent further damage to organs is the first priority. Intravenous administration of nitroprusside (Choice D) would be detrimental to this patient who is hypotensive. Nitroprusside is an intravenous, titratable vasodilator that can be used for the treatment of hypertensive emergencies. It breaks down in circulation to release nitric oxide, which in turn activates guanylate cyclase in vascular smooth muscle to result in vascular smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Increased inhaled oxygen concentration (Choice E) would not be beneficial to this patient. Arterial blood gas analysis of this patient shows adequate partial pressure of oxygen. Educational Objective: Cardiogenic shock can occur when decreased cardiac output leads to organ hypoperfusion, leading to hypotension, edematous extremities, cardiomegaly, decreased urine output, pulmonary edema, and respiratory distress. The intravenous administration of dopamine can be used in cases of cardiogenic shock or refractory hypotension, as it is a vasopressor and inotrope at high doses. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 45 of 50 'I 45 . A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of swelling of his lower lip that has slowly resolved during the past 2 days . He has a 12-month history of intermittent asymmetric swelling of his face , chest , and arms . During three of the episodes , he also had abdominal pain and diarrhea . There is no history of travel outside the USA. He takes no medications . He does not use illicit drugs . He is not sexually active . Examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? A) Skin testing for environmental allergies B) Measurement of serum angiotensin-converting enzyme activity C) Measurement of serum C1 esterase inhibitor concentration D) Radioallergosorbent test (RAST) E) Serum protein electrophoresis Correct Answer: C. Hereditary angioedema presents with intermittent episodes of swelling of the skin, face, and lips, as well as the mucosal lining of the respiratory and gastrointestinal system. It is caused by an autosomal dominant inherited or de novo deficiency in C1 esterase inhibitor, which leads to overactivation of the complement system and overproduction of bradykinin. Bradykinin is a vasodilator that leads to the symptoms associated with hereditary angioedema. Episodes of angioedema can be caused by trauma, medications, and infections. They are not improved by antihistamines but commonly self-resolve. Further evaluation would also demonstrate a decreased C4 complement concentration in addition to the decreased concentration or activity of serum C1 esterase inhibitor.

distractor_explanations.A: Skin testing for environmental allergies may be useful in the evaluation of allergic reactions or anaphylaxis, which may also present with angioedema. However, anaphylaxis also causes wheezing as a result of laryngeal edema, urticaria, emesis, and hypotension. It is generally acute in onset following a specific exposure. Measurement of serum angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) activity (Choice B) would not be useful in the evaluation of hereditary angioedema. However, decreased activity of ACE, as can be caused by ACE inhibitor medications, can lead to angioedema as a result of the decreased degradation of bradykinin. ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in hereditary angioedema. Radioallergosorbent test (RAST) (Choice D) is a test used to identify antibodies against particular antigens, although it is no longer commonly used. Because hereditary angioedema is not caused by an allergic reaction, a RAST would not be useful in its evaluation beyond ruling out an allergic contributor which is unlikely on the basis of no specific exposure history. Serum protein electrophoresis (Choice E) is commonly used to evaluate for malignancy (eg, multiple myeloma), as well as kidney and immunological disorders. It is not frequently used to evaluate the complement system and, thus, would have no role in diagnosing hereditary angioedema.

vignette.presentation:
50. A 7-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department 8 hours after the onset of vomiting bilious material. He has passed one bloody stool during this period .
He has refused to feed for 12 hours . He was born at 38 weeks' gestation following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery . Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at
1 and 5 minutes , respectively . He was initially well except for occasional wet burps after breast-feeding . He appears lethargic . He weighs 3260 g (7 lb 3 oz). His
temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 170/min , respirations are 28/min , and blood pressure is 65/35 mm Hg. Examination shows mottled skin and a supple
neck. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination shows mild distention and diffuse tenderness with guarding . Bowel sounds are decreased . On
digital rectal examination , there is gross blood . A lateral x-ray of the upper gastrointestinal tract with barium contrast is shown . Which of the following events in
utero is the most likely cause of these findings?

question_stem: the most likely cause of these findings?

choices.text: Abnormal exocrine secretions from the pancreas and intestinal glands
Failure of cannulization of the proximal bowel
Failure of caudal migration of ganglion cells
Vascular occlusion in a segment of bowel
Abnormal exocrine secretions from the pancreas and intestinal glands
Failure of cannulization of the proximal bowel
Failure of caudal migration of ganglion cells
Vascular occlusion in a segment of bowel

distractor_explanations.A: Abnormal exocrine secretions from the pancreas and intestinal glands can occur in cystic fibrosis, which is caused by a failure of proper chloride channel function. This leads to inspissated stool and meconium ileus, which can present with abdominal distention but more commonly presents with absence of a bowel movement within the first 48 hours of life. It would not be expected to cause peritonitis, as in this patient. Failure of cannulization of the proximal bowel (Choice B) results in duodenal atresia. It typically presents with signs of intestinal obstruction in the newborn, such as recurrent emesis and poor feeding. It is associated with Down syndrome, polyhydramnios in utero, and a two adjacent contrast filled structures on imaging. This patient was previously able to tolerate oral feeding, making this diagnosis less likely. Failure of caudal migration of ganglion cells (Choice C) causes Hirschsprung disease, which classically presents with the failure to pass stool in the first 48 hours of life. Digital rectal examination commonly demonstrates an explosive release of stool, rather than gross blood, as in this patient. Vascular occlusion in a segment of bowel (Choice E) can result in jejunal or ileal atresia. This most commonly occurs in the setting of maternal smoking or use of cocaine. The newborn typically presents with poor feeding and emesis, and on imaging exhibits multiple air-fluid levels in the small bowel proximal to the site of atresia causing obstruction. r " , r-- r , Exam Sec t . n · Item 50 of 50 80 rd of Medical Examiners 10 • National ~ Self-Assessment Pediatr1cs 1T:rll•1m111 U U U I I X I I W I I I I U WI U I W U digital rectal examination , there is gross blood . A lateral x-ray of the upper gastrointestinal tract with barium contrast is shown . Which of the following events in utero is the most likely cause of these findings? A) Abnormal exocrine secretions from the pancreas and intestinal glands B) Failure of cannulization of the proximal bowel C) Failure of caudal migration of ganglion cells D) Failure of normal bowel rotation E) Vascular occlusion in a segment of bowel CorrectAnswer: D. Midgut volvulus, a dangerous complication of intestinal malrotation, often occurs in children within the first few months of life. Malrotation results from the incomplete rotation of the midgut during embryonal development and leaves the midgut attached to a thin stalk of mesentery at the base of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) instead of the normally broad-based mesenteric stalk. The cecum also remains in an abnormal position within the mid-upper abdomen instead of the right lower quadrant and is attached to the lateral abdominal wall by fibrous bands which cross over the top of the duodenum and can also cause constriction. This leaves the small intestine at risk for volvulus at the base of the SMA. Volvulus can lead to bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and vascular compromise of the small bowel with consequent intestinal necrosis, hematochezia, perforation, and peritonitis. The SMA is susceptible to constriction in midgut volvulus because of its anatomical proximity and embryonal relationship to the formation of the midgut. Evaluation of malrotation and midgut volvulus requires an upper gastrointestinal barium study, which will outline the patient's small bowel anatomy and further assess for the presence of an obstructive volvulus. The upper gastrointestinal barium study in this patient demonstrates a spiral appearance of the duodenum with an abnormal position of the duodenojejunal junction on the lateral view, which indicates the presence of malrotation with a midgut volvulus. Treatment requires emergent surgical correction. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, and E. Abnormal exocrine secretions from the pancreas and intestinal glands (Choice A) can occur in cystic fibrosis, which is caused by a failure of proper chloride channel function. This leads to inspissated stool and meconium ileus, which can present with abdominal distention but more commonly presents with absence of a bowel movement within the first 48 hours of life. It would not be expected to cause peritonitis, as in this patient. Failure of cannulization of the proximal bowel (Choice B) results in duodenal atresia. It typically presents with signs of intestinal obstruction in the newborn, such as recurrent emesis and poor feeding. It is associated with Down syndrome, polyhydramnios in utero, and a two adjacent contrast filled structures on imaging. This patient was previously able to tolerate oral feeding, making this diagnosis less likely. Failure of caudal migration of ganglion cells (Choice C) causes Hirschsprung disease, which classically presents with the failure to pass stool in the first 48 hours of life. Digital rectal examination commonly demonstrates an explosive release of stool, rather than gross blood, as in this patient. Vascular occlusion in a segment of bowel (Choice E) can result in jejunal or ileal atresia. This most commonly occurs in the setting of maternal smoking or use of cocaine. The newborn typically presents with poor feeding and emesis, and on imaging exhibits multiple air-fluid levels in the small bowel proximal to the site of atresia causing obstruction.

explanation.educational_objective: Malrotation occurs secondary to the incomplete rotation of bowel during embryonic development. This places the newborn at risk for midgut volvulus, which can present with bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and pain, and when severe, intestinal necrosis, hematochezia, perforation, and peritonitis. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
1. His mother's blood group is A, Rh-negative , and his blood group is A, Rh-positive . He had a serum total bilirubin concentration of
25 mg/dL at the age of 2 days and received phototherapy for 2 days . He continued to be mildly jaundiced until the age of 1 month . Serum studies since then have shown no abnormalities . Examination today shows no
abnormalities . Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?

question_stem: most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Kernicterus occurs as a result of the deposition of unconjugated bilirubin in a newborn's brain, usually in the basal ganglia, pons, and cerebellum. It typically presents with poor feeding, lethargy, and seizures. If untreated, it can cause long-term neurologic abnormalities, such as gaze palsies or sensorineural hearing loss. Unconjugated or indirect bilirubin is circulating insoluble bilirubin that is largely bound to albumin. It has not yet undergone conjugation in the liver. Causes of increased unconjugated bilirubin include hemolysis, breast milk jaundice, Crigler-Najjar syndrome, Gilbert syndrome, and physiologic jaundice. In newborns, causes also include maternal exposure to sulfonamide antibiotics, which displace bilirubin from albumin in the neonate, thereby increasing the free plasma concentrations of unconjugated bilirubin. Kernicterus typically occurs when the bilirubin concentration exceeds 25-30 mg/dL, which is commonly caused by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency or Rh-hemolytic disease of the newborn, the latter of which was likely present in this patient given the discordant Rh status of him and his mother. Risk factors include prematurity, cephalohematoma or significant bruising, poor breastfeeding, and East Asian ethnicity. Treatment to prevent severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and subsequent kernicterus is phototherapy or exchange transfusion. Exchange transfusions are particularly useful in hyperbilirubinemia that is caused by anti-Rh(D) antibodies, as they allow removal of the antibodies as well as the bilirubin.

distractor_explanations.A: feeding could be considered in breast milk jaundice or breastfeeding jaundice, although it is usually not required as the increased bilirubin concentrations seen are typically benign. Breast milk jaundice is hypothesized to occur because of the presence of beta-glucuronidase in breast milk, which deconjugates bilirubin and allows it to be reabsorbed. Breastfeeding jaundice occurs as a result of relative hypovolemia secondary to inadequate intake, which results in hyperbilirubinemia. Water supplementation (Choice B) is generally not advised in infants, as their kidneys are incapable of properly reabsorbing sodium, which results in hyponatremia. This can cause altered mental status and seizures. Water supplementation is not used to treat hyperbilirubinemia. Longer course of phototherapy (Choice C) could have decreased the overall amount of unconjugated bilirubin, as phototherapy converts indirect bilirubin into a water-soluble form that can be excreted. However, it would have been less effective in this patient with severe hyperbilirubinemia likely secondary to anti-Rh(D) antibody-mediated hemolysis. Antibiotic therapy (Choice D) is used in the treatment of neonatal infections, such as Escherichia coli or Streptococcus aga/actiae meningitis. Bacterial meningitis is associated with a high mortality if untreated, as well as prolonged neurologic complications, such as hearing loss, even when treated. A missed diagnosis of bacterial meningitis would have certainly led to neonatal demise or significant morbidity.

explanation.educational_objective: Kernicterus is caused by high concentrations of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, commonly in hemolysis because of Rh alloimmunization or glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. It is associated with poor feeding, lethargy, and seizures as a result of deposition of bilirubin in the basal ganglia, pons, and cerebellum. If untreated, it can lead to long-term neurologic sequelae, such as hearing loss. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Kernicterus is caused by high concentrations of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, commonly in hemolysis because of Rh alloimmunization or glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. It is associated

vignette.presentation:
2. A previously healthy 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of intermittent right knee pain for 2 months . The pain typically occurs in the morning and after naps . She has not had fever , rash , or symptoms
in any other joint. She plays soccer twice weekly but has not had any injuries . Her parents recall that she had a sore throat for 2 days prior to the onset of her knee pain. There is no family history of osteoarthritis . She is at the
25th percentile for height , 70th percentile for weight , and above the 97th percentile for BMI. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) . Examination shows slight bowing of the lower extremities . The right knee is larger than the left knee .
There is tenderness of the right knee to palpation . Range of motion of the right knee is decreased . Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 45 mm/h . X-rays of the knees show no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most
likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Tear of the anterior cruciate ligament

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Juvenile arthritis (juvenile idiopathic arthritis, or JIA) occurs before the age of 16 and is a common rheumatic disease among children. The disease has an autoimmune cause and is characterized by joint pain and inflammation. Patients commonly exhibit extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis, lymphadenopathy, and rash. There are a variety of sub-categories of JIA. For example, oligoarticular disease is characterized by the involvement of fewer than five joints (typically large joints such as the knee) and antinuclear antibody (ANA) positivity; polyarticular disease is characterized by involvement of greater than five joints (typically both large and small joints such as the interphalangeal joints), uveitis, and negative ANA titers, and systemic disease (also known as juvenile onset Still disease) is characterized by variable joint involvement, rash, quotidian fever, and serositis. Diagnosis is often difficult and is based on a combination of characteristic clinical findings and suggestive laboratory tests, such as ANA, rheumatoid factor, anti-citrullinated peptide, and inflammatory tests such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate. There is no single, confirmatory laboratory test for JIA. Treatment modalities include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, disease modifying antirheumatic medications such as methotrexate, and biologic agents.

distractor_explanations.A: Acute rheumatic fever is a late complication of under- or untreated Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) infection characterized by carditis, subcutaneous nodules, erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea, and migratory polyarthritis. The cause is related to immune cross-reactivity as a result of molecular homology between streptococcal M protein and human cardiac myosin proteins. Septic arthritis (Choice C) is most commonly bacterial and presents with the rapid onset of fever, joint swelling, erythema, pain, tenderness with range of motion, inability to bear weight, and leukocytosis. Arthrocentesis typically shows bacteria on Gram stain, most often Gram-positive organisms, and leukocyte count is greater than or equal to 50,000/mm 3 with a neutrophilic predominance. Tear of the anterior cruciate ligament (Choice D) commonly presents as an acute injury in athletes when attempting rapid changes in direction upon a planted foot. Patients often report an audible pop when the injury is sustained and experience acute onset of pain, joint swelling, and instability. Tibia vara (Choice E) refers to an outward-bowing deformity of the tibia. It commonly occurs in children with vitamin D deficiency (rickets) or Blount disease. It does not typically manifest with joint swelling.

explanation.educational_objective: Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (juvenile idiopathic arthritis, or JIA) occurs before the age of 16 and is the most common rheumatic disease among children. It has an autoimmune cause and is characterized by joint pain and inflammation. Patients also commonly exhibit extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis, lymphadenopathy, and rash. Diagnosis is made by a combination of characteristic clinical and laboratory findings. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
3. A 7-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes mellitus has had fever , cough , and rhinorrhea for 1 week and lethargy for 3 days . His pulse is 100/min , respirations are 30/min , and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. He appears lethargic;
no other abnormalities are noted. Serum studies show :
Na • 120 mEq/L
CI -
95 mEq/L
K+
7.5 mEq/L
HC0
10 mEq/L
3
Glucose 690 mg/dl
Urea nitrogen 23 mg/dl
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the hyperkalemia?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for the hyperkalemia?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) typically occurs in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus as a result of increased insulin requirements during times of physiologic stress (eg, infection) or insulin nonadherence. DKA occurs as a result of the accumulation of serum ketones in the setting of deficient insulin signaling. Dysregulated fatty acid degradation and ketone synthesis occurs because of the relative state of starvation created through absent insulin signaling. Patients may present with complaints of fatigue, polyuria, shortness of breath, and diffuse abdominal discomfort. Vital signs may show tachycardia and tachypnea. Laboratory studies typically show increased glucose and ketone concentrations, metabolic acidosis, and a high anion-gap caused by the accumulation of unmeasured anions in serum. In metabolic acidosis, excess hydrogen ions are transported into the cell in exchange for potassium ions to maintain electroneutrality. Insulin promotes intracellular potassium entry, and in DKA, insulin deficiency contributes to the excess cellular shift of potassium to the extracellular space resulting in hyperkalemia despite decreased concentrations of total body potassium as a result of excess urinary excretion. Treatment is through replacement of insulin, volume repletion, correction of electrolyte abnormalities, and treatment of any precipitating conditions. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Adrenal insufficiency (Choice A) refers to insufficient production of hormones from the adrenal cortex, which include aldosterone and cortisol; sex hormone deficiency may also be present. Primary adrenal insufficiency can present with deficiencies in both aldosterone and cortisol, whereas secondary and tertiary adrenal insufficiency tend to affect cortisol only. Insufficient aldosterone production leads to hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Insufficient cortisol can lead to hypoglycemia, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and depressed mental status. In this patient, DKA is more likely given his history of type 1 diabetes, metabolic acidosis, and hyperglycemia. Excessive potassium intake (Choice C) would be unlikely to cause hyperkalemia in this patient. Kidney potassium filtration typically regulates serum potassium within a normal range, but this can be impaired in end stage kidney disease. In DKA, the kidney excretion of potassium is increased because of osmotic diuresis. Hyperkalemia in this case is as a result of the extracellular shift of potassium and deficient insulin signaling. Hemolysis (Choice D) can result in hyperkalemia because of the release of intracellular potassium into the serum. DKA is unlikely to cause hemolysis. Hemolytic anemia may present with jaundice and increased bilirubin. Respiratory acidosis (Choice E) would be the opposite of what is expected in a patient with DKA. In DKA, metabolic acidosis leads to compensatory respiratory alkalosis. Kussmaul respirations, which are rapid and deep, are a classic physical examination finding. vignette.presentation: 4. While being evaluated for a cardiac murmur , a 12-year-old boy is noted to have bilateral gynecomastia . His sexual development is Tanner stage 3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Evaluate his brothers for this finding
Privately tell his parents about the finding
Reassure him that this is normal

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Gynecomastia refers to an increase in the amount of glandular breast tissue in males, and it is common during puberty. Pubertal gynecomastia is caused by a disruption in the normal balance of androgens and estrogens and is common in boys aged 12 to 14 years old, typically when they have a sexual maturity rating of 3, as in this patient. The increased concentrations of estrogen are caused by the conversion of androstenedione and testosterone to estrone and estradiol. On physical examination, gynecomastia may be tender to palpation. Results of laboratory studies will be within reference ranges in pubertal gynecomastia but could be used to delineate other causes of gynecomastia. These other causes include medications (eg, spironolactone, ketoconazole, antiandrogen therapy), liver cirrhosis, germ cell tumors, hypogonadism, and hyperthyroidism. Physiologic gynecomastia typically self-resolves but medical and surgical options exist for symptomatic patients, such as aromatase inhibitors and liposuction. As this patient has no signs to suggest pathologic gynecomastia, reassurance is appropriate.

distractor_explanations.A: Measuring serum corticosteroid concentrations may be useful in the evaluation of suspected Cushing syndrome (high concentrations of baseline cortisol) or Addison disease (deficiency of cortisol). Cushing syndrome presents with weight gain, fatigue, truncal obesity, fat redistribution, hirsutism, and abdominal striae, whereas Addison disease presents with hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation, and abdominal pain. Neither present with gynecomastia as a direct result, though truncal obesity may resemble it in Cushing syndrome (or in Cushing disease). Measuring serum gonadotropin concentrations (Choice B) may be useful in the evaluation of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, such as Klinefelter syndrome, which can present with gynecomastia. However, patients with Klinefelter syndrome typically have testicular atrophy, tall stature, and long extremities, which this patient does not exhibit. Evaluating his brother for this finding (Choice C) may be useful if the gynecomastia was because of a hereditary disorder, such as partial androgen insensitivity or aromatase excess. However, this patient is presenting with mild gynecomastia associated with puberty, making physiologic gynecomastia more likely. Privately telling his parents about the finding (Choice D) is inappropriate, as the condition is benign, and the patient should be included in health conversations regarding his body.

explanation.educational_objective: Physiologic pubertal gynecomastia is a benign proliferation of glandular breast tissue in boys aged 12 to 14 years, most commonly during at the sexual maturity rating of 3 during puberty. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Physiologic pubertal gynecomastia is a benign proliferation of glandular breast tissue in boys aged 12 to 14 years, most commonly during at the sexual maturity rating of 3 during puberty. r " , r-- r

vignette.presentation:
5. A 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination . She is breast-feeding successfully and has been in good health . She is able to roll from her
stomach to her back , and she looks around with curiosity , coos , and orients to voice . Her parents are concerned about a lesion on her left thigh that has become
darker since birth . The patient appears well. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Examination of the left thigh shows the brown lesion seen in the
photograph. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) is a benign proliferation of melanocytes that is present from birth. Compared to normal skin, within a nevus the melanocytes are clustered into nests. Nests are either located in the basal layer of the epidermis, in the dermis, or both. Compared to acquired nevi, CMN are often larger and darker. CMN are classified by their size: small (<1.5 cm), medium (1.5-20 cm), large (>20-40 cm), and giant (>40 cm). Large and giant CMN are at risk for malignant transformation. In this case, the CMN is symmetrical, uniform in color and thickness, and appears to have a rough texture. Hair is present on the inferior aspect which is common in CMN. CMN should be routinely monitored by a dermatologist. If an area within the CMN develops increased thickness or change in color, it should be biopsied to evaluate for presence of melanoma. Provided the CMN does not develop melanoma, they are benign. However, they can be associated with psychological morbidity if they are located in cosmetically sensitive areas of the body and depending on their size. Complete surgical excision of large or giant CMN is usually impossible, but particularly bothersome areas may be excised to improve function and cosmesis.

distractor_explanations.B: Hyperpigmented macula describe cafe-au-lait spots. A cafe-au-lait spot is characterized by a tan to dark brown, uniformly pigmented macule or patch often seen at birth or noticed in early childhood. This lesion, in contrast, is a dark brown plaque with the presence of hair at the inferior aspect. It may be asymmetrical or have an irregular border. It represents a focal increase in melanin production rather than an increased number of melanocytes or any form of malignancy. While numerous cafe-au-lait spots suggest an underlying genetic disease, a single lesion is a normal finding. Macular stain (Choice C), port-wine stain (Choice D), and superficial hemangioma (Choice E) are all vascular lesions and will appear red to purple rather than brown to black. Macular stains, or nevi flammeus, are common red patches present on the forehead and posterior neck at birth. Port-wine stain and nevus flammeus are both capillary malformations while superficial hemangioma is a benign proliferation of capillary sized vessels. These lesions are benign, but superficial hemangiomas may ulcerate and bleed. Both port-wine stains and superficial hemangiomas can be treated with laser therapy to decrease the size and color if desired. Nevus flammeus on the forehead and eyelids commonly resolves and those on the posterior neck usually fade but do not completely disappear.

explanation.educational_objective: Congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) is a benign proliferation of melanocytes that is present from birth. Compared to acquired nevi, CMN are often larger and darker. Hair may be present. There is an increased risk for malignant transformation in large or giant CMN and regular monitoring should be performed. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) is a benign proliferation of melanocytes that is present from birth. Compared to acquired nevi, CMN are often larger and darker. Hair may be present. There is an inc

vignette.presentation:
6. A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a scaly, pruritic rash on intertriginous areas of her elbows and knees that worsens in the spring and the fall ; it often appears in conjunction with episodes of respiratory
distress and wheezing . Treatment with which of the following is the most effective short-term treatment of the rash?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Atopic dermatitis, or eczema, is a chronic pruritic inflammatory skin disease common in children. The diagnosis of atopic dermatitis is made based on clinical symptoms. Pruritus must be present in addition to three of the following: current or past flexural eczema, history of asthma or hay fever, or presence of dry skin within the past year. The rash is initially characterized by erythematous papules and vesicles with exudates and crusting. With chronic scratching, they become dry, scaly, and excoriated in a process called lichenification. This patient's flexural dermatitis and apparent asthma and hay fever suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis. Treatment of atopic dermatitis begins with gentle skin care: minimizing long baths in warm water which causes drying of the skin, avoiding products with fragrance, and use of bland moisturizers such as petroleum jelly daily. Flares of eczema are treated with mild to moderate potency topical corticosteroids, such as triamcinolone. In children, a moderate potency topical corticosteroid should not be used consistently for over 2 to 3 weeks because of the potential of systemic absorption.

distractor_explanations.A: Clotrimazole is a topical anti-fungal used to treat superficial dermatophyte infections such as tinea pedis and tinea corporis. Griseofulvin (Choice C) is a systemic antifungal used to treat tinea capitis in children. While the bacterial and fungal microbiome do play a role in the development and treatment of atopic dermatitis, triamcinolone is a more effective short-term treatment of eczema. Coal tar (Choice B) is a topical remedy used in psoriasis, not eczema. Its mechanism is not fully elucidated, but it is thought to be anti-inflammatory and anti-proliferative to the epidermis.
distractor_explanations.D: Lindane is an antiparasitic agent which in the past has been used to treat lice infestation. However, it is no longer used given the relatively high incidence of neurologic toxicity. This is especially of concern in young children, who have a lower body surface area to volume ratio.

explanation.educational_objective: Atopic dermatitis, or eczema, is characterized by pruritus and recurrent episodes of dermatitis on the flexural surfaces of children. It is commonly seen in concert with asthma and allergies (food or seasonal), which form the atopic triad. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Atopic dermatitis, or eczema, is characterized by pruritus and recurrent episodes of dermatitis on the flexural surfaces of children. It is commonly seen in concert with asthma and allergies (food or

vignette.presentation:
7. A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination 2 weeks after being treated for an ear infection . He has had recurrent ear infections , sinusitis , and two episodes of bacterial pneumonia since birth . Over the
past year, he has undergone placement of two sets of tympanostomy tubes for otitis media . His mother is HIV negative . He currently takes no medications . He is at the 25th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows no
abnormalities except for small anterior cervical lymph nodes . Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of disease?

question_stem: the most likely mechanism of disease?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: lgA deficiency is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms. Selective lgA deficiency describes a decreased or absent concentration of circulating lgA with normal concentrations of lgG, and normal or increased concentrations of lgM. lgA is critical for immune health and functions in two primary ways. First, lgA binds pathogen surface antigens targeting them for opsonization, complement activation, and phagocytosis. Second, lgA coats mucosal surfaces and prevents colonization, adhesion, and invasion by pathogenic microorganisms. lmmunoglobulins are produced by plasma cells, which are terminally differentiated B lymphocytes; as a result, most causal deficiencies are hypothesized to be related to B lymphocyte abnormalities. Despite this, there is clinical heterogeneity in the severity of lgA deficiency. Some patients remain asymptomatic while others suffer from recurrent sinopulmonary infections or otitis media, as is the case for this patient. In younger patients with severe deficiency, failure to thrive is common. Anaphylactic reactions to blood products such as plasma (which contain donor immunoglobulin) are classic but uncommon, as not all patients with lgA deficiency have reactions to blood products. Such severe reactions are most common in patients with undetectable concentrations of lgA; these reactions occur because of the presence of preformed antibodies against lgA, which is a non-native protein in these patients, and thus, a target of immune activation.

distractor_explanations.B: Impaired chemotaxis describes several syndromes, one of which is hyperimmunoglobulinemia E syndrome. These patients have abnormal Th T-lymphocyte function and thus, impaired release of IL-17, a 17 potent agent for neutrophil chemotaxis. These patients present with recurrent abscesses with minimal inflammation. Impaired respiratory burst (Choice C) describes chronic granulomatous disease, which is caused by a deficiency in NADPH oxidase, an enzyme used to generate hydrogen peroxide and hypochlorous acid. These molecules are typically used to kill bacteria intracellularly. Patients present with recurrent pyogenic infections with catalase-positive organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus, with normal concentrations of leukocytes and immunoglobulins. Splenic dysfunction (Choice D) can be the consequence of splenectomy or can occur in diseases such as sickle cell disease, where patients become functionally asplenic early in the course of disease. This predisposes to infection with encapsulated organisms such as Haemophi/us influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. lgA deficiency is the more likely diagnosis for this patient. T-lymphocyte dysfunction (Choice E) describes numerous disorders affecting either T-lymphocyte maturation, survival, or function. Conditions such as severe combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCIO) or Di George syndrome result in a near absence of T lymphocytes with recurrent viral and fungal infections. T lymphocytes also play a role in augmenting B-lymphocyte activation, so deficiency or dysfunction can impair humoral immunity. These patients present with severe and recurrent invasive infections early in life.

explanation.educational_objective: Selective lgA deficiency describes a decreased or absent concentration of circulating lgA, an immunoglobulin critical to mucosal immunity. Patients may be either asymptomatic or present with recurrent sinopulmonary infections, otitis media, and failure to thrive. Anaphylaxis following a blood transfusion as a result of preformed anti-lgA antibodies can also occur. lmmunoglobulin concentrations will demonstrate decreased or absent concentrations of lgA and normal or high concentrations of lgG and lgM. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Selective lgA deficiency describes a decreased or absent concentration of circulating lgA, an immunoglobulin critical to mucosal immunity. Patients may be either asymptomatic or present with recurrent

vignette.presentation:
8. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination . He is active and has been healthy except for an episode of otitis media 3 weeks ago
treated with amoxicillin . His parents emigrated from Vietnam . His diet consists mainly of fruits and vegetables ; he occasionally eats fish and chicken but no red
meat. Examination shows no abnormalities . Laboratory studies show :
Hemoglobin 10 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 64 µm 3
Leukocyte count 6100/mm 3
Platelet count 225 ,000/mm 3
Red cell distribution width 10% (N=13%-15%)
A blood smear is shown . Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's anemia?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for this patient's anemia?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This asymptomatic child with mild anemia, microcytosis, and low red cell distribution width (RDW), who is of Southeast Asian heritage most likely has either a- or ~-thalassemia minor. Thalassemia is characterized by the decreased synthesis of globin chains. Normal adult hemoglobin is known as HbA (a~2l and is made of two a-globin chains and two ~-globin chains. There are four a-globin alleles and two ~-globin alleles. Mutations in one or two a-globin alleles or one ~-globin allele causes thalassemia minor. Thalassemia trait is common in Southeast Asia and presents with mild microcytic anemia. Features include the presence of target cells on peripheral blood smear (pictured in the photomicrograph above), a low RDW (which indicates that most erythrocytes are of the same size with little variation), and persistence of microcytosis. Iron concentrations can be measured to rule out iron deficiency. Other cell lines including platelets and white blood cells should be within normal ranges. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to distinguish between a- and ~-thalassemia minor. There is no treatment required for thalassemia minor as the resultant anemia is usually not severe. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Antibiotic-induced autoimmune hemolysis (Choice A) can occur after exposure to penicillins and cephalosporins, but the onset is typically acute and occurs within hours to days. While hemolysis can occur weeks later, it is less common. Additionally, patients would be expected to present with normocytic anemia and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Haptoglobin concentrations can be measured and will be decreased, while the reticulocyte count will typically be increased. Iron deficiency (Choice C) is a common cause of anemia in menstruating women, strict vegans or vegetarians, and those with chronic gastrointestinal bleeding or Celiac disease. It commonly presents with microcytosis, although often with a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) that is higher than what is seen in thalassemia, and an increased RDW indicating the release of premature erythrocytes, which are larger, from the bone marrow. The measurement of serum iron and ferritin are used to make the diagnosis. Transient postinfectious bone marrow suppression (Choice D) may occur following viral infections, but more commonly presents with leukopenia, which is not present in this case. In patients with sickle cell disease, infection with parvovirus B19 can cause a transient aplastic crisis and severe anemia. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 8 of 50 A blood smear is shown . Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's anemia? A) Antibiotic-induced autoimmune hemolysis B) Decreased synthesis of globin chains C) Iron deficiency D) Transient postinfectious bone marrow suppression E) Vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency 12 Correct Answer: B. This asymptomatic child with mild anemia, microcytosis, and low red cell distribution width (RDW), who is of Southeast Asian heritage most likely has either a- or ~-thalassemia minor. Thalassemia is characterized by the decreased synthesis of globin chains. Normal adult hemoglobin is known as HbA (a~2l and is made of two a-globin chains and two ~-globin chains. There are four a-globin alleles and two ~-globin alleles. Mutations in one or two a-globin alleles or one ~-globin allele causes thalassemia minor. Thalassemia trait is common in Southeast Asia and presents with mild microcytic anemia. Features include the presence of target cells on peripheral blood smear (pictured in the photomicrograph above), a low RDW (which indicates that most erythrocytes are of the same size with little variation), and persistence of microcytosis. Iron concentrations can be measured to rule out iron deficiency. Other cell lines including platelets and white blood cells should be within normal ranges. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to distinguish between a- and ~-thalassemia minor. There is no treatment required for thalassemia minor as the resultant anemia is usually not severe. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Antibiotic-induced autoimmune hemolysis (Choice A) can occur after exposure to penicillins and cephalosporins, but the onset is typically acute and occurs within hours to days. While hemolysis can occur weeks later, it is less common. Additionally, patients would be expected to present with normocytic anemia and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Haptoglobin concentrations can be measured and will be decreased, while the reticulocyte count will typically be increased. Iron deficiency (Choice C) is a common cause of anemia in menstruating women, strict vegans or vegetarians, and those with chronic gastrointestinal bleeding or Celiac disease. It commonly presents with microcytosis, although often with a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) that is higher than what is seen in thalassemia, and an increased RDW indicating the release of premature erythrocytes, which are larger, from the bone marrow. The measurement of serum iron and ferritin are used to make the diagnosis. Transient postinfectious bone marrow suppression (Choice D) may occur following viral infections, but more commonly presents with leukopenia, which is not present in this case. In patients with sickle cell disease, infection with parvovirus B19 can cause a transient aplastic crisis and severe anemia. Vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency (Choice E) results in megaloblastic anemia, which presents with macrocytosis and segmented neutrophils. It is 12 more common in patients who chronically abuse alcohol, or in patients with a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, Crohn disease, or malabsorptive disorders. This patient demonstrates microcytic anemia. Educational Objective: Thalassemia minor can occur as a result of mutations or deletions in one of the ~-globin alleles or in one or two of the a-globin alleles, leading to the impaired production of globin chains. Patients typically demonstrate a mild microcytic anemia with a low red cell distribution width and normal concentrations of leukocytes and platelets. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to distinguish between these two entities. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 9 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
9. A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination . He has no history of serious illness . During the past 2 years , he has noticed brown urine whenever he has a cold . He has not had
dysuria or urinary urgency or incontinence . Examination shows no abnormalities . Laboratory studies show :
Serum
Urea nitrogen 15 mg/dl
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dl
C3 90 mg/dl (N=83-177)
Urine
Blood 4+
Protein 3+
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: lgA nephropathy (Berger disease) is a type of nephritic syndrome resulting in episodic gross hematuria, often following an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infection. Nephritic syndromes typically present with acute kidney injury with associated hematuria, red blood cell casts, and hypertension. On urinalysis, there will be a significant quantity of red blood cells (RBCs), possible RBC casts, and sub-nephrotic range proteinuria. Serum complement concentrations, including C3, are typically within reference ranges. This differentiates lgA nephropathy from postinfectious glomerulonephritis, which results in decreased serum C3 complement. Additionally, anti-streptolysin O and anti-DNase titers will be negative in lgA nephropathy. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, and E. Hemolytic uremic syndrome {Choice A) is caused by Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (O157:H?) and is usually accompanied by bloody diarrhea. This is characterized by a classic triad of thrombocytopenia, acute kidney injury, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Hemorrhagic cystitis {Choice B) refers to inflammation of the urinary bladder, which commonly is secondary to an acute bacterial urinary tract infection presenting with dysuria, urinary urgency, and frequency. A typical infectious cystitis presents with increased urinary white blood cells with detectable leukocyte esterase and nitrites on urinalysis, depending on the infectious organism. In hemorrhagic cystitis, red blood cells are also present on urinalysis. Nephrotic syndrome {Choice D) typically presents with excessive proteinuria (>3 g/day) hyperlipidemia, hypoalbuminemia, and peripheral edema. It does not cause hematuria. The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis {Choice E) is a nephritic syndrome presenting with urinary RBCs and RBC casts, which typically occurs between 2 and 6 weeks after infection with group A ~-hemolytic streptococci. Results of laboratory studies will show decreased serum C3 concentrations, and anti-streptolysin O and anti-DNase titers are positive. Educational Objective: lgA nephropathy (Berger disease) is a type of nephritic syndrome resulting in episodic gross hematuria, often following an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infection. Serum complement concentrations, including C3, are typically within reference ranges. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 10 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
10. A 13-year-old girl with cystic fibrosis is brought to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive difficulty breathing . Her mother says that her daughter 's hands and feet have appeared swollen during this period .
Her temperature is 37°C (98 .6°F) , pulse is 98/min , respirations are 30/min , and blood pressure is 124/84 mm Hg. Examination shows dusky nail beds and clubbing of the fingers and toes . There is nasal flaring and moderate
intercostal retractions . Bilateral crackles and rhonchi are heard on auscultation . S is loud and split in the second left intercostal space . The liver edge is palpated 5 cm below the right costal margin , and the spleen tip is
2
palpated 1 cm below the left costal margin . There is bilateral pitting edema over the dorsum of the hands and feet. Laboratory studies show :
Serum
Na +
126 mEq/L
CI- 84 mEq/L
K+
4.1 mEq/L
HC0
36 mEq/L
3
Albumin 2.8 g/dl
Urine protein 1+
Pulmonary function tests show a decrease in forced vital capacity from 75% to 30% of predicted value over the past year . An x-ray of the chest shows marked hyperinflation with coarse nodular infiltrates bilaterally . Which of
the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's edema?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for this patient's edema?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient with cystic fibrosis is likely presenting with findings of volume overload in cor pulmonale. Patients with cystic fibrosis may develop pulmonary hypertension as a result of hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction and fibrotic remodeling in chronically hypoventilated and inflamed pulmonary parenchyma leading to increased vascular resistance. If severe, this process can lead to cor pulmonale, which refers to isolated right heart failure secondary to chronic pulmonary pathology with increased pulmonary vascular resistance and right-sided heart pressures. Right heart failure typically presents with venous congestion, seen as jugular venous distention, peripheral edema, and hepatomegaly with or without ascites.

distractor_explanations.A: Cirrhosis of the liver occurs secondary to many causes, the most common being alcoholic and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. Cirrhosis presents with ascites, anasarca, jaundice, increased transaminases, low albumin concentration, and impaired hepatic synthetic function. While right heart failure may cause cirrhosis, this patient only has some consistent findings. Inferior vena cava obstruction (Choice C) causes the obstruction of venous drainage from the lower regions of the body, often related to an underlying malignancy and associated mass effect, thrombosis from an indwelling catheter, or as a result of compression by a gravid uterus. This patient lacks a history suggestive of any likely cause of inferior vena cava obstruction.
distractor_explanations.D: Lymphedema refers to swelling secondary to abnormal lymphatic drainage of a region, often secondary to surgery, radiation, or invasive parasitic disease. This patient lacks the appropriate history for these causes. Nephrotic syndrome (Choice E) results from many causes and typically presents with proteinuria, edema, hyperlipidemia, and a hypercoagulable state. Cystic fibrosis does not commonly cause nephrotic syndrome. Protein-losing enteropathy (Choice F) refers to any gastrointestinal pathology that results in the loss of protein, which may present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and peripheral edema. Potential causes include inflammatory bowel disease, celiac disease, and amyloidosis. Cystic fibrosis may cause steatorrhea. Vitamin E deficiency (Choice G) presents with hemolytic anemia and generalized muscle weakness. It can have a similar presentation to vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency with posterior column and spinocerebellar 12 tract demyelination.

explanation.educational_objective: Cor pulmonale refers to isolated right heart failure secondary to chronic pulmonary pathology with increased pulmonary vascular resistance and right-sided heart pressures. Patients with cystic fibrosis may develop pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale as a result of chronic alveolar hypoventilation with reactive pulmonary hypoxic vasoconstriction and vascular remodeling. r " , r-- r , 'I 11 . A 2-month -old infant has a large posterior fontanelle , a large tongue , and hypotonia. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation; pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 7 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes , respectively . Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of disease? A) Anterior horn cell degeneration B) Connective tissue disorder C) Cortical dysfunction D) Electrolyte imbalance E) Myopathy F) Peripheral neuropathy G) Spinal cord dysfunction H) Thyroid dysfunction CorrectAnswer: H. Congenital thyroid dysfunction that leads to hypothyroidism is typically asymptomatic at birth. This is because maternal thyroid hormone is able to cross the placenta, which keeps the newborn in a euthyroid state. Congenital hypothyroidism commonly presents in the first few months of life with feeding difficulties, lethargy, constipation, myxedematous facies, macroglossia, large fontanelles, hypotonia, and hypothermia. Infants with this disorder may also present with goiter, or congenital cardiac, kidney, or gastrointestinal malformations. Thyroid dysfunction can be caused by a variety of mechanisms, including thyroid dysgenesis, resistance to thyroid-stimulating hormone, abnormalities in thyroid hormone transport, iodine deficiency, maternal antibodies, or antithyroid medications. Congenital hypothyroidism is now typically identified on routine newborn screening. It is treated with thyroid hormone supplementation (eg, levothyroxine) but can lead to intellectual disability or neurologic issues (eg, hearing loss, ataxia) if untreated. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, D, E, F, and G. Anterior horn cell degeneration (Choice A) is seen in spinal muscular atrophy, which presents with hypotonia and weakness in the newborn. It can also present with a weak cry, difficulty feeding, and respiratory failure, which are not seen in this patient. Connective tissue disorders (Choice B) include Ehlers-Danlos and Marfan syndrome. These are not typically apparent at birth, rather manifesting later as hyperflexiblity and skin elasticity (Ehlers-Danlos) or tall stature with long extremities and fingers (Marfan syndrome). They are not associated with macroglossia or a large posterior fontanelle. Cortical dysfunction (Choice C) can occur secondary to cerebral palsy, intracranial hemorrhage, or a variety of other neurologic conditions. It would be expected to present more broadly with intellectual disability or developmental delay, as well neuromuscular abnormalities such as unilateral weakness or spastic paralysis. Electrolyte imbalances (Choice D) can lead to cardiac irritability (potassium, magnesium, calcium), skeletal abnormalities (calcium), altered mental status or neurologic abnormalities (sodium, calcium), and neuromuscular weakness (potassium, magnesium). Changes in electrolyte concentrations would not be expected to present with a large posterior fontanelle and tongue. Myopathy (Choice E) generally presents with muscle weakness, rather than hypotonia, although the latter can also be present. If present at 2 months of age, the diagnosis would likely be congenital myopathy. Depending on the subtype, congenital myopathies can present with a variety of symptoms and anatomic abnormalities, such as respiratory failure or scoliosis, although these do not include a large posterior fontanelle or macroglossia. Peripheral neuropathy (Choice F) commonly presents with paresthesias, numbness, or weakness in the extremities, and it can be caused by congenital disorders, diabetes mellitus, injury, or infection. It would not be expected to present with a large posterior fontanelle and tongue. Spinal cord dysfunction (Choice G) could present with weakness, numbness, paresthesias, or autonomic instability. However, it would be unlikely to cause anatomic changes superior to the area of dysfunction. Educational Objective: Congenital hypothyroidism presents in the first few months of life with feeding difficulties, lethargy, constipation, myxedematous facies, macroglossia, large fontanelles, hypotonia, and hypothermia. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
12. An 18-year-old man has had nausea , fatigue , and periorbital swelling for 4 days ; the swelling is worse in the morning . He had tonsillitis 2 weeks ago that resolved after treatment with penicillin . His temperature is
37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 92/min , respirations are 20/min , and blood pressure is 170/95 mm Hg. There is periorbital edema bilaterally and trace ankle edema . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities .
Laboratory studies show :
Serum
Urea nitrogen 60 mg/dl
Creatinine 4 mg/dl
Urine
Protein 1+
WBC few
RBC many
RBC casts 1/hpf
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A Acute renal failure

question_stem:
the most likely diagnosis?
A Acute renal failure

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient presents with acute renal failure following a tonsillar infection, consistent with a diagnosis of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), a nephritic syndrome. PSGN typically occurs between 2 and 4 weeks following an acute infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) (typically impetigo, streptococcal pharyngitis, or tonsillitis). Appropriate treatment of the streptococcal infection with antibiotics does not reduce the likelihood of subsequently developing PSGN. PSGN is caused by a type Ill hypersensitivity reaction with the kidney deposition of immune complexes and complement. Patients typically present with dark colored urine, hypertension, and peripheral and periorbital edema. Urinalysis typically shows red blood cell casts. The diagnosis is confirmed with kidney biopsy, which shows enlarged glomeruli on light microscopy, bumpy irregularity of the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescence, and subepithelial immune complex deposits on electron microscopy. Treatment is supportive and includes diuretics and antihypertensive agents.

distractor_explanations.B: Biventricular heart failure may occur in severe cases of myocarditis or rheumatic heart disease. Heart failure would not cause hematuria and red blood cell casts, which is more suggestive of a nephritic syndrome. Cirrhosis of the liver (Choice C) occurs secondary to many causes, the most common being alcoholic and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. Cirrhosis presents with ascites, anasarca, jaundice, increased transaminases, decreased albumin, and impaired hepatic synthetic function. It does not occur following streptococcal infections and does not usually present with hypertension or hematuria. Inferior vena cava obstruction (Choice D) prevents venous drainage from the inferior regions of the body, often related to an underlying malignancy and associated mass effect, thrombosis from an indwelling catheter, or as a result of compression by a gravid uterus. This patient lacks a history suggestive of any likely cause of inferior vena cava obstruction. Nephrotic syndrome (Choice E) results from many causes and typically presents with proteinuria, edema, hyperlipidemia, and a hypercoagulable state. PSGN is a primarily nephritic process and usually results in mild, sub-nephrotic range proteinuria.

explanation.educational_objective: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis can cause acute renal failure following an acute infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (group A) (typically impetigo, streptococcal pharyngitis, tonsillitis). Patients present with dark-colored urine, hypertension, and peripheral and periorbital edema; urinalysis shows red blood casts. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
13. A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of vaginal bleeding for 12 hours . She has a 3-month history of a purulent vaginal discharge . Breast and pubic hair development is Tanner stage 1. Examination
shows a purulent bloody discharge on her underwear . Which of the following is the most likely cause?

question_stem: the most likely cause?

distractor_explanations.A: Central lesion causing precocious puberty can occur with craniopharyngiomas, gliomas, or other central nervous system tumors. It is rare and would present with signs of precocious puberty including breast and pubic hair development, growth acceleration, and voice changes. Isolated menarche (Choice B) describes vaginal bleeding in a prepubertal child in which no secondary causes have been identified, such as precocious puberty, infection, foreign bodies, trauma, or tumors. In a patient with purulent and bloody vaginal discharge, the presence of a foreign body is more likely.
distractor_explanations.C: Vulvovaginitis involves the overgrowth of normal vaginal Candida flora, bacterial vaginosis, or Trichomonas vaginitis. Candida as a cause of vulvovaginitis can be distinguished from other causes by abnormal, often white, vaginal discharge with normal vaginal pH, negative KOH testing, and the absence of motile trichomonads on wet mount preparation. Risk factors for Candida vulvovaginitis include the use of medications, especially antibiotics, or an immunocompromised state. It would be unlikely in this child with none of these risk factors. Vaginal tumors (Choice E) can include squamous cell carcinoma, melanoma, adenocarcinoma, and sarcoma. Rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare, aggressive malignancy formed by striated muscle cells. It is found in children and can present as a genitourinary mass with hematuria, urinary tract obstruction, or a protruding vaginal mass.

explanation.educational_objective: Vaginal foreign bodies can present in prepubertal children with genital discomfort, vulvar erythema, vaginal discharge, or vaginal bleeding. While sexual abuse should be considered, vaginal a foreign bodies are more common as a result of child's curiosity and exploratory genital play. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Vaginal foreign bodies can present in prepubertal children with genital discomfort, vulvar erythema, vaginal discharge, or vaginal bleeding. While sexual abuse should be considered, vaginal a foreign

vignette.presentation:
14. A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 10 minutes after he was found coughing and choking near an open can of peanuts . His parents attempted a Heimlich
maneuver , but his condition did not improve . On arrival , he is agitated and unable to speak because of shortness of breath . His pulse is 150/min , respirations are 35/min , and blood
pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. Examination shows intercostal and suprasternal retractions . There are wheezes and poor air movement on the right. An expiratory x-ray of the chest is
shown . Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

question_stem: the most likely explanation for these findings?

choices.text: Complete obstruction and collapse of the left lung
Partial obstruction of the right main stem bronchus

distractor_explanations.A: Aspiration pneumonia on the left would be suggested if there were increased interstitial markings on the left side compared to the right during an inspiratory chest x-ray. Aspiration pneumonia may be caused by infection from oropharyngeal microbes. L R Complete obstruction and collapse of the left lung (Choice B) would appear as reduced volume on the left side with ipsilateral mediastinal shift caused by pressure from the compensatory hyperinflation of the right side. This expiratory film is more suggestive of a right bronchus obstruction, which is a more common site for foreign body aspiration. Obstruction of the midtrachea (Choice C) can be life-threatening because of disruption of air flow to both lungs. Obstructions in the trachea often present with stridor, a distinct high-pitched respiratory sound associated with abnormal laryngeal or tracheal air flow. Pneumothorax on the right (Choice E) is incorrect, as lung markings are present out to the periphery in the plain film. Spontaneous pneumothorax is more common in tall, thin males.

explanation.educational_objective: Partial obstruction of the airways, whether caused by foreign body aspiration or an obstructive pulmonary disease state, may be evaluated by contrasting inspiratory chest imaging with expiratory imaging. Obstruction is worsened by positive intrathoracic pressure during expiration, which results in air trapping in the affected lung segment. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Partial obstruction of the airways, whether caused by foreign body aspiration or an obstructive pulmonary disease state, may be evaluated by contrasting inspiratory chest imaging with expiratory imagi

vignette.presentation:
15. A previously healthy 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 2-hour history of increasing headache , dizziness , and nausea . His father is a butcher and says his son ate a new batch
of sausage shortly before he became ill. Earlier today, the patient was given the task of cleaning out the garage . On arrival , the patient is alert and is not in respiratory distress . His pulse is 136/min , respirations are 20/min , and
blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 73% that increases to 80% when 15 L/min of oxygen is administered via face mask . Examination shows profound central cyanosis .
The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . His methemoglobin is 40 .5% of his total hemoglobin . Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows :
7.37
42 mm Hg
48 mm Hg
24 mEq/L
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Methemoglobinemia occurs when an abnormal fraction of heme iron in the blood exists in the ferric (Fe 3 form (methemoglobin). Methemoglobin cannot effectively bind oxygen, which impairs tissue oxygen delivery. •) Most cases of methemoglobinemia are acquired, typically via exposure to an oxidant stressor such as an anesthetic (eg, benzocaine), nitrate, or dapsone. Symptoms include shortness of breath, fatigue, lethargy, lightheadedness, and in severe cases, arrhythmia, seizure, and multisystem organ failure. Vital signs typically show reduced oxygen saturation, and examination may disclose cyanosis. Characteristically, blood appears darkened on gross visualization, although hemoglobin concentration and erythrocyte morphology are normal. Treatment includes supplemental oxygen plus the intravenous administration of methylene blue, a reducing agent that donates electrons to heme. The reduction of heme iron to the ferrous (Fe 2 form restores the ability of hemoglobin to bind, carry, and deliver oxygen to tissues. •) lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, E, and F. Administration of atropine (Choice A) would be indicated in cases of symptomatic bradycardia or organophosphate poisoning. This patient's pulse is tachycardic and atropine administration would be inappropriate. Administration of deferoxamine (Choice B) is indicated in the treatment of hemochromatosis or iron toxicity. It is a therapy that binds free iron in the serum and promotes elimination in the urine. Administration of naloxone (Choice D) is indicated in cases of opioid overdose. Opioid overdoses are characterized by respiratory depression presenting as a decreased respiratory rate, apnea, and hypoxia. This patient's hypoxia is caused by methemoglobinemia, not respiratory depression. Administration of pyridostigmine (Choice E) is used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis. It is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the concentration of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (Choice F) can be helpful in the treatment of decompression sickness and carbon monoxide poisoning. Educational Objective: Methemoglobinemia occurs when an abnormal fraction of heme iron in the blood exists in the ferric (Fe 3 form (methemoglobin). The treatment of methemoglobinemia includes supplemental •) oxygen plus the intravenous administration of methylene blue, a reducing agent that donates electrons to heme. The reduction of heme iron to the ferrous (Fe 2 form restores the ability of hemoglobin to bind, carry, •) and deliver oxygen to tissues. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 16 of 50 'I
