6. A 3-week-old boy is brought to the physician 4 hours after the onset of vomiting watery, green material. His mother says that he has been drawing up his legs as if in pain while vomiting . He appears uncomfortable . He is
afebrile . The abdomen is tender but not distended. An abdominal x-ray shows dilated loops of small bowel and air-fluid levels . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Foreign body ingestion I) Pyloric stenosis

explanation.educational_objective: Congenital malrotation of the intestines predisposes to midgut volvulus, which presents with signs of small bowel obstruction including bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. X-ray findings of small bowel obstruction include dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Congenital malrotation of the intestines predisposes to midgut volvulus, which presents with signs of small bowel obstruction including bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. X-ray findings of sma

vignette.presentation:
7. A 2-week-old girl is brought for her first well-child examination . Newborn screening showed an increased thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) concentration . Her mother takes propylthiouracil for hyperthyroidism . The patient is
active and eating well. Examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?

question_stem: the most appropriate management of this patient?

choices.text: Reassurance and follow-up examination in 1 month
Measurement of serum growth hormone concentration
Measurement of serum thyroid-binding globulin concentration
Measurement of serum thyroxine TA) and TSH concentrations

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Acrocyanosis refers to a blue-to-purple color of the acral extremities (hands, feet) and around the mouth. It is induced by peripheral vasoconstriction and is a normal finding in healthy babies. Cyanosis is evaluated in the Apgar scoring performed at every hospital delivery at 1 and 5 minutes after birth. A neonate who is completely pink is given the maximum score of 2, a neonate with blue extremities is given a score of 1, and a neonate who is completely pale or blue is given a score of

distractor_explanations.A: month would be inappropriate because of an increased TSH of unclear cause. Early detection and treatment of congenital hypothyroidism is crucial to prevent long-term disability. Measurement of serum growth hormone concentration (Choice B) may be appropriate in patients with suspected central hypothyroidism, who may present with symptoms concerning for deficiencies in TSH along with other pituitary hormones, such as growth hormone. This patient's laboratory testing instead demonstrates increased TSH concentrations, which indicates a dysfunctional thyroid gland as the cause of hypothyroidism. Measurement of serum thyroid-binding globulin concentration (Choice C) or a thyroid scan (Choice E) may ultimately be indicated to elucidate the cause of hypothyroidism. However, the physician must first perform repeat laboratory testing to confirm that the patient continues to demonstrate hypothyroidism. Thyroid-binding globulin assists in the transport of thyroid hormone to its target tissues, and decreased concentrations may indicate thyroid-binding globulin deficiency or thyroid gland dysgenesis. Levothyroxine therapy (Choice F) may be indicated to treat congenital primary hypothyroidism. However, if repeat laboratory testing shows normal thyroid hormone concentrations, indicating transient congenital hypothyroidism, then levothyroxine would not be needed.

explanation.educational_objective: Congenital hypothyroidism can reflect transient congenital hypothyroidism (eg, from maternal antithyroid medication) or congenital primary hypothyroidism. Repeat serum testing can distinguish between these two causes. Congenital hypothyroidism is frequently asymptomatic at birth, though it may present with lethargy, hypothermia, feeding problems, hoarse cry, myxedematous facies, macroglossia, hypotonia, umbilical hernia, prolonged jaundice, and dry skin, along with intellectual disability in childhood. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Congenital hypothyroidism can reflect transient congenital hypothyroidism (eg, from maternal antithyroid medication) or congenital primary hypothyroidism. Repeat serum testing can distinguish between

vignette.presentation:
8. A 2-month -old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination . Pregnancy was uncomplicated . He was born at term following forceps delivery for fetal heart rate decelerations . Apgar scores were 4 and 8 at 1 and 5
minutes , respectively . He is at the 50th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. He keeps his head turned to the right and cries when it is moved toward the left. Examination shows flattening of the right posterior part
of the skull. A 1.5-cm mass is palpated in the left side of the neck . Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

question_stem: the most likely cause of these findings?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient likely experienced an injury of the sternomastoid (also known as sternocleidomastoid, or SCM) muscle as a result of birth trauma, leading to congenital torticollis. Torticollis refers to an abnormal contraction of the neck muscles that results in the head tilting to one side. Congenital torticollis typically presents beginning at 2 to 4 weeks of age with a preferred head position, decreased cervical range of motion, and a mass of the SCM. Hypothesized causes include birth trauma (eg, forceps delivery) or intrauterine malposition of the head, which may lead to SCM injury and consequent fibrosis and contracture of the SCM. The fibrosis may present as a mass of the SCM on physical examination. Birth trauma or intrauterine head malposition may also lead to plagiocephaly (flattening of the head). The diagnosis of congenital torticollis is clinical. Treatment requires physical therapy interventions to stretch the SCM, which leads to the resolution of torticollis in most infants.

distractor_explanations.A: Cervical spine hemivertebrae refers to a rare condition of incomplete vertebral ossification in the cervical spine and may present with cervical scoliosis, neck pain, and torticollis. This condition is not associated with birth trauma and would not demonstrate plagiocephaly or a mass of the SCM.
distractor_explanations.B: Craniosynostosis refers to the premature ossification (closure) of some cranial bone sutures, resulting in asymmetric skull growth in infants. Torticollis and a mass of the SCM would be atypical. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (Choice C) refers to a heterogeneous group of conditions of neonatal central nervous system dysfunction that results from ischemic injury. Patients may present with decreased Apgar scores, an abnormal state of consciousness, a weak cry, poor tone, respiratory distress, feeding difficulties, absent primitive reflexes, or seizures. Similarly, prenatal stroke (Choice E) refers to a heterogeneous group of primarily idiopathic stroke syndromes that may present with nonspecific symptoms such as drowsiness, crying, poor feeding, and seizure. Focal deficits such as torticollis and plagiocephaly are more consistent with birth trauma, and a mass of the SCM would be atypical. Left or right clavicle fractures (Choices D and F) are the most common traumatic injuries during vaginal birth. Patients typically present with pain, swelling, and deformity along the affected clavicle.
distractor_explanations.H: Syringobulbia refers to a rare condition involving a central cystic lesion of the brainstem. Patients typically present with lower cranial nerve and cerebellar signs along with involuntary movements such as torticollis and dystonia. Plagiocephaly and a mass of the SCM would be atypical.

explanation.educational_objective: Congenital torticollis typically presents in newborns with a preferred head position, decreased cervical range of motion, and a sternocleidomastoid muscle mass. Hypothesized causes include birth trauma (eg, forceps delivery) or intrauterine malposition of the head, which may lead to SCM injury and fibrosis. The fibrosis may present as a mass on physical examination. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Congenital torticollis typically presents in newborns with a preferred head position, decreased cervical range of motion, and a sternocleidomastoid muscle mass. Hypothesized causes include birth traum

vignette.presentation:
9. A previously healthy 7-year-old girl is admitted to the hospital because of an 11-day history of fever , fatigue , and progressive nonproductive cough . During the past 2 weeks , she has had a decreased appetite , resulting in a
1 .4-kg (3-lb) weight loss . The family lives on a farm in Missouri , and the patient often plays in an abandoned chicken coop . Her direct contact to animals is limited to a pet dog and turtle . She has not travelled outside of the state
during the past 9 months and has never been out of the USA. She appears alert . She is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 110/min, respirations are 34/min , and blood
pressure is 96/57 mm Hg. Mild wheezes are heard bilaterally . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Laboratory studies show :
Hemoglobin 12.3 g/dL
Leukocyte count 11 ,300/mm 3
Segmented neutrophils 48%
Bands 2%
Lymphocytes 46%
Monocytes 4%
Platelet count 210 ,000/mm 3
An x-ray and CT scan of the chest are shown . A blood culture obtained 4 days ago shows no growth . A PPD skin test performed 3 days ago shows no induration ; a mumps control skin test shows 8 mm of induration . A biopsy
specimen of a mediastinal lymph node shows necrotizing granulomas . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

distractor_explanations.A: and acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) (Choice B) are hematologic malignancies. ALL is more common in children than AML. The clinical presentations of both are similar, as they are caused by the relative burden of leukemic cells, including malaise, persistent fever, bleeding or bruising, bone pain, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Neither would demonstrate necrotizing granulomas on lymph node biopsy. Chlamydia trachomatis infection (Choice C) can cause cervicitis, urethritis, pelvic inflammatory disease, neonatal pneumonia, and neonatal conjunctivitis. Other Chlamydia species, Chlamydophila pneumoniae and Chlamydophila psittaci, are causes of atypical pneumonia, which appear as diffuse, patchy alveolar and interstitial opacities on lung imaging. Q fever (Choice E) is a vector-borne illness caused by infection with Coxiella burnetii. Coxiella burnetii is acquired through the inhalation of spores from cattle or sheep amniotic fluid, to which this patient did not have exposure. Q fever commonly presents as pneumonia or endocarditis. Salmonella enteritidis infection (Choice F) causes nontyphoidal salmonellosis, a leading cause of food borne illness. It is contracted by the consumption of raw or undercooked poultry and eggs. Nausea, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea are classic features of salmonellosis.
distractor_explanations.G: Tuberculosis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a slow-growing organism transmitted via respiratory droplets. It presents with primary, latent, and reactivation patterns. In primary disease, patients present with subacute fevers, weight loss, night sweats, cough, and malaise. A PPD, or tuberculin, test identifies exposure to tuberculosis and was negative in this case.

explanation.educational_objective: Histoplasmosis is an endemic fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. It is endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys in the United States; exposure to bird or bat droppings are risk factors. Pulmonary histoplasmosis can present in acute, subacute, or chronic phases, generally characterized by fevers, malaise, myalgia, cough, and hemoptysis with the associated development of small calcified nodules and mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Histoplasmosis is an endemic fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. It is endemic to the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys in the United States; exposure to bird or bat droppings are risk

vignette.presentation:
10. A 25-year-old woman , gravida 2, para 1, at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She feels well , and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated . Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with
a 20-week gestation . She reports that her first child had bloody diarrhea as an infant when he was fed cow milk-based formula . The diarrhea resolved when the formula was changed to a hypoallergenic type . She states that she
avoids dairy products because they upset her stomach . She asks how she can prevent food allergies in her next child . Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation ?

question_stem: the most appropriate recommendation ?

choices.text: Delay the introduction of solid food until the age of 9 months
Do not feed the infant eggs or peanut-based products until the age of 9 months
Exclusively breast-feed for at least 6 months
Use a hypoallergenic formula for at least 6 months
Use a lactose-free formula exclusively for at least 9 months

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Food allergies are a component of the atopic triad, which consists of atopic dermatitis, asthma, and food or environmental allergies. Food allergies may be immunoglobulin E (lgE)-mediated (eg, urticaria, angioedema, anaphylaxis) or non-lgE-mediated (eg, food protein-induced proctitis, proctocolitis, enterocolitis). Exclusive breast-feeding for at least 6 months is hypothesized to decrease the rate of food allergy in infants. Dietary avoidance of allergenic foods during pregnancy or lactation does not lead to decreased rates of food allergies in children. In actuality, introducing allergenic foods into the diet while lactating may lead to an increased likelihood of tolerance developing in the child and decreased rates of food allergy.

distractor_explanations.A: Delaying the introduction of solid food or delaying introduction of allergenic foods including eggs and peanut-based products (Choice B) until the age of 9 months has not been shown to decrease rates of food allergy. In contrast, the early introduction of allergenic foods has been recommended in order to improve tolerance to these foods. Use of a hypoallergenic formula for at least 6 months (Choice D) or a lactose-free formula for at least 9 months (Choice E) is not necessary nor shown to decrease food allergy development. In contrast, exclusive breast-feeding for at least 6 months is recommended. At 6 months, solid foods can begin to be introduced.

explanation.educational_objective: Exclusive breast-feeding for at least 6 months is hypothesized to decrease the rate of food allergy in infants. r " , r-- r , 'I 11 . A 2-month -old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-week history of sweating and fatigue during feedings . His mother has also noticed that he seems to breathe fast and has a pounding heart rate at rest. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery . He is at the 50th percentile for length and 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 145/min , respirations are 70/min , and blood pressure is 92/40 mm Hg. Examination shows prominence of the left precordium and a palpable parasternal lift. A blowing holosystolic murmur is heard best over the lower left sternal border. A chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascular markings . Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms? A) Anomalous pulmonary blood return B) Increased peripheral vascular resistance C) Increased systemic vascular resistance D) Intermittent supraventricular tachycardia E) Left-to-right shunt Correct Answer: E. A left-to-right shunt from a large ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most likely explanation of this patient's cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascular markings, and failure to thrive. VSDs are among the most common congenital heart malformations. The genetic cause ofVSDs is heterogeneous and includes known associations with well-defined syndromes such as Down, DiGeorge, or Holt-Oram syndrome. It may also occur in isolation and via nonspecific, random mutations and individual point mutations that are de nova. VSDs are characterized by a holosystolic murmur best heard in the left lower sternal border and may have an associated palpable thrill. VSDs result in a left-to-right shunt, which increases pulmonary blood flow. This leads to remodeling of the pulmonary vasculature and resultant smooth muscle hypertrophy. In turn, concentric narrowing of the pulmonary arterioles occurs, which results in the development of pulmonary arterial hypertension. If severe and progressive enough, this can cause increased right ventricular pressures and associated myocardial hypertrophy, which subsequently results in reversal of the shunt (Eisenmenger syndrome), presenting with shortness of breath and cyanosis. Increased pulmonary blood flow results in increased blood return to the left atrium, which may cause left atrial enlargement. Incorrect Answer: A, B, C, and D. Anomalous pulmonary blood return (Choice A) can be total or partial. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return is a congenital heart defect whereby oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins returns to the right atrium, not the left atrium. The presence of a second shunt is necessary to shunt blood from the right to left circulations. It does not present with a holosystolic murmur. Increased peripheral vascular resistance (Choice B), which is also known as systemic vascular resistance (Choice C), refers to increased tone within the peripheral vasculature. It is a normal response to decreased cardiac output in an attempt to maintain peripheral organ perfusion pressure. It does not explain this patient's presentation. Intermittent supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) (Choice D) refers to the presence of cardiac arrhythmias that present with a rapid heart rate originating from above the ventricles (eg, multifocal atrial tachycardia, atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia). ECG would likely demonstrate a narrow QRS complex with or without P waves. A holosystolic murmur is not seen in this condition and does not explain the patient's presentation. Educational Objective: VSDs are common cardiac malformations that result in a left-to-right intracardiac shunt. They may form in isolation or in conjunction with other malformations. The majority are asymptomatic and will self-resolve, but severe disease can result in pulmonary hypertension and the development of Eisenmenger syndrome, if untreated. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Exclusive breast-feeding for at least 6 months is hypothesized to decrease the rate of food allergy in infants. r " , r-- r , 'I 11 . A 2-month -old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-week

vignette.presentation:
12. A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of severe pain and swelling in her right sternoclavicular joint. Ten days ago , the patient had a sore throat. She has no history of serious illness and takes no
medications . Her temperature is 40°C (104 °F). Examination shows erythema , swelling , and tenderness of the right sternoclavicular joint. Aspiration of the affected joint yields thick , yellow , purulent fluid . A Gram stain of the fluid
shows numerous segmented neutrophils and numerous gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the left sternoclavicular joint

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient with monoarticular septic arthritis of the sternoclavicular joint from disseminated infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae should undergo arthrocentesis with culture of the aspirate fluid. Septic arthritis commonly occurs in children as a result of trauma to the joint permitting the translocation of cutaneous organisms (eg, Staphylococcus aureus) and may also occur in adolescents as a result of the dissemination of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted bacterium that initially causes cervicitis, urethritis, or pharyngitis and may hematogenously disseminate to cause septic arthritis. Septic arthritis classically presents with a painful, erythematous, swollen joint along with systemic signs and symptoms of illness such as fever, chills, myalgia, arthralgia, and nausea. Gonococcal arthritis may present with monoarticular or asymmetric polyarticular disease and may feature adjacent tenosynovitis and dermatitis. The most common sites of gonococcal infection are the knee, ankle, wrist, and elbow, though the sternoclavicular joint may also be affected. In all causes of septic arthritis, serum laboratory values typically show leukocytosis along with increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein concentrations. Diagnosis requires arthrocentesis, which typically demonstrates purulent aspirate fluid with an increased concentration of neutrophil-predominant white blood cells. In gonococcal arthritis, culture of the aspirate fluid may disclose gram-negative diplococci. Management requires antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin along with source control.

distractor_explanations.B: ray may be used to detect late findings of underlying osteomyelitis (eg, erosions) in patients with septic arthritis caused by the translocation of cutaneous organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus. However, osteomyelitis is less likely to result from gonococcal arthritis.
distractor_explanations.C: Echocardiography would be helpful in diagnosing gonococcal endocarditis, a rare complication of disseminated Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. However, this patient with symptoms localized to a joint most likely has gonococcal arthritis. CT scan of the left sternoclavicular joint (Choice D) may assist in the visualization of a joint effusion. This is especially true in difficult-to-examine joints such as the hip. However, joint aspiration is the preferred method for definitively diagnosing septic arthritis. Indium-labeled leukocyte scan (Choice E), a nuclear medicine procedure that adds a radioactive tag to white blood cells, assists in localizing sites of infection and inflammation, and is often used in patients with a fever of unknown origin. This patient possesses a clear source of infection.

explanation.educational_objective: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted bacterium that initially causes cervicitis, urethritis, or pharyngitis, and may hematogenously disseminate to cause septic arthritis. Gonococcal arthritis may present with monoarticular or asymmetric polyarticular erythema, edema, and tenderness. Diagnosis requires culture of the aspirate synovial fluid, which typically demonstrates gram-negative diplococci and an increased concentration of neutrophil-predominant white blood cells. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted bacterium that initially causes cervicitis, urethritis, or pharyngitis, and may hematogenously disseminate to cause septic arthritis. Gonococcal arthrit

vignette.presentation:
13. A 5000-g (11-lb 1-oz) male infant is born at term to a 35-year-old woman following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Initial examination shows that he is large for gestational age and has macroglossia , visceromegaly ,
and an omphalocele . This infant most likely has which of the following associated conditions?

question_stem: most likely has which of the following associated conditions?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is a genetic disorder involving mutations of any of several genes located at the 11p15.5 locus that may result from a variety of mechanisms, including defects of imprinting or uniparental disomy. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is characterized by cellular overgrowth and a predisposition to the development of malignancy. Its presentation is heterogenous but commonly includes an above average birth weight, macrosomia, macroglossia, visceromegaly, renal malformations, omphalocele, or umbilical hernia. Children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at an increased risk for developing a variety of malignancies, such as Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma. Although the underlying mechanism is poorly understood, as many as half of children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are affected by neonatal hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia. The diagnosis is confirmed with cytogenetic testing.

distractor_explanations.A: Congenital heart disease may occur as either an isolated anomaly or in association with a variety of syndromes, such as trisomy 21. Congenital heart defects are not commonly associated with Beckwith Wiedemann syndrome. lmperforate anus (Choice C) may occur either as a sporadic defect or as part of syndromic associations such as VACTERL (an association of findings characterized by vertebral anomalies, anorectal malformations, cardiovascular anomalies, tracheoesophageal fistula, esophageal atresia, renal anomalies, and limb defects). lmperforate anus is not commonly observed in association with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.
distractor_explanations.D: Polycythemia may occur in association with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, but it is rare in comparison with hypoglycemia. Neonatal polycythemia commonly occurs in post-term infants and in infants with mothers affected by gestational diabetes mellitus. Renal tubular acidosis (Choice E) is a family of disorders that causes hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and an inability to either absorb HCO -or excrete titratable acid in the form of NH Renal tubular acidosis is •. 3 4 not commonly associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

explanation.educational_objective: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is a heterogenous genetic disorder involving the 11p15.5 locus and is characterized by above average birth weight, macrosomia, macroglossia, visceromegaly, renal malformations, omphalocele, umbilical hernia, and an increased risk for malignancy such as Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma. As many as half of children with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are affected by neonatal hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is a heterogenous genetic disorder involving the 11p15.5 locus and is characterized by above average birth weight, macrosomia, macroglossia, visceromegaly, renal malformati

vignette.presentation:
14. A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of headache and dizziness for the past week . She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections . At the age of 2 years , she received the diagnosis of vesicoureteral reflux
and was treated with prophylactic amoxicillin until the age of 6 years . She has been admitted to the hospital twice for treatment of pyelonephritis . Development is appropriate for age , and her immunizations are up-to-date . Her
height and weight are below the 5th percentile . Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) , pulse is 80/min , respirations are 16/min , and blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg in all four extremities . Funduscopic examination shows narrowing
of the retinal arteries . Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Follow-up blood pressure measurement in 1 week
Measurement of serum urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Measurement of serum urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis. This patient with chronic vesicoureteral reflux and a history of recurrent pyelonephritis with new onset headache and dizziness in the setting of hypertension most likely has hypertensive urgency that has developed as a result of chronic kidney disease. Chronic vesicoureteral reflux predisposes patients to the development of recurrent pyelonephritis as urine from the bladder travels in a retrograde fashion to the kidneys. Recurrent pyelonephritis can lead to scarring of the renal parenchyma and loss of nephron mass, which decreases the glomerular filtration rate, and can lead to chronic kidney disease. Hypertension is a common complication of chronic renal disease and results primarily from impaired handling of sodium leading to expansion of the intravascular volume and subsequent systolic hypertension. Over time, chronic vascular remodeling and increased systemic vascular resistance lead to an increase in diastolic blood pressure. Assessment of the serum urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations is an appropriate first step in assessing kidney function. Increases in both are suggestive of kidney injury. Further assessment of urinary protein excretion is also appropriate.

distractor_explanations.A: week is not appropriate at this time. The patient is presenting with symptoms, including headache and dizziness, that may be attributed to her hypertension. Further workup to determine the cause of her hypertension with simultaneous treatment is necessary. Blood cultures (Choice B) are not necessary. The patient is afebrile and has no flank pain or dysuria, making the diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis unlikely. Thyroid function tests (Choice D) are typically completed in the evaluation of secondary hypertension but would not be the first step. Hypothyroidism is more commonly associated with hypertension than hyperthyroidism, but patients also typically present with weight gain, constipation, fatigue, and cold intolerance. CT scan of the head (Choice E) should be considered in patients with focal neurologic deficits or severe, sudden onset headache, to rule out hemorrhagic stroke or subarachnoid hemorrhage. This patient has had a headache for 1 week and has no neurologic deficits reported; a CT scan would likely provide little additional diagnostic information and would not be the best next step.

explanation.educational_objective: Chronic vesicoureteral reflux predisposes patients to recurrent pyelonephritis, which can result in scarring of the renal parenchyma and loss of nephron mass leading to chronic kidney disease. Impaired salt handling in chronic renal disease leads to expansion of the intravascular volume and subsequent hypertension. Laboratory evaluation should include the measurement of serum urea nitrogen and creatinine concentrations. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Chronic vesicoureteral reflux predisposes patients to recurrent pyelonephritis, which can result in scarring of the renal parenchyma and loss of nephron mass leading to chronic kidney disease. Impaire

vignette.presentation:
15. An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 4-day history of pallor. He has not had cough , rash , abdominal pain, vomiting , or diarrhea . He is alert but pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 150/min ,
respirations are 36/min , and blood pressure is 90/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities . The stool is maroon , and test for occult blood is positive . His hemoglobin concentration is 8 g/dl. Which of the following is the
most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

question_stem: most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

distractor_explanations.A: ray of the abdomen is not sensitive for Meckel diverticulum. It is the first step in identifying a small bowel obstruction or ruling out gastrointestinal perforation but will not provide information about the cause of this patient's gastrointestinal bleeding. Upper gastrointestinal series (Choice B) refers to a series of upper abdominal x-rays taken after the administration of oral contrast. This allows for the visualization of the proximal gastrointestinal tract to assess for a variety of conditions, such as duodenal atresia, malrotation, and midgut volvulus, among others. A gastrointestinal series is unable to identify a Meckel diverticulum. HIDA scan (Choice C) is a nuclear medicine scan used to diagnose cholecystitis when ultrasound is indeterminate. This patient's symptoms are more consistent with a gastrointestinal bleed secondary to a Meckel diverticulum than cholecystitis.
distractor_explanations.E: Anoscopy refers to a direct visualization technique of the anus and distal rectum. Anoscopy is used to visualize bleeding hemorrhoids, which is another cause of bright red bleed per rectum but does not typically cause a decrease in hemoglobin.

explanation.educational_objective: Meckel scan, or technetium 99m pertechnetate scan, is the modality used to confirm a Meckel diverticulum. A Meckel diverticulum is a small diverticulum projecting from the terminal ileum, which may contain ectopic gastric mucosa and lead to painless gastrointestinal bleeding. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Meckel scan, or technetium 99m pertechnetate scan, is the modality used to confirm a Meckel diverticulum. A Meckel diverticulum is a small diverticulum projecting from the terminal ileum, which may co

vignette.presentation:
16. A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of confusion , decreased awareness , headache , weakness , and dyspnea . When his mother returned home from work , she found him sitting
in front of the television with the space heater on and an open package of cookies and glass of milk nearby. The most appropriate treatment is administration of which of the following?

question_stem: The most appropriate treatment is administration of which of the following?

distractor_explanations.A: Acetylcysteine is the principal antidote for acetaminophen toxicity. Acetaminophen, in toxic doses, overwhelms phase II metabolic pathways (eg, sulfation, acetylation) with consequent depletion of glutathione stores; excess is metabolized to the toxic metabolite N-acetyl-P-benzoquinoneimine, a strong oxidant. Acetylcysteine regenerates hepatic glutathione stores, limiting oxidative damage. Amyl nitrite (Choice B) is an antidote for cyanide poisoning; nitrites induce the formation of methemoglobin, which in turn sequesters cyanide as cyanomethemoglobin, preventing its disruption of the electron transport chain. Its use is less frequent, as cobalamin also sequesters cyanide without interfering with hemoglobin and oxygen-carrying capacity.
distractor_explanations.C: Atropine is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning and is a cholinergic antagonist. Organophosphate toxicity is common in the developing world; organophosphates bind to the active site of acetylcholinesterase, preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine. Resultant cholinergic excess leads to bronchospasm, bronchorrhea, bradycardia, diarrhea, lacrimation, and salivation. Atropine reverses the impact of cholinergic excess on the heart and lungs.
distractor_explanations.D: Deferoxamine is an antidote for iron toxicity, which can be fatal in excess as a consequence of hepatic failure and profound metabolic acidosis. Dimercaprol (BAL) (Choice E) is an antidote commonly used to treat arsenic and mercury poisoning, though it additionally chelates lead and gold in serum. Methylene blue (Choice F) is an antidote for methemoglobinemia; it serves to decrease iron in methemoglobin to Fe 2 restoring its ability to bind and transport oxygen. Methemoglobinemia may occur secondary to •, the use of nitrites and anesthetics.
distractor_explanations.G: Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist used in the treatment of opiate overdose, which presents with bradypnea and miosis. Naloxone has also been used to treat clonidine overdose. Vitamin K (Choice I) is used to reverse the effect of overdoses of warfarin and coumarin, which are used therapeutically to decrease the risk for thromboembolic events and are still found in commercial rat poison.

explanation.educational_objective: CO has an affinity for hemoglobin that is hundreds of times greater than that of oxygen, readily displacing oxygen from heme. Treatment for CO poisoning begins with the administration of 100% oxygen. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: CO has an affinity for hemoglobin that is hundreds of times greater than that of oxygen, readily displacing oxygen from heme. Treatment for CO poisoning begins with the administration of 100% oxygen.

vignette.presentation:
17. A previously healthy 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive fatigue and nervousness , intermittent blurred vision , and declining school performance . She has had a 3-kg (6.6-lb)
weight loss during this period despite an increased appetite . Her sister has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine . The patient's temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min , respirations are 18/min , and blood pressure is
110/80 mm Hg. Examination shows warm flushed skin and fine soft hair. There is mild exophthalmos and lid lag. Funduscopic examination and visual fields show no abnormalities . Examination of the neck shows an enlarged
thyroid gland with a bruit. There is a fine tremor when her upper extremities are outstretched . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland
Malignant infiltration of the thyroid gland

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Graves disease is an autoimmune hyperthyroid condition caused by thyroid-stimulating autoantibodies that activate the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor. Hyperstimulation of the TSH receptor leads to overproduction of thyroid hormone and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland on physical examination, along with signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism including weight loss, insomnia, palpitations, heat intolerance, warm skin, tremor, diaphoresis, and pretibial myxedema. TSH-receptor-stimulating antibodies also stimulate orbital fibroblasts and lead to thyroid ophthalmopathy, which is characterized by the expansion of orbital fat and connective tissue with resultant exophthalmos, lid lag, and restrictive strabismus. Thyroid ophthalmopathy may lead to diplopia, corneal exposure, compressive optic neuropathy, and a cosmetic appearance that is distressing for patients. Thyroid laboratory studies typically demonstrate primary hyperthyroidism with increased thyroxine and triiodothyronine, and decreased TSH. Radioactive iodine uptake nuclear scintigraphy typically demonstrates diffuse, abnormally increased uptake of the thyroid gland without a discrete nodule. Graves disease is treated with antithyroid drugs such as methimazole and propylthiouracil, and radioactive iodine ablation of the thyroid gland. Thyroid ophthalmopathy typically responds well to topical lubrication, although severe cases may require intravenous corticosteroids and a staged surgical approach.

distractor_explanations.A: Levothyroxine overdose may present with signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism including tachycardia, hypertension, tremor, and anxiety. Severe cases may cause convulsions and coma. This patient's history of progressive symptoms over a four-month period, as well as her symptoms of exophthalmos and lid lag, are not consistent with an overdose event. Lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland (Choice B) is characteristic of Hashimoto disease. While patients with Hashimoto disease may present with transient symptoms of hyperthyroidism during the acute stage, patients progress to develop signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism, including fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, hyporeflexia, myxedema, and dry, cool skin. Hashimoto disease does not cause orbital findings of exophthalmos and lid lag. Malignant infiltration of the thyroid gland (Choice C) may lead to symptoms of hyperthyroidism through the destruction of thyroid follicular cells with resultant release of thyroid hormone, though patients are generally euthyroid. This mechanism would not cause orbital findings of exophthalmos and lid lag. Thyroid-stimulating hormone-producing pituitary tumor (Choice D) would lead to hyperthyroidism and laboratory findings of an increased serum concentration of TSH, as well as thyroid hormone.

explanation.educational_objective: Graves disease is an autoimmune hyperthyroid condition caused by thyroid-stimulating antibodies that activate the TSH receptor. Overproduction of thyroid hormone causes signs and symptoms of weight loss, insomnia, palpitations, heat intolerance, warm skin, tremor, diaphoresis, and pretibial myxedema. The presence of thyroid eye disease, characterized by exophthalmos, lid lag, and restrictive strabismus, is highly suggestive of Graves disease. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Graves disease is an autoimmune hyperthyroid condition caused by thyroid-stimulating antibodies that activate the TSH receptor. Overproduction of thyroid hormone causes signs and symptoms of weight lo

vignette.presentation:
18. A 2807-g (6-lb 3-oz) newborn has a strong cry immediately after delivery . She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and a spontaneous vaginal delivery complicated by a few decelerations . The newborn was
suctioned at the perineum and placed on the warmer/resuscitation table . After 10 seconds of warming , the newborn's pulse is greater than 100/min , and respirations are 20/min . Examination shows peripheral cyanosis and
minimal movement of the upper and lower extremities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: The initiation of breathing following delivery is crucial for the newborn. A substantial portion of neonates require assistance with the initiation of breathing. Initial, universal steps after delivery include an assessment of the newborn's heart and respiratory rates, muscle tone, reflexes, and color, and immediate warming, drying, and tactile stimulation, all of which are helpful for stimulating spontaneous respirations. Neonates who fail to respond to gentle tactile stimulation should be immediately supported with more invasive support techniques, such as bag and mask ventilation or endotracheal intubation. Tactile stimulation and oxygen therapy are noninvasive and are therefore an appropriate initial step.

distractor_explanations.B: Naloxone therapy may be useful for the immediate reversal of opioid toxicity in neonates. This neonate does not have any known risk factors for opioid toxicity and tactile stimulation is a more appropriate next step. Subcutaneous epinephrine therapy (Choice C) is useful for the treatment of anaphylaxis. This newborn has no exposure to agents likely to cause anaphylaxis, the most common of which is a food allergy. Epinephrine is appropriate for newborns with bradycardia in the setting of neonatal resuscitation. Positive-pressure ventilation via face mask (Choice D) and immediate intubation (Choice E) are both appropriate next steps if the newborn remains apneic and does not respond to initial efforts of tactile stimulation. However, these methods are both invasive and are not appropriate first steps.

explanation.educational_objective: Many neonates require assistance with the initiation of spontaneous respirations. Tactile stimulation and oxygen therapy are noninvasive and decreases neonatal morbidity and mortality. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Many neonates require assistance with the initiation of spontaneous respirations. Tactile stimulation and oxygen therapy are noninvasive and decreases neonatal morbidity and mortality. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
19. A 2-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of bruising on her arms and legs for 2 days . She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy . The delivery was precipitous , but the newborn fed well
soon after birth . Examination shows petechiae over the face and trunk , scattered ecchymoses over the extremities , and an erythematous , fleshy irregular mass on the thigh . A bruit is heard over the hepatic area . Laboratory
studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13 g/dL , leukocyte count of 5000/mm 3 and platelet count of 15,000/mm 3 Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
, .

question_stem:
the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
, .

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Large vascular neoplasms, or hemangiomas, including tufted angioma and kaposiform hemangioendothelioma, are associated with a consumptive coagulopathy characterized by severe thrombocytopenia and decrease in fibrinogen and other coagulation factors called Kasabach-Merritt syndrome. These neoplasms present as red or purple subcutaneous tumors. The increased blood flow may cause the affected area to be warm and swollen or even cause a limb length discrepancy. Signs of other hemangiomas, such as a bruit over the liver, may also be present. The large, convoluted vascular architecture causes platelet adhesion and trapping. This trapping leads to consumption offibrinogen and ongoing fibrinolysis, causing a consumptive coagulopathy. Patients present, as in this case, with mucocutaneous bleeding (bruising and petechiae), which could not be explained by trauma. They also demonstrate thrombocytopenia on laboratory evaluation. Treatment includes supportive measures to maintain hemostasis and treatment of the underlying vascular neoplasm.

distractor_explanations.A: Cutaneous lymphoma has a variety of presentations. It is rare in children, particularly in newborns. The most common type of cutaneous lymphoma is mycosis fungoides, an indolent cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Mycosis fungoides presents with scaly, wrinkled patches in sun-protected areas, more often in adults than children. Cystic hygroma (Choice B) and lymphangioma (Choice E) are both lymphatic malformations. Cystic hygroma may be seen in association with Turner syndrome as a subcutaneous mass of the neck. However, neither of these are associated with Kasabach-Merritt syndrome or the development of thrombocytopenia. Juvenile xanthogranuloma (Choice D) is an uncommon benign proliferation of histiocytes. It clinically appears as a solitary orange-pink papule on the face, neck, or trunk of a child. It is not a vascular neoplasm and does not cause Kasabach-Merritt syndrome.
distractor_explanations.F: Mastocytoma is a benign proliferation of mast cells in the skin. The typical presentation is a single, orange-brown, leathery plaque, which forms a wheal upon scratching. Mastocytosis may also have presentations without cutaneous findings. Rapid mast cell degranulation may cause anaphylaxis but does not contribute to thrombocytopenia.
distractor_explanations.G: Neurofibroma is characteristic of neurofibromatosis, a genetically inherited disorder characterized by a constellation of cutaneous manifestations including neurofibromas, plexiform neurofibromas, cafe-au lait macules, and axillary freckling, none of which are present in this patient. Thrombocytopenia is not a typical clinical finding.

explanation.educational_objective: Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is a consumptive coagulopathy in which a large, convoluted vascular neoplasm traps platelets and then activates fibrinogen and fibrinolysis. It is seen in association with tufted angioma and kaposiform hemangioendothelioma, both of which are hemangiomas that may be present at or shortly after birth. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is a consumptive coagulopathy in which a large, convoluted vascular neoplasm traps platelets and then activates fibrinogen and fibrinolysis. It is seen in association with tu

vignette.presentation:
20. A previously healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive hair loss over the past 4 weeks . Examination shows a swollen and purulent area on the scalp . A photograph
is shown . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp common in children. The most common presentation is scaly patches with alopecia. The patches of alopecia may demonstrate black dots that represent broken hairs. When a significant inflammatory response to the fungal infection occurs, a kerion develops. A kerion is a boggy and swollen lesion on examination. Tinea capitis is caused by dermatophytes including Trichophyton rubrum, Epidermophyton floccosum, and Microsporum canis. First-line treatment of tinea capitis is with an oral antifungal, usually griseofulvin or terbinafine. Close contacts of patients should be examined as the condition is contagious and can be spread through fomites, such as shared combs, pillows, or hats.

distractor_explanations.A: Topical corticosteroid therapy will worsen tinea capitis by inhibiting the inflammatory response necessary to eliminate the infection. Superficial dermatophyte infections treated with topical corticosteroids may become more severe. Tinea treated with topical corticosteroids is often referred to as tinea incognito, because of the severe and unusual morphologies that these infections take on after treatment with topical corticosteroids. Tinea capitis is a fungal infection, not a bacterial infection, and thus oral antibacterial therapy (Choice B) is unnecessary. Tinea capitis and kerion may become secondarily colonized with skin flora, such as S. aureus, in which case antibiotics may be necessary, but this is atypical. Oral antibacterial therapy is appropriate for bacterial skin infections including cellulitis, erysipelas, and severe folliculitis. Surgical excision (Choice D) is unnecessary as the infection can be treated with oral antifungals. In children, dermatologic surgical excision is generally reserved for neoplastic processes. No intervention necessary (Choice E) is not the standard of care for tinea capitis. Without appropriate antifungal treatment, the infection and inflammatory response will worsen. Inadequate treatment puts the patient's close contacts at risk for developing the infection as well.

explanation.educational_objective: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp common in children. When a significant inflammatory response to the fungal infection occurs, a kerion develops. First-line treatment of tinea capitis includes an oral antifungal, usually griseofulvin or terbinafine, along with the treatment of close contacts, if necessary. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp common in children. When a significant inflammatory response to the fungal infection occurs, a kerion develops. First-line treatment of tinea capitis i

vignette.presentation:
22. A full-term 24-hour-old newborn has respiratory distress and seizures . Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes , respectively . An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse hazy infiltrates bilaterally . Leukocyte count is
12,500/mm 3 (65% segmented neutrophils and 10% bands) . Examination of cerebrospinal fluid shows 4 leukocytes/mm 3 (90% lymphocytes) , a glucose concentration of 75 mg/dL , and a protein concentration of 25 mg/dl. Which
of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Neonatal sepsis is categorized often on the basis of time from parturition, since the period of time in which symptoms begin may indicate which pathogen is likely involved, thereby guiding therapy. Early-onset neonatal sepsis (within 72 hours of birth) is marked by symptoms of lethargy, seizures, poor feeding, weak cry, and hypotonia. It presents with tachycardia, tachypnea, occasionally fever, and often with an examination that is nonfocal. If examination findings are present, they may reflect the source of infection or may reflect complications of sepsis such as neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. Early-onset neonatal sepsis generally occurs as a result of pathogens acquired from the mother, either through hematogenous or transplacental spread or, commonly, contact acquisition in the birth canal. The most common pathogens associated with early-onset neonatal sepsis include Streptococcus agalactiae (group B), Escherichia coli, coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and Listeria monocytogenes. Syndromes of serious bacterial infection include bacteremia, meningitis, and pneumonia. Late-onset neonatal sepsis (presenting 72 hours or more after birth) more commonly occurs from environmental pathogens in addition to those acquired from the mother. Pneumonia is more common in early-onset sepsis, and presents with cough, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypoxia, increased work of breathing, and rhonchi on auscultation. Workup for any suspected case of sepsis in a child younger than 30 days of age is broad, and should include a complete blood count, urinalysis, blood cultures, chest x-ray, and lumbar puncture at a minimum, since symptoms in this population are vague and nonspecific, limiting the utility of the history and physical examination to guide workup. X-rays in neonatal pneumonia disclose focal or diffuse airspace disease or may show diffuse interstitial infiltrates suggestive of respiratory distress syndrome. Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover the common pathogens.

distractor_explanations.B: Meconium aspiration occurs when the fetus inhales meconium into the lungs and is a known complication of labor and delivery. It presents with signs of respiratory distress (eg, cough, tachypnea, hypoxia, use of accessory muscles of respiration) and severity is a function of the volume of meconium aspirated. It is generally self-resolving when occurring in small amounts; large aspirations can lead to pneumonia or aspiration pneumonitis. Pneumococcal meningitis (Choice C) most commonly occurs in adults, whereas common pathogens causing meningitis in the neonate include Streptococcus agalactiae (group B), E. coli, coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and L monocytogenes. Pneumocystis jiroveci (formerly P. carini1) pneumonia (Choice D) generally occurs in immunocompromised persons and was seen commonly in individuals with advanced HIV prior to the use of prophylactic antibiotics. Patients classically present with cough, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxia, with rhonchi on lung auscultation and prominent perihilar and multifocal infiltrates on chest x-ray. It would be rare in a neonate. Respiratory syncytial virus pneumonia (Choice E) is one of the most common causes of bronchiolitis and pneumonia in children younger than 2 years of age. In the neonatal period, bacterial infection is more common and is also more consistent with bandemia and diffuse infiltrates on x-ray.

explanation.educational_objective: Common causes of early neonatal sepsis include Streptococcus agalactiae (group B), E. coli, and L monocytogenes, which are generally acquired during birth from the mother. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Common causes of early neonatal sepsis include Streptococcus agalactiae (group B), E. coli, and L monocytogenes, which are generally acquired during birth from the mother. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
23. An 18-month-old boy has had cough, coryza , vomiting , and diarrhea for 5 days and pallor and lethargy for 1 day. His mother states that his urine output has decreased , and the urine is now dark red. He responds poorly to
stimuli. He has a grade 3/6 systolic murmur with a gallop and diffuse abdominal tenderness . Laboratory studies show :
Hematocrit 24%
Platelet count 30,000/mm 3
Serum
Na+
138 mEq/L
Cl· 118 mEq/L
K+
6.5 mEq/L
HCO - 15 mEq/L
3
Creatinine 2.6 mg/dL
Urea nitrogen 60 mg/dL
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) is typically associated with infection from enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli O157:H? caused by the production of Shiga toxin. It classically presents in children with bloody diarrhea accompanied by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury. Other pathogenic precipitants include S. pneumoniae, Salmonella species, and Shigel/a species infections. This patient presents following several days of respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms, suggesting a bacterial or viral trigger. The abrupt change of pallor and lethargy, along with red urine and falling urine output suggests the presence of both anemia and renal failure. Physical examination may show petechiae, purpura, or ecchymosis, all of which are signs of thrombocytopenia. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates thrombocytopenia, increased creatinine and blood urea nitrogen concentrations, and often multiple electrolyte derangements depending on the extent of volume depletion and acute renal failure. Treatment is supportive and may include plasma exchange; many cases self-resolve. Generally, platelet transfusion is contraindicated because of the risk for worsening the degree of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia since platelet administration has been postulated to worsen the degree of thrombosis. If fever and neurologic symptoms are concomitantly present along with the anemia, thrombocytopenia, and renal failure, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is diagnosed. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Goodpasture syndrome (Choice A) is a type II (complement-mediated cytotoxic) hypersensitivity reaction that involves autoimmune deposition of lgG against the basement membrane in the lung and kidney. Patients present with hemoptysis and nephritic syndrome, which may be rapidly progressive and cause renal failure or death if not treated. Henoch-Schonlein nephritis (Choice C) is a vasculitis that classically presents in a child with renal failure and palpable purpura on the lower extremities following an upper respiratory infection. Patients often complain of arthralgias and abdominal pain, and intussusception is a known complication. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis (Choice D) is a nephritic syndrome presenting with gross or microscopic hematuria, peripheral or periorbital edema, and hypertension in a child, typically two weeks after infection with group A ~-hemolytic streptococci. Laboratory evaluation may show low serum C3 concentrations and positive anti-streptolysin O and anti-DNase titers. Systemic vasculitis (Choice E) describes a broad class of diseases that encompass small, medium, and large arterial inflammation affecting various organ systems, commonly the kidney, gastrointestinal tract, and lung. While vasculitides may present following illness, the classic triad of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and renal failure makes HUS a more likely diagnosis. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 23 of 50 Na+ 138 mEq/L Cl· 118 mEq/L K+ 6.5 mEq/L HCO 15 mEq/L 3 Creatinine 2.6 mg/dL Urea nitrogen 60 mg/dL Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Goodpasture syndrome B) Hemolytic uremic syndrome. C) Henoch-Schonlein nephritis D) Postinfectious glomerulonephritis E) Systemic vasculitis Correct Answer: B. Henoch-Schonlein nephritis (Choice C) is a vasculitis that classically presents in a child with renal failure and palpable purpura on the lower extremities following an upper respiratory infection. Patients often complain of arthralgias and abdominal pain, and intussusception is a known complication. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis (Choice D) is a nephritic syndrome presenting with gross or microscopic hematuria, peripheral or periorbital edema, and hypertension in a child, typically two weeks after infection with group A ~-hemolytic streptococci. Laboratory evaluation may show low serum C3 concentrations and positive anti-streptolysin O and anti-DNase titers. Systemic vasculitis (Choice E) describes a broad class of diseases that encompass small, medium, and large arterial inflammation affecting various organ systems, commonly the kidney, gastrointestinal tract, and lung. While vasculitides may present following illness, the classic triad of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and renal failure makes HUS a more likely diagnosis. Educational Objective: HUS is typically associated with infection from enterohemorrhagic E.coli O157:H? as a result of the production of Shiga toxin. It classically presents in children with bloody diarrhea accompanied by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 24 of 50 24 . A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination . He is active and has been healthy except for an episode of otitis media 3 weeks ago treated with amoxicillin. His parents emigrated from Vietnam . His diet consists mainly of fruits and vegetables ; he occasionally eats fish and chicken but no red meat. Examination shows no abnormalities . Laboratory studies show : Hemoglobin 10 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume 64 µm 3 Leukocyte count 6100/mm 3 Platelet count 225 ,000/mm 3 Red cell distribution width 10% (N=13%-15%) A blood smear is shown . Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's anemia? A) Antibiotic-induced autoimmune hemolysis B) Iron deficiency C Thalassemia mino D) Transient postinfectious bone marrow suppression E) Vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency 12 Correct Answer: B. This asymptomatic child with mild anemia, microcytosis, and low red cell distribution width (RDW) who is of southeast Asian heritage most likely has either a- or ~-thalassemia minor. Thalassemia is characterized by the decreased synthesis of globin chains. Normal adult hemoglobin is known as HbA (a~2l and is composed of two a-globin chains and two ~-globin chains. There are four a-globin alleles and two ~-globin alleles. Mutations in one or two a-globin alleles or one ~-globin allele causes thalassemia minor. Thalassemia trait is common in southeast Asia and commonly presents with mild microcytic anemia. Supportive features include the presence of target cells on peripheral blood smear (pictured in the photomicrograph), a low RDW (which indicates that most erythrocytes are of the same size with little variation), and persistence of microcytosis. Iron concentrations can be measured to rule out iron deficiency. Other cell lines including platelets and white blood cells should be within normal ranges. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to distinguish between a- and ~-thalassemia minor. There is no treatment required for thalassemia minor as the resultant anemia is usually not severe. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Antibiotic-induced autoimmune hemolysis (Choice A) can occur after exposure to penicillins and cephalosporins, but the onset is typically acute and occurs within hours to days. While hemolysis can occur weeks later, it is less common. Additionally, patients would be expected to present with normocytic anemia and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Haptoglobin concentrations can be measured and will be low, while the reticulocyte count will typically be increased. Iron deficiency (Choice C) is a common cause of anemia in menstruating women, strict vegans or vegetarians, and those with chronic gastrointestinal bleeding or celiac disease. It commonly presents with microcytosis, although often with a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) that is higher than what is seen in thalassemia, and an increased RDW indicating the release of premature erythrocytes from the bone marrow. The measurement of serum iron and ferritin, which will be low, are used to make the diagnosis. Transient postinfectious bone marrow suppression (Choice D) may occur following viral infections, but more commonly presents with leukopenia, which is not present in this case. In patients with sickle cell disease, infection with parvovirus B19 can cause a transient aplastic crisis and severe anemia. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 24 of 50 B) Iron deficiency C) Thalassemia mino D) Transient postinfectious bone marrow suppression E) Vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency 12 Correct Answer: B. There are four a-globin alleles and two ~-globin alleles. Mutations in one or two a-globin alleles or one ~-globin allele causes thalassemia minor. Thalassemia trait is common in southeast Asia and commonly presents with mild microcytic anemia. Supportive features include the presence of target cells on peripheral blood smear (pictured in the photomicrograph), a low RDW (which indicates that most erythrocytes are of the same size with little variation), and persistence of microcytosis. Iron concentrations can be measured to rule out iron deficiency. Other cell lines including platelets and white blood cells should be within normal ranges. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to distinguish between a- and ~-thalassemia minor. There is no treatment required for thalassemia minor as the resultant anemia is usually not severe. lncorrectAnswers:A, C, D, and E. Antibiotic-induced autoimmune hemolysis (Choice A) can occur after exposure to penicillins and cephalosporins, but the onset is typically acute and occurs within hours to days. While hemolysis can occur weeks later, it is less common. Additionally, patients would be expected to present with normocytic anemia and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Haptoglobin concentrations can be measured and will be low, while the reticulocyte count will typically be increased. Iron deficiency (Choice C) is a common cause of anemia in menstruating women, strict vegans or vegetarians, and those with chronic gastrointestinal bleeding or celiac disease. It commonly presents with microcytosis, although often with a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) that is higher than what is seen in thalassemia, and an increased RDW indicating the release of premature erythrocytes from the bone marrow. The measurement of serum iron and ferritin, which will be low, are used to make the diagnosis. Transient postinfectious bone marrow suppression (Choice D) may occur following viral infections, but more commonly presents with leukopenia, which is not present in this case. In patients with sickle cell disease, infection with parvovirus B19 can cause a transient aplastic crisis and severe anemia. Vitamin B (cobalamin) deficiency (Choice E) results in megaloblastic anemia, which presents with macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils. It 12 is more common in patients who chronically abuse alcohol, or in patients with a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, Crohn disease, or malabsorptive disorders. This patient demonstrates a microcytic anemia. Educational Objective: Thalassemia minor can occur as a result of mutations or deletions in one of the ~-globin alleles or in one or two of the a-globin alleles, leading to the impaired production of globin chains. Patients typically demonstrate a mild microcytic anemia with a low RDW and normal concentrations of leukocytes and platelets. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to distinguish between these two entities. Treatment is often not necessary. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 25 of 50 'I
