It classically presents in children with bloody diarrhea accompanied by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: HUS is typically associated with infection from enterohemorrhagic E.coli O157:H? as a result of the production of Shiga toxin. It classically presents in children with bloody diarrhea accompanied by m

vignette.presentation:
25. A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination prior to beginning college . She has had intermittent urinary frequency over the past 6 months without urgency or pain with urination . She
feels otherwise well and has no history of serious illness . Menarche was at the age of 14 years . Menses occur every 3 to 4 months and last 3 to 8 days . Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago . She is not sexually active .
She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (177 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m 2 Vital signs are within normal limits . Examination shows a mild increase in hair growth over the upper lip and upper extremities . There are hyperpigmented ,
•
velvety, hyperkeratotic plaques on the neck , axillae , and groin . The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities . Urinalysis shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

distractor_explanations.A: Cushing syndrome presents with fatigue, hypertension, truncal obesity, hyperglycemia, fat redistribution, amenorrhea, and abdominal striae. It is a less likely cause of this patient's menstrual irregularities, polyuria, and acanthosis nigricans.
distractor_explanations.B: Hypothyroidism presents with weight gain, fatigue, constipation, cold intolerance, and menstrual irregularities. It does not cause acanthosis nigricans. Ovarian neoplasm (Choice C) classically presents indolently in an older, postmenopausal female with abdominal distention and weight loss. Some ovarian tumors (eg, germ cell tumors, choriocarcinomas, dysgerminomas) can lead to abnormal uterine bleeding. However, physical examination may demonstrate an adnexal mass, and symptoms of diabetes would be atypical. Urinary tract infection (Choice E) classically presents with dysuria, frequency, and urgency, as well as occasional hematuria. Physical examination may demonstrate suprapubic tenderness. Urinalysis, in the setting of a urinary tract infection, will show positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites, white blood cells, and pyuria.

explanation.educational_objective: PCOS presents with irregular menses, infertility, hirsutism, and acne, often in patients with an increased body weight. It is strongly associated with insulin resistance and the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus, which can present with polydipsia and polyuria. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: PCOS presents with irregular menses, infertility, hirsutism, and acne, often in patients with an increased body weight. It is strongly associated with insulin resistance and the development of type 2

vignette.presentation:
26. A ?-month -old girl is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of fever and cough . She was born at term following an uncomplicated delivery . She was treated for acute otitis media at 5 months of age . She takes no
medications . Immunizations are up-to-date . She appears ill. She is at the 50th percentile for length and 25th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101 .3°F) , pulse is 140/min , respirations are 80/min , and blood
pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 80% . Several 0.5- to 1.5-cm , mobile lymph nodes are palpated in the anterior cervical chain , axillae , and groin . Examination shows white
plaques on the buccal mucosa . Diffuse crackles are heard bilaterally . The spleen tip is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin . Laboratory studies show :
Leukocyte count 10,500/mm 3
Segmented neutrophils 66%
Lymphocytes 30%
Monocytes 4%
Bronchoalveolar lavage shows Pneumocystis jiroveci (formerly P carini1). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

distractor_explanations.A: Higashi syndrome is caused by mutations in the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LY ST) essential for normal formation and transportation of lysosomes within the cell. It presents with frequent bacterial infections, oculocutaneous albinism, peripheral neuropathy, and progressive neurologic dysfunction. Chronic granulomatous disease (Choice B) is caused by NADPH oxidase deficiency and results in impaired intracellular killing of pathogens. This presents as recurrent pyogenic infections with catalase-positive organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus with normal concentrations of leukocytes and immunoglobulins. Complement deficiency (Choice C), particularly of the terminal complement cascade, typically presents with recurrent infections with Neisseria species. Hyperimmunoglobulinemia E syndrome (Choice E) is caused by mutations in the JAK-STAT signaling cascade, which impairs the development and function of T helper 17 cells (Th n). Patients present with recurrent skin infections, noninflamed abscesses (cold abscesses), and diffuse atopic dermatitis. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 26 of 50 F) Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCIO) G) Thymic-parathyroid dysplasia (DiGeorge syndrome) H) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome I) X-linked agammaglobulinemia CorrectAnswer: D. HIV infection acquired via vertical transmission in the perinatal period is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with oral thrush, diffuse lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and Pneumocystis pneumonia. HIV transmission may occur at any time during gestation but is most commonly acquired at or around the time of delivery and in the immediate postpartum period when children are breastfeeding. Transmission is uncommon if the mother is taking antiretroviral therapy and has a low HIV viral load. As a result of universal screening for HIV in most developed countries, the incidence of perinatal and pediatric HIV has decreased, although this is not true around the world. Most patients present within the first few months of birth with recurrent pneumonia or opportunistic infections. AIDS-defining illnesses in children are numerous but include P. jiroveci pneumonia, as in this patient. Initial evaluation should include measurement of the HIV viral load with concomitant testing for mutations. While this patient should receive treatment for her P. jiroveci pneumonia and thrush, she should also be started on antiretroviral therapy once an HIV infection is confirmed. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, E, F, G, H, and I. Chediak-Higashi syndrome (Choice A) is caused by mutations in the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene (LY ST) essential for normal formation and transportation of lysosomes within the cell. It presents with frequent bacterial infections, oculocutaneous albinism, peripheral neuropathy, and progressive neurologic dysfunction. Chronic granulomatous disease (Choice B) is caused by NADPH oxidase deficiency and results in impaired intracellular killing of pathogens. This presents as recurrent pyogenic infections with catalase-positive organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus with normal concentrations of leukocytes and immunoglobulins. Complement deficiency (Choice C), particularly of the terminal complement cascade, typically presents with recurrent infections with Neisseria species. Hyperimmunoglobulinemia E syndrome (Choice E) is caused by mutations in the JAK-STAT signaling cascade, which impairs the development and function of T helper 17 cells (Th n). Patients present with recurrent skin infections, noninflamed abscesses (cold abscesses), and diffuse atopic dermatitis. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCIO) (Choice F) describes a syndrome of failed Band T lymphocyte activity leading to impaired cellular and humoral immunity. This commonly occurs as a result of adenosine deaminase deficiency and presents with recurrent viral, bacterial, and fungal infections starting around the time of birth. Thymic-parathyroid dysplasia (DiGeorge syndrome) (Choice G) presents with thymic hypoplasia or aplasia and consequent impaired immunity, conotruncal cardiac defects, hypocalcemia caused by parathyroid hypoplasia, and craniofacial abnormalities. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (Choice H) is caused by a mutation in the WAS gene on the X-chromosome that encodes a protein essential for actin cytoskeleton rearrangement that occurs during interactions between T lymphocytes, antigen-presenting cells, and B lymphocytes, leading to an impaired innate and adaptive immune system. Patients present with eczema, thrombocytopenia, and infections with encapsulated bacteria and opportunistic pathogens. X-linked agammaglobulinemia (Choice I) occurs as a result of mutations in the BTK gene that encodes a tyrosine kinase essential for all stages of B lymphocyte development and proliferation. Patients lack functioning B lymphocytes and therefore have recurrent infections caused by impaired humoral immunity.

explanation.educational_objective: Pediatric HIV/AIDS should be suspected in patients who present with recurrent bacterial pneumonia or AIDS-defining illnesses such as disseminated mycobacterial and nonmycobacterial tuberculosis infection, or Pneumocystis jiroveci infection. Treatment for the presenting infection in conjunction with initiation of antiretroviral therapy is required. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Pediatric HIV/AIDS should be suspected in patients who present with recurrent bacterial pneumonia or AIDS-defining illnesses such as disseminated mycobacterial and nonmycobacterial tuberculosis infect

vignette.presentation:
27. A previously healthy 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents 1 day after she fainted during soccer practice . Her teammates said that she fell to the ground while running and appeared to be unconscious for
approximately 15 seconds ; no abnormal movements were noted . There is no prior history of syncope , palpitations , or murmurs . Her parents are concerned because a maternal cousin died suddenly at the age of 22 years of an
unknown cause . The patient is alert and oriented . Her vital signs are within normal limits . Examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Admission to the hospital for observation

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: An ECG should be obtained in this patient with unexplained exertional syncope. There are several high-risk cardiac conditions that can present with syncope in pediatric patients, and these can be classified as structural defects, including hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, coronary artery anomalies, or valvular aortic stenosis, or can be a result of electrical abnormalities, such as long QT syndrome or Brugada syndrome. Evaluation with ECG is mandatory in all patients with unexplained syncope. Of these, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is one of the more common causes of syncope. It is generally inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion and may be the cause of death in this patient's cousin. Syncope occurs as a result of left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction with a consequent decrease in cardiac output leading to decreased cerebral perfusion and syncope. Decreased perfusion of the coronary arteries can cause angina and increase the risk for ventricular arrhythmias, although this is not always seen. ECG classically demonstrates left ventricular hypertrophy with non-specific T wave abnormalities in the precordial leads. Deep, narrow, symmetric Q waves may also be seen in the lateral and inferior leads. Echocardiography should be subsequently performed to evaluate the underlying cardiac anatomy, which would allow for assessment of the degree of LVOT obstruction, if present.

distractor_explanations.A: Reassurance is inappropriate. Patients with unexplained exertional syncope are at a high-risk for sudden cardiac death. ECG is a low-cost and noninvasive means of assessing for underlying cardiac defects and should be performed as soon as possible. Chest x-ray (Choice B) could be considered in patients with exertional shortness of breath, wheezing, or a prodrome suggestive of bacterial pneumonia, but this patient's presentation is more consistent with a cardiac cause of syncope. EEG (Choice D) is not necessary as this patient's syncopal episode was not associated with classic seizure-like activity. Often, seizures that result in syncope are preceded by an aura, and patients are typically confused upon waking, which is known as a postictal state. The patient's history is not consistent with a seizure. Convulsions can also be seen during syncope. Admission to the hospital for observation (Choice E) is not necessary. Had the patient not regained consciousness or required cardiopulmonary resuscitation, admission to the hospital would be appropriate. This patient should be advised not to participate in exercise until a complete evaluation has been undertaken, but this can be performed in the outpatient setting.

explanation.educational_objective: Exertional syncope is a characteristic feature of several high-risk cardiac conditions, including hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. After patient stability is documented, the next step in evaluation should include ECG, which classically demonstrates left ventricular hypertrophy and nonspecific T wave abnormalities. ECG can also help to diagnose conditions such as long QT syndrome or Brugada syndrome, which are other potential causes of cardiac syncope. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Exertional syncope is a characteristic feature of several high-risk cardiac conditions, including hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. After patient stability is documented, the next step in evaluation should

vignette.presentation:
28. A previously healthy 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by friends after they found her unresponsive at a party. There is no history of trauma . Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F) , pulse is 80/min , respirations
are 6/min , and blood pressure is 95/55 mm Hg. Physical examination shows constricted pupils . The abdomen is slightly distended , and bowel sounds are decreased . Neurologic examination shows a diminished gag reflex and
generalized hypertonia . The most appropriate next step in management is administration of which of the following?

question_stem: The most appropriate next step in management is administration of which of the following?

distractor_explanations.A: Administration of activated charcoal would be unlikely to be beneficial in a patient with opioid overdose and would not be safe in a patient with altered mental status and a diminished gag reflex. Charcoal, if aspirated, can be harmful to the pulmonary parenchyma and cause aspiration pneumonitis. 5% glucose (Choice B) would be helpful for the treatment of hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemia can also cause altered mental status and a decreased level of consciousness, but it would not cause miosis or respiratory depression as seen in opioid overdose.
distractor_explanations.C: Methadone is a long-acting opioid agonist that is used in the long-term maintenance therapy of opioid dependence. It would not be helpful for the initial management of opioid overdose. 0.9% saline (Choice E) would be unlikely to be beneficial in this patient as it would not reverse opioid toxicity. Administration of 0.9% saline may be helpful as an adjunct for patients who may be dehydrated in the setting of substance use, but it would not be the initial step in management.

explanation.educational_objective: Opioid overdoses are characterized by miosis, altered mental status, and respiratory depression presenting as a decreased respiratory rate, apnea, and hypoxia. Naloxone is a short-acting opioid receptor antagonist that reverses the respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose and should be administered emergently to patients presenting with altered mental status and respiratory depression. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Opioid overdoses are characterized by miosis, altered mental status, and respiratory depression presenting as a decreased respiratory rate, apnea, and hypoxia. Naloxone is a short-acting opioid recept

vignette.presentation:
29. A previously healthy 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 6-week history of right knee pain. She plays volleyball for her school , and the pain is worse after jumping or running . There is no history of trauma .
She appears well. Examination shows a tender right knee ; there is crepitance with flexion . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Patellofemoral instability is a common cause of anterior knee pain, which is caused by an anatomical defect leading to excessive movement of the patella. It is exacerbated by overuse and activities that put weight on a flexed knee, such as running and jumping. On examination, passive movement of the patella demonstrates increased sliding of the patella in either the lateral axis or superior-inferior axis. The patella may also be tender to palpation. The mainstay of treatment for patellar instability is activity modification and physical therapy. The goal of physical therapy is to strengthen the surrounding muscles and recruit stability of the patella from these muscles, as well as improve the position and balance of the limb overall. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) may also be prescribed for use as needed.

distractor_explanations.B: Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune connective tissue disease that causes pink papules over the dorsal fingers (Gottron papules), pink to light purple patches over the upper eyelids (heliotrope sign), light pink to lilac colored patches with telangiectasias on the upper back and sun-exposed chest, dilated capillaries with dropout on the proximal nail folds, and proximal muscle weakness. Growing pains (Choice C) are recurrent, self-limited pains in the extremities that occur during childhood and early adolescence. Physical examination is normal. Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (Choice D), or systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, is characterized by fever, arthritis, an evanescent salmon-colored rash, and lymphadenopathy. Legg-Calve-Perthes disease (Choice E) is an idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head, which often presents in young males. The classic presentation includes a slow onset of hip pain that is worsened by activity and associated with a limp. The pain may or may not be relieved with rest. Neuroblastoma with bone marrow metastases (Choice F) is a malignancy of neuroendocrine cells associated with the sympathetic nervous tissue. Bone marrow metastases classically cause pain at night, and the patient would likely appear ill and cachectic. Septic arthritis (Choice H) results from a bacterial infection of the synovial joint space, most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus. The affected joint demonstrates pain, swelling, and erythema. Arthrocentesis is indicated for the evaluation of monoarticular erythema and swelling to evaluate for septic arthritis, which characteristically discloses purulent synovial fluid with >50,000 leukocytes/mm

explanation.concept: TBD

vignette.presentation:

Serum
Na+ 138 mEq/L
Cl · 100 mEq/L

4.2 mEq/L
HCO 14 mEq/L

Urea nitrogen 12 mg/dL

pH 6.2
Protein 1+
RBC 0-1/hpf
WBC 0-1/hpf
Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows :
pH 7.17
Pco 50 mm Hg
2
Po 40 mm Hg
2
Which of the following is the most likely acid-base disorder?

question_stem: the most likely acid-base disorder?

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis complicated by renal failure
Respiratory acidosis complicated by renal failure

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's laboratory and arterial blood gas evaluation demonstrates a mixed respiratory and anion-gap metabolic acidosis. The metabolic acidosis is indicated by a pH less than 7.35 (acidemia) with decreased HCO Anion gap ([Na•] - {[Cl·]+ [HCO calculates unmeasured anions in serum that are contributing to acidity; in this case, the anion gap is increased to 24. Causes of anion gap metabolic acidosis include the -. ·])) 3 3 ingestion of methanol, propylene glycol, salicylates {late phase), or ethylene glycol, along with uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis, isoniazid use, and lactic acidosis. In this case, a lactic acidosis secondary to inadequate perfusion of organs and forced anaerobic metabolism is likely the cause of the metabolic acidosis as a result of hypoxemia. If functioning correctly, the respiratory system compensates for the acidosis by increasing minute ventilation, which eliminates carbon dioxide, an acid. This results in a decreased pCO and an increased pH to approximately normal range. This patient's increased pCO suggests that respiratory 2 2 compensation is not only inadequate but that there is also a concomitant respiratory acidosis. The Winters formula is used to determine the range of pCO if compensation is adequate: 1.5(HCO + 8 +/- 2. In this ·) 2 3 case, the range of pCO2o if adequately compensated, would be 27 to 31 mmHg. The measured pCO of 50 mmHg, outside this range, indicates an accumulation of pCO in addition to organic anions. 2 2

distractor_explanations.A: Both lactic acidosis with respiratory compensation and pure metabolic acidosis (Choice B) would demonstrate a metabolic acidosis with a measured pCO within the range predicted by the Winters 2 formula. In this case, the measured pCO is well above that predicted range, thus respiratory compensation is not adequately occurring and CO:2, an acid, is accumulating. 2 Respiratory acidosis and metabolic compensation (Choice C) would present with acidemia, an increased pCOi, and an increased HCO concentration. In contrast, this patient has a decreased HCO - - 3 3 concentration. Respiratory acidosis complicated by renal failure (Choice D) would present with acidemia, an increased pCOi, and an increased creatinine and urea nitrogen, which are absent.

The Winters formula should be calculated to determine whether adequate compensation or a second acid-base disturbance is present. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
32. A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a syncopal episode . At the time of the episode , she turned blue around the mouth while having a temper tantrum ; she then fell down and became
unresponsive . Her extremities became rigid and shook and then became limp. After a few seconds , she resumed normal activity. She currently is alert , active , and well hydrated. Her temperature is 37.1 °C (98.8°F), pulse is
110/min, respirations are 22/min , and blood pressure is 94/52 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation . A grade 1/ 6, systolic ejection murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border with no gallops or rubs . The cranial nerves
are intact. Muscle tone is normal , and deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally . Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's syncopal episode?

question_stem: the most likely cause of this patient's syncopal episode?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Syncope triggered by emotional distress in this 2-year-old girl was likely caused by a breath-holding episode. Breath-holding episodes are common paroxysmal events between the ages of 6 months to 6 years, typically triggered by stress-induced autonomic dysfunction. The typical sequence of events is crying, followed by breath-holding and cyanosis, then muscle rigidity and shaking, and finally limpness and loss of consciousness. Episodes may recur daily. Physicians should assess patients for iron deficiency anemia, which is commonly associated with breath-holding episodes, and treat with supplemental iron if deficient. Breath-holding episodes typically remit spontaneously.

distractor_explanations.A: Atonic seizures are generalized seizures that cause a sudden loss of muscle tone and consciousness. Complex partial seizures (Choice E) are focal seizures that feature focal motor or sensory symptoms and impaired consciousness. Stress-related triggers and cyanosis are more consistent with breath-holding episodes than seizures. In ambiguous cases, seizures should be ruled out using EEG. Patients with hypochondriasis (Choice C), commonly called illness anxiety disorder, typically present with persistent and excessive anxiety about the possibility of having or acquiring a serious illness. This 2-year-old patient does not likely understand the concept of a serious illness. Low cardiac output (Choice D) may lead to syncope but would be atypical of this otherwise healthy child with a physiologic flow murmur. In the case of frequent or prolonged breath-holding episodes, or a family history of sudden cardiac death, cardiac evaluation should be considered. However, this patient's episode was brief and featured a sequence of events typical for breath-holding episodes.

explanation.educational_objective: Breath-holding episodes are common paroxysmal events in infants and toddlers, typically arising from stress-induced autonomic dysfunction. Patients typically present with the sequence of breath-holding, acute cyanosis, muscle shaking, atonia, and loss of consciousness after crying. Stress-related triggers and cyanosis differentiate breath-holding episodes from seizures. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Breath-holding episodes are common paroxysmal events in infants and toddlers, typically arising from stress-induced autonomic dysfunction. Patients typically present with the sequence of breath-holdin

vignette.presentation:
33. A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 10 minutes after a firecracker accident ; he has pain and tearing of the right eye . The right eye appears normal. Both pupils are equally round and accommodate to light.
His visual acuity is 20/20 . Ocular movements are full. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the eye pain?

question_stem: the most likely cause of the eye pain?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Loss of corneal epithelium describes the pathogenesis of a corneal abrasion, sustained in this example from debris scattered into the eye from a firecracker explosion. Corneal abrasions classically present with pain, conjunctival injection, tearing, and foreign body sensation. Visual acuity may be diminished, and blurry vision may be reported if the abrasion involves the visual axis. If the abrasion is large enough, it may be grossly visible as a discontinuity in the surface of the cornea, but if it cannot be clearly visualized, the use of fluorescein stain and blacklight or slit lamp may be required to detect the epithelial defect, which will be visible as an area of concentrated fluorescein stain, often in a linear or geometric pattern. Treatment includes irrigation to clear any residual debris, analgesia, and prophylactic ophthalmic antibiotic ointment to prevent superimposed infection.

distractor_explanations.A: Increased intraocular pressure describes a common finding in glaucoma. In children, this may be a result of congenital glaucoma, which presents with characteristic findings including buphthalmos (an enlarged eye), a large cornea, which may be edematous and opacified, and increased intraocular pressure. Infants typically present with epiphora, photophobia, and blepharospasm or eye rubbing. Inflammation of periorbital tissues (Choice B) describes the pathophysiology of periorbital cellulitis, which presents with erythema, pain, and induration of the eyelids or adjacent skin. The globe itself is not affected. Obstruction of the lacrimal duct (Choice D) presents with tearing (epiphora) from the ipsilateral eye, though it is generally not painful unless the obstructed lacrimal duct is also infected (eg, dacryocystitis). Retinal detachment (Choice E) can occur in the setting of ocular trauma; however, it is generally painless and is accompanied by visual symptoms of photopsia, floaters, and often with a visual field defect.

explanation.educational_objective: Corneal abrasions arise as a result of injury to the surface epithelium of the cornea and are diagnosed on gross examination or with the use of fluorescein and a blacklight. Treatment includes irrigation, analgesia, and topical antibiotics. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Corneal abrasions arise as a result of injury to the surface epithelium of the cornea and are diagnosed on gross examination or with the use of fluorescein and a blacklight. Treatment includes irrigat

vignette.presentation:
34. A previously healthy 1-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of cough and difficulty breast-feeding . Her mother is concerned because the patient's face turns red when she coughs .
She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy , labor, and delivery . She is otherwise healthy. Her mother has had a similar cough for 3 weeks . The patient appears thin . Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F) , pulse is
110/min, and respirations are 45/min . Examination shows moist mucous membranes and clear rhinorrhea. During the examination , she has a long series of single coughs ending with a loud , high-pitched inhalation . Which of the
following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

distractor_explanations.A: Acute bronchiolitis is often the result of infection with respiratory syncytial virus and is likely to present with fever, tachypnea, rhinorrhea, and wheezing. Patients may also display apneic episodes, but severe paroxysms of coughing would be atypical. Chlamydia! pneumonia (Choice B) is commonly preceded by neonatal conjunctivitis. It classically presents in infants with a staccato cough, in which each cough is separated by a brief inspiration. Physical examination may also show tachypnea and crackles. Foreign body aspiration (Choice C) symptoms depend on the size of the aspirated item and its location in the bronchial tree. It can present with respiratory distress and stridor, a high-pitched sound caused by turbulent airflow through obstructed or narrowed upper airway structures, such as the pharynx, larynx, or trachea. Viral laryngotracheobronchitis (Choice E), also known as croup, typically presents with fever, rhinorrhea, a barking cough, and inspiratory stridor. It is commonly secondary to a viral infection from parainfluenza virus.

explanation.educational_objective: Pertussis occurs as a result of an infection from Bordetella pertussis and may lead to severe paroxysmal coughing, which may be accompanied by cyanosis and followed by syncope, emesis, or apnea. Pertussis can be prevented with immunization, although this patient is too young to receive the immunization and likely acquired the infection from her mother. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Pertussis occurs as a result of an infection from Bordetella pertussis and may lead to severe paroxysmal coughing, which may be accompanied by cyanosis and followed by syncope, emesis, or apnea. Pertu

vignette.presentation:
35. A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination . She has no history of serious illness . Immunizations are up-to-date . Menarche has not occurred . She is not sexually active . Her mother asks if her
daughter should receive the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine . She is reluctant to give permission to administer the vaccine if her daughter is not at risk for infection . The patient and her mother should be advised that which
of the following is the most appropriate timing for the patient to receive the HPV vaccine?

question_stem: the most appropriate timing for the patient to receive the HPV vaccine?

choices.text: Immediately after she becomes sexually active
At the time of her first Pap smear
The vaccine is not indicated if she and her future sexual partners use condoms

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Because about 80% of people will be infected by HPV in their lifetime, the HPV vaccine should be administered to all patients. The vaccine should be administered at age 11 to 12 years, since the immune response is most robust before the teenage years and the onset of sexual activity may occur during the teenage years. HPV is sexually transmitted and is associated with genital warts along with premalignant and malignant lesions of the cervical, anogenital, and oropharyngeal regions. HPV vaccines have significantly decreased the incidence and prevalence of HPV and protect against HPV-related malignancies such as cervical and anal squamous cell carcinoma.

distractor_explanations.B: Menarche is unrelated to vaccine efficacy. The vaccine should be given to patients at age 11 to 12 years because of immune response patterns and the onset of sexual behavior, which are not associated with the timing of menarche. The vaccine should be administered to all patients regardless of risk factors such as sexual activity or condom use (Choices C and E) to promote herd immunity. Giving the vaccine after the onset of sexual activity would not protect patients from HPV infection, and condoms decrease but do not eliminate the risk for HPV transmission. The first Pap smear is recommended at age 21 years (Choice D). By age 21, many patients have initiated sexual activity and may already be infected with HPV. HPV infection typically occurs years before concerning cervical lesions may be detected by Pap smear.

explanation.educational_objective: HPV is a common sexually transmitted infection that increases the risk for cervical and anogenital cancer. Vaccination against HPV is recommended for all patients at age 11 to 12 years, since the immune response is most robust before the teenage years and the onset of sexual activity may occur during the teenage years. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: HPV is a common sexually transmitted infection that increases the risk for cervical and anogenital cancer. Vaccination against HPV is recommended for all patients at age 11 to 12 years, since the immu

vignette.presentation:
36. A 10-year-old boy with sickle cell disease is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of increasing fatigue and shortness of breath . He has had a persistent upper respiratory tract infection for 5 days that has been
unresponsive to over-the-counter medications . His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1° F), pulse is 120/min , respirations are 28/min , and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae and dry mucous
membranes . Cardiac examination shows an active precordium ; a grade 3/6, systolic ejection murmur is heard along the left sternal border . His hematocrit is 16%. Which of the following is most likely to be increased in this
patient?

question_stem:
most likely to be increased in this
patient?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Cardiac output is most likely to be increased in this patient with severe anemia secondary to sickle cell disease (SCD). Adequate oxygen delivery to peripheral tissues occurs in several steps: oxygenation of the lung alveoli, binding of oxygen to hemoglobin in erythrocytes, and delivery of oxygenated erythrocytes to peripheral tissues with an adequate cardiac output. Peripheral oxygen delivery is mathematically defined by the product of the cardiac output and the arterial oxygen content. Arterial oxygen content is significantly lower in the setting of severe anemia, as in this patient, because there is a substantially lower hemoglobin content. As such, cardiac output must increase to accommodate a substantially lower arterial oxygen content if oxygen delivery to the peripheral tissues is to remain the same. This phenomenon accounts for the patient's active precordium and grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur. Additionally, this patient likely suffers from a component of sepsis given his persistent upper respiratory tract infection and fever, which would increase the patient's risk for concomitant septic shock. In the early stages of septic shock, the cardiac output is also increased in an attempt to maintain mean arterial pressure.

distractor_explanations.B: is likely to be decreased in this patient, who has evidence of dehydration including dry mucous membranes. CVP is often used as a surrogate for preload and correlates with the volume of the right atrium, provided the pulmonary artery pressure is normal. Peripheral tissue oxygenation (Choice C) will either remain the same or decrease further if the patient's cardiac output cannot maintain its increased state and/or the hemoglobin concentration further decreases. Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) (Choice D) is likely to be normal or low because of the patient's hypovolemia. In older patients with SCD, chronic high-output cardiac states can lead to pulmonary hypertension and increase the PVR. Systemic afterload (Choice E) is likely low or normal in this patient with components of both hypovolemic and septic shock. The patient presents with a severe anemia and evidence of hypovolemia on examination, which would typically result in an increased systemic vascular resistance in an attempt to maintain mean arterial pressure. This patient also presents with a persistent infection and fever, which may indicate a component of concomitant septic shock, which would result in a low systemic vascular resistance from cytokine-mediated arterial vasodilation.

explanation.educational_objective: Peripheral oxygen delivery is based on the arterial concentration of hemoglobin and the cardiac output. In states of severe anemia, where the hemoglobin concentration is low, cardiac output must increase in order to compensate, resulting in a high-output cardiac state, as seen in this patient. r " , r-- r ,
explanation.concept: Peripheral oxygen delivery is based on the arterial concentration of hemoglobin and the cardiac output. In states of severe anemia, where the hemoglobin concentration is low, cardiac output must incre

vignette.presentation:
37. A previously healthy 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of fever , rash , and lethargy for 4 hours . She has had one previous episode of similar symptoms . Her brother died of fulminant
meningococcemia 4 years ago . Her temperature is 38.6°C (101 .5°F), pulse is 128/min , respirations are 32/min , and blood pressure is 95/42 mm Hg. There are scattered purpuric lesions over the trunk and extremities . Her
capillary refill time is 4 seconds . Which of the following is the most likely cause?

question_stem: the most likely cause?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Complement system immunodeficiency is the most likely diagnosis in this patient with meningococcemia. Late component complement deficiency (CS to C9) is a common finding in patients who have recurrent infections with Neisseria species, and increases susceptibility to this pathogen through failure to form the membrane attack complex (MAC). Complement activation can occur through the classical, lectin, or alternative pathways, with each pathway converging at the point where C3 is cleaved by C3 convertase, releasing C3a and C3b. Following this, C3b is incorporated into the C3 convertase complex, which subsequently acts on CS convertase to lower the Km (increase the affinity) of CS convertase for its substrate, CS. Cleavage of CS results in the formation of C5a, a potent chemoattractant, and C5b. C5b complexes with C6, C7, CB, and C9 (terminal complement factors) to form the MAC, which allows for the creation of a transmembrane pore that interferes with the integrity of the cellular membrane, leading to cell lysis. Deficiencies of terminal complement factors impair the formation of the MAC and preferentially predispose patients to infection with Neisseria species. While most patients experience mild infection with atypical serotypes, they can also develop fulminant meningococcemia from typical Neisseria serotypes, as in this patient. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, D, E, and F. AIDS (Choice A) can develop in pediatric patients who have acquired the infection vertically during the perinatal period from a mother with untreated HIV infection. Most patients present with evidence of recurrent pneumonia, infection with atypical organisms such as Mycobacterium avium, or with opportunistic infections such as Pneumocystis pneumonia. It commonly presents within months of birth but can also develop many years after birth. Child abuse (Choice B) should be suspected in cases where bruising is located in atypical locations such as the back or is with an atypical appearance, such as a linear mark on the upper arm. Purpura on the trunk and extremities is classic for meningococcemia and is far more likely in this patient with sepsis and a family history of meningococcemia. Congenital humoral system immunodeficiency (Choice D) is caused by numerous syndromes, including X-linked agammaglobulinemia, whereby B lymphocyte development is impaired by mutations in the BTK gene. Low or absent immunoglobulin secretion increases the risk for recurrent bacterial infections, but patients present within the first eighteen months of life. Increased susceptibility to Neisseria species, in particular, is not characteristic of this disease. Frequent exposure to multiple pathogens (Choice E) is incorrect. Healthy children are exposed to numerous pathogens on a daily basis and most do not develop invasive bacterial infections. While Neisseria meningitidis is associated with outbreaks in college dorms and military barracks, there is no such history in this case. Vitamin A deficiency (Choice F) is classically associated with xerophthalmia but does not cause the findings described in this patient. Educational Objective: Deficiency of the terminal complement proteins prevents the formation of the MAC, which is a critical component in the complement cascade, typically leading to the formation of a pore in the membrane of pathogenic organisms. Deficiency predisposes to recurrent and invasive infections with Neisseria species. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 38 of 50 'I

38. A 4-month -old female infant is brought to the physician by her mother for a routine examination . The patient was born at 27 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old multiparous woman after premature rupture of the membranes and
premature labor. The patient's birth weight was 1200 g (2 lb 10 oz), and she spent the first 3 months of her life in the hospital. During hospitalization , she was treated for sepsis and respiratory distress syndrome that required
intubation , mechanical ventilation , and umbilical artery catheterization . She is currently receiving oxygen and diuretic therapy at home . She is at the 5th percentile for length and weight. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) , pulse is
104/min , respirations are 32/min , and blood pressure is 78/45 mm Hg. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally , and wheezing is heard occasionally . Cardiac examination shows a pronounced S and a precordial heave .
2

question_stem: the most likely cause of these cardiac findings?

distractor_explanations.A: Cardiomyopathy may be dilated, hypertrophic, or restrictive. While the right ventricle in this patient has hypertrophied, this is secondary to pulmonary hypertension rather than a primary disorder of the myocardium. lntracardiac left-to-right shunting (Choice B) is seen in some congenital cardiac defects such as an atrial septal defect or ventricular septal defect. Oxygenated blood from the left side of the heart passes to the right side of the heart, where it then returns to the pulmonary vasculature. If severe and untreated, the increased blood flow through the pulmonary vasculature can trigger pathologic remodeling of the vessel walls, leading to pulmonary hypertension. Right ventricular hypertrophy follows, causing a right-to-left shunt to occur. This phenomenon is called Eisenmenger syndrome. However, in this case, the pulmonary hypertension is secondary to bronchopulmonary dysplasia, not intracardiac left-to-right shunting. Peripheral pulmonary stenosis (Choice C) and pulmonary outlet obstruction (Choice E) are potential causes of pulmonary hypertension and increased right-sided heart pressure. In this case, the patient's history is more consistent with bronchopulmonary dysplasia as a cause of pulmonary hypertension and right-sided heart failure.

explanation.educational_objective: Pulmonary hypertension may be secondary to bronchopulmonary dysplasia in neonates. Car pulmonale, or right heart dysfunction, may follow as a result of the inadequacy of the right ventricle to pump against the thickened, remodeled pulmonary vasculature. r " , r-- r ,

vignette.presentation:
39. A previously healthy 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of heavy vaginal bleeding for 5 weeks . Menarche was at the age of 12 years . Menses occur at irregular 30- to 45-day intervals . Examination shows no
abnormalities except for blood at the cervical os . On day 21 of her menstrual cycle , her serum progesterone concentration is 0.5 ng/ml (follicular N<3; luteal N>3-5) . Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of
these findings?

question_stem:
the most likely underlying cause of
these findings?

distractor_explanations.B: is a common cause of primary amenorrhea, which is a result of ovarian dysgenesis. Other signs include the absence of secondary sexual characteristics, short stature, cystic hygroma or webbed neck, swelling in the hands/feet, coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve, fused kidney, and infertility. This patient has no physical signs to suggest Turner syndrome. Pituitary tumors (Choice C), such as prolactinomas, can cause menstrual irregularities. However, they are more commonly associated with amenorrhea than menorrhagia, and also may present with galactorrhea. A pituitary tumor would be a less common cause of heavy menstrual bleeding in this patient. Sexual abuse (Choice D) can present with abnormal vaginal bleeding caused by genital trauma, such as a cervical or vaginal laceration. This patient had no signs of trauma on physical examination, and trauma would be less likely to cause bleeding for 5 weeks. Von Willebrand disease (Choice E) is an autosomal dominant inherited bleeding disorder caused by a decreased or dysfunctional von Willebrand factor. It typically presents with epistaxis, ecchymoses, or menorrhagia. However, as it is an inherited disorder, it would have likely been apparent with prior menses, rather than occurring within the past 5 weeks only.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. ACE inhibitors are a first-line treatment for hypertension since they block the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin 11, which has direct vasoconstrictive effects and promotes salt and water retention. Additionally, inhibition of angiotensin production has the secondary effect of suppressing aldosterone production. Aldosterone is responsible for the retention of sodium and excretion of potassium, and its suppression may lead to hyperkalemia. Other important potential side effects of ACE inhibitors include cough and angioedema.

50. A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother , who is concerned that her daughter might have been abused . The mother states that her daughter has been touching her genital area since she began attending day
care 6 weeks ago . The mother says , "I've heard about bad things happening to kids in day care." The patient is a picky eater and is occasionally defiant. She has had intermittent nighttime awakening . She interacts well with
other children but sometimes does not want to share her toys . She separates from her mother after initial hesitation when dropped off at the preschool. Her teacher reports no behavior problems . Today, the patient appears
mildly anxious . Physical examination shows no abnormalities . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Reassure the mother that this is normal behavio~
Interview the patient for suspected sexual abuse
Schedule an appointment with child protective services

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This patient's social development is normative. Starting at age 2 years, toddlers become more curious about their genitalia and associated sensations, along with gender differences. Normative sexual behavior of toddlers includes solitary behaviors such as touching their own genitals along with social behaviors such as looking at another person's genitals. Sexual behaviors that are concerning for sexual abuse (or violence or neglect in the home) include imitations of specific sexual acts, coercive sexual behavior, and excessive preoccupation with sexual behavior. Toddlers typically demonstrate occasional defiance, and cooperative play is not expected to develop until age 4 years, so this child's inclination not to share her toys is typical. Nighttime awakenings, picky eating, and anxiety about physician appointments are also typical for toddlers.

distractor_explanations.B: Sexual abuse may lead to sexual behavior problems. Physicians are mandated to investigate and report suspected abuse to child protective services (Choice E). Problem behaviors include imitating sexual acts along with coercive sexual behavior or excessive preoccupation with sexual behavior. Parent management training (Choice C) assists parents in managing excessive oppositional behavior by modeling parent-child interactions. This modality is utilized in oppositional defiant disorder and conduct disorder rather than normative oppositional behavior in toddlers. Recommending individual psychotherapy (Choice D) would be inappropriate in this patient demonstrating normative social behaviors.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Intussusception occurs when a segment of bowel telescopes into an adjacent segment, resulting in colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and potential bloody, mucoid stools. Classically, it presents in an infant or young child with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain often punctuated by asymptomatic periods. Intussusception typically occurs due to the presence of a pathologic lead point, often lymphoid hyperplasia, lymphadenopathy, Meckel diverticulum, stricture, or malignancy, which acts to draw one segment of bowel into an adjacent segment during peristalsis. If the intussusception self-resolves, there may be no symptoms. If it does not resolve, traction on mesenteric vessels can result in hypoperfusion of the segment with resultant inflammation, hemorrhage, obstruction, and pain. It may be detected on physical examination as an elongated mass, often in the right upper quadrant. Diagnosis consists of clinical history, physical examination, and is supported by imaging. Ultrasound evaluation is preferred in young children and will show telescoping interposed bowel segments in longitudinal orientation, or a targetoid appearance in transverse orientation. A contrast enema can also demonstrate intussusception with appearance of a mass prolapsing into the lumen and an inability of the contrast to reach the proximal bowel. Treatment of an ileocolic intussusception requires the administration of a contrast enema, which reduces the intussusception. Contrast enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic in this setting. Surgery may be required in cases where there is repetitive failure of the enema to reduce the intussusception or if the patient presents with symptoms concerning for bowel necrosis or perforation. , q (> ¢@  © € € @

distractor_explanations.A: is a common cause of painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding in older adults. In children, a Meckel diverticulum can bleed, though it would not present with signs of obstruction as in this case. Malrotation volvulus (
distractor_explanations.C: occurs secondary to the incomplete rotation of bowel during embryonic development. This places the newborn at risk for midgut volvulus, which can present with bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and pain. In severe cases, presentation may also include intestinal necrosis, hematochezia, perforation, and peritonitis. A peptic ulcer (
distractor_explanations.D: is uncommon in children and can be related to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or Helicobacter pylori infection. Patients typically present with epigastric discomfort, nausea, and vomiting, typically after eating. Peptic ulcer disease can be complicated by hemorrhage, typically resulting in melena or perforation. Pyloric stenosis (
distractor_explanations.E: presents at several weeks of life and is characterized by repeated nonbilious vomiting after feeds, leading to dehydration and a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. Diagnosis is made with ultrasonography, and treatment is with surgical pyloromyotomy.

explanation.educational_objective: Intussusception occurs when a segment of bowel telescopes into an adjacent segment, resulting in colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and potential bloody, mucoid stools. A barium enema is useful in the diagnosis as well as treatment for intussusception. @ € ¢@  (3 (i (2) @

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: This neonate presents with findings consistent with congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV, also known as human herpesvirus 5 (HHV-5), belongs to the family of herpesviruses, and possesses a large, double-stranded DNA genome. Congenital CMV infection presents with intrauterine growth restriction, microcephaly, intracranial calcifications, hearing loss, seizures, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, and petechial rash. The diagnosis is confirmed with viral culture or polymerase chain amplification from urine or blood within the first week of life. It is the most common cause of nonhereditary sensorineural hearing loss. In about 10% of cases, hearing loss may be an isolated finding without other symptoms of infection present. Hearing loss is also the most common sequela of an initially asymptomatic neonate. Fetal hydrops is a potential complication of CMV infection, although it is less common than with parvovirus B19 infection. Intracranial calcifications demonstrate a characteristic periventricular distribution and may be detected by ultrasonography or computed tomography. Pregnant women most often contract CMV through exposure from young children, often through daycare centers. A primary maternal infection has a high risk for vertical transmission via the placenta to the fetus. Treatment is with antiviral agents, such as ganciclovir or valganciclovir.

distractor_explanations.A: is utilized in the diagnosis of lymphoproliferative or lymphodepletive disorders such as lymphoma, leukemia, and aplastic anemia, among others. It does not play a role in the diagnosis of congenital CMV infection. Chromosomal microarray (
distractor_explanations.B: is useful for the detection of chromosomal copy number variants, including microdeletions and duplications. It is useful for the diagnosis of children with syndromic abnormalities that are thought to have a genetic cause. It is not useful for the diagnosis of congenital infectious syndromes. Lymphocyte enumeration by flow cytometry (
distractor_explanations.C: is useful for the diagnosis of primary immune deficiencies. While infants with immune deficiencies may present with recurrent infections, congenital infections and associated abnormalities suggest an alternate diagnosis. q (> ¢@  © € € @

A primary maternal infection has a high risk for vertical transmission via the placenta to the fetus. The diagnosis is confirmed with viral culture or polymerase chain amplification from urine or blood within the first week of life. q (> ¢@  © € € @

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a severe mucocutaneous drug reaction that may progress to toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) with an accompanying high mortality rate. SS and TEN are distinguished from each other based on the amount of body surface area involvement (<10% for SJS and >30% for TEN) and are driven by the same underlying pathophysiology. Common drugs implicated in the development of SJS or TEN include beta-lactam antibiotics, antiepileptics, sulfa- containing medications including trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and allopurinol. SS and TEN are characterized by confluent areas of dusky erythema with desquamation of the epidermis. It can be distinguished from a morbilliform drug eruption by the presence of skin pain, desquamation, and mucosal involvement. SJS and TEN are often complicated by infection of the denuded areas of skin, thus meticulous wound care, preferably in a burn unit, is critical. The first step in treatment is to identify and discontinue the offending agents. Supportive care in a burn intensive care unit setting has been shown to improve mortality, but the role of other agents including systemic steroids, cyclosporine, and intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) are controversial.
explanation.educational_objective: Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis are severe mucocutaneous drug reactions with high mortality rates. They are distinguished from each other by the amount of body surface area involvement, <10% for SUS and >30% for TEN, and common causes include beta-lactam antibiotics, anti-epileptics, sulfa-containing medications including trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and allopurinol. Treatment includes identifying and stopping the offending agent, supportive care, and wound management, preferably in a burn intensive care unit. q (> ¢@  © € € @

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Topical clotrimazole and other azole antibiotics are commonly used to treat superficial dermatophyte infections, including tinea corporis. Tinea corporis is commonly caused by Trichophyton species and results from direct inoculation from an affected individual or animal, including dogs or cats. Tinea corporis is treated with topical azole antifungals, including clotrimazole, which inhibit conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol in the fungal cell wall by 14-a demethylase.

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Postoperative myocardial infarction is a complication that can occur following physiologically stressful surgical procedures, especially those with high blood loss in patients already predisposed to myocardial infarction (e.g., older, male smokers with history of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease). Myocardial infarction can present nonspecifically but classically occurs with shortness of breath, chest pain, light-headedness, nausea, vomiting, or altered mental status, and may be complicated by cardiogenic shock, seen as tachycardia, hypotension, and impaired end-organ perfusion (cool extremities, low urine output). In postoperative cases, especially with intubated patients, it may be difficult to assess the presence of myocardial infarction. Evaluation using ECG, serial troponin assays, and echocardiogram should be considered in such cases. Right-heart catheterization can be used to determine cardiac output and index, along with pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, which can distinguish right heart failure from left heart failure. An increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure indicates that filling pressures in the left heart are abnormal, which is consistent with myocardial infarction and cardiogenic shock.

vignette.presentation:
2. A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of five to six loose stools daily and a 7.3-kg (16-lb) weight loss . He notes that he had two to three bowel movements daily for 3 weeks following a 10-day
course of tetracycline 2 months ago . He underwent antrectomy with Billroth II reconstruction for a perforated gastric ulcer 1 year ago . He has not had any changes in his diet. He has osteoarthritis of the hips treated with
ibuprofen . He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (160 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m 2 Examination shows excess skinfolds over the abdomen . The abdomen is scaphoid with a well-healed surgical scar. Which of the following is the
•
most likely cause of this patient's diarrhea ?

question_stem: most likely cause of this patient's diarrhea ?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Bacterial overgrowth results from abnormal growth of bacteria in the small intestine, which disrupts normal digestion of macromolecules. Patients present with recurrent nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, bloating, weight loss, loose stools, and vitamin and mineral deficiencies. Bacterial overgrowth classically occurs in patients with previous history of abdominal surgeries, resection of the ileocecal valve, creation of blind loops, or following prolonged use of proton pump inhibitors. This is caused by the loss of normal intestinal peristalsis, retrograde translocation, or disruption of acidic pH as means of limiting bacterial presence or promoting bacterial elimination in the small bowel. The increased metabolism from bacteria, their colonization of the bowel wall, and disruption of normal gut flora contribute to malabsorption and resultant symptoms. Bacterial overgrowth occurs more frequently in patients with blind or limited-transit intestinal loops created during procedures such as the Billroth II or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, resulting from the loss of passing food bolus which allows for appropriate anterograde propulsion of bacteria along the gastrointestinal tract. Patients may see improvement in symptoms following administration of antibiotics, which decreases bacterial burden.

distractor_explanations.B: Bile reflux occurs when bile travels retrograde through the pylorus and into the stomach or esophagus, causing symptoms of nausea and heartburn. COX-2 inhibition (Choice C) may result in the development of peptic ulcers because of the loss of mucosal barrier protection; peptic ulcers typically present with abdominal pain, nausea, and occasional vomiting or darkened stools. Neither bile reflux nor peptic ulcer disease are associated with loose stools and increased stool frequency. Dumping syndrome (Choice D) occurs because of rapid gastric emptying into the duodenum and often presents with abdominal pain and cramping. It would be unlikely to improve with the administration of antibiotics. Efferent loop obstruction (Choice E) refers to mechanical obstruction of the efferent jejunal limb of intestine following a gastric reconstruction procedure and presents with symptoms of small bowel obstruction, not increased stool frequency. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 3 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
3. A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a head-on motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. On arrival , he is in severe respiratory distress . Breath sounds are decreased
over the left hemithorax . There is crepitant swelling over the face , neck , and hemithorax . An x-ray of the chest shows extensive subcutaneous air and a left pneumothorax . After proper placement of a left chest tube , the patient
has a persistent large air leak . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Pneumothorax results from air entering the intrapleural space from either an external (e.g., stab wound) or internal (e.g., ruptured bleb or bronchus, bronchopleural fistula) source. As the air accumulates within the space, the lung parenchyma becomes compressed, resulting in reduced breath sounds, respiratory distress, and, in severe cases, tension on the mediastinal structures impeding venous return. In cases of acute trauma, evacuating the accumulated air permits expansion of the lung and elimination of tension on the great vessels; this is done through needle decompression in cases of tension pneumothorax, tube thoracostomy, or both. Once a tube thoracostomy is placed and healing of the inciting injury occurs, leakage of air into the pleural space should stop. If a persistent air leak is noted, the source of the leak should be investigated. A ruptured bronchus requires extended time to heal and is one source of a potential air leak. If the leak persists, surgical correction of the rupture may be required to prevent chronic pneumothorax from a resultant bronchopleural fistula. lncorrectAnswers:A, B, and D. Esophageal injury (Choice A) can result in pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax, and, if severe, bacterial mediastinitis can occur. While diminished breath sounds may occur in the setting of an esophageal injury, additional findings such as mediastinal crepitus, crunching on auscultation, and signs of sepsis would likely be present. Open pneumothorax (Choice B) would be detected on examination as a penetrating wound in continuity with the pleural space. Tension pneumothorax (Choice D) occurs when air accumulates within the pleural cavity to an extent that results in compression and shifting of the mediastinal structures. Such structural compromise results in impaired venous return leading to diminished cardiac output. It typically presents as severe respiratory distress, jugular venous distention, tracheal deviation, diminished breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and hemithorax hyperinflation. Vital signs will show tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 4 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
4. A previously healthy 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of light-headedness and hunger in the late evening before dinner and after strenuous exercise . His symptoms improve if he eats or
drinks something sweet. Two weeks ago, he fell to the ground nearly unconscious while running with some friends in the late afternoon ; his symptoms improved by drinking fruit punch . His only medication is one aspirin tablet
each morning. He does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs and drinks one or two glasses of wine each evening . He is an emergency medical technician . His father has type 2 diabetes mellitus . The patient is 183 cm (6 ft)
tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m 2 His pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. Examination shows no other abnormalities . He is given a meal and then given nothing orally. Seven hours later when he
•
develops similar symptoms, his serum glucose concentration is 25 mg/dl, and serum insulin and C-peptide concentrations are increased . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_stem: the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Exogenous production of insulin-like growth factor
Exogenous production of insulin-like growth factor

distractor_explanations.A: Adrenal insufficiency refers to insufficient production of hormones from the adrenal cortex, which include aldosterone and cortisol; sex hormone deficiency may also be present. Primary adrenal insufficiency can present with deficiencies in both aldosterone and cortisol, whereas secondary or tertiary adrenal insufficiency tends to affect cortisol concentrations only. Insufficient aldosterone production leads to hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Insufficient cortisol can lead to hypoglycemia, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and lethargy. Adrenal insufficiency would not present with increased serum insulin and C-peptide concentrations. Cushing syndrome (Choice B) results from increased endogenous or exogenous glucocorticoid activity and presents with fatigue, hypertension, hyperglycemia, fat redistribution (moon facies, buffalo hump, truncal obesity, extremity wasting), and abdominal striae. Exogenous production of insulin-like growth factor (Choice C) results in gigantism or acromegaly depending on whether the production of the hormone occurs prior to or following closure of growth plates; it presents in an adult with enlargement of flat bones, notably in the face, hands, and feet, and is often associated with the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It would not classically present with hypoglycemia. Pituitary insufficiency (Choice E) presents with a variety of symptoms depending on which hormones are deficient and generally refers to deficiency of the anterior pituitary hormones. Hypopituitarism carries a complex presentation, though symptoms of hypoglycemia can result from secondary adrenal insufficiency resulting from inadequate adrenocorticotropic hormone production. However, symptoms of hypoglycemia from adrenal insufficiency would not always follow activity or fasting, and concentrations of insulin would be low or normal. Reactive hypoglycemia (Choice F) refers to blood glucose fluctuations, specifically hyperglycemia followed by hypoglycemia, following a high carbohydrate meal. Symptoms of hypoglycemia occur typically two to four hours following a large meal and are thought to occur from the rapid decrease in blood glucose during insulin-triggered uptake by cells. Surreptitious self-administration of insulin (Choice G), also known as factitious hypoglycemia, presents with low serum C-peptide, as the hyperinsulinemic state is secondary to exogenous administration, not r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 4 of 50 tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m 2 His pulse is 60/min , and blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. Examination shows no other abnormalities . He is given a meal and then given nothing orally. Seven hours later when he • develops similar symptoms , his serum glucose concentration is 25 mg/dl , and serum insulin and C-peptide concentrations are increased . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A) Adrenal insufficiency B) Cushing syndrome C) Exogenous production of insulin-like growth factor D) lnsulinoma E) Pituitary insufficiency F) Reactive hypoglycemia G) Surreptitious self-administration of insulin H) Type 1 diabetes mellitus CorrectAnswer: D. lnsulinoma is a rare neoplasm of pancreatic islet cells that functionally produces insulin. These neoplastic cells classically do not respond to the typical feedback mechanisms, and as a result, insulin is continuously produced even in periods of hypoglycemia. Patients present with symptoms of hypoglycemia which are generally neuroglycopenic (agitation, headache, blurry vision, diplopia, tremor), autonomic (diaphoresis, tremor, nausea, vomiting, cramping, tachycardia, anxiety), and nonspecific (fatigue, weakness, lethargy), often exacerbated by periods of fasting or exercise. In extreme cases, hypoglycemia can present with seizures, coma, arrhythmias, and death. Whipple triad characterizes the presentation of true hypoglycemia and includes 1) signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia, 2) concomitant serum glucose less than 45 mg/dl, and 3) reversibility of symptoms with administration of glucose. lnsulinomas seldom metastasize and are considered predominantly benign neuroendocrine tumors apart from their dysregulated functional production of hormone. They are occasionally associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia. Diagnosis of an insulinoma is via laboratory evaluation demonstrating increased serum proinsulin, insulin, C-peptide, and decreased glucose, and imaging of the pancreas with CT scan or MRI. Definitive treatment is surgical resection. Incorrect Answers: A, B, C, E, F, G, and H. Adrenal insufficiency (Choice A) refers to insufficient production of hormones from the adrenal cortex, which include aldosterone and cortisol; sex hormone deficiency may also be present. Primary adrenal insufficiency can present with deficiencies in both aldosterone and cortisol, whereas secondary or tertiary adrenal insufficiency tends to affect cortisol concentrations only. Insufficient aldosterone production leads to hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Insufficient cortisol can lead to hypoglycemia, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and lethargy. Adrenal insufficiency would not present with increased serum insulin and C-peptide concentrations. Cushing syndrome (Choice B) results from increased endogenous or exogenous glucocorticoid activity and presents with fatigue, hypertension, hyperglycemia, fat redistribution (moon facies, buffalo hump, truncal obesity, extremity wasting), and abdominal striae. Exogenous production of insulin-like growth factor (Choice C) results in gigantism or acromegaly depending on whether the production of the hormone occurs prior to or following closure of growth plates; it presents in an adult with enlargement of flat bones, notably in the face, hands, and feet, and is often associated with the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus. It would not classically present with hypoglycemia. Pituitary insufficiency (Choice E) presents with a variety of symptoms depending on which hormones are deficient and generally refers to deficiency of the anterior pituitary hormones. Hypopituitarism carries a complex presentation, though symptoms of hypoglycemia can result from secondary adrenal insufficiency resulting from inadequate adrenocorticotropic hormone production. However, symptoms of hypoglycemia from adrenal insufficiency would not always follow activity or fasting, and concentrations of insulin would be low or normal. Reactive hypoglycemia (Choice F) refers to blood glucose fluctuations, specifically hyperglycemia followed by hypoglycemia, following a high carbohydrate meal. Symptoms of hypoglycemia occur typically two to four hours following a large meal and are thought to occur from the rapid decrease in blood glucose during insulin-triggered uptake by cells. Surreptitious self-administration of insulin (Choice G), also known as factitious hypoglycemia, presents with low serum C-peptide, as the hyperinsulinemic state is secondary to exogenous administration, not functional production by islet cells. Type 1 diabetes mellitus (Choice H) refers to the autoimmune destruction of pancreatic islet cells, which presents with hyperglycemia, low insulin, and low serum C-peptide. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 5 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
5. A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician 48 hours after the onset of sharp pain in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. The pain has been gradually resolving . Examination shows a 2-cm tender area in the upper outer
quadrant of the right breast ; there is no associated mass . Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Mastalgia, also known as mastodynia, is most often benign. Benign causes without anatomic abnormality include cyclic hormonal fluctuations related to the menstrual cycle, occult trauma, the use of oral contraceptive pills, exogenous hormones, and antipsychotics. Fibrocystic breast disease is a benign and cyclic cause of breast pain that presents with focal masses or nodules. Noncyclic mastalgia can arise from malignancy or infection, both of which present with positive examination findings. Provided that no focal findings are present on examination, symptoms are improving, the patient is reliable and with no risk factors, and the low likelihood of confounding diagnoses (e.g., pneumothorax, pneumonia, acute coronary syndrome), reassurance and watchful waiting is appropriate. If a mass is palpated, the patient is above age 40 to 50 years, or if there are secondary or concerning features in the history for malignancy or infection, breast imaging should be obtained.

distractor_explanations.B: Mammography and MRI (Choice C) would be appropriate as screening techniques and in the investigation of palpable breast masses. Mammography is preferred as an initial screening and diagnostic modality in patients over age 40 years. MRI is preferable in younger women with dense breast tissue, high lifetime risk for breast cancer (e.g., BRCA 1 or BRCA2 mutation), or in those with anatomic or surgical abnormalities that would confound the accurate interpretation of a mammogram. Antibiotic therapy (Choice D) would be appropriate for a patient with a breast abscess or mastitis, which would present with erythema, tenderness, fluctuance, and systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever, chills, myalgias, arthralgias, nausea). Biopsy of the tender area (Choice E) is appropriate for lesions concerning for malignancy; the procedure is invasive and reserved for cases of moderate to high clinical suspicion after investigation with diagnostic imaging takes place (e.g., mammography, ultrasonography, MRI). r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 6 of 50 'I

vignette.presentation:
6. A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the anterior neck 30 minutes ago . A large hematoma is evident and is pulsatile at the level of the thyroid cartilage . As the physician watches , the
hematoma expands . Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

question_stem: the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Barium esophagography to rule out esophageal injury
Esophagoscopy to rule out esophageal injury
Indirect laryngoscopy to determine vocal cord injury

explanation.correct_answer_explanation: Airway obstruction is an immediate life-threatening condition that must be addressed at the time of discovery. Causes of acute airway obstruction may include expanding neck hematoma, facial trauma, foreign body aspiration, and angioedema/anaphylaxis. If care is not taken to immediately maintain or restore an unobstructed path for air to flow into the tracheobronchial tree, rapid hypoxia, hypercapnia, and death can occur. Emergent endotracheal intubation is the best initial step and should be performed immediately.

distractor_explanations.D: Indirect laryngoscopy to determine vocal cord injury is important to assess for damage to the vocal cords, which can play a role in future speech and airway protective reflexes, but this should occur after the management of immediate life-threatening conditions.
distractor_explanations.E: Tracheostomy may be necessary if securing the airway via laryngoscopy is unsuccessful; however, it should be attempted after traditional attempts at orotracheal or nasotracheal intubation have failed. In the case of an expanding neck hematoma, cricothyroidotomy or tracheostomy may not be possible if the hematoma overlies the operative site. r " , r-- r , Exam Section : Item 7 of 50
